comment_title: Comment 180:  Brewing, Food & Beverage Industry Suppliers' Association
comment_text: Petition for Exemption of Isinglass from Allergen Labelling under Section 403(w)(1) of the FD&C Act This petition, submitted by the Brewing, Food and Beverage Industry Suppliers' Association (BFBi), seeks an exemption from the allergen labelling requirements of Section 403(w)(1) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FD&C Act) for isinglass when used as a fining/clarification agent in beer production. Isinglass is a purified collagen derived from the swim bladders of select tropical and subtropical fish species. It has been used for centuries in brewing to clarify beer, and is removed from the final product through filtration or sedimentation. The petition presents comprehensive scientific, analytical, and clinical evidence demonstrating that isinglass does not pose an allergenic risk to fish-allergic individuals. Key findings include: • Clinical trials (including double-blind placebo-controlled oral challenges) show no allergic reactions in fish-sensitive individuals, even at doses equivalent to extreme beer consumption. • Manufacturing protocols have been optimized to minimize residual parvalbumin, the primary fish allergen, in commercial isinglass products. • Analytical data confirms that residual isinglass and parvalbumin levels in beer are extremely low, often below detection limits. • International regulatory bodies (EFSA, FSANZ, Health Canada) have granted similar exemptions based on comparable evidence. • Literature reviews and updated searches found no documented cases of allergic reactions to isinglass in beer or wine. The petition concludes that isinglass-fined beer does not elicit allergic responses and supports its exemption from allergen labelling requirements, aligning with global regulatory practices and current scientific consensus.
document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
The EFSA Journal (2007) 536, 1-10 
 
 
© European Food Safety Authority, 2007  
 Page 1 of 10 
Opinion of the Scientific Panel on Dietetic Products, Nutrition and Allergies 
on a request from the Commission related to a notification from Brewers of 
Europe and BFBi on isinglass used as a clarifying agent in brewing  
pursuant to Article 6 paragraph 11 of Directive 2000/13/EC  - for permanent 
exemption from labelling 
 
 
(Request Nº EFSA-Q-2006-312) 
 
(Adopted on 6 July 2007) 
 
 
SUMMARY 
 
Beer production normally incl udes fining of the beer. Fining  is achieved by mixing fining 
agents with the beer duri ng production, thereafter comple xed materials are removed by 
sedimentation, filtration, or both. Commonly used fining agents include a collagen preparation 
from fish swim bladders, isinglass. Fish alle rgy has been reported to affect 0.2%-2.2% of the 
population in European countries. Fi sh can cause severe reactions in allergic individuals and it 
is appropriate to assess allergen levels in beer clarified with isinglass. 
                                                                                                                                                                              
Allergens of concern in isinglass are primaril y residual amounts of the major fish allergen 
parvalbumin, and collagen/gelatine which constitu te the major component (95%) of isinglass. 
An industry-agreed Code of Good Manufactur ing Practice (GMP) for isinglass has been 
adopted by the applicant to lower the content of parvalbumin in the product. This substantially 
reduced the levels of parvalbumin in isinglass. A history of safe use is claimed. However, there 
may have been a significant under-reporting of react ions against isinglass in beer, because it is 
uncertain whether beer drinkers and health pr ofessionals have been aware of the possible 
presence of fish protein in beer. Analytical data indicate a re sidue level of isinglass in beer up 
to 5 mg/L. Parvalbumin levels in isinglass ranged from 0.2 mg/Kg to 0.7 mg/Kg. The estimated 
maximum concentration of parvalbumin in beer is 0.005 μg/L. However, there is considerable 
uncertainty about the accuracy of the assa ys. Two new double-blind placebo-controlled food 
challenge studies with isingla ss are reported, in which none of  21 fish allergic patients 
experienced any adverse effects.  
 
On the basis of the data provide d, the Panel considers that it is not very likely that isinglass 
used as clarifying agent in beer will trigger a severe allergic r eaction in susceptible individuals 
under the conditions of production and use specified by the applicant. 
 
  
KEY WORDS 
 
Beer, fining, isinglass, fish, allergy.  
 
© European Food Safety Authority, 2007  
 Page 2 of 10 
BACKGROUND  
 
In November 2003, the European Parliament and the Council adopted  Directive 2003/89/EC 1 
amending Directive 2000/13/EC, as regards indication of the ingredients present in foodstuffs. 
  
Annex IIIa of the Directive specif ies a list of food ingredients or substances that are known to 
trigger allergic reactions or intolerances in sensitive individuals for which no labelling 
exemptions are allowed. Whenever the listed ingr edients/substances or their derivatives are 
used in the production of foodstuffs, they must be labelled. 
 
Article 1, paragraph 11, subparagraph 2 of the Di rective establishes a procedure allowing for 
temporary labelling exemption of derivatives fr om ingredients listed in Annex IIIa for which it 
has been scientifically established that it is not  possible for them to cause adverse reactions. In 
accordance with this provision, submissions of re quest for temporary labelling exemption were 
notified to the Commission before 25 August 2004. The Commission, after consultation with 
the European Food Safety Authorit y, adopted a list (Directive 2005/26/EC
2) of those 
ingredients which are temporarily excluded fr om Annex IIIa until 25 November 2007, pending 
the final results of the notified studies.  
 
Consequently, applicants who submitted a dossier in 2004 on the basis of subparagraph 2, 
resulting in the inclusion of a product in the list of Direc tive 2005/26/EC, and who are seeking 
exclusion of that product from Annex IIIa beyond 25 November 2007, will have to submit a 
request enclosing the final results of the notified scientific studies. Therefore in the context of 
the permanent labelling exemption procedure, th e European Food Safety Authority is asked to 
provide scientific opinions on the submissi ons in accordance with the present terms of 
reference. 
 
 
TERMS OF REFERENCE 
 
In accordance with Article 29 (1) (a) of Regulation (EC) N° 178/2002, the European 
Commission requests the European  Food Safety Authority to evaluate the scientific data 
submitted by the Brewers of Europe and BFBi (Brewing Food and Beverage Industry Suppliers 
Association) in the framework of the procedur e laid down for temporary labelling exemptions 
in Article 6, paragraph 11 of Di rective 2000/13/EC. On the basis of that evaluation, EFSA is 
requested to issue an opinion on the informati on provided, and particul arly to consider the 
likelihood of adverse reactions triggered in susc eptible individuals by th e consumption of the 
following ingredients/substances used under the conditions specified by the applicant: isinglass. 
 
 
ASSESSMENT  
 
The magnitude of the adult fish-allergic popul ation is uncertain. A Danish population-based 
study with double-blind, placebo-controlled food challenge (DBPCFC) verification of allergy 
                                                           
1 Directive 2003/89/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2000/13/EC as regards 
indication of the ingredients present in foodstuffs. OJ L 308. 25.11.2003, p. 15. 
2 Commission Directive 2005/26/EC of 21 March 2005 establishing a list of food ingredients or substances 
provisionally excluded from Annex IIIa of Directive 2000/13/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council. 
OJ L 75, 22.03.2005, p. 33-34.  
 
© European Food Safety Authority, 2007  
 Page 3 of 10 
(Osterballe et al., 2005), found 0.2% of the adult population to  be allergic to codfish. The total 
number of fish-allergic individuals may be somewhat higher, because some fish-allergic 
individuals do not react to codfish. A population-based Amer ican study (telephone survey) 
(Sicherer et al., 2004) gave numbers in the same range , whereas in a European questionnaire-
based study (Woods et al., 2001) 2.2% reported (self-perceived) fish allergy or intolerance. 
 
Taking into account the numerous and well documented reports of allergic individuals reacting 
to fish (NDA, 2004a), it is appropriate for the Panel to assess th e likelihood of adverse 
reactions in allerg ic individuals consuming products wher e the fish-derived product isinglass 
has been used during the manufacturing process. 
 
A dossier submitted by the Brewing, Food and Beverage Industry Suppliers Association (BFBi) 
and The Brewers of Europe to the European Commission pursuant to Article 6, Paragraph 11 of 
Directive 2000/13/EC as amended by Dire ctive 2000/89/EC on 13 May 2004 for temporary 
exemption from labelling was the basis for an earlier assessment of isinglass by the NDA panel 
(NDA, 2004b).  
 
The present opinion is based on an updated dossi er from the same organization, with an 
application for permanent exemption from labe lling. The updated dossier  contains additional 
information and data mainly with regard to  improvement of the manufacturing process, 
analytical studies on isinglass in beer and on the amount of parvalbumin in isinglass, and 
clinical studies of allergenicity. 
 
1. Manufacturing process  
 
Isinglass is a form of collagen derived from  dried swim bladders of  certain tropical and 
subtropical fish. The production process vari es, according to the applicant, between 
manufacturers. It consists of blending of swim bladders from di fferent fish to meet quality, 
functionality, cost and supply criteria. Then various step s follow including granulation, 
washing, sterilisation with dilute hydrogen peroxide and further washing.  
 
Isinglass powder, paste and “ready-to-use” liqui ds are tested empirically for functionality 
(clarification efficiency) by the isinglass indust ry to ensure consiste nt performance of the 
product. The customers purchase according to certain specifications, including hygienic 
(bacteria, heavy metals) and functionality (pro tein) parameters. The Panel notes that the 
traditional manufacturing process does not have a high level of standardization, which may 
affect possible residual levels of the majo r fish allergen, parvalbumin. However, in 
consideration of results from an alytical studies (see below), an  industry-agreed Code of Good 
Manufacturing Practice (G MP) for isinglass has been adop ted by the applicants. To reduce 
parvalbumin content in isinglass, this GMP C ode includes an additiona l washing stage using 
phosphate buffer, the introduction of a sieving step in the granulation stage to ensure that swim 
bladder wall particle size does not exceed 25 mm , and the exclusion of some previously used 
fish species with high parvalbumin levels in the swim bladder. 
 
2. Characterisation of the product and its use  
 
2.1 Characterisation of isinglass  
 
It is stated that the major component of isingl ass (95%) is Type I colla gen together with its 
denaturation product, gelatine (Hickman et al ., 2000; Leach and Barrett, 1967; Moir et al. ,  
 
© European Food Safety Authority, 2007  
 Page 4 of 10 
1984). Isinglass collagen has a molecular wei ght of 800-1300 kDa. Key to the structure, 
functionality and quantification of  isinglass collagen is the presence of hydroxyproline, which 
is rare in other proteins but characteristic of collagen (regar ding its use for quantification of 
isinglass, see below). The profile  of amino acids varies dependi ng on the fish species, and the 
proportion of hydroxyproline reportedly depends on activity and environm ental temperature. 
Isinglass also contains elastin at levels up to 2.5% dry weight . Like collagen, elastin contains 
hydroxyproline.  
 
2.2 Conditions of use  
 
Isinglass is used to remove particles from beer . Isinglass is added to beer in soluble form, 
typically after fermentation an d cooling of the beer, at 15  mg/L (range 10-60 mg/L) for 
brewery-conditioned beers and around 50 mg/L for cask-conditioned beers. Isinglass is 
thereafter removed by sedimentation fo llowed by filtration (sometimes high-speed 
centrifugation can replace filtration). Isinglass redu ces the particle load that goes to the filters, 
and also removes some small particles that would pass through the filters.  
 
Cask-conditioned beer is a traditio nal style of beer in England, in which the yeast remains in 
the cask. Isinglass is dosed either into the beer  before filling or directly into the cask. The 
action of isinglass, it is state d, takes place within the first 3 to 4 hours and results in compact 
sediment at the base of the cask. The beer is drawn from the cask to a point above the sediment, 
and must be essentially free of suspended part icles. Cask-conditioned beer accounted for 7.5% 
of beer produced in the UK in 2002.  
 
2.3 Residual amounts of isinglass in beer, and exposure levels 
 
2.3.1 Residual amounts of isinglass in beer 
 
Data submitted for temporary exemption (NDA 2004b)  indicated that leve ls of isinglass in 
typical commercial beers ranged from 0.02 to 0.16 mg/L, based on a pr otein precipitation and 
separation method. Another method was based on the separation by affinity chromatography 
using rabbit anti-isinglass antibodies, followed by quantification of isin glass by measuring the 
amount of hydroxyproline using high-pressure liquid chromatography (HPLC). The method 
employing hydroxyproline as a marker for collagen has been further developed, and the limit of 
detection (LOD) is reported to correspond to 0.17 mg/L on an isinglass dry weight basis. 
 
Results indicate that for many bottle and can beers, residual levels of isinglass are below the 
LOD. The highest concentrations of isinglass detected in these types of beer did not exceed 1 
mg/L. For large containers (kegs and casks), isi nglass concentrations were higher. Residues in 
kegs were generally below 1 mg/L, but occasio nal samples contained up to 3 mg/L. For cask-
conditioned beers, the highest concentrations of isinglass measured did not exceed 5 mg/L. 
Even in cloudy beer, i.e. beer  drawn from just above the se dimented material, in which 
isinglass concentrations were slightly higher th an in the bulk, isinglass concentrations did not 
exceed 5 mg/L. Thus, there was little evidence of a concentration gradient of residues within 
the beer in either casks or kegs. 
 
2.3.2 Exposure levels 
  
 
© European Food Safety Authority, 2007  
 Page 5 of 10 
According to the applicant, annually an estimated 150 million hectolitres of beer worldwide are 
treated with isinglass, approximately 30 milli on hectolitres of that being in Europe. An 
estimated 200 tonnes of isinglass are used annually worldwide to clarify beer. 
 
With 5 mg/L isinglass and a serving of 350 mL clarified beer, the isinglass intake per serving of 
clarified beer would be 1.75 mg. A consumer drinking 1 litre of beer would have an intake of 5 
mg. The Panel notes that  the new analytical methodology has led to the ten-fold increased 
exposure estimate for isinglass over that in the previous application (NDA, 2004b).  
 
Parvalbumin exposure must be calculated from isinglass residue data, because the applicant 
was unable to measure parvalbumin directly in beer (see below). According to the applicant’s 
calculations, the maximum concentration of pa rvalbumin in beer could range from 0.001 μg/L 
(bottle and can beer) to 0.005 μg/L (cask conditioned beer) ba sed on measurement data with 
the new GMP isinglass. With the use of traditio nal commercial isinglass the estimate would be 
about ten-fold higher. Taking measurement un certainties into account and making certain 
assumptions, e.g. that parvalbumin is not eluted from the isinglass into  the beer, the highest 
parvalbumin concentration (new GMP code) derived for cask beer is 0.02 µg/L according to the 
applicant’s estimates. These doses are lower than doses reported to trigger adverse reactions in 
double blind placebo controlled food challenge studies (Taylor et al., 2002), assuming that the 
parvalbumin content of fish muscle is 4000 µg/g or less (Vornanen et al., 1999). However, the 
Panel notes the uncertainties about the accuracy of the measurements and assumptions 
regarding the parvalbumin concentration in beer, as well as the uncertainty with regard to the 
lowest dose of parvalbumin that can trigger an allergic reaction.  
 
3. Evidence of non-allergenicity 
 
3.1 History of non-allergenicity of the product  
 
3.1.1 Literature search strategy  
 
The literature search strategy used to provide historical evidence fo r safety of isinglass used in 
the process of brewing is well de scribed in the application, both in terms of databases searched 
and search terms used.  
 
3.1.2 Historical evidence of safe use  
 
The applicant states that isinglass has been used  as a fining agent for at least two centuries. 
Traditionally, all beer in the UK was fined with isinglass. Addi tionally, isinglass has 
historically been used as an ingredient in f oods and as a setting agent for jellies. Finally, the 
swim bladders themselves are consumed as a food delicacy. In the lit erature search, three 
papers were identified that me ntioned isinglass or fish maws. However, no report s of allergic 
responses to beer, isinglass or fish maws in fish sensitive individuals were found. 
 
The Panel notes that it is uncer tain whether allergy to fish ha s been considered by patients 
experiencing, or by doctors inve stigating, reactions to beer. Mo st people, including medical 
personnel, are likely to be unaware that subs tances derived from fish are used during 
production of beer. Thus, there may have been under-reporting of reactions caused by isinglass 
in beer. 
  
 
© European Food Safety Authority, 2007  
 Page 6 of 10 
The Panel further notes that according to the scien tific literature, adverse reactions in part with 
allergy-like symptoms, do not appear to be infrequent following alcoholic beverage 
consumption. In some surveys of asthmatics,  over 40% have reported the triggering of 
symptoms and 30-35% reported worsening of their asthma. Although wine was the most 
frequently reported trigger of these adverse reactions (Vally and Thompson, 2003), reactions to 
beer also occur often without etiological investigations being undertaken.  
 
3.2 Preclinical studies on allergenicity  
 
Allergic reactions to isinglass as fining agent in  beer could be due to residual amounts of the 
major fish allergen parvalbumin, or the collagen and gelatine th at are major constituents of 
isinglass. 
 
3.2.1 Residual amounts of parvalbumin  
 
The major fish allergen is parvalbumin (NDA , 2004a). The swim bladders of the primitive 
species of fish used for isingl ass production have certain anatomical differences from the swim 
bladders of other fish, and are not generally asso ciated with skeletal muscle tissue. However, 
there is a smooth muscle layer in the swim bl adder wall, and the presence of parvalbumin has 
previously been demonstrated in swim bladders  of fish not used fo r isinglass manufacture 
(Feher et al., 1998; Parmentier et al., 2003).  
 
SDS-PAGE analysis of fish used for isingl ass production showed a band at 12 kDa which is 
characteristic of parvalbumin, whereas a si milar band was not displayed by swim bladder 
extracts. With immunoblotting (polyclonal ra bbit anti-cod parvalbumin antiserum) however, 
traces of parvalbumin were detected in one out of six swim bladder samples.  
 
Homology studies of 18 fish parvalbumins fro m 10 species, based on publicly available 
sequences are reported (NCBI, 200 7). A given fish species cont ains usually 2-5 different 
parvalbumins. Fish species used for isinglass production were not included in the homology 
studies. Two Atlantic and one Baltic cod pa rvalbumins were 63% to 74% identical, and 
parvalbumins from the other fish were from 53% to 92% identical to the three codfish 
parvalbumins. Referring to the literature (Aalberse, 2000), the applicants conclude that high 
levels of sequence identity were observed th at indicate a high likelihood of antibody cross-
reactivity.  
 
ELISA tests based on carp and cod parvalbumins were developed. The anti-carp parvalbumin 
monoclonal antibody-based competitive ELISA was capable of detecting 0.05 µg/mL carp 
parvalbumin in a phosphate buffered saline (PBS) extract (1 µg/g on a weight/weight basis), 
using the amount of recombinant carp parvalbu min needed to obtain 20% inhibition as the 
detection limit. Strong matrix effects were obs erved when 10% fish gelatine extract was used 
instead of PBS. Comparing different fish speci es, the protein concentration needed to obtain 
50% inhibition was 1.8 µg/mL for carp, 0.4 µg/mL for catfish, 2.8 µg/mL for cod and 10 
µg/mL for tuna, equivalent to 0.1 µg/mL recombinant carp parvalbumin. Fish used for isinglass 
production was not available for testing. The Pane l notes the lack of accuracy of the carp 
parvalbumin-based ELISA, possibly due to species differences, matrix effects or a combination 
thereof. 
 
 
The anti-cod parvalbumin polyclonal antibody-ba sed sandwich ELISA is reported to have a 
limit of detection of 0.20 µg/g cod parvalbumin in PBS. Muscle extracts from the fish species  
 
© European Food Safety Authority, 2007  
 Page 7 of 10 
used for isinglass production did not react substantially in the cod parvalbumin ELISA, 
although there was evidence for the presence of parvalbumin based on SDS-PAGE and 
immunoblotting with an antibody used in the ELIS A. However, eleven isinglass preparations 
tested gave positive results (see below). The Panel notes that there are uncertainties with regard 
to the accuracy and appropriateness of the cod parvalbumin-based ELISA for the assessment of 
parvalbumin in tropical fish-derived isinglass. 
 
Parvalbumin was detected in single-species isingl ass preparations from a range of fish species, 
obtained from six different supplie rs. Certain fish species appear ed to have more parvalbumin 
than others. Accordingly it was decided that t hose species with high levels of parvalbumin 
which were not otherwise essential in commer cial blends for func tional reasons would no 
longer be used, and a common list of 6 fish speci es was agreed by isinglass manufacturers and 
incorporated into a new GMP code. Further st udies suggested that washing with phosphate 
buffer could reduce residual parvalbumin in isingl ass approximately 4-fold over levels in the 
original raw material, and such washing was also  incorporated into the new GMP code. Levels 
of residual parvalbumin in commercial isinglas s blends on the market (8 products from 3 
manufacturers) were found to be in the range of 1-35 mg/Kg, but  mostly less than 10 mg/Kg. 
Experience with the new GMP code is limited, but isinglass parvalbumin levels are expected by 
the applicant to be less than 1 mg/Kg, and valu es in 9 samples for which data are provided 
ranged from undetectable to 0.7 mg/Kg, most being less than 0.3 mg/Kg (codfish ELISA).  
 
Studies of beer from a 212.700 L tank, as well as theoretical considerations on parvalbumin 
solubility, suggested that parv albumin was significantly concentr ated in the beer sediment, 
rather than partitioning into the bulk of th e beer. In studies on freeze-dried beers employing 
both ELISA assays, with a detection limit of about 9 µg parvalbumin/L of beer, no parvalbumin 
was detected.  
 
3.2.2 Pepsin digestion 
 
The applicant reports pepsin digestion experime nts on isinglass. The Pa nel notes that this 
method is unsuitable for assessing the allergenicity of isinglass. 
 
3.2.3 Allergenicity of collagen and gelatine from fish – IgE binding studies 
 
 
Gelatine is denatured collagen. A number of scientific papers re port that serum IgE from some 
fish allergic individuals binds to fish collagen and gelatine. However, the presence of IgE-
binding to gelatine and collagen does not mean that clinical reactivity is present (see below).   
 
3.3 Clinical studies on allergenicity 
 
3.3.1 Skin testing  
  
Protocols were developed for skin testing with ex tracts of fish muscle and swim bladders from 
a range of species of fish used for commercial isinglass manufacture. Of eight Danish fish 
allergic patients tested, 8/8 reacted to the fish muscle, and 7/8 reacted to the swim bladder. This 
indicates that fish allergic individuals in Wester n Europe have the potential to react to the fish 
species and the starting material from which isi nglass is produced. No skin prick testing with 
commercial isinglass is reported. 
 
3.3.2 Double blind placebo cont rolled food challenge (DBPCFC) studies with isinglass   
 
© European Food Safety Authority, 2007  
 Page 8 of 10 
 
According to the applicant, the isinglass us ed for DBPCFC was prepared from a typical 
commercial blend of the agreed six fish species using the new GMP protocols. The 
parvalbumin content, as determined with the ELISA, was 1.0 μg/g carp parvalbumin 
equivalents, and 0.695 μg/g cod parvalbumin equivalents. Inclusion criteria were subjects age 3 
to 70 years in good health, a convincing clinical hi story of a Type I allergic reaction when fish 
was consumed, a positive skin pric k test (as large or larger than  the positive control histamine 
skin prick test) to one or more species of fi sh with a commercial ex tract, and a specific IgE 
score to fish greater than 0.35 kU A/L; both tests had to be perfor med no more than 6 months 
previously. Isinglass was given with mashed pot atoes at cumulative doses of 50.5 mg over two 
hours (0.5 mg, 5 mg, 15 mg, 30 mg ), corresponding to about 10 litres of cask conditioned beer 
or 50 litres of brewery conditioned beer. None of  fifteen patients subjected to this challenge 
protocol in Denmark and Switzerland reacted to the challenges. 
 
In a study in France employing a different protoc ol, a cumulative dose of 20 mg isinglass was 
given corresponding to the e quivalent of four litres of beer. Inclusion criteria  were “allergic 
patients” age 14 to 18 years, but are not further specified in the dossier. None out of six patients 
challenged (2/6 skin test positive to fish) had a reaction.  
 
The Panel notes that the DBPCFC were performed in food matrices in which isinglass is not 
usually consumed. Alcohol is considered to lo wer the dose that may trigger a food allergic 
reaction in susceptible individuals (Sicherer, 2000). 
 
3.3.3 Food challenge studies with fish gelatine  
 
There are no reports of clinical reactions to fish gelatine in relation to food intake, and 
DBPCFC studies have so far been negative, except for one individual reacting to 7.6 g of 
gelatine (NDA, 2004 a and b). Food challenges with gelatine or collagen were not performed in 
the various studies reporting fi sh collagen and gelatine IgE bi nding, except for the two studies 
referred below.  
 
In a DBPCFC study by a Danish group (Hansen et al ., 2004), no adverse reactions were 
observed when 30 codfish allergic patients were  given a cumulative dose of 3.6 g of fish 
gelatine derived from codfish skin. A mild r eaction confirmed in a repeated challenge was 
experienced by one patient when given a cumulative dose of 7.6 g. There was no reaction to the 
next higher dose.  
 
In a French single-blind study (André et al ., 2003) of 100 children and adults with IgE 
reactivity to various species of fish, fish (tuna) skin-derived collagen was used. It was found 
that 3 out of 100 sera showed IgE binding to tuna  skin-derived fish ge latine. A food challenge 
test using 5 g of tuna gelatine was negative in these three subjects.  
 
 
CONCLUSIONS  
 
On the basis of the data provide d, the Panel considers that it is not very likely that isinglass 
used as clarifying agent in beer will trigger a severe allergic r eaction in susceptible individuals 
under the conditions of production and use specified by the applicant. 
  
  
 
© European Food Safety Authority, 2007  
 Page 9 of 10 
DOCUMENTATION PROVIDED TO EFSA 
 
Dossier submitted by the Brewers of Europe and the Brewing, Food and Beverage Industry 
Suppliers Association (BFBi) to the European Commission pursuant to Article 6, Paragraph 11 
of Directive 2000/13/EC as amended by Directive 2000/89/EC, 31 October 2006. 
 
 
REFERENCES

18: 121-126.

U.S. National Library of Medicine and U.S. National Institutes of Health. 
http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/

comment_title: Comment 180:  Brewing, Food & Beverage Industry Suppliers' Association
comment_text: Petition for Exemption of Isinglass from Allergen Labelling under Section 403(w)(1) of the FD&C Act This petition, submitted by the Brewing, Food and Beverage Industry Suppliers' Association (BFBi), seeks an exemption from the allergen labelling requirements of Section 403(w)(1) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FD&C Act) for isinglass when used as a fining/clarification agent in beer production. Isinglass is a purified collagen derived from the swim bladders of select tropical and subtropical fish species. It has been used for centuries in brewing to clarify beer, and is removed from the final product through filtration or sedimentation. The petition presents comprehensive scientific, analytical, and clinical evidence demonstrating that isinglass does not pose an allergenic risk to fish-allergic individuals. Key findings include: • Clinical trials (including double-blind placebo-controlled oral challenges) show no allergic reactions in fish-sensitive individuals, even at doses equivalent to extreme beer consumption. • Manufacturing protocols have been optimized to minimize residual parvalbumin, the primary fish allergen, in commercial isinglass products. • Analytical data confirms that residual isinglass and parvalbumin levels in beer are extremely low, often below detection limits. • International regulatory bodies (EFSA, FSANZ, Health Canada) have granted similar exemptions based on comparable evidence. • Literature reviews and updated searches found no documented cases of allergic reactions to isinglass in beer or wine. The petition concludes that isinglass-fined beer does not elicit allergic responses and supports its exemption from allergen labelling requirements, aligning with global regulatory practices and current scientific consensus.
document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
INSTITUTE OF AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES 
FOOD ALLERGY RESEARCH AND RESOURCE PROGRAM 
 
 
 
 
EXPERT OPINION 
 ON  
ALLERGENICITY OF ISINGLASS 
 
 
Steve L. Taylor, Ph.D. 
Susan L. Hefle, Ph.D. 
Jamie Kabourek, R.D. 
 
Food Allergy Research & Resource Program 
University of Nebraska 
Lincoln, NE, USA 
 
October 25, 2006 
 
Prevalence
 
     Allergy to fish is a common cause of IgE-mediated food allergic reactions. Although 
the exact prevalence of fish-allergic subjects is not firmly established clinically, fish is 
widely accepted as one of the most common allergenic foods (Bousquet et al., 1998).  
Fish allergy is expected to be more common in geographic areas where fish is an 
important dietary component although other factors beyond dietary preferences appear to 
be involved in determination of the sensitization to both food and airborne allergens 
(Gislason et al., 1999).  Because of certain nutritional benefits particularly the levels of 
omega-3 fatty acids, dietary advice often emphasizes the increased consumption of fish.  
The prevalence of adverse reactions to fish is expected to increase worldwide as 
consumers increase their consumption of fish and also because of technological advances 
in fish processing which encourage fish consumption in areas further from the seaside 
(O’Neil and Lehrer, 1995).     
 
     Certainly, fish consumption is reasonably high in the European Union and fish allergy 
is undeniably of considerable clinical importance.  Fish allergy is often identified as one 
of the most common allergenic foods in studies involving pediatric allergy patients 
(Dannaeus and Inganas, 1981; Boyano Martinez et al., 1987; Crespo et al., 1992; Sicherer 
et al., 2000; Rance et al., 1996; Rance and Dutau, 2002).  Fish is also an important cause 
of food allergy in adults (Helbling et al., 1999; Hansen and Bindslev-Jensen, 1992; 
Hansen et al., 1997).  In the general population, fish was responsible for about 10% of all 
cases of food anaphylaxis in a case series reported in France by Moneret-Vautrin and 
Kanny (1995).  In an investigation of anaphylaxis episodes in Italy, fish was the most 
common cause of food-related anaphylaxis accounting for 30% of all cases (Novembre et 
al., 1998).      
     A recent survey in the United States indicated that the prevalence of fish allergy in the 
population was 0.4% (Sicherer et al., 2004).  Although this estimate was not confirmed 
by clinical studies, the estimate is probably reasonable given the immediate and often 
clinically noteworthy presentation of allergic reactions to fish.  Sensitization to fish was 
reported in 0.2% of the populations of both Iceland and Sweden (Gislason et al., 1999), 
although challenges were not done in this study either to confirm the existence of fish 
allergy.  The prevalence of sensitization to fish in Sweden had previously been estimated 
at 0.3% (Björnsson et al., 1996).  These prevalence estimates are in reasonable agreement 
with one another suggesting that the true prevalence of fish allergy in the general 
population is likely to be 0.2-0.4%. 
 
Clinical Manifestations
 
     Symptoms of fish allergy are similar to other IgE-mediated food allergies (Lopata and 
Jeebhay, 2001).  Symptoms usually appear immediately (minutes to an hour) following 
exposure and range from mild to life-threatening.  In clinical challenge trials, cutaneous, 
gastrointestinal, and respiratory symptoms have been provoked by fish (Helbling et al., 
1999; Sicherer et al., 2000). 
 
     Severe, life-threatening allergic reactions have certainly been triggered by fish on 
occasion.  In a study of 60 patients who presented with severe, near-fatal reactions, fish 
were identified as the cause of 13% of the cases (Andre et al., 1994).  In another study of 
14 patients with histories of severe allergic reactions to food, four reactions were caused 
by fish intake (Eigenmann and Calza, 2000).  Several fatalities in the USA have been 
attributed to inadvertent ingestion of fish by fish-allergic individuals (Yunginger et al., 
1988; Bock et al., 2001).  In the U.K., three fatalities are attributed to “seafood” which 
could be fish (Pumphrey, 2000). 
 
Natural History of Fish Allergy
 
     Clearly, fish allergy can have its onset in young children as documented by challenge 
trials in pediatric patients (Dannaeus and Inganas, 1981; Boyano Martinez et al., 1987; 
Crespo et al., 1992; Sicherer et al., 2000; Rance et al., 1996; Rance and Dutau, 2002).  
While young children often become tolerant of certain allergenic foods, such as milk and 
egg, over time, fish allergy is not known to be outgrown. 
 
Clinical Cross-Reactivity
 
     A large number of different fish species have been implicated in allergic reactions to 
fish (Taylor et al., 2004).  Typically, fish-allergic individuals are advised to avoid 
ingestion of all species of fish (Helbling et al., 1999).  The Codex Alimentarius 
Commission has recommended the labeling of fish and products thereof because of the 
notion that fish-allergic individuals are allergic to all species of fish and may also be 
allergic to ingredients derived from fish.  However, while this advice is likely prudent, it 
is not consistent with clinical challenge trials.  In clinical challenge trials conducted in 
 2several clinical centers, fish-allergic patients were sometimes reactive to all fish species 
but on other occasions were able to tolerate certain species while reacting to others 
(Bernhisel-Broadbent et al., 1992; Helbling et al., 1999).  In many studies, serological 
cross-reactivity among various fish species is widespread (examples see:  Hansen et al., 
1997; Sten et al., 2004; Helbling et al., 1999; De Martino et al., 1993). 
 
Fish Allergens: Parvalbumin as the Major Allergen 
 
     The major allergen in codfish, namely Gad c 1, is a muscle protein that is a member of 
the parvalbumin family (Elsayed and Aas, 1971).  The muscles of all fishes contain 
parvalbumins that are homologous, acidic proteins with molecular weights in the range of 
11-12,000 Da that control the flow of Ca2+ in and out of cells.    Gad c 1 is a very stable 
molecule, resistant to extremes in pH, temperature or random folding of the molecule 
when exposed to dissociating agents (Aas and Elsayed, 1975).  All cod-allergic patients 
react to Gad c 1 (Elsayed and Aas, 1971).  Parvalbumin is found as the major allergen in 
both Baltic cod (Gad c 1; Elsayed and Aas, 1971) and Atlantic cod (Gad m 1; Das Dores 
et al., 2002a).  The allergens from other fish species are also parvalbumins including 
salmon (Sal s 1), horse mackerel (Tra j 1), several species of tuna including bigeye tuna 
(Thu o 1), bluefin tuna, yellowfina tuna and albacore tuna, three species of mackerel (Sco 
j 1, Sco a 1, Sco s 1), pollack (The c 1), and carp (Cyp c 1) (Bugajaska-Schretter et al., 
1998; Van Do et al., 1999; Bugajska-Schretter et al., 2000; Hamada et al., 2003a; 
Hamada et al., 2004; Lindström et al., 1996; Van Do et al., 2005; Shiomi et al., 1998; 
Shiomi et al., 1999; Yamada et al., 1999).  Evidence indicates that parvalbumin is present 
in numerous other species of fish even if the protein has not been isolated and 
documented as the major allergen in these species.  Parvalbumin is also the major 
allergen in frog legs and appears to be responsible for cross-reactions between fish and 
frog (Hilger et al., 2004).  Taken together, this research suggests that parvalbumins are 
major pan-allergens in fish and suggests a basis for the cross-reactivity of fish-allergic 
individuals to many, if not all, species of fish.   
 
    Curiously, fish-allergic individuals do not always appear to react on challenge to all 
species of fish.  Although unexplained, several reasons could exist for this lack of clinical 
reactivity.  Some species of fish may have very low levels of parvalbumin.  Chen et al. 
(2006) noted that tuna had low levels of parvalbumin as detectable with an anti-frog 
parvalbumin antibody that was able to detect parvalbumin in other fish species.  
Similarly, fish-allergic patients displayed little or no binding to parvalbumins or proteins 
in that molecular weight range in previous studies with tuna (Bugajaska-Schretter et al., 
1998; James et al., 1997; Lim et al., 2005).  Tuna are among the more commonly 
tolerated fish by individuals with fish allergy (Bernhisel-Broadbent et al., 1992; Torres 
Borrego et al., 2003).  Secondly, parvalbumin is now known to have conformational 
epitopes (Untersmayr et al., 2006).  Therefore, slight differences in the three-dimensional 
structure of parvalbumin could affect individual patient reactivity.  Also, heat processing 
in particular could affect these conformational epitopes.  Severe heat processing such as 
the canning of tuna appears to affect allergenicity (Bernhisel-Broadbent et al., 1992).  
Finally, the dark muscles of sardine, horse mackerel, yellowtail, Pacific mackerel, and 
red sea bream were found to contain 4-8 times lower levels of parvalbumin than the white 
 3muscles suggesting another basis for individual patient variability (Kobayashi et al., 
2006).  Similar results were obtained in studies of dark and white muscles of longtail tuna 
(Lim et al., 2005). 
 
Fish Allergens – Others
 
     In addition to the major parvalbumin allergen, some evidence exists for the possible 
presence of other minor allergens in various species of fish including codfish (Aas, 1966; 
Aukrust et al., 1978; Dory et al., 1998).  A 41 kDa protein, dissimilar to Gad c 1 with 
respect to molecular weight, isoelectric point, and proportion of hydrophobic amino acids 
was able to bind IgE from some cod-allergic individuals (Das Dores et al,, 2002b; 
Galland et al., 1998).  However, the clinical significance of this minor fish allergen has 
not been established. 
 
    An unidentified IgE-binding protein of 50 kDa was identified in two species of fish, 
hilsa and pomfret, that are popular in India (Das et al., 2005).  Curiously, these fish 
species did not appear to contain parvalbumin or any IgE-binding proteins migrating in 
that molecular weight range.  This immunoblotting study was not confirmed by oral 
challenges to document the clinical reactivity of the patients who provided the blood 
serum. 
 
     Hamada et al. (2001) identified a high molecular weight allergen detected in bigeye 
tuna muscle as collagen.  However the clinical significance of collagen as a fish allergen 
was not confirmed by oral challenge of fish-allergic individuals.  In subsequent studies, 
Hamada et al. (2003b) noted in IgE-binding studies that 10 of 15 fish-allergic patients 
reacted only to parvalbumin from bigeye tuna, while 2 of 15 fish-allergic patients reacted 
only to collagen, 2 of 15 patients reacted to both parvalbumin and collagen, and 1 of 15 
patients reacted to neither protein.  Except for IgE-binding studies, no other evaluations 
were done (challenges, skin tests, etc.) to document further the allergenicity of collagen.  
The sera of the collagen-reactive patients also reacted with collagen from other fish 
species including Japanese eel, alfonsin, mackerel, and skipjack (Hamada et al., 2003b). 
Thus, collagen appears to be a minor fish allergen, although more studies are needed to 
better gauge the prevalence of sensitization to fish collagen.  And, oral challenge studies 
would be useful to confirm the clinical relevance of fish collagen sensitization. 
  
Isinglass 
 
     Isinglass is prepared from the swim bladders, also known as fish maws, of various 
species of tropical fish.  The fish species most commonly used in the preparation of 
isinglass on a worldwide basis include corvina, purse, and several types of sea catfish.  
These are very large fish that also have large maws.  Since these fish are not commonly 
consumed beyond the local tropical areas in which they are caught, the allergenicity of 
these species of fish is not documented.  However, research has now confirmed the 
presence of parvalbumin in these species of fish (FARRP-09-2006).  Thus, parvalbumin-
sensitized individuals seem likely to react to ingestion of these fish species although that 
has not been confirmed by oral challenge trials. 
 4 
     Isinglass has been widely used as a clarifying agent for beers, ales, and wines for 
many years.  Sensitization to isinglass has not been reported despite this widespread use. 
 
     Furthermore, fish maws are commonly consumed as food in many parts of the world 
especially in the form of fish maw soup.  Of the more than 3000 metric tons of fish maws 
that are consumed each year, only 240 metric tons are used for the production of isinglass 
for clarification of beers and ales.  The remainder is mostly eaten as fish maw soup.  
Allergic reactions to fish maw soup have also not been reported.  Although consumption 
of this product occurs primarily in countries where clinical allergy is not a common 
medical specialty e.g. China, consumption does also occur among Chinese populations in 
certain EU countries such as the U.K. that have excellent allergy specialization.  Allergic 
reactions to fish maws have also not been reported in any of these EU countries. 
However, research has now confirmed that fish maws from the species of fish used to 
produce isinglass do contain parvalbumin (FARRP-09-2006).  Thus, the ingestion of fish 
maws by fish-allergic individuals should be avoided. 
 
     Collagen is the primary component of isinglass.  Molecular weights of well over 200 
kD are described for collagen preparations.  Fish maws are composed primarily of 
collagen.  The processing of the maws is not extensive because the objective is to retain 
the three-dimensional structure of collagen that allows it to entrap proteins and other 
haze-producing substances in alcoholic beverages.  Collagen is very insoluble and 
precipitates quickly upon addition to alcoholic beverages.  Since most of the collagen 
precipitates, extremely low levels of collagen would be expected to remain in the treated 
beverages.   
 
     Since isinglass is primarily composed of fish collagen and collagen is not a major 
allergen from fish, the primary concern about the allergenicity of isinglass focuses around 
the presence of small amounts parvalbumin in isinglass.  Parvalbumin is the major 
allergen in several different species of fish including cod, salmon, carp, mackerels, and 
tuna (Elsayed and Aas, 1971; Bugajaska-Schretter et al., 1998; Van Do et al., 1999; 
Bugajska-Schretter et al., 2000; Hamada et al., 2003a; Hamada et al., 2004; Lindström et 
al., 1996; Van Do et al., 2005; Shiomi et al., 1998; Shiomi et al., 1999; Yamada et al., 
1999) and is considered as a pan-allergen for individuals with fish allergy (Taylor et al., 
2004).  The presence and levels of parvalbumin in the muscle and swim bladders of the 
fish species used in the manufacturing of isinglass has now been confirmed.  Thus, the 
detection of residual parvalbumin levels in commercial isinglass seems to be a key factor 
in the assessment of the potential allergenicity of this material. 
 
     As has now been demonstrated in research funded by the isinglass industry, very low 
but detectable levels of parvalbumin do exist in isinglass as measured by ELISAs using 
both anti-carp parvalbumin and anti-cod parvalbumin antibodies.  The presence of very 
low levels of parvalbumin in isinglass is not surprising given its presence in the fish 
maws used to obtain the isinglass.  This same research has documented that the 
parvalbumin content of isinglass can be reduced by washing with phosphate buffer.  
Since parvalbumin is a highly soluble protein, this finding is also not surprising.  
 5However, the results documented that parvalbumin could not be eliminated completely 
from isinglass by washing.  The 3-dimensional structure of collagen likely allows it to 
entrap some parvalbumin which is then very difficult to remove. 
 
     The ultimate documentation of the safety of isinglass involves various clinical 
investigations with fish-allergic individuals.  Furthermore, skin testing of fish-allergic 
patients with fish muscle and fish maw extracts from the relevant species of fish 
demonstrated that the muscle and maws of these fish do contain parvalbumin because 
positive skin tests were obtained (FARRP-09-2006).  Thus, these fish contain 
parvalbumin which is capable of provoking allergic reactions in the fish-allergic 
individuals.  A number of double-blind, placebo-controlled oral challenge tests with 
commercial isinglass have now been completed.  The isinglass used in these clinical trials 
was equivalent to the isinglass samples that was previously shown to contain trace 
quantities of parvalbumin (FARRP-08-2006).  The exposure doses (up to 30 mg for the 
highest individual dose and 50.5 mg cumulative dose) were beyond the levels of isinglass 
exposure from cask ale where exposure would be highest (using worst-case assumptions 
about the amount of residual isinglass, the cumulative challenge dose is equivalent to the 
levels of isinglass found in 50 liters of beer of 10 liters of cask ale consumed over a 2-hr 
time period; thus, even high-level consumers of beer and ale are unlikely to reach this 
level of exposure).  So far, 15 fish-allergic individuals have been challenged with 
isinglass and none have reacted.  Although oral challenges on additional patients are 
planned, the conclusion can already be reached that ingestion of isinglass does not elicit 
allergic reactions in the majority of fish-allergic consumers.  Additionally, under a 
separate clinical protocol, Dr. Fabienne Rance of Toulouse, France challenged 6 fish-
allergic patients with a cumulative dose of 20 mg of isinglass and no adverse reactions 
were noted.  This challenge study, while limited to a small number of patients, adds 
support to the conclusion that ingestion of isinglass does not elicit allergic reactions in the 
majority of fish-allergic consumers. 
 
Expert Opinion on Isinglass
 
     In releasing their opinion on isinglass in late 2004, the EFSA panel commented that 
evidence was needed regarding the possible presence of residues of isinglass in treated 
beers and also of the presence of residues of parvalbumin in isinglass.  Furthermore, the 
EFSA panel requested further research to establish whether isinglass may cause allergic 
reactions in fish-allergic individuals.  DBPCFC trials, in our opinion, would be the best 
approach to address this latter question. 
 
     As noted above, the research sponsored by Brewing Food and Beverage Industry  
Suppliers Association (BFBi) and the Brewers of Europe is answering all of these  
questions.  Research has been conducted to develop a suitable assay for parvalbumin  
residues in isinglass.  ELISAs were developed to detect parvalbumin using anti-frog,  
anti-carp, andanti-cod parvalbumin antibodies.  All of these ELISAs were able to detect 
parvalbumins.  Trace quantities of parvalbumin were detected in commercial isinglass 
using the anti-cod and anti-carp parvalbumin ELISAs.  The ongoing DBPCFCs with 
isinglass on fish-allergic individuals have demonstrated that exposure to low levels of 
 6parvalbumin through the consumption of treated beers and ales is unlikely to be 
allergenic to fish-allergic consumers.   
 
    Exposure levels to parvalbumin in isinglass used to clarify beers and ales are likely to 
be extraordinarily low.  Based on current application levels of isinglass in beer for its 
clarification function and based upon the new knowledge of residual parvalbumin levels 
in isinglass, an estimated 0.05 μg of parvalbumin is added per liter of beer.  However, a 
prudent assumption would be that the parvalbumin mostly co-sediments with the 
isinglass.  Since maximum isinglass residues are estimated at 5 mg per liter in unfiltered 
ales (cask ale), a reasonable estimate of the level of parvalbumin in ale would be only 
0.0065 μg per liter.  The dosages of isinglass in the ongoing clinical challenge trial are 
0.5, 5.0, 15, and 30 mg which is equivalent to exposure of up to 50 liters of beer (and 10 
liters of cask ale).  This dosage range covers all reasonable levels of exposure to beer and 
should document whether isinglass ingestion presents any risk to fish-allergic consumers. 
 
    One remaining concern would relate to fish collagen as a fish allergen.  Evidence 
indicates that sensitization to fish collagen occurs in only a small percentage of fish-
allergic individuals (4 of 15 in fish-allergic patients studied in Japan).  Oral challenge 
trials have not been conducted to confirm that allergenicity of fish collagen in fish-
allergic individuals.  Furthermore, the fish collagen used in the Japanese studies may 
differ from isinglass and no evidence exists to indicate that the fish collagen-sensitized 
individuals would react to isinglass.  In our opinion, fish collagen is likely a minor fish 
allergen but it is likely a very minor allergen based on the lack of reactivity in the fish 
gelatin trials (Hansen et al., 2004).  Individuals with fish collagen sensitivity may be at 
some risk of ingestion of isinglass but that risk remains unproven especially at low 
challenge doses. 
  
     Although isinglass is an ingredient derived from a commonly allergenic food (fish) 
and despite the fact that isinglass contains protein derived from that source (in fact 
isinglass IS protein from fish), the oral challenge trials and other key evidence obtained 
in recent industry-sponsored studies indicates rather clearly that ingestion of isinglass 
does not present a risk to fish-allergic individuals.  This information is pivotal to any 
determination of need for source labeling of isinglass when it is used in clarification of 
beers and ales.

comment_title: Comment 180:  Brewing, Food & Beverage Industry Suppliers' Association
comment_text: Petition for Exemption of Isinglass from Allergen Labelling under Section 403(w)(1) of the FD&C Act This petition, submitted by the Brewing, Food and Beverage Industry Suppliers' Association (BFBi), seeks an exemption from the allergen labelling requirements of Section 403(w)(1) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FD&C Act) for isinglass when used as a fining/clarification agent in beer production. Isinglass is a purified collagen derived from the swim bladders of select tropical and subtropical fish species. It has been used for centuries in brewing to clarify beer, and is removed from the final product through filtration or sedimentation. The petition presents comprehensive scientific, analytical, and clinical evidence demonstrating that isinglass does not pose an allergenic risk to fish-allergic individuals. Key findings include: • Clinical trials (including double-blind placebo-controlled oral challenges) show no allergic reactions in fish-sensitive individuals, even at doses equivalent to extreme beer consumption. • Manufacturing protocols have been optimized to minimize residual parvalbumin, the primary fish allergen, in commercial isinglass products. • Analytical data confirms that residual isinglass and parvalbumin levels in beer are extremely low, often below detection limits. • International regulatory bodies (EFSA, FSANZ, Health Canada) have granted similar exemptions based on comparable evidence. • Literature reviews and updated searches found no documented cases of allergic reactions to isinglass in beer or wine. The petition concludes that isinglass-fined beer does not elicit allergic responses and supports its exemption from allergen labelling requirements, aligning with global regulatory practices and current scientific consensus.

CENTRE HOSPITALIER UNIVERSITAIRE

I undersigned, Dr Fabienne Rancé, that I have carried out a
clinical study on the allergenicity of isinglass according to a protocol in
the children hospital of Toulouse. The protocol was approved by the
Consultative Committee for Human Protection in Biomedical Research
(CPPRB) at Toulouse I on 17th March 2003.

This was a double-blind study using internationally recognised
standard tests. Informed consent was obtained before inclusion in the
study. A double-blind, placebo-controlled, oral isinglass challenge was
performed. For each patient the test was performed twice: once
containing isinglass and once containing the placebo. The order of
administration of the tests was determined at random. The test
containing the substance was prepared by mixing 20 milligrammes of
isinglass with 10 grammes of cooked potato.

Six patients with fish allergy, aged 6 to 22 years participated in
the study. Fish allergy was determined by oral food challenge or by a
convincing clinical history at the time of the study.

Size of skin prick test with fish and isinglass, value of IgE
specific to fish, and result of provocation test by the oral route (signs,
cumulative reactogenic dose in mg) for fish and isinglass was
determined.

For this 6 fish allergic patients, we obtained 2 positive skin prick
test with isinglass, and 6 negative double-blind, placebo-controlled food
challenges with isinglass.

The study take its course in Toulouse to prospectively obtain 35
allergic patients and 5 non-allergic.

10/2005

comment_title: Comment 180:  Brewing, Food & Beverage Industry Suppliers' Association
comment_text: Petition for Exemption of Isinglass from Allergen Labelling under Section 403(w)(1) of the FD&C Act This petition, submitted by the Brewing, Food and Beverage Industry Suppliers' Association (BFBi), seeks an exemption from the allergen labelling requirements of Section 403(w)(1) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FD&C Act) for isinglass when used as a fining/clarification agent in beer production. Isinglass is a purified collagen derived from the swim bladders of select tropical and subtropical fish species. It has been used for centuries in brewing to clarify beer, and is removed from the final product through filtration or sedimentation. The petition presents comprehensive scientific, analytical, and clinical evidence demonstrating that isinglass does not pose an allergenic risk to fish-allergic individuals. Key findings include: • Clinical trials (including double-blind placebo-controlled oral challenges) show no allergic reactions in fish-sensitive individuals, even at doses equivalent to extreme beer consumption. • Manufacturing protocols have been optimized to minimize residual parvalbumin, the primary fish allergen, in commercial isinglass products. • Analytical data confirms that residual isinglass and parvalbumin levels in beer are extremely low, often below detection limits. • International regulatory bodies (EFSA, FSANZ, Health Canada) have granted similar exemptions based on comparable evidence. • Literature reviews and updated searches found no documented cases of allergic reactions to isinglass in beer or wine. The petition concludes that isinglass-fined beer does not elicit allergic responses and supports its exemption from allergen labelling requirements, aligning with global regulatory practices and current scientific consensus.
document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
Clinical Study Protocol 
 
Project Title 
Study into the allergenicity of isinglass, a fi sh derivative, used as a technological aid in the 
drinks industry 
 
Sponsor 
Lallemand SA, 19 rue des Briquetiers, 31072 Blagnac Cedex 
Represented by Claude Espeillac 
 
Investigator 
Dr. Fabienne Rancé 
Hospital practitioner (Hôpital des Enfants, Allergy and Pneumology, 330 avenue de Grande 
Bretagne, TSA 70034, 31059 Toulouse cedex 9) 
 
The protocol was approved by the Consultative Committee for Human Protection in 
Biomedical Research (CPPRB) at Toulouse I on 17th March 2003 
 
 
I. State of Scientific Knowledge  
 
The frequency of fish allergy is regarded differently according to geographical location and 
food habits. In France, fish allergy corresponds to the 5th food allergy in children, and the 
14th food allergy in adults [1, 2]. 
 
Fish Allergy 
Fish form a very wide group with over 20,000 species. The first publication of fish allergy is 
attributed to Besche in Norway [3]. The in vitro work by Tuft [4] and Aas [5], analysing 
several species of fish, notes that fish allergies apply to all species due to cross reactivity 
between them. However certain fish allergies trigger allergic reactions only for a particular 
species. Fish allergy can therefore be isolated to a single species or include all fish:  it 
appears that 40% of patients tolerate at least one fish species [6, 7]. There is no cross 
reactivity between fish and crustaceans or molluscs. 
 
Allergens are agents capable of provoking pathological reactions in an individual sensitive to 
this allergen [8]. Allergens are proteins of molecular weight between 10 and 70 kDa [9]. Fish 
allergens belong to the family of parvalbumines, muscular proteins. The different 
parvalbumines are present in the sarcoplasma of fish muscular cells. The major allergen in 
cod was identified by Aas and Elsayed in 1971, then named according to international 
nomenclature Gad c 1 (Gadus callarias)  [10]. This is the M allergen of cod, a muscular 
protein (sarcoplasma of muscular cells) with MW 12.3 kDa, a family of parvalbumines 
bonding calcium [11]. It is resistant to denaturation and proteolysis. This is an important 
allergen for cod but is not present in all fish species. There are homologies of structure of the 
order of 34% between fish species. Cod also has other allergens, known as intermediary or 
minor, of which one with a molecular weight of 63 kDa is also found in surimi [12]. Recent 
works have also isolated the major allergen of Atlantic salmon Sal s 1 (Salmo salar) , 
muscular extract, parvalbumine family [13]. Cooking or smoking reduces the allergenicity. 
 
Fish Derivatives in the Drinks Industry 
The swim bladders of tropical species such as Aridae, Siluridae, Sciaenidae and 
Polynemidae are used for the preparation of a glue or isinglass. This technological aid is 
used essentially to clarify beer but also wines. It is a collagen of molecular weight 800 to 
 11300 kDa. The swim bladder undergoes several processes: drying, granulation, cleaning 
(physical and cold water) and solubilisation. 
 
In beer, as in wine, isinglass is used at the rate of 1 to 2 grammes per hl. After 
sedimentation, centrifuging and filtration, the highest value found in the end product for 
consumption is 0.16 ppm. These derivatives are t herefore difficult to implicate in allergies 
because of the non-muscular origin in fish, the very high molecular weight far greater than 
for listed allergens, and above all their presence at infinitesimally small levels. Despite the 
traditional use dating from the 18th century, to our knowledge there is no information in the 
literature mentioning an observation of allergy linked to this product. 
 
 
 
II. Purpose of the Study  
 
No work has studied the allergenicity of isinglass, used as a technological aid to clarify beers 
and wines. The allergenicity of isinglass has never been shown, although the allergic risk is 
low. At present we have supposition only. 
 
The main objective is to specify the allergenicity of fish-derived isinglass present in drinks by 
standardised double-blind allergy tests, by comparing the results obtained in patients allergic 
to fish and controls. 
 
 
 
III. Study Protocol  
 
This is a double-blind study using internationally recognised standard tests. 
 
Informed consent is obtained before inclusion in the study. A pregnancy test will be 
performed in girls and young women of child-bearing age. 
 
All patients will undergo the prick test for isinglass, placebo, different fish species, and 
positive and negative controls. 
 
A double-blind, placebo-controlled, oral isinglass challenge will be performed. For each 
patient the test is performed twice:  once containing isinglass and once containing the 
placebo. The order of administration of the tests is determined at random. The test 
containing the substance is prepared by mixing 20 milligrammes of isinglass with 10 
grammes of cooked potato. This quantity has been selected to comply with the extreme 
conditions from the following hypotheses: 
 
* the maximum dose of use of isinglass in beer or wine is 2 g/hl, or 20 ppm 
* the maximum residual doses of the technological aid, isinglass, found in filtered beer is 
less than 0.16 ppm or 0.16 mg/l. As a precautionary measure, it is considered that these 
doses could be 20 times larger, or 3.2 mg/l 
* the quantity of beer ingested is considered as being excessive, 4 litres 
 
The placebo test contains only 10 g cooked potato. The mixture is given in 3 doses of 1, 3 
and 6 grammes at 30 minute intervals. The second test (substance or placebo depending on 
random allocation) is performed 2 hours after the end of the first test. A clinical examination 
with measurement is performed before the food challenge. The test is stopped as soon as a 
clinical sign appears. The patient fasts during the test with permission to drink water or apple 
juice. A meal is served 30 minutes after the end of the test. In the case of a reaction, food is 
served earlier to delay the absorption or dilute the allergen. A doctor and a nurse watch and 
 2report all symptoms. The monitoring covers the skin condition and searches for digestive 
and respiratory signs. Emergency treatment in the case of reaction is prepared before the 
start of the test and available during the test. A doctor with experience in allergies is present 
throughout the test. 
 
Number of patients 
40 patients aged 14 to 18 participate in the study (35 allergic to fish and 5 not allergic). It is 
necessary to obtain 35 consecutive allergic patients to establish that, in the absence of 
positive tests in the allergic patients, it can be concluded with a confidence interval of 95% 
and an α  risk of 5% that isinglass is non-allergenic for at least 90% of patients with fish 
allergy. The same tests with isinglass performed in just 5 patients not allergic to fish allows 
us to establish the absence of allergy to isinglass also in persons not allergic to fish. 
 
Choice of adolescent or young adult volunteers 
Recruitment is not possible amongst adults for successful performance of this study. The 
food allergy is three times more common in children than in adults. The study is easier to 
perform in young persons aged 14 to 18 years. The study cannot therefore be performed in 
any other way. 
 
Methods of recruitment 
Volunteers will be recruited by Dr. Rancé at the Children's Hospital, CHU Toulouse, on the 
basis of 2 groups:  one allergic group and one non-allergic group. The study is carried out 
prospectively to obtain 35 allergic patients and 5 non-allergic. Patients will be selected in the 
same location and time period (consecutive recruitment). 
 
Data analysis 
The data will be analysed at the Children's Hospital in Toulouse. It concerns the following 
indicators:  signs of fish allergy, size of cutaneous test with fish and isinglass, value of IgE 
specific to fish, and result of provocation test by the oral route (signs, cumulative reactogenic 
dose in mg) for fish and isinglass. 
 
The statistical tests used are chi2 for qualitative variables, Student test for mean 
comparison, calculation of association force with OR and precision measurement with IC at 
95%. 
 
Civil liability insurance will be concluded by the sponsor, the company Lallemand. 
 
 
 
IV. References  
 
1. Kanny G, Moneret-Vautrin DA, Flabee J, Beaudoin E, Morisset M, Thevenin F. Population study of 
food allergy in France. J Allergy Clin Immunol 2001, 108, 133-40. 
 
2. Sampson HA. Epidemiology of food allergy (review). Pediatr Allergy Immunol 1996; 7 : S42-50. 
 
3. Rancé F, Kanny G, Dutau G, Moneret-Vautrin DA. Food hypersens itivity in children : clinical 
aspects and distribution of allergens. Pediatr Allergy Immunol 1999 ; 10 : 33-38. 
 
4. Johansson SGO, Hourihane JO ’B, Bousquet J, Bruijnzeel-K oomen C, Dreborg S, Haahtela T, 
Kowalski ML, Mygind N, Ring J, van Cauwenberge P, van Hage-Hamsten M, Wuthrich B. A revised 
nomenclature for allergy. An EAACI position statem ent from the EAACI nomenclature tesk force. 
Allergy 2001; 56: 813-24. 
 
5. Rancé F., Bidat E., Allergie alimentaire chez  l’enfant. Genève : Médecine & Hygiène, Médecine & 
enfance; ISBN : 2-88049- 149-5  
 3 
6. Altman DR, Chiaramonte LT. Pub lic perception of food allergy. J Allergy Clin Immunol  1996; 97 : 
1247-51. 
 
7. Young E, Stoneham MD, Petruckevitch A, Bart on J, Rona R. A population study of food 
intolerance. Lancet 1994; 343: 1127-30.  
 
8. Niestijl Janssen JJ, Kardinaal AFM, Huijbers G, Vli eg-Boerstra J, Marten s BPM, Ockhuizen T. 
Prevalence of food allergy and intolerance in the adult dutch population. J Allergy Clin Immunol 1994 ; 
93 : 446-456.  
 
9. htpp:// www cicbaa.com 
 
10. de Besche A. On asthma bronchial in man pr ovoked by cat, dog and different others animals. 
Acta Med Scand 1937; 42 : 237-55. 
 
11. Tuft L, Blumstein GI. Studies in food allergy.  V. Antigenic relationship among members of fish 
family. J Allergy 1946; 17 : 329-39. 
 
12. Aas K. Studies of hypersensitivity to fish: clinical study. Int Arch Allergy 1966; 29 : 346-63. 
 
13. Aas K, Elsayed S. Physico-chemical properties and specific activity of a purified allergen (codfish). 
Dev Biol Stand 1975; 29 : 90-8. 
 
14. Elsayed S, Bennich H. The primar y structure of allergen M from cod. Scand J Immunol 1975; 4 : 
203-8. 
 
15. Pascual C, Esteban M, Crespo JF. Fish allergy:  evaluation of the importance of cross-reactivity. J 
Pediatr 1992; 121 : S29-34. 
 
16.  Sicherer SH. Clinical implications of cross-reactive food allergens. J Allergy Clin Immunol 2001; 
108 : 881-90. 
 
17. Mata E, Favier C, Moneret-Vautrin DA, Nicola s JP, Han Ching L, Gueant JL. Surimi and native 
codfish contain a common allergen identified as a 63-kDa protein. Allergy 1994; 49 : 442-7. 
 
18. Lindstrom CD, van Do T, Hordvik I, Endresen C, Elsayed S. Cloning of two distinct cDNAs 
encoding parvalbumin, the major allergen of atlantic salmon (Salmo salar). Scand J Immunol 1996; 44 
: 335-44. 
 
19. Yunginger JW, Sweeney Y, Sturner WQ, Gianand rea LA, Teigland JD, Bray M, et al. Fatal food-
induced anaphylaxis. JAMA 1988 ; 260: 1450-2. 
 
20. Sicherer SH, Noone SA, Munoz-Furlong A. The impac t of childhood food allergy on quality of life. 
Ann Allergy 2001; 8 : 461-4. 
 
21. Kjellman NIM, Nilsson L. From food allergy and atopic dermatitis to respiratory allergy. Pediatr 
Allergy Immunol 1998;  9 (Suppl. 11) : 13-7. 
 
22. Sampson HA. Utility of food-specific IgE concentr ations in predicting symptomatic food allergy. 
Food and drug reactions and anaphylaxis. J Allergy Clin Immunol 2001; 107 : 891-6. 
 
 
 
 
V. State of Progress of Study  
 
The feasibility of the study is good taking into account the prevalence of fish allergy and 
hospital recruitment.  
 
 4
