University of Nebraska  Page 4 of 15 
  
 
Tables 
   
Table 1.1. Description of fish and fish maw samples ........................................................................... 6 
Table 1.2 Protein and parvalbumin content in fish and swim bladder extracts.................................... 9 
Table 2.1 Characteristics of fish-allergic subjects............................................................................ .. 13 
Table 2.2. History of alcoholic beverage consumption by subjects enrolled in trial .......................... 14 Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-09-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 5 of 15 
  
 I.  Skin Testing with Fish Muscle Tissue and Swim Bladder Extracts 
 
 Lead Clinicians:  Carsten Bindslev-Jensen, M.D.,Odense University Hospital, Denmark 
         Richard Pumphrey, M.D., Manchester Royal Infirmary, England 
 
 Lead Scientists:   Steve L. Taylor, Ph.D., FARRP, University of Nebraska 
        Sue L. Hefle, Ph.D., FARRP, University of Nebraska 
        Julie A. Nordlee, M.S., FARRP, University of Nebraska 
        Lingyun Chen, Ph.D., FARRP, University of Nebraska 
        Stef Koppelman, Ph.D., AllerTeQ, the Netherlands 
        Martin Hessing, Ph.D., Podiceps B.V., the Netherlands 
 
A.  Introduction: 
 
Isinglass is a commonly used ingredient for the clarification of beers and ales.  Isinglass is 
prepared from the swim bladders of various species of tropical fish.  Collagen is the primary 
component of isinglass.  Molecular weights of well over 200 kilo Daltons (kD) are described for 
collagen preparations.  Parvalbumin, a comparatively small protein from fish muscle, is widely 
considered as the major pan-allergen from fish (Taylor et al., 2004a).  Fish collagen is not 
considered as a major fish allergen.  Although swim bladders are composed primarily of 
collagen, swim bladders are also likely to contain parvalbumin (Gerday et al., 1989).  However, 
the presence of parvalbumin in fish swim bladders has not been thoroughly investigated and 
certainly not from the species of fish used to produce isinglass.  Although parvalbumin is 
thought to be a ubiquitous protein in the muscles of all fish species, the presence of parvalbumin 
in the muscles of the fish species used in the preparation of isinglass has not been clearly 
demonstrated.  Furthermore, the allergenicity of these particular species of fish is also not well 
known even though another common assumption is that all species of fish are allergenic.  
Sensitization to isinglass has not been reported nor have allergic reactions been reported in fish-
sensitized individuals, despite its widespread use as a clarifying agent for beers, ales, and wines.  
This observation suggests that fish collagen is an unlikely allergen and that isinglass contains 
insufficient parvalbumin to elicit reactions in fish-allergic individuals. 
 
Skin testing was performed with extracts of fish muscle and swim bladders of the fish species 
used in the commercial manufacturing of isinglass.  The primary purpose of skin testing was to 
confirm the likely presence of parvalbumin in the muscle tissues of these unique species and to 
document the presence of parvalbumin in the swim bladders of these species.  This clinical 
investigation will serve to demonstrate that these fish and their swim bladders are likely to 
provoke allergic reactions in fish-allergic individuals. 
 
B. Materials: 
 
Fish samples Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-09-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 6 of 15 
  
Whole fish and dried maws (swim bladder) were forwarded to Podiceps BV by various suppliers 
used by the isinglass manufacturers.  Table 1.1 gives a list of the samples obtained (6 maws, 6 
whole fish).  The whole fish samples were filleted, and clean fillets (essentially free of collagen-
like tissue and fat) were used for preparation of extracts.  The remainder of the fish was 
discarded.  In this report, samples are referred to by species code (first column in Table 1.1) and 
the description maw or fish, the latter meaning fillet.  
 
Table 1.1 Description of Fish and Fish Maw Samples 
 
Species code Description Species 
J 52/04 Corvina from S. America 
 
Corvina del Lago, Cynoscions 
acoupa 
FL 17/18/05 Singala from India 
 
Black sea catfish, Arius 
dussumieri 
FL 13/04  Singala from Pakistan 
 
Spotted catfish, Arius maculates 
F 21/05 Purse from Uganda/West Africa 
 
Bagrus docmak 
FA 1/2/05 Purse from the Gambia 
 
African sea catfish, Arius 
africanus 
FA 13/05 Purse from Venezuela 
 
Bagre Blanco (white catfish), 
Bagrus pseudopimelodus sp. 
 
All maw samples arrived in dried condition.  The processing background of these samples was 
unknown. All fish samples arrived frozen, except for F 21/05, which arrived non-frozen and 
covered with mold rendering this particular sample unusable.  Samples of maw and fish (after 
fillets were prepared) were stored until use at -20° C. 
 
Extraction buffer 
Phosphate buffered saline (PBS) was used to prepare extracts (see FARRP 08-2006 for details of 
optimization of extraction buffer).  PBS was from Fresenius Kabi (Schelle, Belgium, catalogue 
number N400500) and contained per liter: 8.2 g NaCl, 1.9 g Na
2HPO4·2H2O and 0.3 g 
NaH2PO4·2H2O (pH = 7.4).  PBS was sterile and pyrogen free solution.  Containers with 
extraction buffer were only used once after opening.  
 
General extraction procedure 
Fish and maw samples were ground using a kitchen-scale blender and if necessary with a 
professional blender (Super Total Nutrition Center, stainless steel, Whole food machine®, Vita-
mix Corp., Cleveland, OH, USA).  Ground samples were stored frozen.  Extracts were prepared 
by stirring 1 part of ground fish or maw sample with 4 parts of PBS for 2 hours at room 
temperature.  Suspensions were centrifuged (15 minutes at 4°C, 4000 rpm in sterile 50 ml PP-
test tubes, Greiner Bio-one, Longwood, FL, USA, catalogue reference Cellstar® 227261).  Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-09-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 7 of 15 
  
Extracts were filtered over 0.22 μm bottle-top filters (500 ml filter system 0.22µm PES 
[polyethersulfone] sterilizing, low protein binding membrane, non pyrogenic [Corning Inc., 
Acton, MA, USA]). After filtration, extracts were subdivided into 1 ml aliquots (2 ml 
polypropylene cryo vials, 12.5/48 mm, sterile and pyrogen-free vials with screw cap, Greiner 
Bio-one catalogue number 121263).  Filtration and subdividing were done in a flow chamber.  
The extracts were aseptically distributed into sterile vials and stored at -80°C until distributed to 
the clinical test sites.  One vial of each extract was prepared for each subject.  The materials were 
distributed frozen and subsequently held frozen.  Once thawed for use, the material was used for 
only one subject on one day and then discarded.   
 
Protein concentration determination
Protein concentrations were determined by Bradford analysis using Bradford reagent from 
Sigma-Aldrich (St. Louis, MO, catalogue number B6916) with bovine serum albumin (BSA) as 
a standard (Sigma: A7906, minimum BSA content: 98%). 
 
Histamine analysis 
Histamine was measured with a Ridascreen Histamin kit (R1604, r-Biopharm, Darmstadt, 
Germany), according to the manufacturer’s instruction. All samples were measured once, in 
various dilutions. This assay is a competitive ELISA for the quantification of histamine in food 
 
pH determination 
In order to avoid cross contact between extracts, pH was determined using pH paper instead of a 
pH electrode (pH-Fix 0-14, Machery-Nagel GmbH, Düren, Germany, catalogue number 921 10) 
with an estimated accuracy of 0.5 pH unit. 
 
Microbiological testing
Skin test extracts were checked for sterility by the University of Nebraska-Lincoln Food 
Processing Center Microbiological Services Laboratory. 
 
Parvalbumin concentration
Parvalbumin levels were determined by the ELISA method using anti-carp parvalbumin 
monoclonal antibody as described in FARRP-07-2006.  The results are expressed in carp 
parvalbumin equivalents. 
 
  C.  Methods: 
 
Subject Selection
Fifteen fish-allergic subjects will be challenged.  Thus far, 8 fish-allergic subjects have 
completed the skin testing challenge.  Criteria for inclusion in the study were: 
 
1. Convincing clinical history of a Type I allergic reaction when fish are consumed.  
Subjects were well characterized fish-allergic children and adults in generally good 
health.  Potential subjects were at least three years old and not older than 70 years.   Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-09-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 8 of 15 
  
  
2. Positive skin prick test to one or more species of fish with a either commercial or 
fresh fish extract AND positive specific IgE to fish that meet the following criteria: 
 
a).  Recently performed skin prick tests as large or larger than the positive control 
histamine skin prick test or at least 3 mm in diameter. 
b).  Recently performed specific IgE score to fish of greater than 0.35 kUA/L. 
 
Since certain medications may interfere with the development and interpretation of the skin test 
responses, conventional antihistamines were discontinued at least 3 days before skin testing, long 
acting antihistamines were discontinued for at least 7 days prior to skin testing, and topical 
steroids were discontinued at the skin test site for at least 2-3 weeks before skin testing.  
Tricyclic antidepressants such as Doxepin were withheld for at least 7 days before skin testing. 
Topical local anesthetics may suppress the flare responses and were avoided at skin test sites.  
 
Skin testing procedure
 
Skin prick testing was done by placing a drop of fish extract or control extracts on the cleansed 
volar surface of the forearm or the back of the individual, and lightly pricking the skin with a 
sterile needle or lancet.  Negative and positive skin prick test controls are done in the same 
fashion with saline solution or the solution used to prepare the extract and histamine solution 
(1%), respectively.  Skin prick test materials used to qualify subjects for this study were either 
fresh cod extracts or commercial products expressly prepared for diagnostic skin testing.  The 
commercial extract was used in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions.   Experimental 
skin test materials were prepared by the procedures described above. 
 
Skin prick tests for fish extracts were judged and recorded based on the size of the wheal (raised 
welt around prick site) and flare (reddened area around wheal) as compared to the positive and 
negative control skin prick tests after 15 minutes and re-inspected at 30 minutes.   The SPT is 
deemed positive by comparison to the negative and positive control skin prick tests and needed 
to be at least as large as the positive histamine control SPT or at least 3 mm in diameter to be 
considered positive.   
 
Ethics board approvals were obtained from the University of Nebraska-Lincoln and from the 
participating clinical centers. 
 
D.  Results: 
 
Protein and parvalbumin content
The skin test extracts from fish muscle and swim bladders (maws) had somewhat lower protein 
levels than reported previously in FARRP-08-2006 probably because of the ultrafiltration for 
sterilization.  The protein and parvalbumin levels are shown in Table 1.2. 
 Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-09-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 9 of 15 
  
 
Table 1.2.  Protein and Parvalbumin Content in Fish and Swim Bladder Extracts 
 
Description 
Parvalbumin content, g 
carp parvalbumin 
equivalent/g protein (%) 
Protein concentration 
(mg/mL) determined by 
Bradford assay 
FL 13/04 FISH 1.51 3.55 
FA 1/2/05 FISH 15.15 3.47 
FA 13/05 FISH 8.32 2.39 
J 52/04 FISH 0.71 3.21 
FL 17/18/05 FISH 0.03 3.54 
FL 13/04 MAW 0.30 0.59 
F 21/05 MAW 0.88 1.43 
FA 1/2/05 MAW 0.91 0.30 
FA 13/05 MAW 0.28 0.40 
J 52/04 MAW 0.88 0.41 
FL 17/18/05 MAW 0.24 0.50 
 
Skin Tests with Fish-Allergic Individuals
Skin testing as described above has been completed on 8 fish-allergic subjects at the clinic in 
Odense, Denmark.  As noted, skin testing of 7 additional individuals is planned in Denmark and 
England but those results are not yet available. 
 
All eight fish-allergic subjects had positive skin test responses to the extracts of the fish fillet 
muscles of each of the fish noted in Table 1.2.  Seven of the eight fish-allergic subjects had 
positive skin test responses to the extracts of the fish swim bladders (maws) of each of the fish 
noted in Table 1.2.  The eighth subject had positive skin test reactions to 5 of the 6 swim bladder 
extracts but had a negative response to a prick test with the extract of swim bladder of  FA 13/05 
(Bagrus pseudopimelodus sp.). 
 
E. Discussion 
 
These results indicate rather clearly that the fish muscle of these tropical fish species contain 
parvalbumin and that the parvalbumin is cross-reactive with IgE antibodies in European subjects 
sensitized to fish eaten more commonly in Europe.  This result is not particularly surprising 
because parvalbumin is considered as a pan-allergen (Taylor et al., 2004a) that should be found 
in the edible muscle tissues of all fish species.  However, while the levels of protein in the fish 
muscle extracts were reasonably consistent from species to species, the levels of apparent 
parvalbumin were quite variable.  In earlier reports, three different ELISAs for parvalbumin 
were developed and shown to have differing specificities for parvalbumin from various species 
of fish.  Thus, this result should be attributed, at least in part, to possible specificity issues arising 
from use of the monoclonal anti-carp parvalbumin antibody in this particular ELISA.  While the 
allergenicity of the muscle tissue of these species of fish has not been confirmed by oral Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-09-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 10 of 15 
  
challenge tests, the presence of parvalbumin in these tissues strongly suggests that fish-allergic 
individuals should avoid consumption of the muscle tissue of these fish. 
 
The extracts of the swim bladders had considerably lower protein levels by comparison to the 
muscle extracts (Table 1.2).  Certainly, this is due to the insoluble nature of the collagen, the 
predominant protein in swim bladders which is thus unlikely to be present in large amounts in 
the saline extracts.  Parvalbumin levels in the extracts of the swim bladders are lower (in 5 of 6 
cases) than parvalbumin levels in muscle extracts.  However, this investigation confirms that the 
swim bladders of these 6 species of fish contain parvalbumin.  While the swim bladder of the 
oyster toadfish has previously been known to contain parvalbumin (Gerday et al., 1989), the 
ubiquity of parvalbumin in fish swim bladders of various species had not been thoroughly 
investigated.  These results demonstrate that parvalbumin is present in swim bladders from all of 
these species so perhaps parvalbumin is ubiquitously present in fish swim bladders.    
 
The swim bladder extract of the black sea catfish contained higher levels of apparent 
parvalbumin than did the muscle extract of that species.  However, that result could also be a 
function of the comparative specificity of the anti-carp parvalbumin antibody.  The parvalbumin 
types in swim bladder and muscle could be different leading to variable recognition by the 
various antibodies to parvalbumin.  It would be interesting to repeat this result with the anti-frog 
and anti-cod parvalbumin antibodies but we have not yet done that experiment. 
 
Since fish swim bladders also contain parvalbumin, the ingestion of fish maws is likely 
hazardous for fish-allergic individuals.  Fish maw soup is consumed in several countries 
including China.  Again, oral challenge trials would be necessary to confirm the hazards 
associated with fish maws but caution would certainly be prudent based upon the existing 
results. 
 
Since the muscle tissue and maws of these fish species used to manufacture isinglass contain 
parvalbumin, the allergenicity of isinglass is likely related to residual levels of parvalbumin in 
commercial isinglass.  As previously noted (see FARRP-08-2006), very low levels of residual 
parvalbumin were found in isinglass.  The following section will describe the results of clinical 
oral challenge trials with isinglass on fish-allergic individuals which will determine the 
allergenic hazard, if any, associated with ingestion of isinglass by such individuals. 
 
II.  Oral Challenge Trials with Commerical Isinglass in Fish-Allergic Individuals 
 
 Lead Clinicians:  Carsten Bindslev-Jensen, M.D., Odense University Hospital, Denmark 
       Barbara Ballmer-Weber, M.D., University of Zürich, Switzerland 
       Richard Pumphrey, M.D., Manchester Royal Infirmary, England 
 
Lead Scientists:  Steve L. Taylor, Ph.D., FARRP, University of Nebraska 
     Sue L. Hefle, Ph.D., FARRP, University of Nebraska 
     Julie A. Nordlee, M.S., FARRP, University of Nebraska Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-09-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 11 of 15 
  
 
  A.  Introduction:  
 
Isinglass is a commonly used ingredient for the clarification of beers and ales.  Isinglass is 
prepared from the swim bladders of various species of tropical fish.  Collagen is the primary 
component of isinglass.  Molecular weights of well over 200 kD are described for collagen 
preparations.  Parvalbumin, a comparatively small protein from fish muscle, is widely 
considered as the major pan-allergen from fish (Taylor et al., 2004a).  Fish collagen is not 
considered as a major fish allergen.  Although swim bladders are composed primarily of 
collagen, swim bladders are also likely to contain parvalbumin (Gerday et al., 1989).  
Sensitization to isinglass has not been reported nor have allergic reactions been reported in fish-
sensitized individuals, despite its widespread use as a clarifying agent for beers, ales, and wines.  
This observation suggests that fish collagen is an unlikely allergen and that isinglass contains 
insufficient parvalbumin to elicit reactions in fish-allergic individuals. 
   
A clinical challenge trial was needed to confirm this suspicion that ingestion of typical quantities 
of isinglass does not pose a hazard to fish-allergic individuals.  In this section of the report, the 
results of oral challenges of 15 fish-allergic individuals are presented.  
 
B.  Materials & Methods: 
 
Subject Selection
Twenty-nine fish-allergic individuals will be selected and challenged based on the guidelines put 
forth in “A consensus protocol for the determination of the threshold doses for allergenic foods:  
how much is too much?” (Taylor et al., 2004b).   Thus far, 15 subjects have completed the oral 
challenge trials.  Criteria for inclusion in the study were: 
 
1. Convincing clinical history of a Type I allergic reaction when fish are 
consumed.  Subjects were well characterized fish-allergic children and adults 
in generally good health, between the ages of 3 and 70 years.  Subjects with 
severe reactions to fish were not excluded. 
 
2.   Positive skin prick test to one or more species of fish AND positive specific 
IgE to fish that meet the following criteria: 
 
a).  Recently performed skin prick test as large or larger than the positive 
control histamine skin prick test, or at least 3 mm in diameter. 
b). Recently performed specific IgE score to fish of greater than 0.35 kUA/L. 
 
The subjects enrolled in this challenge trial ceased taking all prescribed medications related to 
their allergies for suitable withdrawal periods before commencement of the challenge trial.  In 
particular, H
1 anti-histamines with a short duration of activity were withheld for a minimum of 
48 hours.  Hydroxyzine was withheld for a minimum of 72 hours, leukotriene receptor Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-09-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 12 of 15 
  
antagonists were withheld for up to 1 week, and second generation anti-histamines (cetirizine) 
were withheld for at least 1 week.  In the case of patients with co-existing or food-induced 
asthma, short-acting inhaled or oral beta-agonists and inhaled anticholinergics were continued up 
to 6 hours before challenge.  Long-term beta-agonists were stopped 12 hours before challenge.  
Chromones (cromolyn and nedocromil) were withheld for 48 hours.  Inhaled steroids or oral 
corticosteroids were continued in patients where prescribed, although patients with serious 
asthma were not included in this challenge.   
 
Caffeine and alcohol were also excluded for 24 hours prior to challenge.  Females of child-
bearing age were required to have a negative pregnancy test each day that oral challenges were 
given. 
 
Oral challenge procedure
Oral challenges were performed in double-blind, placebo-controlled fashion on two separate 
days (randomly assigned placebo and isinglass challenge days).  The isinglass challenge material 
was a commercially available product supplied by worldwide isinglass manufacturers and 
representative of isinglass as manufactured currently.  This isinglass material has also been 
analyzed for residual parvalbumin (see FARRP-08-2006).  The isinglass was disguised in 
mashed potatoes and the inability to distinguish between potatoes containing isinglass and 
placebo potatoes was confirmed by sensory evaluation.  Subjects were challenged with four 
doses of isinglass in a rehydrated, seasoned mashed potato preparation.  The doses were 0.5 mg, 
5 mg, 15 mg and 30 mg isinglass in about 40 grams mashed potato given in order of increasing 
amount.  Four portions of mashed potatoes containing no isinglass were given on a different day 
and act as the placebo portion of the oral challenge.  The doses were given at 30-minute 
intervals.  Duplicates of each dose and placebo were provided (all in blinded fashion) in the 
event that a dose needed to be repeated.  Doses could be repeated if there was a question about 
the objectivity of the reaction.  If no objective reaction was observed after the duplicate dose, the 
next dose was given. 
 
Dehydrated potatoes and isinglass challenge material were pre-weighed into challenge containers 
in a food grade facility at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln.  Preparation of the challenge 
material at the clinical investigation site required the addition of nearly boiling water to the 
challenge containers, briefly stirring to moisten, allowing the mixture to stand for thirty seconds, 
mixing and then presenting to the subject.  The challenge order was randomized for each subject 
and all challenge materials blinded before shipping to the clinical investigation site.   
 
 
C.   Results: 
 
The characteristics of the subjects enrolled in the isinglass challenge trial are portrayed in Table 
2.1. 
 
 Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-09-2006

These subjects also reported on their consumption of alcoholic beverages (Table 2.2).  These 
individuals reported that they regularly consumed beers, ales, and wines without incident.  The 
alcoholic beverages are likely to have been treated with isinglass on at least some occasions.  
This small survey was conducted to document that fish-allergic individuals do not avoid 
isinglass-treated beverages.

      OAS=oral allergy symptoms with 2 sips of red wine 
 
None of the 15 individuals challenged thus far has reacted adversely to the isinglass challenge.  
Therefore, consumption of a cumulative dose of 50.5 mg of isinglass or an upper dose of 30 mg 
of isinglass occurred without provocation of any adverse reactions.  One subject had a mild 
adverse reaction (skin rash) to placebo but not to isinglass.  This response was the only objective 
symptom encountered during the oral challenge trials.  Three subjects each experienced mild 
subjective reactions (e.g. palatal itching) to placebo and isinglass at initial doses used in the trial.  
However, these symptoms resolved quickly and further doses of either placebo or isinglass were 
administered without these or other symptoms developing.  Thus, these subjective reactions do 
not appear to be related to the challenge trial.  
 
D.  Discussion: 
 
While our ultimate aim is to enroll 29 fish-allergic patients in the isinglass challenge trial, only 
15 subjects have completed the challenges so far.  However, none of these patients has reacted 
adversely to the administration of a cumulative challenge dose of 50.5 mg of isinglass.  This 
amount of isinglass is far in excess of the amount that might be achieved with beer and wine 
consumption.  Cask ale, under certain circumstances, may allow higher levels of isinglass 
exposure but the 50.5 mg cumulative dose was intended to represent a worst-case scenario that is Food Allergy Research and Resource Program  Study No. FARRP-09-2006 
University of Nebraska  Page 15 of 15 
  
even beyond the exposure levels that likely occur with cask ale.  Thus, this challenge trial 
confirms that fish-allergic individuals may safely consume alcoholic beverages that have been 
treated with isinglass. 
 
III. References:  
 
Gerday Ch, Collin S, Gerardin-Otthiers N.  1989.  The amino acid sequence of the parvalbumin 
from the very fast swimbladder muscle of the toadfish (Opsanus tau). Comp Biochem Physiol B   
93:49-55.  
 
Taylor SL, Kabourek JL, Hefle SL.  2004a.  Fish allergy: fish and products thereof.  J Food Sci 
69:R175-R180. 
 
Taylor SL, Hefle SL, Bindslev-Jensen C, Atkins FM, Andre C, Bruijnzeel-Koomen C, Burks 
AW, Bush RK, Ebisawa M, Eigenmann PA, Host A, Hourihane JO’B, Isolauri E, Hill DJ, Knulst 
A, Lack G, Sampson HA, Moneret-Vautrin DA, Rance F, Vadas PA, Yunginger JW, Zeiger RS, 
Salminen JW, Madsen C, and Abbott P.  2004b. A consensus protocol for the determination of 
the threshold doses for allergenic foods: how much is too much? Clin Exp Allergy 34:689-695.

comment_title: Comment 180:  Brewing, Food & Beverage Industry Suppliers' Association
comment_text: Petition for Exemption of Isinglass from Allergen Labelling under Section 403(w)(1) of the FD&C Act This petition, submitted by the Brewing, Food and Beverage Industry Suppliers' Association (BFBi), seeks an exemption from the allergen labelling requirements of Section 403(w)(1) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FD&C Act) for isinglass when used as a fining/clarification agent in beer production. Isinglass is a purified collagen derived from the swim bladders of select tropical and subtropical fish species. It has been used for centuries in brewing to clarify beer, and is removed from the final product through filtration or sedimentation. The petition presents comprehensive scientific, analytical, and clinical evidence demonstrating that isinglass does not pose an allergenic risk to fish-allergic individuals. Key findings include: • Clinical trials (including double-blind placebo-controlled oral challenges) show no allergic reactions in fish-sensitive individuals, even at doses equivalent to extreme beer consumption. • Manufacturing protocols have been optimized to minimize residual parvalbumin, the primary fish allergen, in commercial isinglass products. • Analytical data confirms that residual isinglass and parvalbumin levels in beer are extremely low, often below detection limits. • International regulatory bodies (EFSA, FSANZ, Health Canada) have granted similar exemptions based on comparable evidence. • Literature reviews and updated searches found no documented cases of allergic reactions to isinglass in beer or wine. The petition concludes that isinglass-fined beer does not elicit allergic responses and supports its exemption from allergen labelling requirements, aligning with global regulatory practices and current scientific consensus.
document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
Food Allergy Research and Resource Program (FARRP) 
Determination of the Allergenicity of Isinglass in Fish Allergic Individuals 
 
Isinglass is a product composed principally of collagen derived mainly from the swim 
bladders of certain species of tropical and subtropical fish (corvina, threadfin, croaker, 
and others), although cod, sturgeon and hake swim bladders may also be used 
occasionally (1).   
 
Isinglass is a processing aid used to clarify beers, ales, wines, and champagnes of  
yeasts, proteins, and other macromolecular components used or created during the 
fermentation process (1).  Without use of clarifying agents, these alcoholic beverages 
would be cloudy rather than clear.  Because the collagen molecules are amphoteric, the 
negative charges attract and bind to yeast cells while the positive charges attract and 
bind to proteins.  Furthermore, isinglass is highly insoluble and its addition results in 
immediate clarification of the liquid.  Clarification can be achieved with a rather low level 
of addition of isinglass, typically in the range of 0.001% to 0.002% (2).  In most cases, 
the isinglass and the components that precipitate with it are removed by filtration or 
centrifugation before packaging of the beverage.  In those situations, exposure to 
isinglass in the beverage as consumed would be quite low because the majority of it is 
likely removed.  Residue levels in filtered beer have been measured in the range of 0.02 
– 0.16 parts per million (ppm) or mg/l (2).  Cask ale, a popular beverage in the U.K., is 
an exception where the precipitated mass is left in the bottom of the cask.  In this case, 
isinglass exposure can be higher for consumers of cask ale especially as the cask is 
tipped and some sludge from the bottom of the cask may be intermixed with the ale.  
The levels of residual isinglass in cask ale have not been measured and, as noted, are 
likely to be variable from glass to glass. 
 
Because it is derived from a major allergenic food source, namely fish, the allergenicity 
of isinglass to fish-allergic individuals is a question of interest.  Fish are considered to 
be one of the most commonly allergenic foods in the human diet (1).  Fish and 
ingredients derived from fish are included on lists of commonly allergenic foods in 
countries in which such lists exist including the US, EU., Canada, and Australia/New 
Zealand (1).  Isinglass is certainly an ingredient derived from fish although its 
allergenicity has not been established.  Thus, regulations in these countries and regions 
would require that isinglass be labeled on the alcoholic beverages and that its fish origin 
also be declared unless an exemption could be granted.  Some countries and regions 
including the EU and US provide for the possibility of labeling exemptions in cases 
where the lack of allergenicity of the ingredient can be established. 
 
Fish-allergic individuals are typically advised to avoid ingestion of all species of fish and 
ingredients derived from fish.  While it has been observed clinically that some fish-
allergic individuals are tolerant of certain species of fish, the basis for this tolerance has 
not been elucidated (3).  In other clinical studies, fish-allergic individuals appear to be 
sensitive to all species of fish (4,5).  The major allergen of fish has been identified as 
parvalbumin, a muscle protein (6).  Parvalbumin appears to be a pan-allergen that 
exists in the edible muscle tissue of all fish (7,8).  Parvalbumin has been described to 
 1also occur in the swim bladders of some fish species (9) but the level and allergenicity 
of this parvalbumin has not been determined.  A few reports exist of other higher 
molecular weight protein allergens from fish (7, 10).  Collagen isolated from fish muscle, 
not swim bladder, has been identified as one of these allergens (10).  However, only a 
few Japanese patients have thus far been identified with IgE reactivity to fish collagen 
(7) and its allergenicity by oral challenge has not been documented.  Furthermore, the 
comparative lack of allergenicity of another fish collagen product, fish gelatin made from 
fish skins, in fish-allergic subjects has been documented (11). 
 
Isinglass may contain residual parvalbumin although the level of parvalbumin in 
isinglass has not been determined analytically (this is another research objective that is 
being simultaneously pursued).  Despite centuries of use in wines, ales, and beers, 
allergic reactions to isinglass have not been reported in the clinical literature (1).  The 
objective of this clinical trial is to determine the potential allergenicity of commercially 
produced isinglass in fish-allergic individuals. 
 
Objective:  Determine the allergenicity of isinglass by performing double blind placebo 
controlled food challenges in fish allergic individuals. 
 
Overview:  Twenty-nine fish allergic individuals will be selected and challenged based 
on the guidelines put forth in “A consensus protocol for the determination of the 
threshold doses for allergenic foods:  how much is too much?” (12).   Oral food 
challenges will be performed according to the following protocol by clinical collaborators 
with challenge materials supplied by FARRP.  The amount of isinglass used for the 
challenges will reflect typical exposure amounts. 
 
Clinical collaborators will be required to submit protocols and receive approval for the 
use of human subjects at their specific institutions.  
 
Statistical Design:  The proposed sample size of 29 subjects is based upon the 
assumption that no subjects will react at the lowest challenge dose and assuming that if 
a subject reacts to one dose, then they will also react to higher doses.  If 29 subjects 
are challenged and a dose is identified where 0/29 subjects reacts, then there is 95% 
confidence that 90% of fish-allergic individuals will not react to this amount of isinglass 
or less.  The sample size of 29 is based upon the hypothesis that the reaction rate is 
equal to 10%. 
 
Data analysis plan 
We will attempt to set a no observed adverse effect level (NOAEL) as well as estimate 
the false positive rate and the proportion of truly sensitive individuals.  Data will be 
captured as reaction / no reaction for each dose of active challenge material. The 
placebo reaction rate will be taken into account as follows: 
 2 
Subject ID Placebo 
1 
Placebo 
2 
Placebo  
3 
Placebo

Isinglass

Isinglass 
5 mg 
Isinglass
