comment_title: Comment 180:  Brewing, Food & Beverage Industry Suppliers' Association
comment_text: Petition for Exemption of Isinglass from Allergen Labelling under Section 403(w)(1) of the FD&C Act This petition, submitted by the Brewing, Food and Beverage Industry Suppliers' Association (BFBi), seeks an exemption from the allergen labelling requirements of Section 403(w)(1) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FD&C Act) for isinglass when used as a fining/clarification agent in beer production. Isinglass is a purified collagen derived from the swim bladders of select tropical and subtropical fish species. It has been used for centuries in brewing to clarify beer, and is removed from the final product through filtration or sedimentation. The petition presents comprehensive scientific, analytical, and clinical evidence demonstrating that isinglass does not pose an allergenic risk to fish-allergic individuals. Key findings include: • Clinical trials (including double-blind placebo-controlled oral challenges) show no allergic reactions in fish-sensitive individuals, even at doses equivalent to extreme beer consumption. • Manufacturing protocols have been optimized to minimize residual parvalbumin, the primary fish allergen, in commercial isinglass products. • Analytical data confirms that residual isinglass and parvalbumin levels in beer are extremely low, often below detection limits. • International regulatory bodies (EFSA, FSANZ, Health Canada) have granted similar exemptions based on comparable evidence. • Literature reviews and updated searches found no documented cases of allergic reactions to isinglass in beer or wine. The petition concludes that isinglass-fined beer does not elicit allergic responses and supports its exemption from allergen labelling requirements, aligning with global regulatory practices and current scientific consensus.
document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
Page 1 of 26 
 
    PETITION  
This petition seeks exemption from the labelling requirements of Section 403(w)(1) of the 
Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act (the FD&C Act) for isinglass used as a 
fining/clarification aid in beer production  
 
This petition is submitted by the Brewing, Food and Beverage Industry Suppliers  
Association (BFBi)  
  
Mail address: 
 
Brewing, Food & Beverage Industry Suppliers’ Association 
11 Sidestrand 
Pendeford Business Park 
Wolverhampton 
WV9 5HD 
UK 
Tel:  +44 (0)1902 422303 
 
Contact person: 
Ruth Evans MBE,  Chief Executive Officer 
Email: ruth.evans@bfbi.org.uk 
Mobile:  +44 (0)7867 526267 
 
 
 
     
 
 
July 2025 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
  
  
  Page 2 of 26 
 
 Table of Contents 
1. Executive summary 
2. Applicant 
3. Subject of petition 
4. Manufacturing process 
5. Documented history of non-allergenicity 
6. Analytical data 
6.1. Isinglass residues in beer 
6.2. Analysis of proteins in source fish, swim bladders, commercial isinglass 
products and beer 
6.2.1. Extraction methods and SDS analysis of fish and swim bladders 
6.2.2. Residual parvalbumin in swim bladders and in isinglass 
6.2.3. Minimization of residual parvalbumin in isinglass 
6.2.4. Residual parvalbumin in commercial isinglass products 
6.2.5. Residues of parvalbumin in beer 
6.2.6. Association of parvalbumin and isinglass during fining of beer 
7. Exposure data 
8. Pre-clinical data 
8.1. Pepsin digestion 
9. Clinical (human) data 
9.1. Preparation of fish extracts 
9.2. Skin prick tests 
9.2.1. FARRP protocol 
9.2.2. Results 
9.3. Oral challenge tests – FARRP protocol 
9.4. Skin prick tests and oral challenge tests – French protocol   
10. Expert Opinion on the allergenicity of isinglass (FARRP) 
11. Conclusions 
 
 
 Page 3 of 26 
 
1. Executive Summary  
  
This petition is submitted by the Brewing, Food and Beverage Industry Suppliers  
Association (BFBi) in support of a request for exemption from the labelling requirements of 
Section 403(w)(1) of the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act (the FD&C Act) for isinglass 
when used as a fining/clarification processing aid in beer. This request is being sought on 
the grounds of: 
 
• clinical evidence (Double Blind Placebo Controlled Food Challenge) that fish sensitive     
individuals do not have allergic responses to isinglass, even when challenged with very high 
oral doses   
• the manufacturing process for isinglass minimizes allergenic potential  
• extremely low potential for dietary exposure to isinglass through beer consumption  
• long history of safe use  
• absence of published reports of allergenicity   
  
This document presents details on:    
1. composition and characterization of isinglass.  
2. development of an ELISA method for the detection of parvalbumin (the allergenic 
molecule generally associated with fish allergenicity) and it’s use in the 
quantification of parvalbumin in isinglass raw materials (‘fish maws’) and in 
commercially available, processed isinglass products. 
3. development of an ELISA method for the detection of residual isinglass in beer 
together with analytical results for levels of residual isinglass found in commercial 
beers. 
4. a ‘Code of Good Manufacturing Practice for Isinglass’ adopted by the major 
producers of isinglass and specifically designed to minimize parvalbumin levels in 
commercial isinglass products. 
5. expected level of consumer exposure to isinglass and associated parvalbumin 
6. comprehensive literature searches was conducted to identify any documented 
instances of confirmed allergenic responses related to isinglass or to beers treated 
with isinglass. 
7. results of clinical trials (skin prick tests and double blind placebo  
controlled oral challenge tests), carried out in Denmark and Switzerland and the 
associated protocols used.  
8. results of clinical trials (skin prick tests and oral challenge tests),   
carried out in France and the associated protocols used. 
 
 
The scientific studies described herein were conducted during the period 2004-2007 in 
support of a submission by BFBi and The Brewers of Europe for an exemption from Annex 
IIIa of EU Directive 2005/26/EC and thus from the requirement to label isinglass, under 
allergen labelling regulations, when used as a clarifying aid in brewing.   Page 4 of 26 
 
The petitioners note that the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) delivered their 
Opinion (adopted on 6th July 2007), concluding that ‘the Panel considers that it is not very 
likely that isinglass used as clarifying agent in beer will trigger a severe allergic reaction in 
susceptible individuals under the conditions of production and use specified’ (Appendix 
11). Isinglass was subsequently granted a permanent exemption from allergen labelling, 
this exemption being granted for both beer and wine (Appendix 11A). 
It is also noted that Food Standards Australia New Zealand (FSANZ) deliberated on a 
request by the Beer, Wine and Spirits Council of New Zealand, an application subsequently 
taken over by the Brewers Association of New Zealand, for the exemption of isinglass from 
allergen labelling requirement when used as a clarifying agent in beer and wine. FSANZ 
undertook a robust and extensive assessment of the public health and safety implications 
and concluded that since residual isinglass in beer and wine, if present, did not exceed 
1mg/liter of bottled beer or wine and since parvalbumin was demonstrated to co-sediment 
with and thus be removed by sedimentation or filtration then the consumption of isinglass-
fined beer and wine was not likely to present a risk of allergic reactions in fish-allergic 
consumers. FSANZ also deliberated on the wider aspects of such allergen labelling 
requirements, including potential impact on consumer choice, cost to industry, cost to 
Government enforcement agencies, and international trade considerations. FSANZ 
approved an exemption from the requirement to declare isinglass on the label when present 
in beer and wine as a result of its use as a clarifying agent (Appendix 12) 
It is the position of Health Canada that if an ingredient derived from Canada's priority a food 
allergen source (like a fining agent) is added to a food during its production but later is 
removed from the food, so that it is no longer present in the finished food, then that will not 
trigger the application of Canada’s allergen labelling regulations. This is the situation for 
most commercial wines even where the a  food allergen source of the derived fining agent 
is used is from food considered a priority allergen source (i.e. the priority that the allergen 
food source derived fining agent is added to the wine but later removed by effective 
filtration and is no longer present in the finished wine). The fact that the protein from the 
food allergen is not present in the finished wine means that the use of the fining agent is not 
expected to pose a risk to allergic consumers, and so allergen labelling regulations would 
not be triggered. 
With regards to the use of isinglass in beer, isinglass is derived from the dried swim 
bladders of fish and consists primarily of collagen, which is a protein.  If the isinglass is used 
as a fining agent in the beer but is then removed by filtration or some other method and the 
isinglass is no longer present in the finished beer, then no labelling would be 
required.  Health Canada have taken the view that any protein present in an ingredient 
derived from a priority food allergen source should be regarded as a potential allergen. The 
published studies, including food challenge clinical tests,  clearly indicate that collagen, the 
primary protein in isinglass, does not elicit an allergic response in fish sensitive individuals. 
It is the opinion of the petitioners that the scientific evidence and conclusions presented 
herein remain valid and, in particular, the clinical studies described remain in line with 
current best practice for assessing allergenic potential of a food substance. Page 5 of 26 
 
The petitioners are supportive of informative allergen labelling. The petitioners 
acknowledge that ‘fish’ is a common cause of allergies and that fish-derived material may 
also contain potential allergens. However, all available published evidence indicates that 
isinglass, when used as a beer fining agent, does not cause an allergic response that poses a 
risk to human health when consumed by fish sensitive individuals.  
  
Isinglass used in brewing is a pure form of collagen (greater than 92% collagen on a  
dry, ash free basis). It is derived from the swim bladders of specific physostomatous  
tropical and sub-tropical fish. In these fish, the swim bladder forms a distinct organ  
which can be readily detached as a discrete entity, and as such is unlikely to be  
contaminated with significant quantities of skeletal muscle (fish meat) or other tissue.  
The isinglass raw material (swim bladders or ‘fish maws’) are processed under defined 
conditions to produce saleable isinglass in various forms (powder, paste or liquid). The dry 
powder form is typically supplied as a blend containing microbiological stabilizer and acid 
required to solubilize the collagen molecules and produce liquid isinglass which is then 
applied in the beer or winemaking process,  
The isinglass solution used in brewing consists mainly of solubilized collagen molecules 
(mostly as dimers and trimers with molecular weights of 800-1300kDa) together with 
lesser amounts of gelatine (denatured collagen), low levels of elastin plus low levels (<5% 
concentration) of other non-collagenous material. Very low levels of material that react in a 
dose-dependent manner in ELISA assay designed to detect Gad c1 parvalbumin (presumed 
to be parvalbumin) have also been identified in isinglass. Unlike many allergens, pepsin 
digestion studies have demonstrated that isinglass is readily and completely hydrolyzed by 
pepsin.   
  
Isinglass is used as a clarifying agent in brewing. It is added at a low dosage (typically 
15mg/litre; total range 10-60mg/litre) to the beer after fermentation, where it reacts with 
yeast and proteins, forming large flocs. These flocs are removed from the bulk of the liquid 
by filtration, centrifugation or sedimentation. Residual isinglass levels in treated beers have 
been quantified using an ELISA assay developed to detect residual levels of isinglass in beer. 
Beer as presented to consumers will typically contain levels ranging from 0 – 5.0 mg/litre 
maximum. Brewery-conditioned beers (filtered beers) typically contain less residual 
isinglass than traditional unfiltered British cask beers but results indicate that no types of 
beer contain more than 5 mg/litre.  
Parvalbumin is not detectable in beer, even when isinglass is dosed at rates which are more 
than double the highest known commercial rates.  
  
Although isinglass has been used as a beer clarifying agent for centuries, extensive  
searches of the scientific and medical literature have not identified any documented  
cases of allergic reaction due to isinglass. This absence of documented evidence of  
allergic reactions to isinglass in beer suggests that such a response, if it exists at all,  
is extremely rare.   
  Page 6 of 26 
 
Results from investigation into parvalbumin levels in isinglass products confirm that  
commercial isinglass products may contain parvalbumin at extremely low levels (around 1 
μg/g on dry weight basis). The manufacturing process for isinglass includes several steps 
that are designed specifically to minimize levels of residual parvalbumin in commercial 
products.  
 
Comprehensive clinical studies on the allergenic potential of isinglass have  
been carried out. Oral challenges have demonstrated no allergic reaction in 21 fish  
sensitive individuals when challenged with isinglass at very high rates, despite skin  
prick tests having confirmed that the species of fish used in isinglass production are  
capable of inducing allergic response in some fish sensitive individuals. It should also be  
noted that since the actual residual amounts of isinglass in commercial beers are  
very low, the oral challenge doses equate to extremely high rates of beer consumption  
(greater in some instances than would be physically possible to consume).   
  
BFBi hereby request exemption from the labelling requirements of Section 403(w)(1) of the 
Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act (the FD&C Act) for isinglass used as a 
fining/clarification aid in beer production on the basis that there is no allergic response 
elicited in fish-allergic individuals consuming beers fined with isinglass, even at 
theoretically impossible levels of beer consumption. 
2. Applicant   
This application is made by the Brewing, Food and Beverage Industry Suppliers Association 
(BFBi). The BFBi, established in 1907, represents the full range of suppliers to the brewing  
and beverage industries, from raw materials through to process equipment, packaging,  
dispense and point of sale.  
 
3. Subject of Petition  
Isinglass is the usual term for piscine collagen; within the context of this petition 
"isinglass" is used exclusively to mean the collagen obtained from the dried swim  
bladders of the fish rather than from fish skins. Isinglass used in brewing (and wine) is a 
pure form of collagen derived from the dried swim bladders (known in the industry as  
“maws”) of specific tropical and subtropical fish. Only a restricted range of species  
are used; these are specific catfish, croakers and threadfins.  Swim bladders are part of the 
buoyancy mechanism of bony fish, and are distinct organs situated in the dorsal area of the 
body cavity, quite separate from the voluntary (skeletal) muscles which make up the fish 
"meat". There is little adherence between the bladder and the body cavity, thus when the 
fish are processed, these swim bladders are readily detached and removed from the body of 
the fish without extraneous tissue. Thus levels of parvalbumin (the major allergen in fish, 
which is associated with fish muscle) would be expected to be low.   
   
ELISA methods have been developed in order to measure the actual levels of parvalbumin 
in the dried fish maws and in the processed isinglass. Details are provided in Section 6 
(Analytical data).    Page 7 of 26 
 
  
Isinglass used in the brewing industry is prepared from fish maws by a defined series of 
processes. The manufacturing process includes a buffer washing stage that is particularly 
efficient at removing the low levels of parvalbumin that might be associated with the raw 
materials. The manufacturing process is described in the ‘Code of Good Manufacturing 
Practice for Isinglass’. Details are provided in Section 4 (Manufacturing process).    
  
Isinglass has been used for several centuries to clarify beer. At the end of the  
primary fermentation beer contains large quantities of yeast and suspended protein  
solids which must be removed from the beer. The contribution from yeast is typically  
in the range 100 to 400 mg/l (dry solids) equivalent to 1x106 to 4x106 cells/ml. Protein  
particles contribute a further 150 to 300 mg/l (dry solids).   
  
After fermentation the beer/yeast mixture is cooled to halt yeast growth. For brewery- 
conditioned beers, isinglass can be added to the beer at this stage. It reacts with the  
flocculating yeast and protein particles, causing them to sediment rapidly at the base  
of the storage vessel, so that the majority can be removed prior to filtration. Once the  
sedimented solids (consisting of isinglass, yeast and protein) are removed, the beer  
can then be filtered, typically through a bed of kieselguhr (diatomaceous earth). High  
speed centrifugation can replace filtration in certain treated beers. The dosage rate of  
isinglass is typically 15 mg/litre for brewery-conditioned beers.  
  
Cask-conditioned beer is a specific style of beer in the UK (sometimes referred to as  
real ale) and represents an important traditional product. In this style of beer the yeast 
remains in the cask, and promotes flavour changes that contribute to the essential character 
of the final product. Isinglass is dosed either into the beer before it is transferred to the cask 
or directly into the cask. The action of isinglass takes place generally within the first 3 to 4 
hours after cask filling so that the flocculated solids (yeast plus isinglass plus protein) 
rapidly settle to the base of the cask, forming a compact sediment. The beer is drawn from 
the cask at a point above the sediment, so that it remains bright, (i.e. no cloudiness) and free 
of suspended particles. Cloudy beer is not acceptable to the consumer in this type of  
product. (It should be noted that there are other styles of beer which are typically  
cloudy, for example, wheat beers: however, these are not fined with isinglass).  
Dosage rates for cask-conditioned beers are typically in the range 35-60 mg/litre.   
   
Since the added isinglass is removed from the treated beer by either filtration, 
centrifugation and/or sedimentation, residual levels in the beer as consumed are expected 
to be very low. Investigations into the actual residues of isinglass remaining in beer have  
been carried out, using a highly sensitive antibody-based method. These studies are 
described in Section 6 (Analytical data).   
Although not the subject of this petition, it is noted that the similarities between the 
application of isinglass in beer and wine, together with scientific studies performed to 
assess the allergenic potential of wine treated with isinglass suggests that it is not likely that 
isinglass-treated wine presents a risk to fish-sensitive wine consumers. (Appendix 12 pp54-
56)  
  
4. Manufacturing process  
  
Isinglass is sold in 3 main forms – powder, paste, and pre-dissolved ‘ready to use’  Page 8 of 26 
 
liquids. Powders are typically pre-blended with dry acid, and often include a source of  
sulfur dioxide in the form of sodium or potassium metabisulfite. Paste is a hydrated form of 
isinglass, typically 10% w/w isinglass, where the particle size has been reduced to less than 
1 mm. ‘Ready to use’ liquids are dilute acidic solutions of isinglass containing between 0.3 
and 1.0 % w/w isinglass. Sulfur dioxide is included as a preservative.  
Studies described in Section 6 (Analytical data) established that the traditional 
manufacturing process could be adapted to minimize the presence of the common fish 
allergen, parvalbumin, in isinglass.  The new manufacturing process for isinglass (Appendix 
1) was implemented by the isinglass manufacturers in 2007 and the process is outlined 
below.   
• Maws are inspected visually at intake to ensure that they are not discolored, are free 
from infestation and are of the specified fish species.   
• Maws are blended by type to meet quality, functionality, cost and supply criteria.  
• Maw size is reduced by granulation (to max 25mm) to facilitate subsequent cleaning 
and sterilization.  
• Granules are sterilized in dilute hydrogen peroxide solution 
• Granules are thoroughly washed and rinsed with chilled water 
• The sterilized granules are then soaked in a phosphate buffer solution 
• The granules are then thoroughly washed and rinsed with chilled water  
• The granules are then dried in a controlled environment with temperature not 
exceeding 400C (1040F) 
 
Note that during the wet processing stages a temperature below 150C (590F)is maintained 
and the temperature of acidified liquid ’ready to use’ isinglass is maintained below 10oC 
(500F). 
  
The analytical studies described in Section 6 indicate that low levels of parvalbumin  
can be found in fish maws prior to processing, up to a maximum of around 30 µg/g (mg/kg). 
Fish species with apparently high parvalbumin levels in the swim bladders are not used in 
isinglass production. 
Phosphate buffer, routinely used in clinical studies to extract parvalbumin from fish flesh 
(Lehrer, 1986), is included in isinglass processing to ensure parvalbumin levels are 
minimized. The levels of residual parvalbumin achievable in commercial isinglass products 
are typically below 1 µg/g (mg/kg), on a dry weight basis.  
The detailed industry-agreed Code of Good Manufacturing Practice for isinglass is included 
as Appendix 1.  
 
5. Documented History of Non-allergenicity  
  
Comprehensive literature searches in 2004 by Nerac (a specialist data retrieval company)  
and Dr Steve Taylor of Food Allergy Research & Resource Program (FARRP) at the  
University of Nebraska-Lincoln (USA)  did not identify any reports of allergic  
responses to isinglass or to fish maws (which are widely consumed as a food in their  
own right amongst Chinese ethnic populations). The searches also failed to find any  
reports of allergic responses to beer which could be attributed to the use of isinglass  Page 9 of 26 
 
(of the few reports of allergic responses to beer which were found, most were cereal- 
related ; one was related to the proteolytic enzyme papain, two were related to yeast  
and one was related to an allergy to pollen). Other reports were related to biogenic  
amines, ethanol and ethanol metabolites and sulfites.     
  
This search was repeated in 2007 by Nerac, using the same key words (beer, brewery,  
allergy, non-allergenic, anaphylactic, hypersensitivity) to identify any reports which  
might have been published since 2004. Additional search terms were also used  
(parvalbumin, isinglass).  Again no reports of allergic responses to beer or isinglass by fish 
sensitive individuals were found. The three papers that mentioned ‘isinglass’ or ‘fish maws’.  
  
• Taylor, 2004; was a review article and did not contain any reports of  
allergic responses to either isinglass or to fish maws.   
• Chlup, 2006; reported analysis of isinglass residues in  
beer. This is discussed in section 6.1 (Isinglass residues in beer).    
•Phillips, 2003; was a report for a brewing journal of the allergen  
labelling Directive 2000/13/EC.  
Full copies of these articles are included in the References section.    
 
A paper published after the 2007 search was completed, describes double  
blind placebo controlled oral challenge trials with wine clarified with protein fining  
agents (Rolland et al, 2006). The study included 10 fish-allergic patients, who were  
challenged with wine fined with isinglass and with un-fined wine as a control. No  
allergic reactions to the isinglass-fined wine were reported by any of the patients.   
An updated literature search was commissioned in 2025 to see if any new reports were 
published since 2007. The search terms used were the same as previously and the search 
was conducted by Intertek (a global consultancy firm). Across all sources, no documented 
IgE-mediated allergic reactions were attributed to isinglass in beer (or wine), even among 
fish-allergic individuals.

Based on the collective evidence from clinical studies, analytical detection methods, animal 
models, and regulatory reviews, there is no substantiated evidence that isinglass used in 
beer or wine production elicits IgE-mediated allergic reactions in fish-allergic individuals. 
Even in cases where in vitro sensitization markers (e.g., skin prick tests or basophil 
activation tests) were positive, no clinical symptoms were observed upon ingestion.  
The full search results are included as Appendix 2 and Appendix 2.A   
 
 6. Analytical data  
  
6.1 Isinglass residues in beer  
As described earlier, residues of isinglass in fined beers are low, since the majority of  
the isinglass added is either removed by centrifugation and/or filtration (for brewery-
conditioned beers) or by sedimentation (for cask-conditioned beers). Analysis of isinglass 
residues in beer is problematic, not only because of the low levels, but also because of the 
presence of other unrelated proteins. Published studies where beer has not been 
concentrated prior to analysis have failed to detect any isinglass residues (Chlup, 2006).  
  
 A method has been developed whereby residual isinglass present in isinglass treated beers 
can be concentrated by means of an antibody raised using isinglass as an antigen. The  
separated isinglass can then be hydrolyzed to its constituent acids and quantified by  
measuring the content of hydroxyproline, which is an imino acid present in significant  
quantities only in animal collagens. The limit of quantification of this method, that is  
the concentration of isinglass in beer which can be distinguished from background  
levels of hydroxyproline, is 0.17 mg of isinglass / litre of beer (on an isinglass dry  
weight basis).   
  
This method has been used to quantify the concentration of isinglass residues which  
could be present in brewery and cask-conditioned beers, and also to determine  
whether there is likely to be stratification of residues in casks, such that beer drawn  
from a position close to the bottom of the cask but still clear enough to be  
marketable, could nevertheless contain significantly higher concentrations of  
isinglass.   
  
The results indicate that isinglass residues in many bottled and canned beers fined with  
isinglass in the brewery are below the limit of quantification of the method. Where  
isinglass could be quantified, the highest concentrations found did not exceed  
1mg/litre.  
  
For large containers (kegs and casks), isinglass concentrations were only slightly  
higher. Residues in kegs were also generally below 1 mg/litre, although occasional  Page 12 of 26 
 
samples could contain up to 3 mg/litre. For cask-conditioned (unfiltered) beers, the  
highest concentration of isinglass found did not exceed 5 mg/litre.  
  
There was no evidence of stratification of residues within either casks or kegs. The  
concentration of isinglass in noticeably hazy beer (that is, beer drawn from just above  
the level of sedimented material) was marginally higher than in the bulk, but still  
below 5 mg/litre.   
The full report of this investigation is included as Appendix 3.   
 
6.2 Analysis of proteins in source fish, swim bladders, commercial isinglass  
products and beer   
  
6.2.1. Extraction methods and SDS analysis of fish and swim bladders (maws)  
 
The SDS-PAGE band patterns for extracts of fish used as isinglass sources were  
similar to those of other fish, including cod, and all samples showed a clear band at  
12 kDa which is characteristic of parvalbumin. Extracts of swim bladders (maws) did  
not display this characteristic band. However, the presence of parvalbumin could not  
be completely ruled out on the basis of SDS electrophoresis.  
Western Blotting was also carried out on extracts of fish flesh and swim bladders  
(maws) in order to try and confirm the presence or absence of parvalbumin.  
Parvalbumin could be detected in all samples of fish flesh. However, with the swim  
bladders, traces of parvalbumin could be detected in only one sample.   
  
Full details of the experimental methods and results are given in Appendix 4.  
  
  
6.2.2 Residual parvalbumin in swim bladders and in isinglass  
 
 The principal components of isinglass are collagen and elastin, together with  
degradation products of collagen, such as gelatine, which are not major fish  
allergens. Less than 5% of isinglass is non-collagenous material (Hickman et al,  
2000) (Leach and Barrett, 1967a) (Moir et al, 1984).  There is little adherence  
between the bladder and the body cavity, thus when the fish are processed, these  
swim bladders are readily detached and removed from the body of the fish without  
extraneous tissue. Thus isinglass would not be expected to contain substantial  
amounts of parvalbumin and no definitive values have been reported in the  
literature. ELISA tests for fish parvalbumins (carp and cod) have therefore been  
developed in order to measure parvalbumin in swim bladders and in commercial samples of  
isinglass and beer.  
  Page 13 of 26 
 
As a preliminary, an investigation into the homology of fish parvalbumins was carried  
out by Food Allergy Research & Resource Program (FARRP).  This showed a high degree of 
sequence identity, indicating a high likelihood of IgE cross–reactivity. A full report of the 
homology search is given in Appendix 5.   
  
A restricted number of fish species are used in isinglass manufacture, and  
commercial products are generally made from a blend of species, chosen to provide  
the technological qualities required by the brewer. Preliminary studies on these  
source materials were carried out using an inhibition ELISA test based on carp  
parvalbumin, since the cod parvalbumin ELISA was not yet available. Details of the  
carp ELISA are given in Appendix 6. These tests indicated that low levels of  
parvalbumin could be detected in a range of swim bladders, the starting raw materials for 
isinglass (see Table 1).   
  
These studies also suggested that swim bladders from certain species contained  
more parvalbumin than others. Accordingly it was decided that those species with  
higher levels of parvalbumin which were not otherwise essential in commercial blends  
for functional reasons would no longer be used, and a common list of 6 species was agreed 
by the manufacturers. This species list was incorporated into the Code of Good 
Manufacturing Practice described in Section 4.

6.2.3 Minimization of residual parvalbumin in isinglass  
 
Washing with phosphate buffer is a well-recognized technique for extracting  
parvalbumin from fish flesh, and is widely utilized in research studies (Lehrer, 1986).  
Trials were therefore initiated to determine whether phosphate buffer could be used  
to further reduce residual parvalbumin in isinglass products.   
  
Powdered isinglass, prepared using a typical commercial blend of fish species, was  
tested for parvalbumin using the carp ELISA before and after washing with water and  
with phosphate buffer, on the laboratory scale. The results (shown in Table 2)  
indicate that phosphate buffer washing could significantly reduce residual  
parvalbumin. An alternative approach, washing with calcium solutions, had no effect.

phosphate buffer could indeed reduce residual parvalbumin on the commercial scale. 
Although not all samples showed a significant reduction, the greatest effects were with 
those samples containing the highest initial parvalbumin. Since commercial isinglass 
products are made from blends of swim bladders from different sources, it appeared likely 
that phosphate buffer washing, if incorporated into the manufacturing process, could 
significantly reduce the range of residual parvalbumin in commercial products.

Following these promising preliminary results, trials were undertaken to optimize the 
washing protocols in order to achieve maximum parvalbumin removal.    
The extent of parvalbumin reduction throughout the manufacturing process was  
then checked again using a sandwich ELISA test based on cod parvalbumin, which had been 
specifically developed for this project (see Appendix 4). The starting material was isinglass 
powder from a typical commercial blend, using the six agreed species. The results (shown in 
Table 4) confirmed that residual parvalbumin can be significantly reduced to around 0.4 
µg/g on an isinglass dry weight basis, a reduction of approximately 4-fold over the original 
level in the raw material.  
  
This processing protocol has subsequently been implemented as a ‘Code of Good 
Manufacturing Practice’ by the major isinglass manufacturers, as described in Section 4.

6.2.5 Residues of parvalbumin in beer  
 
The overwhelming majority of the isinglass added to beer for clarification is removed, 
either by centrifugation and/or filtration (for brewery-conditioned beers) or by 
sedimentation (for cask-conditioned beers).   
  
Using the analytical method described in Section 6.1 whereby any isinglass present is 
concentrated, it has been demonstrated that residues of isinglass in brewery-conditioned 
bottled and canned beers were largely below 0.17 mg/litre (the limit of quantification of the 
method), with the highest concentrations found not exceeding 1mg/litre. For brewery 
conditioned beers in keg, residues did not exceed 3 mg/litre. For cask-conditioned beers, 
the highest concentration of isinglass found did not exceed 5 mg/litre.  
  
The analyses described in Section 6.2.4, Tables 4 & 6, indicated that residual parvalbumin  
levels in commercial isinglass products produced using the new protocol described in 
Section 4 would be expected to be less than 1 µg/g. If it is assumed that the parvalbumin in 
isinglass remains associated with it during the fining process, the theoretical maximum for 
residues of parvalbumin remaining in fined beer would be in the range <0.001 – 0.005 
µg/litre. This is illustrated in Table 7.   
  
The measurement uncertainty of the cod ELISA is relatively high. If this is taken into  
account (i.e. measured value + 3 x Standard Deviation), the concentration of  
parvalbumin in isinglass manufactured using the new production protocol could be  
4 µg/g. This would give a theoretical concentration of parvalbumin of 0.02 µg/litre for  
a “worst case” (i.e. a cask beer with the highest level of isinglass residues detected) .   Page 18 of 26 
 
 These levels of parvalbumin are extremely low and well below the limit of  
determination of the analytical method.

6.2.6 Association of parvalbumin and isinglass during fining of beer  
 
One scenario which needs to be considered is the possibility that parvalbumin (which  
is  known to be soluble in water and dilute salt solutions at neutral and alkaline pH’s)  
could be extracted from isinglass into the bulk of the beer during the fining process,  
rather than partitioning with the isinglass and thus being removed  with it. In this case  
parvalbumin residues in beer could potentially be higher. Chemistry theory suggests that 
this is unlikely, since parvalbumin is not very soluble in acid conditions. The isoelectric 
point (which is the pH at which it is least soluble) of the main isoform of fish parvalbumin is 
generally considered to be around 4.7 (Bugajska-Schretter et al, 2000), with other isoforms 
being around 4.4 (Swoboda et al, 2002). Studies of three species of catfish (although not the 
same species as used for commercial isinglass) found isoelectric points of most isoforms to 
be in the range 4.5 – 4.8 (Focant, et al, 1999).  Beer pH is typically in the range 4.0 – 4.4.  
 
  
The behavior of parvalbumin during the fining process was investigated on a commercial 
scale, using a 2127 hl beer tank.  Isinglass finings (7.7 kg), prepared using historical 
manufacturing protocol, were added, equivalent to a typical commercial finings dose of 36 
mg/litre. Assuming a typical parvalbumin content of 10 µg/g, this would be approximately 
0.36 μg parvalbumin/litre of beer. The sedimented material, which contains isinglass and 
beer proteins, was collected and tested for parvalbumin. The concentration of parvalbumin 
in the sediment (carp equivalents) was found to be 120 μg/litre, suggesting that 
parvalbumin was significantly concentrated in the beer sediment (which is not consumed) 
rather than partitioning into the bulk of the beer (see Appendix 6A).    
   
 Page 19 of 26 
 
Further experiments were conducted using the cod ELISA in order to determine  
whether detectable parvalbumin remained in the beer. A lager and a cask ale were  
fined using isinglass at typical commercial dose rates (10 mg/litre and 40 mg/litre  
respectively), using an isinglass preparation made using the new manufacturing protocol 
with the same blend of fish species, in the same ratios, as the blend used for the clinical 
tests. The clear beer was freeze dried, which achieved a concentration of approximately 22-
fold, and the freeze-dried powder tested for parvalbumin using the cod ELISA. The limit of  
detection achieved by this procedure was equivalent to approximately 9 µg/litre  
parvalbumin in beer. No parvalbumin could be detected in either of the two beers.  
  
 A third beer was dosed with commercial isinglass powder 2 from Manufacturer 1  
(see Table 5), which contained a relatively high concentration of parvalbumin  
(7.32 µg/g as detected with the cod ELISA). The dose rate of isinglass in this  
case was 156 mg/litre, which is 3-4 times the dose rate typically used for beer and  
double the highest dose rate likely to be used commercially. The clear beer was  
freeze dried as before, and the freeze-dried powder analyzed for parvalbumin using the  
cod ELISA.  As before, no parvalbumin could be detected in the beer. Theoretical  
calculation suggested that even this high isinglass dose rate would deliver a  
concentration of parvalbumin of not more than 1.14 µg/litre, still below the limit of  
detection of the method.   
(Original data, Appendix. 7, Table 1).   
   
A further attempt to determine whether parvalbumin could be detected in  
commercially fined beer was carried out using the carp ELISA, which appeared to be  
slightly more sensitive than the cod-based test.   
  
• Two control samples consisted of two commercial brands of beer which had  
not been fined with isinglass.   
• Three trials, consisting of beer which was fined on a commercial scale using  
typical dose rates of commercial isinglass pastes   
  
The control and test beers were concentrated by freeze drying in order to achieve a  
parvalbumin level closer to the lower limit of detection, then analysed for parvalbumin at 
FARRP using the carp ELISA.   The results indicated that the range of “parvalbumin” 
detected in the test beers, after correction for concentration, was similar to, or indeed lower 
than, that in the control. Since the control beer contained no animal products whatsoever, 
this apparent “parvalbumin” must be due to non-specific binding to other components of 
the beer. Such non-specific binding is known to occur with ELISA-based tests and would in 
this case be exacerbated by the concentration of the sample. The conclusion is therefore  
that the beers fined with isinglass contained no detectable parvalbumin (Appendix 6A, 
Part 2)   
 
 Page 20 of 26 
 
7. Exposure data  
  
The studies referred to in Section 6 indicate that if present at all, levels of parvalbumin in  
beers are below the limit of detection, that is, less than 9 µg/litre. Residual parvalbumin 
residues in isinglass manufactured according to the old protocol are typically 10μg/g (dry 
weight basis). The new manufacturing protocol reduces potential parvalbumin residues to 
below 1µ/g (dry weight basis).    
  
Since parvalbumin residues in beer (if present) are too low to measure, potential  
residues have been calculated on a theoretical basis. The assumptions used are:  
  
• The dose rate of isinglass during fining is 50 mg/litre. This is around the highest  
dose rate which would be used commercially for cask beers, and is 2-3 times  
higher than the rate used for most brewery-conditioned beers.  
• Residual parvalbumin level in isinglass products manufactured using the old protocol is  
10μg/g (dry weight basis) cod equivalents.  
• Residual parvalbumin in commercial products manufactured using the new production 
protocol is 1 µg/ (dry weight basis).  
• Parvalbumin co-sediments with isinglass and does not partition into the bulk of  
the beer.  
  
Table 8 shows the maximum potential exposure to parvalbumin which would be 
experienced by a person drinking at a moderate rate (1.5 liters of beer in 2 hours) and a 
heavy drinker (3 liters in 2 hours). It can be seen that the greatest exposure, that is, for a 
heavy drinker consuming beer fined with isinglass manufactured as per the old protocol, 
would be around 0.15 µg parvalbumin in 2 hours. This exposure falls to around 0.015 µg 
when isinglass manufactured using the new manufacturing Code of Practice is used.

8. Pre-clinical data  
  
8.1 Pepsin digestion  
It is recognized that allergenic proteins are frequently resistant to digestion in the gut,  
thus digestibility by pepsin is often used as a parameter for assessing potential  
allergens. The major fish allergen Gad c 1 is comparatively resistant to pepsin  
digestion (Bindslev-Jensen et al., 2003).  
  
Isinglass was analyzed for digestibility by pepsin, using a similar approach to that  
widely used for assessing the digestibility of several allergens and proteins  
considered to be non-allergenic (Thomas et al., 2004). Digestibility of peanut  
allergens was used as a reference. It was found that isinglass was digested  
significantly faster than peanut allergens both at pH 1.2 and pH 2.0. No high  
molecular weight material remained after 2 minutes incubation with pepsin at pH 1.2,  
or 5 minutes at pH 2.0. All low and intermediate molecular weight material was fully  
digested at the end of the 60 minute incubation.  Full details of the experimental  
procedure and results are given in Appendix 8.    
  
  
9. Clinical (human) data  
  
9.1 Preparation of fish extract for clinical studies  
The preparation of extracts of fish suitable for use in clinical studies was based on  
findings from the protein analyses described in Appendix 4. The extracts were  Page 22 of 26 
 
checked for any microbiological contamination as described in Appendix 9.A.  
  
 
9.2. Skin prick tests  
  
9.2.1 Protocols  
FARRP have developed protocols for skin prick testing of fish allergic individuals,  
using extracts of fish flesh and swim bladders from a range of species used as  
source fish for commercial isinglass manufacture. Samples of blood are also taken  
from the individuals and tested for IgE antibodies to fish. The detailed protocols are  
given in Appendix 9.B.  Studies have been carried out at Odense University Hospital in 
Denmark, under the direction of Dr. Carsten Bindslev-Jensen, and at the University of Zurich 
in Switzerland, under the direction of Dr Barbara Ballmer-Weber. 
  
9.2.2 Results  
Studies of 8 patients in Denmark were completed. All 8 of the patients reacted to the fish 
flesh, and 7 out of 8 reacted to the swim bladder extracts, suggesting that fish allergic 
patients in Western Europe would be likely to react to the fish species from which isinglass 
is obtained. Detailed results are given in Appendix 9.D.  
  
9.3 Oral challenge tests – FARRP protocol  
FARRP developed standard protocols for double blind placebo controlled  
(DBPCFC) oral challenge tests, using a commercial sample isinglass (manufactured 
according to the new protocol) as the challenge material. The detailed protocols are given in 
Appendix 9.C. Isinglass at four dose rates (0.5, 5, 15 and 30 mg) was administered over a 
total period of 2 hours.  Table 9 shows the amount of beer which these doses of isinglass are 
equivalent to. It is apparent that the cumulative dose over 2 hours substantially  
exceeds the equivalent volume (50.5 liters) of beer which it is physically possible to drink in 
that period of time.    
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Page 23 of 26 
 
Table 9. Isinglass dose rates in terms of volume of beer  
  
Isinglass dose 0.5mg 5mg 15mg 30mg 50.5mg 
(cumulative dose in 
2 hours) 
Equivalent volume of 
beer at typical 
brewery conditioned 
beer (isinglass 
residues <1mg/liter) 
500ml 5liters 15liters 30liters 50.5liters 
Equivalent volume of 
cask conditioned beer 
(isinglass residues 
<5mg/liter 
100ml 1liter 3liters 6liters 10.1liters 
 
The isinglass used for the oral challenges was prepared using the new manufacturing 
protocols. The parvalbumin content as determined by the two ELISA tests was 1.0 µg/g 
(carp parvalbumin equivalents) and 0.695 +/-0.30 µg/g (cod parvalbumin equivalents).    
  
Oral challenge studies of 15 fish allergic patients were carried out at the same  
centers as, and in conjunction with, the skin prick tests, namely, Odense University  
Hospital in Denmark, under the direction of Dr. Carsten Bindslev-Jensen, and at the  
University of Zurich in Switzerland, under the direction of Dr Barbara Ballmer-Weber.  
Details of these studies are reported in Appendix 9.D.   
 
None of the patients reacted to the oral challenges with isinglass, even at the very highest 
doses administered.   
  
 9.4 Skin prick tests and oral challenge tests, French protocol  
 
Double Blind Placebo Controlled Food challenge trials were also carried out by  
Dr Fabienne Rancé at the Hôpital des Enfants, Allergy and Pneumology, Toulouse,  
in France, using slightly different protocols. These are shown in Appendix 9.E. The  
oral challenge consisted of a cumulative dose of 20 mg of isinglass, in three doses of 2, 6 and 
12 mg isinglass, at 30 minute intervals over a period of 2 hours. In this case the total dose of 
isinglass was equivalent to at least 4 liters of beer fined at the maximum commercial rate, or 
20 liters of typical brewery conditioned beer. It should be noted however, that these trials 
were initiated before it was known that isinglass could contain parvalbumin, thus the 
isinglass used in the challenge contained more parvalbumin (a typical level would be up to 
10 µg/g) than that used in the FARRP protocols.   Page 24 of 26 
 
  
Tests of six patients with fish allergies were completed using these protocols.  
Skin prick tests with positive and negative controls to confirm allergenicity to fish,  
were carried out first. Two out of the six showed positive reactions to the skin prick  
tests, but there were no positive reactions to the oral challenge tests. (See Appendix  
9.F).   
  
  
11. Expert Opinion on the allergenicity of isinglass (FARRP)  
  
Experts at FARRP (the Food Allergy Research and Resource Programme at the  
University of Nebraska, USA) were asked to give an expert opinion on the  
allergenicity of isinglass. This Opinion is included as Appendix 10.  
  
In the view of FARRP, ingestion of isinglass does not present a risk to fish allergic 
individuals. FARRP consider that the very high doses of isinglass used, together with the 
complete lack of allergic reactions, adequately compensate for the fact that the original 
target of 29 patients was not achieved (see Appendix 9D).  
  
Since the oral challenges were carried out with significant quantities of isinglass itself,  
and the amount of isinglass remaining in fined beer is extremely small, it follows that  
drinking beer fined with isinglass is even less likely to present any hazard to fish-allergic 
individuals.  
  
12. Conclusions  
  
Using the analytical methods described in this report, low but variable amounts  
of parvalbumin are shown to be associated with commercial isinglass. These levels can be 
substantially reduced by limiting the species of source fish used and by simple 
modifications to the isinglass manufacturing process. Both of these changes have been 
incorporated into a Code of Good Manufacturing Practice, implemented by isinglass 
producers since 2007.  
  
Despite the possible presence of very low levels of parvalbumin in commercial isinglass 
products, the potential for parvalbumin to remain in beer is extremely low. The actual 
potential amounts of parvalbumin added to beer during fining (and also to wine, the other 
beverage where isinglass is commonly used as a fining agent) are extremely small. Both 
chemical theory and the experimental evidence available suggest that parvalbumin co-
sediments with isinglass and is largely removed from the bulk of the beer. No parvalbumin 
can be detected in beer, even when the isinglass dose levels are substantially higher than 
typical commercial rates. Theoretical calculations indicate that even in a worst case Page 25 of 26 
 
scenario the amount of parvalbumin which could be consumed in a few hours even by a 
heavy drinker of beer is in the order of 0.1-0.2 µg.  
Repeated literature searches confirm that there have been no published reports of  
allergic reactions which could be attributed to isinglass or parvalbumin in beer. An oral 
challenge trial reported in the literature, using wine fined with isinglass, also showed  
no allergic responses amongst fish-allergic subjects.   
Clinical trials were carried out in order to define the allergenic status of isinglass. These 
trials included both skin prick tests, using extracts of fish flesh and swim bladders, and oral 
challenge tests, using isinglass administered at high rates. 
The doses of isinglass administered are equivalent to extremely high rates of beer 
consumption. In total twenty-one patients were tested (15 using the FARRP protocol and 6 
using the Rancé protocols). No subjects displayed any objective allergic responses on 
ingestion of very high levels of isinglass.   
In conclusion, the scientific and clinical evidence available indicates that drinking  
beer fined with isinglass does not elicit allergic reactions in fish sensitive individuals.   
It also seems highly likely that the use of isinglass in wine production, which uses the same 
isinglass products as used in beer, with wine being similarly clarified by filtration, is also 
not very likely to pose a risk of allergic reaction in susceptible individuals 
 
References

comment_title: Comment 178:  Fédération des Exportateurs de Vins & Spiritueux de France (FEVS)
comment_text: Please, find enclosed comments on behalf on the Fédération des Exportateurs de Vins & Spiritueux de France (FEVS)
document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
10, Rue Pergolèse – 75116 PARIS – Tel +33 1 45 22 75 73 – contact@fevs.com  
 
 
 
 
August 11
th, 2025 
 
 
Comments filed on behalf of FEVS (Fédération des Exportateurs de Vins et Spiritueux de France) 
 
Filed via www.regulations.gov 
 
 
Re: TTB‐2025‐0003: Major Food Allergen Labelling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages 
 
 
The French Federation of Wine and Spirits Exporters (FEVS), appreciates the opportunity to submit comments 
on Notice No. 238 relative to Major Food Allergen Labelling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages. 
 
FEVS is the trade association representing the wine and spirit exporting companies of France. FEVS's 
membership comprises around 600 companies, international corporations as well as small businesses, with 
exports around 15.6 billion Euros in 2024 ($ 16.2 billion). The United States is the largest market in value for 
French wine and spirits exports worldwide (€3.8 billion / $3.9 billion). 
 
FEVS and its members are committed to providing wines and spirits in all price ranges to the American 
consumers, while ensuring that consumers are provided with adequate information as to the identity and 
quality of the wines and spirits they purchase. 
 
Therefore, FEVS is pleased to provide the following comments on the TTB’s proposed rulemaking. 
 
 
On allergen labelling for distilled spirits 
 
FEVS warmly welcomes the proposed approach taken by TTB not to require allergen labelling for distilled 
spirits. This rightly acknowledges the fact that no protein, allergenic or otherwise, remains in a product which 
has been going through a distillation process. It also ensures coherence with the approach already adopted 
by TTB regarding the gluten-free labelling of distilled products. 
 
 
On processing aids and fining agents 
 
FEVS appreciates the possibility for isinglass and fish gelatin, which could be used as fining agents in the 
wine production process, to only label “fish” as the name of the allergen, without being required to indicate 
the fish species used to make the product. 
 
Nevertheless, FEVS would like to share concerns about the proposal made by TTB to require the disclosure 
of processing aids derived from major food allergens on label . As rightly pointed out in the Notice,  this 
proposal should negatively impact wine products since albumen, isinglass or casein are usually used as fining 
and/or clarifying agents for wines. 
 
2 
All of the nine substances considered as “major food allergen” under TTB proposed Notice (with the 
exception of soybean which  is subject to lesser standards ) are part of a list of food or ingredients which, 
according to Codex Alimentarius 1, “shall always be declared as allergenic food using the specified name in 
addition to or as part of the ingredient name when intentionally present in the food” (bold added). 
 
This has to be read in conjunction with the Codex definition of a processing aid
2 which is “ a substance or 
material, not including apparatus or utensils, and not consumed as a food ingredient by itself, intentionally 
used in the processing of raw materials, foods or its ingredients, to fulfil a certain technological purpose during 
treatment or processing and which may result in the non‐intentional but unavoidable presence of residues 
or derivatives in the final product” (bold added). 
 
In addition, most of the operators using fining or clarifying agents  proceed to filtration of their wine before 
bottling to ensure the limpidity of the product as well as the complete removal of any allergenic substance, 
in line with good manufacturing practices. 
 
While acknowledging the necessity to rightly inform consumers on the presence of all allergens derived from 
major food allergens in the final product, FEVS kindly requests TTB not to require the labelling of processing 
aid when producers have followed good manufacturing practices and/or international standards relating to 
the management of allergen in the food production process, such as the Codex Alimentarius Code of practice 
on food allergen management for food business operators (see here) or the OIV Code of good fining practices 
for wine to be applied in the use of proteinaceous wine fining agents with allergenic potential (casein and egg 
white) (see here). 
 
Adopting a diverging approach from international standards could lead to the creation of access market 
barriers, not only for foreign operators willing to export their products to the US but also for US producers 
exporting their wines to foreign markets. For instance, according to EU harmonized rules, all food products, 
including alcoholic beverages, put on the EU market have to indicate  “any ingredient or processing aid (…) 
used in the manufacture or preparation of a food and still present in the finished product, even if in an altered 
form”
3 (bold added). 
 
 
On the wording of the labeling statement and other mandatory disclosures 
 
FEVS encourages TTB to require the use of the terms “ Contains” (followed by a colon and the name of the 
food source from which each major food allergen is derived) rather than “Contains Major Food Allergens”. 
 
As long as only some allergens would fall under a compulsory requirement of disclosure for alcoholic 
beverages, FEVS does not consider such indication would be confusing or misleading for US consumers. 
 
On the contrary, adopting the terms “ Contains” would increase the legibility  and understandability of the 
alcoholic beverages label for US consumers by using  the same terms as those already required  for other 
health-sensitive ingredients (FD&C Yellow No.5, carmine…) when used in spirits or wine products , including 
allergen like sulfites which is present and labelled in the overwhelming majority of wines sold on the US 
market. 
 
This approach would also build on consumers’ habits and purchasing behaviors by ensuring consistency with: 
- current commercial practices used by alcoholic beverages operators who voluntarily label major food 
allergens according to the 2006 TTB Interim rules, 
- alcoholic beverages regulated under FDA and FALCPA rules, 
- other food products sold on the US market. 
 
1 See Point 4.2.1.4 of the General Standard for the labelling of pre -packaged foods CXS 1 -1985: “4.2.1.4 The following foods and 
ingredients are known to trigger food allergy or coeliac disease and shall always be declared as allergenic foods using the specified 
name in addition to or as part of the ingredient name when intentionally present in the food:” 
2 See Point 2 « Deﬁnitions » of the General Standard for the labelling of pre-packaged foods CXS 1-1985 
3 See article 9.1 (c) of Regulation (EU) No 1169/2011 on the provision of food information to consumers 3 
In addition, requiring the use of the terms “ Contains” will guarantee the alignment of US rules for alcoholic 
beverages with international standards applying to all food products, as agreed in the 2024 revised Codex 
Alimentarius General Standard for the labelling of pre-packaged foods4. 
 
This would be of great importance, for economic operators as well as US consumers, considering the growing 
number of countries across the world which require to label either the full list of ingredients (as it is the case 
in the EU for wine products) or, at least, allergens on alcoholic beverages packaging  (as it is the case in the 
EU for all alcoholic beverages). 
 
For the same reason, and in line with our preference for using the terms “Contains”, FEVS would welcome 
the possibility for operators to choose how to label major food allergen s on their packaging either by a 
specific “Contains” statement or by their inclusion within a list of ingredients . This will allow operators to 
rightly inform consumers without having to change their packaging whatever the TTB will ultimately decide 
regarding ingredient listing for alcoholic beverages (see Notice of proposed rulemaking No. 237 ), but also 
when providing the list of ingredients on a voluntary basis according to US currently applying rules. 
 
It's also the reason why FEVS requests TTB not to mandate specific placement, type size or presentation 
requirements for the indication of major food allergens beyond what it is already required for the sulfites 
statement. This should include the possibility for operators either to make two separate statements (one for 
the food major allergen, the other one for sulfites) or to gather all of them  in one single statement, as long 
as legibility requirements are fulfilled.  
 
All the above elements will also enable operators to manage the limited space available on label to include 
such requirements, while ensuring clear, not misleading and accurate information to US consumers. 
 
 
On the effective date and compliance with the proposed regulations 
 
FEVS welcomes the proposed 5-year transition period as well as the exemption from requiring new COLA 
when the only change being made to a label is the inclusion of a statement of major food allergens. 
 
In addition, FEVS kindly requests an unlimited inventory exhaustion clause which would allow operators to 
put on the US market products labelled in accordance with the current rules but before the entry into force 
of any compulsory labelling requirement of major food allergens. 
 
Last but not least, if TTB decides to adopt a final rule on Alcohol Fact Statements for alcoholic beverage (as 
envisaged in Notice of proposed rulemaking No. 237), FEVS ask s for an identical date of entry into force 
for both regulations. This will prevent operators changing their label twice, with the disproportionate cost 
this approach could have for them, especially considering the overwhelming majority of SMEs in the sector. 
 
 
4 See Point  8.3.2.1 of the General Standard for the labelling of pre- packaged foods CXS 1 -1985: “ 8.3.2.1 If used, the separate 
statement shall commence with the word ‘contains’ (or equivalent word) and be placed directly under or in close proximity to the 
list of ingredients when present”

comment_text: I support the proposal to require disclosure of major food allergens on wines, distilled spirits, and malt beverage labels. Consumers deserve clear and consistent information about ingredients that may pose health risks to potential buyers. This rule aligns alcohol labeling with existing food allergen standards and promotes transparency and safety for individuals with allergies. The proposed compliance timeline of five years is reasonable yet still gives producers time to adjust. I appreciate the attention to this matter and think it is relevant to many consumers nationwide.
document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text: I support the proposal to require disclosure of major food allergens on wines, distilled spirits, and malt beverage labels. Consumers deserve clear and consistent information about ingredients that may pose health risks to potential buyers. This rule aligns alcohol labeling with existing food allergen standards and promotes transparency and safety for individuals with allergies. The proposed compliance timeline of five years is reasonable yet still gives producers time to adjust. I appreciate the attention to this matter and think it is relevant to many consumers nationwide.

comment_text: My name is Heidi Baxley, I am a licensed Substance Use Prevention Specialist and Chair of the Utah Prevention Coalition Association. Roughly 11% of U.S. adults have food allergies. Many alcoholic beverages contain major allergens, such as wheat in many beers, milk and nuts in liqueurs, and even fish and eggs used as processing aids in wine. But consumers with food allergies have no way of knowing if they can safely consume alcoholic beverages because neither ingredient lists, nor major allergen labeling is required. Nearly all foods and beverages we consume are required to have basic labeling of ingredients and allergens. Alcohol shouldn't be exempt. TTB should make clear in the final rule that this information should never be provided solely via QR code, as this would specifically disadvantage populations that are less able to utilize smart phones or similar technology (e.g., those who are older, lower income, or living rurally or on tribal land) Consumers need this information as soon as possible! In the final rule, TTB should shorten the compliance period from 5 years to 3.5 years to prevent further delay of consumer access to this basic safety information. Thank you for your time. Heidi Baxley

My name is Heidi Baxley, I am a licensed Substance Use Prevention Specialist and Chair of the Utah Prevention Coalition Association. Roughly 11% of U.S. adults have food allergies. Many alcoholic beverages contain major allergens, such as wheat in many beers, milk and nuts in liqueurs, and even fish and eggs used as processing aids in wine. But consumers with food allergies have no way of knowing if they can safely consume alcoholic beverages because neither ingredient lists, nor major allergen labeling is required. Nearly all foods and beverages we consume are required to have basic labeling of ingredients and allergens. Alcohol shouldn’t be exempt.
TTB should make clear in the final rule that this information should never be provided solely via QR code, as this would specifically disadvantage populations that are less able to utilize smart phones or similar technology (e.g., those who are older, lower income, or living rurally or on tribal land) Consumers need this information as soon as possible! In the final rule, TTB should shorten the compliance period from 5 years to 3.5 years to prevent further delay of consumer access to this basic safety information.
Thank you for your time.
Heidi Baxley

comment_text: My name is Terrence Spain, and I am a public health professional and a parent. Many alcoholic beverages contain major allergens, such as wheat in many beers, milk and nuts in liqueurs, and even fish and eggs used as processing aids in wine. The rule could be strengthened by specifying where the allergen disclosure should appear, outlining specific formatting requirements, and requiring species specific disclosure for the labeling of finish. TTB should make clear in the final rule that this information should never be provided solely via QR code, as this would specifically disadvantage populations that are less able to utilize smart phones or similar technology (e.g., those who are older, lower income, or living rurally or on tribal land). Please take this suggestion into consideration.

comment_text: These comments are submitted on behalf of the European Commission, DG Internal Market, Industry, Entrepreneurship and SMEs (GROW) International Value Chains – A3
document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
COMMENTS FROM THE EUROPEAN UNION REGARDING NOTIFICATION  
G/TBT/N/USA/2183 and G/TBT/N/USA/2182 
Allergen and Nutrition Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt 
Beverages 
 
The European Union (EU) would like to thank the authorities of the United States 
of America for providing the opportunity to comment on the draft “ Major Food 
Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages ”, notified on 22 
January 2025 as G/TBT/N/USA/2183.  
The mandatory labelling of ‘Major Food Allergen’ referred to in the US proposed 
rulemaking includes fish ingredients. The listing of ‘fish’ would also be required 
when the processing aid isinglass or fish gelatine is used as a fining agent to clarify 
wines and beers. 
At a global level, in a report  (1) published last year, the FAO/WHO estimated the 
exposure details including gelatine and isinglass in wine and beer. The Expert 
Committee concluded that for the curren tly accepted exemptions (i.e. in the 
European Union , Australia, New Zealand, Argentina, Paraguay) there is an 
established history of safe consumption and that the exposure estimates at the 
reference dose - RfD/30 - level appears to provide an adequate marg in of 
exposure for derivative safety assessment. 
The EU invites the United States to consider the possible exclusion of isinglass or 
fish gelatine as a processing aid in wine and beer from mandatory allergen 
labelling. 
As regards the “ Alcohol Facts Stateme nts in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled 
Spirits, and Malt Beverages” notified on 22 January 2025 as G/TBT/N/USA/2182, 
the EU invites the United States of America to take into account Codex Guidelines 
on the use of technology to provide food information in food labelling  (CXG 105-
2024) and to consider whether some or all of the mandatory information particulars 
included in the “Alcohol Facts” could be provided to consumers using technology  
such as QR codes instead of on-pack labelling. The EU would furthermore like to 
highlight that none of the Codex standards or guidelines requires the mandatory 
indication of the quantity of pure ethyl alcohol on alcoholic beverages and that, 
contrary to the alcohol content by volume, this information is nearly never indicated 
on traded alcoholic beverages. 
Finally, concerning the proposed transition period, the EU welcomes the proposed 
5-years. In a similar vein, the EU requests that the United States grants the 
operators a possibility to exhaust all their stock which was put on the market before 
the proposed rule comes into effect. 
 
(1) FAO/WHO Report – Risk Assessment of Food Allergens; 
https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789240088924  
2 
 
The EU would be grateful if the above -mentioned comments could be taken into 
account and replied to before adoption of the notified draft. 
*** 
 
 
 
  
Electronically signed on 07/08/2025 11:43 (UTC+02) in accordance with Article 11 of Commission Decision (EU) 2021/2121

comment_text: Dear TTB, As a public health advocate, I appreciate the opportunity to comment on Notice No. 238. I strongly support TTB's efforts to modernize and improve the transparency of malt beverage labeling. Accurate, standardized, and easily accessible labeling is critical for informing consumer decisions and reducing alcohol-related harms. However, I am concerned that the proposed reliance on QR codes as a means of conveying essential product information—such as ingredients, nutritional content, and allergens—is inadequate from a public health standpoint. Key Public Health Concerns with the QR Code Approach: 1. Limited Access and Equity: Not all consumers have smartphones, reliable internet access, or the technological literacy to use QR codes. This disproportionately affects older adults, lower-income populations, and rural communities, creating inequitable access to vital health information. 2. Reduced Transparency at Point of Purchase: Important health information should be immediately visible to consumers when they are making purchasing decisions. Relegating this data to a QR code discourages real-time engagement and undermines informed choice. 3. Inconsistent Use by Industry: Without mandatory formatting and content requirements, the use of QR codes could become inconsistent across brands, further confusing consumers and limiting usefulness. 4. Consumer Expectation of On-Label Information: Unlike most other packaged food and beverages, alcohol products are still not required to provide basic nutritional or ingredient data directly on the label. Continuing this practice via QR codes perpetuates a harmful double standard. Recommendations: To align alcohol labeling with broader public health goals, I respectfully urge the TTB to: • Require on-label disclosure of key information: alcohol by volume (ABV), ingredient lists, common allergens, calories per serving, and nutritional information. • Limit the use of QR codes to supplemental information only, not as a substitute for on-label transparency. • Establish mandatory labeling standards across the alcohol industry to promote consistency and prevent consumer confusion. Consumers deserve to know exactly what they're consuming—clearly, consistently, and equitably. Thank you for considering this public health perspective. Sincerely, Cassandra Tourre

text:
Dear TTB,

As a public health advocate, I appreciate the opportunity to comment on Notice No. 238. I strongly support TTB’s efforts to modernize and improve the transparency of malt beverage labeling. Accurate, standardized, and easily accessible labeling is critical for informing consumer decisions and reducing alcohol-related harms.

However, I am concerned that the proposed reliance on QR codes as a means of conveying essential product information—such as ingredients, nutritional content, and allergens—is inadequate from a public health standpoint.

Key Public Health Concerns with the QR Code Approach:
1.Limited Access and Equity: Not all consumers have smartphones, reliable internet access, or the technological literacy to use QR codes. This disproportionately affects older adults, lower-income populations, and rural communities, creating inequitable access to vital health information.
2.Reduced Transparency at Point of Purchase: Important health information should be immediately visible to consumers when they are making purchasing decisions. Relegating this data to a QR code discourages real-time engagement and undermines informed choice.
3.Inconsistent Use by Industry: Without mandatory formatting and content requirements, the use of QR codes could become inconsistent across brands, further confusing consumers and limiting usefulness.
4.Consumer Expectation of On-Label Information: Unlike most other packaged food and beverages, alcohol products are still not required to provide basic nutritional or ingredient data directly on the label. Continuing this practice via QR codes perpetuates a harmful double standard.

Recommendations:
To align alcohol labeling with broader public health goals, I respectfully urge the TTB to:
•Require on-label disclosure of key information: alcohol by volume (ABV), ingredient lists, common allergens, calories per serving, and nutritional information.
•Limit the use of QR codes to supplemental information only, not as a substitute for on-label transparency.
•Establish mandatory labeling standards across the alcohol industry to promote consistency and prevent consumer confusion.

Consumers deserve to know exactly what they’re consuming—clearly, consistently, and equitably. Thank you for considering this public health perspective.

Sincerely,
Cassandra Tourre

document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
**Comment on TTB Notice No. 238 – Proposed Revisions to Malt Beverage Labeling and Advertising Regulations**

**Subject: Public Health Concerns and Recommendations Regarding Alcohol Labeling Transparency**

Dear TTB,

As a public health advocate, I appreciate the opportunity to comment on Notice No. 238. I strongly support TTB’s efforts to modernize and improve the transparency of malt beverage labeling. Accurate, standardized, and easily accessible labeling is critical for informing consumer decisions and reducing alcohol-related harms.

However, I am concerned that the proposed reliance on **QR codes** as a means of conveying essential product information—such as ingredients, nutritional content, and allergens—is inadequate from a public health standpoint.

**Key Public Health Concerns with the QR Code Approach:**

1. **Limited Access and Equity**: Not all consumers have smartphones, reliable internet access, or the technological literacy to use QR codes. This disproportionately affects older adults, lower-income populations, and rural communities, creating inequitable access to vital health information.
2. **Reduced Transparency at Point of Purchase**: Important health information should be immediately visible to consumers when they are making purchasing decisions. Relegating this data to a QR code discourages real-time engagement and undermines informed choice.
3. **Inconsistent Use by Industry**: Without mandatory formatting and content requirements, the use of QR codes could become inconsistent across brands, further confusing consumers and limiting usefulness.
4. **Consumer Expectation of On-Label Information**: Unlike most other packaged food and beverages, alcohol products are still not required to provide basic nutritional or ingredient data directly on the label. Continuing this practice via QR codes perpetuates a harmful double standard.

**Recommendations:**

To align alcohol labeling with broader public health goals, I respectfully urge the TTB to:

* Require **on-label disclosure** of key information: alcohol by volume (ABV), ingredient lists, common allergens, calories per serving, and nutritional information.
* Limit the use of QR codes to **supplemental information only**, not as a substitute for on-label transparency.
* Establish **mandatory labeling standards** across the alcohol industry to promote consistency and prevent consumer confusion.

Consumers deserve to know exactly what they’re consuming—clearly, consistently, and equitably. Thank you for considering this public health perspective.

Sincerely,
Cassandra Tourre

comment_text: As a Registered Dietitian working closely with patients who have allergies, I strongly support allergen labeling on alcohol products. Many individuals with food allergies rely on clear ingredient information to avoid potential health risks. Since alcohol can contain hidden allergens such as gluten, nuts, sulfites, or artificial additives, transparent labeling is essential for their safety. Sophia Medinsky MS RD CDN

Sophia Medinsky MS RD CDN

text:
T. NEAL MORRIS
nmorris@mcbravelfi rm. com MEElRAYER 20I EAST MAIN STREET, SUITE 9OO
LEXINGTON, KY 40507
