document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
Page 1 of 4 
 
 
 
   
 
 
 
 
February 28, 2025 
 
Amy Greenberg 
Director, Regulations and Rulings Division 
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau 
1310 G. Street NW, Box 12 
Washington, DC 20005 
 
RE: Docket No.  TTB-2025-0003; Notice No. 238: Major Food Allergen Labeling for  Wines, 
Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages - Request for 120-Day Extension for Comments  
 
Dear Ms. Greenberg, 
 
Wine Institute is the public policy advocacy association representing over 1,000 California 
wineries and affiliated businesses.  California is responsible for more than 81 percent of the 
nation’s wine production and more than 95 percent of U.S. wine exports .  Distilled Spirits 
Council of the United States (“DISCUS”) is the principal trade association for the leading 
producers and importers of distilled spirits products sold in the  U.S. and represents 
distillers of all sizes .  The Beer Institute (“BI”) represents the $ 409.2 billion beer industry –  
an industry that includes over 6,600 brewers and more than 2.4 million American jobs.  BI is 
a national trade association for the American brewing industry, representing both large and 
small brewers, as well as importers and industry suppliers.  The Brewers Association (“BA”) 
seeks to promote and protect the interests of craft brewers and the craft brewing 
community, including beer consumers and home brewers. Today the BA  has roughly 5,000 
full voting brewery members – including members in every state – as well as over 1,000 allied 
trade members and over 30,000 home brewer and beer enthusiast members.   The National 
Beer Wholesalers Association’s (“NBWA”) purpose is to provide leadership, which 
enhances the independent beer and beverage distribution industry; to advocate before 
government and the public; to encourage the responsible consumption of alcohol ; and to 
Page 2 of 4 
 
provide programs and services that will benefit its members.  Wine & Spirits Wholesalers of 
America (“WSWA”) is the only national membership organization of wine and spirits 
distributors.  On behalf of its more than 380 member companies, WSWA advocates on their 
behalf with regards to federal, state, regulatory, and legal issues impacting distributors and 
the beverage alcohol industry.   WineAmerica is the National Association of American 
Wineries, representing wineries, winery associations, and wine industry supply companies 
across the country.  WineAmerica’s mission is to encourage the dynamic growth and 
development of American wineries  and winegrowing through the advancement and 
advocacy of sound public policy.  The American Craft Spirits Association (“ACSA”) the only 
national registered non-profit trade association representing the U.S. craft spirits industry. 
Its mission is to elevate and advocate for the community of craft spirits producers, and 
membership in ACSA is open to anyone.  American Distilled Spirits Alliance (“ADSA”) is a 
trade association comprised of 29 leading companies with common needs and interests in 
the manufacturing, importation, and marketing of distilled spirits products in the U.S. and 
around the world.   
 
We refer to Wine Institute , DISCUS, BI, BA, NBWA, WSWA, WineAmerica, ACSA, and ADSA 
collectively as “the Associations” in this joint letter.   
 
The Associations respectfully request an extension of the comment period in Notice No. 
238: Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages (“Notice  
238”).  The comment period for Notice 2 38 is scheduled to end on April 17, 20 25. The 
Associations request a 120-day extension to the current comment period that would extend 
to August 15, 2025. 
 
As a threshold matter , we note that these rulemakings come at a time when heavily 
regulated industries, and the agencies that regulate them , are adjusting to the priorities of 
the new administration.  There were many potentially impactful rulemakings published in 
the final days of the previous administration and then a regulatory freeze put in place on the 
first day of the new administration.  Additional time will allow agencies, and the industries 
they regulate, to better understand new priorities, expectations, and directives put into 
place since Notice 238 issued.  This is particularly important for the thousands of small and 
midsize wineries , craft brewers, and craft distillers, who will bear great  costs and 
operational burdens that a new and sweeping mandatory labeling regime imposes .  Even 
meaningfully participating in the comment process means  they must redirect time and 
resources. 
 
Notice 238 is expansive—i.e., 16 pages in the Federal Registers’ 10- point, single -spaced 
font—and poses at least 14 questions and expressly solicits comments in other areas.  It is 
also the first opportunity in a long while to comment on the important issues that  it raises.  
Indeed, TTB acknowledges in Notice 238 that it had been almost 20  years since it last 
solicited comments on these issues .  Accordingly, it undertook two “virtual listening 
sessions” in February 2024, however, there was no proposed rule at that time and the notice 
issued just 28 days in advance of the sessions .  A ddressing these issues in response to a  
proposed rule, and nearly two decades since the last proposed rule, will necessarily require 
updated input.  That said, it will take time to conduct a detailed analysis of the proposed Page 3 of 4 
 
rule—including the many questions and requests for comments in Notice 238—and for our 
members to provide comprehensive and useful feedback that will benefit the overall 
process and TTB’s objectives with this rulemaking. 
 
It is important to keep in mind that the  issues and questions addressed in Notice 23 8 will 
impact small, midsize, and large industry members in different ways.  Given the importance 
of the issues, the Associations will need substantial time to collect, deliberate, and convey 
the input of all  our members to ensure their perspectives are  included and well-reflected.  
TTB acknowledges that the Codex Committee on Food Labelling has been discussing food 
allergen standards, allergen labeling provisions, and a possible framework for evaluating 
exemptions for food allergens .  Our members need time to review and consider that same 
work and related issues that evolved in the nearly two decades since TTB last addressed 
these issues with a proposed rule.   Moreover, TTB seeks comments in Notice 23 8 on 
important but s weeping areas of interest such as comments on “ whether there are better 
alternatives” to what it proposes.  Our members will need additional time to consider other 
options available for those purposes  and then explain and discuss them  in submitted 
comments. 
 
Last, additional time is necessary due to several ongoing and overlapping rulemakings that 
impact our members .  As you know, TTB also published a rulemaking proposing alcohol 
facts statements in the labeling for wines, distilled spirits, and malt beverages on the same 
day as Notice 238 and with the same deadline for comments.  One day prior to Notice 238’s 
publication, the FDA published a rulemaking propos ing front-of-package labeling for 
nutrition which will also impact industry members.  All these rulemakings, including Notice 
238, propose new rules with many potential impacts that de serve due consideration .  We 
therefore believe a 120-day extension is appropriate and necessary. 
 
We would be pleased to respond to any questions that you might have about this request. 
 
[ SIGNATURES ON FOLLOWING PAGE ] 
  Page 4 of 4 
 
 
Respectfully Submitted,

comment_title: Comment 38:  A Voice for Choice Advocacy
comment_text: On behalf of A Voice for Choice Advocacy, we believe that the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) should mandate ingredient labeling of all contents used in the production of alcoholic beverages regulated under the Federal Alcohol Administration Act. This requirement is essential for several reasons. Firstly, food allergies are a significant public health concern. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), approximately 32 million Americans suffer from food allergies. Currently, many consumers remain unaware that alcohol beverages often lack proper ingredient labeling, including allergen labeling requirements established by the Food Allergen Labeling and Consumer Protection Act (FALCPA). By requiring comprehensive ingredient disclosure, TTB would empower consumers to make safer choices, mitigating the risk of unforeseen reactions, including triggering allergic responses. Secondly, transparency in labeling aligns with modern consumer expectations and public health advocacy. In 2021, various consumer groups and public health advocates called for mandatory labeling, emphasizing that consumers should have full access to information about the content of the products they consume. The public has expressed dissatisfaction with the current voluntary labeling system, which upholds ambiguity. A standardized disclosure of all ingredients would be a significant step toward greater transparency and consumer protection. Furthermore, the TTB possesses the statutory authority under the Federal Alcohol Administration Act to ensure that consumers receive "adequate information" about the identity and quality of alcohol products. The absence of mandatory ingredient labeling represents a gap in consumer protection that the TTB is well-positioned to address. Implementing such regulations would not only enhance consumer awareness but also foster trust in alcohol brands that prioritize transparency and safety. Lastly, the proposed regulations align with the TTB's mission to protect public health and well-being. By establishing uniform ingredient labeling requirements, the TTB would not only fulfill expectations set forth in previous public health initiatives but also adhere to the discussions and recommendations highlighted in the Treasury's Competition Report on alcohol markets. This report emphasizes that regulatory actions promoting public health should take precedence. Establishing a consistent framework for full ingredient disclosure would reflect a proactive response to these recommendations. In conclusion, mandating ingredient labeling on alcohol beverages is a vital initiative that would enhance consumer safety, ensure compliance with public health standards, and fulfill the TTB's regulatory responsibilities. Such requirements would provide Americans - particularly those vulnerable to food allergies, and/or sensitive to a diverse range of ingredients - with the necessary information to make informed choices about their consumption of alcohol beverages. Lea Jones Legislative Director A Voice for Choice Advocacy, Inc. www.avoiceforchoiceadvocacy.org

On behalf of A Voice for Choice Advocacy, we believe that the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) should mandate ingredient labeling of all contents used in the production of alcoholic beverages regulated under the Federal Alcohol Administration Act. This requirement is essential for several reasons.

Firstly, food allergies are a significant public health concern. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), approximately 32 million Americans suffer from food allergies. Currently, many consumers remain unaware that alcohol beverages often lack proper ingredient labeling, including allergen labeling requirements established by the Food Allergen Labeling and Consumer Protection Act (FALCPA). By requiring comprehensive ingredient disclosure, TTB would empower consumers to make safer choices, mitigating the risk of unforeseen reactions, including triggering allergic responses.

Secondly, transparency in labeling aligns with modern consumer expectations and public health advocacy. In 2021, various consumer groups and public health advocates called for mandatory labeling, emphasizing that consumers should have full access to information about the content of the products they consume. The public has expressed dissatisfaction with the current voluntary labeling system, which upholds ambiguity. A standardized disclosure of all ingredients would be a significant step toward greater transparency and consumer protection.

Furthermore, the TTB possesses the statutory authority under the Federal Alcohol Administration Act to ensure that consumers receive "adequate information" about the identity and quality of alcohol products. The absence of mandatory ingredient labeling represents a gap in consumer protection that the TTB is well-positioned to address. Implementing such regulations would not only enhance consumer awareness but also foster trust in alcohol brands that prioritize transparency and safety.

Lastly, the proposed regulations align with the TTB's mission to protect public health and well-being. By establishing uniform ingredient labeling requirements, the TTB would not only fulfill expectations set forth in previous public health initiatives but also adhere to the discussions and recommendations highlighted in the Treasury’s Competition Report on alcohol markets. This report emphasizes that regulatory actions promoting public health should take precedence. Establishing a consistent framework for full ingredient disclosure would reflect a proactive response to these recommendations.

In conclusion, mandating ingredient labeling on alcohol beverages is a vital initiative that would enhance consumer safety, ensure compliance with public health standards, and fulfill the TTB's regulatory responsibilities. Such requirements would provide Americans - particularly those vulnerable to food allergies, and/or sensitive to a diverse range of ingredients - with the necessary information to make informed choices about their consumption of alcohol beverages.

Lea Jones

comment_text: Dear Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau, I am writing to you in support of this proposed rule. As someone with food allergies that drinks — and is loath to have to look up what is in the alcoholic libation they are considering purchasing — requiring the listing of the major food allergens that are found in the alcoholic beverage would be a very good "quality of life" change, to borrow a tech term. Moreover, requiring the listing of some other other allergens that are common in wines, spirits, and malt beverages would be wise. Thus, I propose the mandated labeling of mangoes, gluten and coconuts. Moreover, as there are some unusual things in alcohol that could trigger an allergic reaction (histamines, sulfites, and yeast), requiring the listing or at least a warning that the beverage contains those things would be equally prudent. For more information, see https://www.verywellhealth.com/alcohol-allergies-and-intolerances-1324211; https://precisionpointdiagnostics.com/alcohols-effect-on-food-allergies-and-sensitivities/; https://home.allergicchild.com/alcohol-and-food-allergies/) Thanks!

comment_text: What will you do about 50ml? The print will be too small for it to be read. If it is a requirement on all sizes This will harm trial of products (causing issues for both consumers, retailers and suppliers) and will also reduce profits for retailers and suppliers on many levels.
document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text: What will you do about 50ml? The print will be too small for it to be read. If it is a requirement on all sizes This will harm trial of products (causing issues for both consumers, retailers and suppliers) and will also reduce profits for retailers and suppliers on many levels.

comment_text: I am allergic to milk products. These can be in a number of alcoholic beverages, so an allergy label is important for me. It must be printed on the bottle. A QR code or similar is not acceptable. It would be very difficult to say, go through 5 different bottles labelled 'creme de menthe' and look up each QR code and figure out which one has milk or not. For comparison shopping, comparing allergens or nutrition info, etc, you want all this info right there in front of you. Or say I attend a party and the host has 3 different bottles available to drink, I am supposed to scan them all on my phone to find this info? What if I'm at a bar and I ask about allergens? Is the bartender going to scan QR codes for me?? That is crazy, please make it printed right there on the label!

comment_text: This should 100% be enacted. I have multiple family members with major allergies that this will benefit greatly. Most producers do not label when allergens are used in the production process which has led to multiple allergy attacks that could have been prevented. This will benefit all.
document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text: This should 100% be enacted. I have multiple family members with major allergies that this will benefit greatly. Most producers do not label when allergens are used in the production process which has led to multiple allergy attacks that could have been prevented. This will benefit all.

comment_text: I think it is due time that beverage companies be held to the same transparency that all food & other adhere too. This is apparent for many reasons including toxic materials, dietary decisions, and allergens. I think a few consumers who follow vegan lifestyles may find it upsetting to have their wines and beverages filtered by fish or egg by products. My wife has many allergies including peas and eggs. These two allergens are often used in cheap filtering of wines of sediments. Because these labels do not share this use, we have had numerous hospital runs that makes her life unsafe and anxiety filled. The move to accepting this regulation is well overdue and I commend anyone who moves forward with its improvement. Thank you

document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text: Allergens should most definitely be listed on alcohol beverage labels. This will help guide consumers both to and from products within their area of concern.

comment_text: My name is Annika Dhawan and I am a third year MD/MPH students at a university-affiliated hospital in South Florida. The regulation I wish to provide commentary on is RIN 1513-AC94, Major Food Allergen Labelling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages proposed by the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) on 01/17/2025. This regulation proposes to require disclosure of all major food allergens used in the production of alcohol beverages subject to TTB's regulatory authority, and under the proposed regulations, labels must declare milk, eggs, fish, crustacean shellfish, tree nuts, wheat, peanuts, soybeans, and sesame, as well as ingredients that contain protein derived from these foods, if used in the production of the alcohol beverage and unless one of three exceptions apply. TTB proposes a compliance date of 5 years from the date that a final rule resulting from this proposal is published in the Federal Register. I strongly support this proposed regulation to adopt RIN 1513-AC94. As incoming medical professionals, one rationale behind our support is ensuring accessibility of allergen advisories and safety to everyone purchasing alcoholic beverages. 33 million Americans are living with food allergies, some of whom with allergies so severe they would experience a life-threatening emergency if not adequately informed. After this regulation was first introduced, the majority of comments during public hearings were universally supportive of RIN 1513-AC94. The Asthma and Allergy Foundation of America, a patient advocacy organization, stated that "To the extent possible, labeling information should be displayed on alcoholic beverages similar to labeling on FDA-regulated foods. Consumers with food allergies are accustomed to FDA labeling, and would be able to easily transition to a similar model for checking the safety of alcoholic beverages . . .". Our support is further guided by input from professional organizations providing medical guidance related to allergen labelling. The American Academy of Allergy, Asthma, and Immunology explains that, "Teens and young adults may need to be reminded or taught anew that the Food Allergen Labeling Consumer Protection Act (FALCPA) does not cover alcoholic beverages. Therefore, this is an unregulated area which may make determination of the ingredients of mixed alcoholic drinks difficult to ascertain. Additionally, they may encounter inconsistencies in how well educated restaurants and bar staff are about food allergy, anaphylaxis and cross-contact issues with food proteins." We agree that these labels should be written clearly on food products, and should not be shared via QR code, as this may disadvantage individuals without smartphones or the internet, particularly affecting older adults, low-income individuals, and those in rural or tribal areas. I agree that any use of a major food allergen or its protein derivative in production would require disclosure, regardless of any threshold level. This proposed rule matters for public health because improved transparency regarding food and drink consumption is of utmost importance, enabling people to make informed decisions of what they ingest. Though there are costs associated with the labeling, the universal benefits greatly outweigh the cost. This measure is supported by both patient and professional societies.

comment_text: I have a friend who seems to have breakouts every time they consume certain brands of wine. Only having the ingredients of the product itself to view as a consumer doesn't successfully show us what kinds of ingredients were used in the production of it. Therefore I would like to recommend adding allergy labels onto alcohol products as it'd be extremely helpful to us consumers to get a better idea of what we're putting into our bodies.
document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text: I have a friend who seems to have breakouts every time they consume certain brands of wine. Only having the ingredients of the product itself to view as a consumer doesn't successfully show us what kinds of ingredients were used in the production of it. Therefore I would like to recommend adding allergy labels onto alcohol products as it'd be extremely helpful to us consumers to get a better idea of what we're putting into our bodies.

comment_text: I do not see why they would not have to label the allergens. Even food labels have to specify "may contain trace amounts of XYZ" or state "Was prepared in a factory that contains XYZ". The labels have the alcohol percentage %, and for some people with a severe food allergy, coming into contact, not even ingesting, just coming into contact with certain foods, can be more dangerous to them than a high proof alcohol. Allergies have the potential to be fatal, so why wouldn't you want to do everything you can to protect your customers, not to mention yourself, from a lawsuit?

comment_text: On behalf of the Project Extra Mile coalition of more than 400 Nebraskans working to prevent alcohol-related harms resulting from excessive alcohol consumption, we urge the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax Trade Bureau to implement guidelines requiring the disclosure of nutrition, allergen, and ingredient information on labeling serves an important public health purpose. Increased transparency is warranted on these products given that most other consumable products already contain this detailed labeling. Why should alcohol be any different than other consumables, especially because alcohol consumption is identified by the United States federal government's National Toxicology Program as a known human carcinogen (see attachment)? Years of evidence have shown that there is no safe amount of alcohol to consume for cancer risk and that excessive consumption is related to at least seven types of cancer in humans (Jun et al., 2023; LoConte et al., 2017). Most recent data shows that over 17,000 Americans die of alcohol-related cancers each year (CDC ARDI, 2024). A study conducted by the American Association for Cancer Research found only approximately 30% of Americans are aware of this association, therefore alcoholic product must contain these warnings, as is seen on other potentially cancer-causing products (Seidenberg, Wiseman, & Klein, 2023). A recent study found that 65.1% of American support warning labels on products and 63.9% support drinking guidelines being added to alcoholic products (Seidenberg et al., 2021). That is why we also feel strongly that a cancer warning be prominently displayed on the labels.
document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text: On behalf of the Project Extra Mile coalition of more than 400 Nebraskans working to prevent alcohol-related harms resulting from excessive alcohol consumption, we urge the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax Trade Bureau to implement guidelines requiring the disclosure of nutrition, allergen, and ingredient information on labeling serves an important public health purpose. Increased transparency is warranted on these products given that most other consumable products already contain this detailed labeling. Why should alcohol be any different than other consumables, especially because alcohol consumption is identified by the United States federal government's National Toxicology Program as a known human carcinogen (see attachment)? Years of evidence have shown that there is no safe amount of alcohol to consume for cancer risk and that excessive consumption is related to at least seven types of cancer in humans (Jun et al., 2023; LoConte et al., 2017). Most recent data shows that over 17,000 Americans die of alcohol-related cancers each year (CDC ARDI, 2024). A study conducted by the American Association for Cancer Research found only approximately 30% of Americans are aware of this association, therefore alcoholic product must contain these warnings, as is seen on other potentially cancer-causing products (Seidenberg, Wiseman, & Klein, 2023). A recent study found that 65.1% of American support warning labels on products and 63.9% support drinking guidelines being added to alcoholic products (Seidenberg et al., 2021). That is why we also feel strongly that a cancer warning be prominently displayed on the labels.

comment_text: Nearly 26 million adults in America are affected by a food allergy. Approximately 3% of those affected have life threatening symptoms. It's unbelievable that in our country, we allow for anything consumable to be an unknown life threat to anyone. Please change your label rules so that ALL can consume these products safely.
document_title: Notice No. 238:  Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text: Nearly 26 million adults in America are affected by a food allergy. Approximately 3% of those affected have life threatening symptoms. It’s unbelievable that in our country, we allow for anything consumable to be an unknown life threat to anyone. Please change your label rules so that ALL can consume these products safely.

comment_text: I have a few severe food allergies along with my brother and many others I know. Avoiding my allergens is relatively simple when I know the ingredients in what I am consuming. When I can't see the ingredients on alcohol, it is very concerning as I have to guess if I am able to consume the alcohol without having a severe allergic reaction. It does not make sense that alcohol producers are able to hide what is in their products at a major risk to millions of Americans. This regulation would make me and millions others much safer and avoid potential tragedies and hospital bills.

comment_text: The attached comments are submitted by the USA WTO TBT Enquiry Point on behalf of the WTO TBT Enquiry Point of Japan.
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text: The attached comments are submitted by the USA WTO TBT Enquiry Point on behalf of the WTO TBT Enquiry Point of Japan.

comment_text: The attached comments are submitted by the USA WTO TBT Enquiry Point on behalf of the WTO TBT Enquiry Point of Japan.
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
1 
 
Japan’s Comment on the “G/TBT/N/USA/2182” 
 
Japan appreciates that the United States of America provided WTO members the 
opportunity to comment on 27 CFR Part 4, 5, 7, 24, 25 and 27 by notifying the 
“G/TBT/N/USA/2182”.  
 
The proposed mandatory labeling of Alcohol Facts could impose a significant burden 
on small businesses such as liquor manufacturers and importers. In order to reduce 
the burden on businesses in both countries as much as possible and to prevent any 
problems regarding trade, Japan would like to make the following requests: 
 
[Comment 1] 
Regarding nutrient labeling requirements, we would like nutrients to be listed only if 
mentioned nutrients are present at a certain level or higher. In the case of alcoholic 
beverages, most products do not contain, or contain only a de minimis amount of, 
fat and protein. We believe that it should not be mandatory to label substances that 
are not present or that are present only a small amount in a product. 
 
[Comment 2] 
TTB proposes a compliance date of 5 years from the date that a final rule is 
published in the Federal Register. As it is necessary to ensure that businesses have 
sufficient time to prepare for making changes to labels of their products, we request 
that the proposed 5-year period be maintained, and not be shortened. 
 
[Comment 3] 
Given that label space is limited, in order to reduce  the burden on businesses we 
would like it to be possible to provide Alcohol Facts through electronic  means such 
as QR codes. By allowing the use of electronic means, we believe that businesses 
will find it easier to accommodate different languages and to update information, 
thereby reducing the burden of displaying Alcohol Facts. If this request is not granted, 
this will become a trade barrier. 
 
[Comment 4] 
Although the proposal does not make analytical testing mandatory, nevertheless we 
would like the TTB website to clearly state proper analytical testing methods for each 
nutrient for reference. When we examined TTB website, w e found we were unable 
to confirm the contents of the Official TTB method described in the TTB Procedures 
2020-1, and we were also unable to access the AOAC method for free. It would be  
 
2 
 
much appreciated if a document containing all of  the information necessary for 
analysis would be made publicly available free of charge, for reference. We also ask 
that the proposed tolerance of 20 percent, either above or below the stated amount 
of calorie, carbohydrate, protein and fat, not be altered. 
 
We would also like the U.S. to answer the following questions: 
 
[Question 1] 
Regarding the serving size, given that a serving size  for sake i s not explicitly 
mentioned in the proposal, do you anticipate that sake will use the reference amount 
for wine? 
 
[Question 2] 
The proposal allows b usinesses to rely on  published databases rather than on 
analytical testing. Would it be acceptable to quote and use databases published by 
any organization in any country? If you expect any specific published databases to 
be referenced, we would appreciate it if you could share that information with us.

text: Attached please find a comment from the Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine.

comment_title: Comment 136:  Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine
comment_text: Attached please find a comment from the Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine.
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
June 16, 2025 
 
 
The Honorable Robert F. Kennedy, Jr.     The Honorable Scott Bessent 
Secretary        Secretary 
U.S. Department of Health & Human Services    U.S. Department of the Treasury  
200 Independence Avenue SW      1500 Independence Avenue SW 
Washington, DC 20201       Washington, DC 20220 
Re: Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau - Notice No. 237: Alcohol Facts Statements in the 
Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages 
 
Dear Secretary Kennedy and Secretary Bessent, 
On behalf of the Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine, a national health no-profit organization, I write 
today to call your attention to the negative health effects of alcohol and to ask you to inform consumers by 
moving forward with the proposed alcohol labeling rule. These labels will help fulfill the administration’s goals of 
preventing and reducing chronic disease. 
The “First Special Report to the U.S. Congress on Alcohol and Health” was issued in 1971, but even by that time 
the health risks of consuming alcohol had already been well documented.1 As the evidence on alcohol’s health 
risks continues to mount, our organization recommends the current warning label on alcoholic beverages, which 
first appeared in 1989, be updated to better protect Americans by listing specific health risks, as well as nutrition 
and allergen information. 
The label, which has not been updated in more than 35 years, currently reads: “GOVERNMENT WARNING: (1) 
According to the Surgeon General, women should not drink alcoholic beverages during pregnancy because of the 
risk of birth defects. (2) Consumption of alcoholic beverages impairs your ability to drive a car or operate 
machinery and may cause health problems.”2 
Using the vague term “health problems” leaves Americans unaware of the true toll alcohol consumption can have 
on health, including a growing understanding of how it raises the risk of several types of cancer. It is vital that this 
label be updated to reflect the increased evidence and understanding of the specific risks of alcohol consumption. 
In January 2025, the Surgeon General released “Alcohol and Cancer Risk,” an advisory report that cites scientific 
evidence on the link between alcohol consumption and increased risk for at least seven different types of cancer, 
including breast (in women), colorectum, esophagus, laryngeal, liver, mouth, and throat.3 The report recommends 
that the existing Surgeon General’s health warning label on alcohol-containing beverages be updated to include a 
warning about the risk of cancer associated with alcohol consumption. Our organization, which has 17,000 doctor 
members, already recommends avoiding alcohol as part of our Let’s Beat Breast Cancer campaign, which 
provides healthcare providers and the public with evidence-based resources and powerful steps to reduce breast 
cancer risk.4 This campaign echoes the recently passed policies of the American Medical Association, which 
support not only clearer alcohol labelling but also efforts to educate the public about the benefits of lifestyle 
changes that may reduce breast cancer risk, including limiting alcohol intake, regular physical activity, 
maintenance of a healthy body weight, and a healthy plant-based diet.5 This policy also encourages physicians to 
regularly discuss with their individual patients the benefits of lifestyle changes that may reduce cancer risk.  In addition to adding a cancer warning, we recommend that the label also address other health risks to the liver, 
brain, gut, pancreas, lungs, cardiovascular system, immune system, and other parts of the body, as detailed by the 
National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism.6  
Ingredient information should also be included for those looking to avoid allergens—such as sulfites and grains 
like wheat, rye, or barley—or animal products that are sometimes used as flavoring or fining agents, which are 
used to filter out impurities and improve the clarity of some alcoholic beverages. 7 Common animal-based fining 
agents include milk byproducts including whey, casein, and lactose. Other ingredients commonly found in 
alcoholic beverages include eggs; isinglass, which is derived from fish bladders; and gelatin, which is derived 
from animal skin, bones, and cartilage.8 Consumers who wish to avoid consumption of these ingredients, whether 
for health or other reasons, should have access to this information. 
Updated warning labels on alcohol are long overdue and should reflect current knowledge about the health risks 
of alcohol, as well as allergen and ingredient information that will help Americans make well-informed decisions. 
Thank you for your attention to this important issue. 
 
Sincerely, 
 
 
Stephanie McBurnett, RDN, LDN 
Nutrition Educator 
Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine 
 
 
 
References: 
 
1 National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism. History of NIAAA. Accessed June 11, 2025. 
https://www.niaaa.nih.gov/about-niaaa/our-work/history-niaaa 
 
2 Congress.gov. S.2047 - Alcoholic Beverage Labeling Act of 1988. Accessed June 11, 2025. 
https://www.congress.gov/bill/100th-congress/senate-bill/2047 
 
3 U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. Alcohol and Cancer Risk. The U.S. Surgeon General’s Advisory. 2025. 
Accessed June 11, 2025. https://www.hhs.gov/surgeongeneral/reports-and-publications/alcohol-cancer/index.html 
 
4 Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine. Let’s Beat Breast Cancer. Accessed June 11, 2025. 
https://www.pcrm.org/letsbeatbreastcancer 
 
5 “AMA adopts new public health policies to improve health of nation.” June 10, 2025. Accessed June 13, 2025. 
https://www.ama-assn.org/press-center/ama-press-releases/ama-adopts-new-public-health-policies-improve-health-nation-11 
 
6 National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism. Alcohol's Effects on the Body. Updated June 2025. Accessed June 11, 
2025. https://www.niaaa.nih.gov/alcohols-effects-health/alcohols-effects-body 
 
7 American Academy of Allergy, Asthma & Immunology. Out to eat with food allergies? Don’t forget about your drinks. 
January 10, 2025. Accessed June 11, 2025. https://www.aaaai.org/tools-for-the-public/conditions-library/allergies/food-
allergy-drinks 
 
8 Meixner M. Is alcohol vegan? A complete guide to beer, wine, and spirits. Healthline. January 30, 2020. Accessed June 11, 
2025. https://www.healthline.com/nutrition/is-alcohol-vegan

comment_text: We express a preference for the title "Serving Facts", which is more specific and relevant to the beverage itself rather than referring broadly to alcohol. We emphasize the need to allow digital labeling for this information. Digital formats would free up physical label space, reduce costs, facilitate multilingual communication, and allow for easier and more frequent updates. We recommend the removal of the black box around the declaration, as this would provide greater flexibility for industry members in how the information is presented. In cases where physical labeling is used, we propose that a linear display format be permitted instead of a tabular/column format, offering more adaptability in design. Regarding content, sugar should remain an optional element, in contrast to some EU industry practices where additional nutritional values like calories, fat, carbohydrates, protein, and salt are voluntarily disclosed. We support the use of international units such as milliliters (ml) or centiliters (cl), as U.S. ounces can cause confusion for consumers in global markets. We are in favor of the proposal not to align the declaration for distilled spirits with the FDA's "Nutrition Facts" label, as it is not suitable for these types of products. It is also important to avoid providing nutritional information for the entire bottle, which could mislead or confuse consumers. We advocate for greater flexibility regarding serving sizes, which can vary by country. A 20% tolerance on the declared nutritional values would be reasonable and consistent with industry practices. We also support an exemption from the requirement to request a new COLA, simplifying the implementation process for producers. Finally, we request a 5-year transition period, along with the ability to sell through existing stock that was placed on the market before the proposed rule comes into force.
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
We express a preference for the title "Serving Facts", which is more specific and relevant to the beverage itself rather than referring broadly to alcohol.

We emphasize the need to allow digital labeling for this information. Digital formats would free up physical label space, reduce costs, facilitate multilingual communication, and allow for easier and more frequent updates.

We recommend the removal of the black box around the declaration, as this would provide greater flexibility for industry members in how the information is presented.

In cases where physical labeling is used, we propose that a linear display format be permitted instead of a tabular/column format, offering more adaptability in design.

Regarding content, sugar should remain an optional element, in contrast to some EU industry practices where additional nutritional values like calories, fat, carbohydrates, protein, and salt are voluntarily disclosed.

We support the use of international units such as milliliters (ml) or centiliters (cl), as U.S. ounces can cause confusion for consumers in global markets.

We are in favor of the proposal not to align the declaration for distilled spirits with the FDA’s "Nutrition Facts" label, as it is not suitable for these types of products.

It is also important to avoid providing nutritional information for the entire bottle, which could mislead or confuse consumers.

We advocate for greater flexibility regarding serving sizes, which can vary by country.

A 20% tolerance on the declared nutritional values would be reasonable and consistent with industry practices.

We also support an exemption from the requirement to request a new COLA, simplifying the implementation process for producers.

Finally, we request a 5-year transition period, along with the ability to sell through existing stock that was placed on the market before the proposed rule comes into force.

document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
July 14, 2025 
 
Mary G. Ryan 
Administrator 
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) 
U.S. Department of Treasury 
 
Comment on Proposed Rules re Alcohol Facts Statements, Major Food Allergens in the Labeling of 
Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages (Dockets No. TTB-2025-0002; TTB-2025-0003) 
VIA ONLINE SUBMISSION 
Dear Administrator Ryan:  
Consumer Federation of America appreciates the opportunity to comment on this important 
rulemaking. As noted in our joint comments with the Center for Science in the Public Interest 
(CSPI) and other public health and consumer advocates, we strongly support the Alcohol and 
Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau’s (TTB’s) proposed rules to mandate AlcoholௗFacts panels and 
MajorௗFoodௗAllergen disclosures on wines, spirits, and malt beverages, and encourage TTB to 
strengthen the rule by requiring disclosure elements such as added sugars in grams, saturated fat in 
grams, and sodium in milligrams, within the “Alcohol Facts” panel, and by further specifying the 
format and location of allergen disclosures on labels. We write separately here to underscore how 
this rulemaking advances the Administration’s stated “Make America Healthy Again” objectives, and 
to urge you to follow through with ingredients labeling requirements that will give consumers the 
basic information on alcoholic beverage labels that they have come to expect when buying all other 
beverages and food. 
Leading wellness influencers have called attention to the lack of transparency in alcohol 
labeling. The “Food Babe” Vani Hari has pointed out that “the government agency that regulates 
alcoholic drinks does not require alcohol manufacturers to label their ingredients or tell consumers 
what’s actually in their drinks,”1 and cited various brands that “are trying to slowly poison us with 
cheap and harmful ingredients.”2 In response to the question of how alcohol fits with MAHA, 
Calley Means, a special advisor to HHS Secretary Kennedy, stated “Phase 1 of MAHA is full 
transparency on what’s making us sick to the American people.”3 
CFA welcomes this call for full transparency, which we have been asking for in alcohol 
labeling for over 20 years. Better labeling will not eliminate all alcohol-related harms, but the 
available evidence indicates that it will help reduce those harms. For instance, researchers have 
documented that consumers are aware of calorie counts for alcohol on restaurant menus,4 and that 
 
1 hƩps://foodbabe.com/alcoholic-drink/  
2 hƩps://foodbabe.com/the-shocking-ingredients-in-beer/  
3 hƩps://www.statnews.com/2025/01/14/alcohol-health-risks-rŅ-jr-maha  
4 hƩps://link.springer.com/arƟcle/10.17269/s41997-021-00599-0  enactment of state laws requiring menu calorie labeling for alcohol were correlated with a small but 
significant decline in reported alcohol consumption.5  
Similarly, researchers have found that labels with information about the number of standard 
drinks per container and low risk drinking guidelines help consumers to more accurately estimate 
their alcohol consumption than percentage alcohol by volume (%ABV) alone.6 Even consumers that 
do not pay attention to alcohol labels may still benefit from a broader population shift towards more 
conscientious consumption. Across the world, research shows that declines in the overall level of 
alcohol consumption—the average per capita consumption—coincide with reduced alcohol-related 
harms.7  
These spillover effects support a broad range of policies to provide accurate information to 
consumers about alcohol, both on and off the label. In particular, as President Trump’s nominee for 
Surgeon General, Casey Means, has pointed out, “people don’t realize [] that alcohol is the third 
biggest risk factor for cancer other than smoking and obesity,” and that “[e]ven 1 drink per day can 
increase the risk of some cancers.”8 The combined high public health burden, and low public 
awareness, of alcohol attributable cancers support lower recommended limits for “moderate 
drinking” in the Dietary Guidelines for Americans, and a cancer warning on alcohol labels. Updating 
the health warning statement on labels will require Congress to amend the Alcoholic Beverage 
Labeling Act of 1988, and so the Administration will need to exercise leadership to accomplish that 
worthy objective. In the meantime, however, TTB should follow through on this rulemaking and its 
pledge to propose a rule requiring ingredients disclosure.  
There is no good reason for alcohol labels to omit the standard information consumers see 
on the labels of every other food and beverage product. This era of alcohol labeling exceptionalism 
can end with this Administration and absolutely should if the MAHA agenda is to be taken seriously.   
Thank you for your consideration of these comments.  
Sincerely,  
  
Thomas Gremillion 
 Director of Food Policy 
 Consumer Federation of America 
 
 
5 hƩps://www.sciencedirect.com/science/arƟcle/abs/pii/S0091743517302359  
6 hƩps://link.springer.com/arƟcle/10.1186/s12889-023-16327-x  
7 Rossow I, Mäkelä P. Public Health Thinking Around Alcohol-Related Harm: Why Does Per Capita Consumption 
Matter? J Stud Alcohol Drugs. 2021 Jan;82(1):9-17. PMID: 33573718.  
8 hƩps://www.caseymeans.com/learn/arƟcle-why-i-did-alcohol-free-dry-january

comment_text: As a small US importer representing small foreign producers, the proposed regulation will necessitate costly laboratory testing, relabeling, and in some cases, recasting of custom bottles in order to comply with the additional labeling requirements, as well as additional paperwork and administrative burdens to comply on both the Federal and State levels. This will add significant testing, manufacturing, legal validation, and paperwork costs for both our foreign producers and our small business. Additionally, small artisanal producers use their valuable label space to present their unique stories and history, their values, and selling points to consumers. Adding more required information to beverage alcohol labels will reduce the ability of small businesses to stand out to consumers in a crowded beverage alcohol market dominated by large brands. That being said, the proposed regulations are vague on many of the details of the labeling implementation, including: • how the values in the Alcohol Facts panel will be determined; and if laboratory analysis is mandatory, whether laboratory analysis must be done on domestic or foreign soil, • TTB should clarify how the individual quantities on the Alcohol Facts panel will be assessed: whether via laboratory analysis (whether domestic or foreign or through the TTB) or via lookup tables by Type and Designation. • Additionally, how will alcohol beverage products that comply with a foreign appellation (IGP, AOC, etc.) be assessed. • whether currently approved COLAs will need to be resubmitted for approval, • whether the proposed Alcohol Facts panel will follow the current FDA requirements vis-à-vis proportional nutrition panel sizing, typography, and formatting, or if TTB will stick with more minimalist typography guidelines such as those currently employed for mandatory information on COLAs, • where the placement of the Alcohol Facts panel will be mandated, i.e. whether it can be placed on any label (brand, back, neck, side, neck tag) or whether it will be required to be on a specific label • whether inventory imported before the implementation of the new regulations would be grandfathered in or whether previously imported products will need to be re-labeled • whether there will be an exemption for limited bottlings, for example single bottles/single cases of a vintage imported once. • whether there will be any exemptions for small producers similar to the US FDA/CFSAN - Small Business Nutrition Labeling Exemption. • TTB should add a Small Business Nutrition Labeling Exemption to enable micro-producers of craft spirits to continue to offer their products to US consumers by eliminating these prohibitive costs to market. • Additionally, TTB should clarify exactly what specific Alcohol Facts information will be required on the panel. While we are not opposed to adding Alcohol Facts that will improve consumer understanding of alcohol beverage products and allow them to make better informed decisions, we do urge the TTB to consider adding a Small Business Labeling Exemption, as well as small quantity exemption for limited bottling/case imports to allow artisanal, family-owned and operated producers such as those we import to continue being able to offer their products to US consumers at competitive prices. In addition, we urge TTB to clarify the proposed regulations to allow us as a small business to better understand and anticipate the impact these proposed Alcohol Facts panels will have on our business.
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
As a small US importer representing small foreign producers, the proposed regulation will necessitate costly laboratory testing, relabeling, and in some cases, recasting of custom bottles in order to comply with the additional labeling requirements, as well as additional paperwork and administrative burdens to comply on both the Federal and State levels. This will add significant testing, manufacturing, legal validation, and paperwork costs for both our foreign producers and our small business.

Additionally, small artisanal producers use their valuable label space to present their unique stories and history, their values, and selling points to consumers. Adding more required information to beverage alcohol labels will reduce the ability of small businesses to stand out to consumers in a crowded beverage alcohol market dominated by large brands.

That being said, the proposed regulations are vague on many of the details of the labeling implementation, including:
•how the values in the Alcohol Facts panel will be determined; and if laboratory analysis is mandatory, whether laboratory analysis must be done on domestic or foreign soil,
•TTB should clarify how the individual quantities on the Alcohol Facts panel will be assessed: whether via laboratory analysis (whether domestic or foreign or through the TTB) or via lookup tables by Class Type and Designation.
•Additionally, how will alcohol beverage products that comply with a foreign appellation (IGP, AOC, etc.) be assessed.
•whether currently approved COLAs will need to be resubmitted for approval,
•whether the proposed Alcohol Facts panel will follow the current FDA requirements vis-à-vis proportional nutrition panel sizing, typography, and formatting, or if TTB will stick with more minimalist typography guidelines such as those currently employed for mandatory information on COLAs,
•where the placement of the Alcohol Facts panel will be mandated, i.e. whether it can be placed on any label (brand, back, neck, side, neck tag) or whether it will be required to be on a specific label
•whether inventory imported before the implementation of the new regulations would be grandfathered in or whether previously imported products will need to be re-labeled
•whether there will be an exemption for limited bottlings, for example single bottles/single cases of a vintage imported once.
•whether there will be any exemptions for small producers similar to the US FDA/CFSAN - Small Business Nutrition Labeling Exemption.
•TTB should add a Small Business Nutrition Labeling Exemption to enable micro-producers of craft spirits to continue to offer their products to US consumers by eliminating these prohibitive costs to market.
•Additionally, TTB should clarify exactly what specific Alcohol Facts information will be required on the panel.

While we are not opposed to adding Alcohol Facts that will improve consumer understanding of alcohol beverage products and allow them to make better informed decisions, we do urge the TTB to consider adding a Small Business Labeling Exemption, as well as small quantity exemption for limited bottling/case imports to allow artisanal, family-owned and operated producers such as those we import to continue being able to offer their products to US consumers at competitive prices.

In addition, we urge TTB to clarify the proposed regulations to allow us as a small business to better understand and anticipate the impact these proposed Alcohol Facts panels will have on our business.

comment_text: As a patient advocate, I fully support the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau's proposed rule to require standardized "Alcohol Facts" labeling on all alcoholic beverage products regulated under the Federal Alcohol Administration Act. Consumers should be provided with all the nutritional facts that are clear about what is entering their bodies. Currently, there are some "Alcohol Facts" provided on alcoholic beverage products, but these are limited. Informed decisions can be made by including more facts related to nutrition. Suppliers should think of consumers first, as that is who will supply this information to consumers. This proposed rule would provide transparency and align with alcohol labeling using public health standards that are used today. The proposed 5-year compliance period will provide industry stakeholders with time to adjust, while ensuring the benefits of transparency are recognized soon. I encourage the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau to finalize this rule to prioritize public health, consumer rights, and transparency.

text:
As a patient advocate, I fully support the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau’s proposed rule to require standardized “Alcohol Facts” labeling on all alcoholic beverage products regulated under the Federal Alcohol Administration Act.
Consumers should be provided with all the nutritional facts that are clear about what is entering their bodies. Currently, there are some “Alcohol Facts” provided on alcoholic beverage products, but these are limited. Informed decisions can be made by including more facts related to nutrition. Suppliers should think of consumers first, as that is who will supply this information to consumers. This proposed rule would provide transparency and align with alcohol labeling using public health standards that are used today.
The proposed 5-year compliance period will provide industry stakeholders with time to adjust, while ensuring the benefits of transparency are recognized soon.
I encourage the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau to finalize this rule to prioritize public health, consumer rights, and transparency.

comment_text: Dear TTB, As a public health advocate, I appreciate the opportunity to comment on Notice No. 237. I urge the TTB to consider the broader implications of expanding definitions and permitted ingredients for distilled spirits. While regulatory modernization is important for industry innovation, public health protection must remain paramount. Widening the standards of identity—particularly allowing for a broader range of flavorings, additives, and processing techniques—risks further obscuring the true content of alcohol products from consumers. Transparency and clarity are essential for consumers to make informed decisions about their health. If new ingredients or processes are allowed, there must be strict labeling and disclosure requirements to ensure that consumers are not misled or unknowingly exposed to compounds that could pose health risks. Moreover, the normalization or rebranding of certain spirits under broader standards may appeal to younger or more vulnerable populations. The TTB should take into account the potential for increased alcohol consumption and related harms, including addiction, liver disease, and alcohol-related injuries. Public health considerations should be integrated into any final rule. I respectfully recommend TTB: • Require mandatory ingredient disclosure on labels for all spirits. • Conduct or require pre-market safety reviews for novel additives. • Assess the public health implications of marketing changes enabled by revised standards. Thank you for considering my perspective. Sincerely, Cassandra Tourre

text:
**Comment on TTB Notice No. 237 – Proposed Revisions to Distilled Spirits Standards of Identity**

**Subject: Public Health Perspective on Proposed Changes to Distilled Spirits Standards**

Dear TTB,

As a public health advocate, I appreciate the opportunity to comment on Notice No. 237. I urge the TTB to consider the broader implications of expanding definitions and permitted ingredients for distilled spirits. While regulatory modernization is important for industry innovation, public health protection must remain paramount.

Widening the standards of identity—particularly allowing for a broader range of flavorings, additives, and processing techniques—risks further obscuring the true content of alcohol products from consumers. Transparency and clarity are essential for consumers to make informed decisions about their health. If new ingredients or processes are allowed, there must be strict labeling and disclosure requirements to ensure that consumers are not misled or unknowingly exposed to compounds that could pose health risks.

Moreover, the normalization or rebranding of certain spirits under broader standards may appeal to younger or more vulnerable populations. The TTB should take into account the potential for increased alcohol consumption and related harms, including addiction, liver disease, and alcohol-related injuries.

Public health considerations should be integrated into any final rule. I respectfully recommend TTB:

* Require mandatory ingredient disclosure on labels for all spirits.
* Conduct or require pre-market safety reviews for novel additives.
* Assess the public health implications of marketing changes enabled by revised standards.

Thank you for considering my perspective.

Sincerely,
Cassandra Tourre

comment_text: My name is Heidi Baxley, I am a licensed Substance Use Prevention Specialist and Chair of the Utah Prevention Coalition Association. Alcohol content labeling is a simple commonsense approach that increases consumer awareness of the contents of alcoholic beverages and promotes transparency, health, and safety. Excess alcohol consumption is associated with various harms including injuries, motor vehicle accidents, liver disease, cardiovascular disease, and certain cancers. Overall, substance use prevention coalitions in Utah support this rule as a major step forward for transparency on alcoholic beverages that will allow consumers to make more informed choices about their alcohol purchases and how much they consume.

document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
b NFIB

555 12th St. NW, Ste. 1001
Washington, D.C. 20004

Via www.requiations.gov and via U.S. First Class Mail

July 29, 2025
Hon. Scott Bessent Hon. Russell T. Vought
Secretary of the Treasury Director
c/o Director, Regulations & Ruling Div’n Office of Management and Budget
Alcohol & Tobacco Tax & Trade Bureau Attn: Director, OIRA
1310 G St. NW, Box 12 725 17th Street NW
Washington, DC 20005 Washington, DC 20503

Dear Mr. Secretary and Mr. Director:

RE: (1) Department of the Treasury Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau
(TTB) Notice of Proposed Rulemaking Titled “Major Food Allergen
Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages,” Docket No.
TTB-2025-0003, 90 Fed. Reg. 5763 (January 17, 2025), 90 Fed. Reg.
14932 (April 7, 2025) (extending comment period) ("Biden-proposed
Allergen Labeling Rule”)

(2) TTB Notice of Proposed Rulemaking Titled “Alcohol Facts Statements in
the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages,” Docket No.
TTB-2025-0002, 90 Fed. Reg. 6654 (January 17, 2025) 90 Fed. Reg.
14932 (April 7, 2025) (extending comment period) (“Biden-proposed
Alcohol Facts Rule’)

This letter presents comments of the National Federation of Independent Business
(NFIB)' on the Department of the Treasury Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau
(TTB) Allergen Labeling and Alcohol Facts proposed rules cited above. NFIB finds it
hard to understand why the Department of the Treasury and the Office of Management
and Budget continue to pursue these Biden Administration proposals that would place
heavy and unwarranted burdens on the small businesses of America in the beer, wine,
and spirits industry. NFIB recommends and requests that the Treasury Department
withdraw both Biden proposals.

1 NFIB is an incorporated nonprofit association representing small and independent businesses. NFIB
protects and advances the ability of Americans to own, operate, and grow their businesses and ensures
that governments of the United States and the fifty states hear the voice of small business as they
formulate public policies. America’s small businesses participate in the beer, wine, and spirits industries.
TABLE OF CONTENTS

1. The Biden-proposed Rules Aim Directly at the Small Businesses That Constitute
Most of the Beer, Wine, and Spirits Industry

2. TTB Did Not Get the President's Deregulatory Message
3. These Biden-proposed Rules Originated from a Flimsy Record

4. The Biden-proposed Allergen Labeling Rule Fails Legal, Truth, and
Analytical Requirements

5. The Biden-proposed Aicohol Facts Rule Fails Legal, Benefit-Cost, and
Analytical Requirements

eR RE

1. The Biden-proposed Rules Aim Directly at the Small Businesses
That Constitute Most of the Beer, Wine, and Spirits Indust

Census Bureau data from 2017 published by the Treasury Department? shows that
small businesses (here those with fewer than 20 employees) constitute most of the
beer, wine, and spirits industry:

Line of Number of Firms That Had

Business Total No. ofFirms Fewer Than 20 Employees Percentage
Breweries 3,214 2,609 81%
Wineries 3,576 2,975 83%
Distilleries 760 659 86%

In the Treasury Department report Competition in the Markets for Beer, Wine, and
Spirits (February 2022), the Department stated that the United States had more than
6,400 operating breweries, 6,600 operating wineries, and 1,900 operating distilleries.
The report further stated: “While larger firms account for significant market share, the
number of smaller brewers, vintners, and distillers, often called the craft sector, has

2 90 Fed. Reg. at 5775, col. 1.

? Department of the Treasury, Competition in the Markets for Beer, Wine, and Spirits (February 2022), p.
2, available at https://nome.treasury.gowsystem/files/136/Competition-Report.pdf (visited July 25, 2025).
grown dramatically but still occupies only a small share of the market.’ Thus, the
Government's own data makes clear that, when the Treasury Department aims new
labeling requirements at the beer, wine, and spirits industry, it hits primarily small
businesses.5 The two Biden-proposed rules fail to recognize the practicalities of
running small businesses and fail to make the adjustments for small businesses that the
congressional policy stated in the Regulatory Flexibility Act contemplates.®

Small businesses, unlike the corporate behemoths in the beer, wine, and spirits industry
whose names and fortunes most everyone knows, cannot afford the bevy of lawyers
and experts necessary to decipher the rules and physically implement them, let alone
afford the cost of changes in processing and machinery to accommodate them.
Regulatory compliance costs small business owners time and money, both of which are
generally in short supply as they strive to keep their small businesses going, meet their
customers’ needs, and create jobs. The Biden-proposed rules would impose
unaffordable, unwarranted costs on small businesses and constitute an anti-competitive
barrier for small businesses that cannot afford such costs in comparison to the giants in
the industry who can.

The Biden-proposed Allergen Labeling Rule and the Biden-proposed Alcohol Facts Rule
fail to take appropriate account of the needs of small businesses as called for in the
Regulatory Flexibility Act (RFA).” In paragraph 2(a)(4) of the RFA, Congress declared
that “the failure to recognize differences in the scale and resources of regulated entities
has in numerous instances adversely affected competition in the marketplace,

4 Department of the Treasury, Competition in the Markets for Beer, Wine, and Spirits (February 2022), p.
8.

5 Indeed, the Department of the Treasury admitted, in explaining the Biden-proposed Allergen Labeling
Rule, that “most businesses subject to the proposed rule are small businesses ....” 90 Fed, Reg. at
5775, col. 2.

§ As the adoption in 1919 of the 18th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution prohibiting the manufacture,
sale, or transportation of intoxicating liquors and its repeal in 1933 by the 21st Amendment reflect,
differing views exist among Americans about whether, to what extent, and under what conditions sale and
consumption of alcoholic beverages should occur, and the relevance of and weight to give to health,
moral, and religious factors in addressing those matters. NFIB expresses in this letter no view on these

President Trump noted that America’s small businesses employ nearly half the
country’s private work force and create two-thirds of net new jobs, and said:

My Administration is unleashing a new era of opportunity for small businesses built
on common sense and pro-growth policies that put our workers and our job creators
first. We are cutting red tape, keeping taxes low, promoting fair and reciprocal trade
practices, and fighting for hardworking Americans.°

To help make true what the President said about putting job creators first and cutting
red tape, the Treasury Department needs to withdraw the Biden-proposed Allergen
Labeling Rule and the Biden-proposed Alcohol Facts Rule.

2. TTB Did Not Get the President's Deregula’ Message

President Trump could not have been clearer to the federal bureaucracies that they
should seek to deregulate, rather than further regulate, the American economy.

On January 31, 2025 -- eleven days after President Trump took office and fourteen days
after TTB published in the Federal Register the Biden-proposed Allergen Labeling Rule
and the Biden-proposed Alcohol Facts Rule, President Trump issued Executive Order
14192 on “Unleashing Prosperity Through Deregulation.” The President said: “The
ever-expanding morass of complicated Federal regulation imposes massive costs on
the lives of millions of Americans, creates a substantial restraint on our economic
growth and ability to build and innovate, and hampers our global competitiveness.” He
also said: “It is the policy of my Administration to significantly reduce the private

not proposing them. One option considered was to exempt small businesses from the requirements of
the proposed rule. The primary purpose of this proposed rule is to provide information to consumers who
are allergic to one or more of the nine major food allergens. This purpose would be weakened by a
permanent exemption for small businesses. Consumers would not be able to rely on alcohol beverage
labels to disclose the presence of major food allergens if the requirements did not apply to all such
products.”). Thus, the Treasury Department did precisely the kind of dismissive, one-size-must-fit-all
pseudo-consideration of a small business alternative that the Regulatory Flexibility Act was designed to
combat.

expenditures required to comply with Federal regulations to secure America’s economic
prosperity and national security and the highest possible quality of life for each citizen.”
He emphasized that “[i]t is the policy of the executive branch . . . to alleviate
unnecessary regulatory burdens placed on the American people.” *°

On February 19, 2025, the President issued Executive Order 14219 on “Ensuring
Lawful Governance and Implementing the President's ‘Department of Government
Efficiency’ Deregulatory Initiative.” The President made clear that agency heads should
identify regulations that undermine the national interest, including “regulations that
impose significant costs upon private parties that are not outweighed by public benefits”
and “regulations that impose undue burdens on small businesses and impede private
enterprise and entrepreneurship.”*'

On April 9, 2025, the President issued Executive Order 14267 on “Reducing Anti-
Competitive Regulatory Barriers.” The order stated: “Federal regulations should not
predetermine economic winners and losers.” The order further stated: “Regulations that
reduce competition, entrepreneurship, and innovation -- as well as the benefits they
create for American consumers -- should be eliminated.” The President directed
agency heads to identify anti-competitive regulations that “impose anti-competitive ...
distortions on the operation of a free market.”!2

These are not old orders by other Presidents that the bureaucracies can safely (though
improperly) ignore. These are not Executive Musings, Executive Wishes, or Executive
Suggestions to the bureaucracies. These are Executive Orders to the bureaucracies,
issued by the President the American people elected to direct those bureaucracies.

To comply with the clear anti-regulation, pro-competition policies the President set in the
quoted Executive Orders, the Treasury Department needs to withdraw the Biden-
proposed Allergen Labeling Rule and the Biden-proposed Alcohol Facts Rule. And the
Department of the Treasury should draw Executive Orders 14192, 14219, and 14267 to
the specific attention of the head of TTB and the departmental supervisors of the head
of TTB, to help the Department avoid issuance in the future of regulatory proposals that
unreasonably burden small and other businesses.

3. These Biden-proposed Rules Originated from a Flimsy Record

TTB says'® it pursued the Biden-proposed rules based on two things: (1) a finding and a
recommendation in the Treasury Department February 2022 report titled Competition in
the Markets for Beer, Wine, and Spirits '4 (“Treasury Competition Report”), and (2) a
February 24, 2021, letter from the Center for Science in the Public Interest (CSPI)'®
joined by six other organizations. Those documents, whether considered individually or
together, do not provide a reasonable and practical basis for pursuing the Biden-
proposed rules.

Regarding the Treasury Competition Report, TTB quotes'® the Executive Summary at
the front of the Report finding it a matter of concern that “[rjegulatory proposals that
could serve public health and foster competition by providing information to consumers,
such as mandatory allergen, nutrition, and ingredient labeling proposals, have not been
implemented”? and a recommendation at the other end of the report stating that “TTB
should revive or initiate rulemaking proposing ingredient labeling and mandatory
information on alcohol content, nutritional content, and appropriate serving sizes.”!® In
between the finding at the front of the report and the recommendation at the back of the
report, a scant five paragraphs’? addressed the matters that ended up in the
recommendation, and none of it was science as opposed to expressions of views by
commenters or views of the TTB itself. So, the Treasury Competition Report
recommendation provides no real justification for proceeding with the Biden-proposed
Allergen Labeling Rule. Moreover, although the finding mentioned allergen labeling, the
recommendation does not mention allergen labeling -- it mentions only ingredient
labeling, alcohol content, nutritional content, and appropriate serving sizes. It was
therefore misleading for TTB to state in the preamble to the Biden-proposed Allergen

The CSPI letter of February 24, 2021, represented the view of seven organizations that
exist to advocate particular views, in this case not favorable to the beer, wine, and

Consumer Federation of America, Breast Cancer Prevention Partners, National

4. The Biden-proposed Allergen Labeling Rule Fails
Legal, Truth, and Analytical Requirements

In addition to the heavy and unwarranted compliance burden the Biden-proposed
Allergen Labeling Rule imposes on small businesses, TTB has no lawful basis to issue
the rule, the rule compels untruthful speech, and TTB failed to conduct and provide the
benefit-cost analyses required by law and Executive Order.

First, no federal agency has any power whatsoever unless Congress has by law
conferred that power on the agency,’ and the law does not provide the Treasury
Department allergen labeling authority. The Treasury Department claims authority to
impose the Biden-proposed Allergen Labeling Rule under section 105(e) of the Federal
Alcohol Administration Act.22 The current absence of labeling about major allergens by
the beer, wine, and distilled spirit industry does not involve actual or alleged deception,
misleading of consumers, inaccurate statements, disparaging, false, misleading,
obscene, or indecent statements, or misleading brand or trade names, so the only

labeling authority. Accordingly, the Treasury Department lacks fegal authority to issue
the Biden-proposed Allergen Labeling Rule.

TTB forces compelled speech upon the manufacturers of beer, wine, and distilled spirits
with its labeling requirement, but it is truly beyond the pale for TTB to compel speech
that is untrue. Proposed 27 CFR 4.32, 5.63, and 7.63 require, respectively, a wine,

the production of” the item.25 But it may be possible in some cases to use a major

allergen ending up in the beer, wine, or distilled spirits. TTB recognizes this possibility
in exempting from labeling a major allergen used in the production of distilled spirits if
the allergen was completely distilled so that no protein remains in the distilled spirits.7°
If an allergen is used in the production of wine, distilled spirits, or malt beverages, but

5. The Biden-proposed Alcohol Facts Rule Fails
Legal, Benefit-Cost, and Analytical Requirements

In addition to the heavy and unwarranted compliance burden the Biden-proposed
Alcohol Facts Rule imposes on small businesses, TTB has no lawful basis to issue the
rule, failed to conduct and provide the benefit-cost analyses required by law and
Executive Order, and failed to provide the initial regulatory flexibility analysis required by
law.

First, no federal agency has any power whatsoever unless Congress has by law
conferred that power on the agency,°2 and the law does not provide the Treasury
Department authority to impose the Biden-proposed Alcohol Facts rule. The Treasury
Department claims authority to impose alcohol facts labeling from two sources: (1)
chapter 51 and sections 5301, 5368, and 5412 of the Internal Revenue Code, and (2)
section 105(e) of the Federal Alcohol Administration Act.*? None of those statutes grant
the authority to impose the Alcohol Facts labeling that the Biden Administration
proposed.

Of the Internal Revenue Code (IRC) provisions the Treasury Department cites, only
three provisions approach the subject of labeling. Section 5301(a)(1) provides: “(a)
REQUIREMENTS.--Whenever in his judgment such action is necessary to protect the
revenue, the Secretary is authorized, by the regulations prescribed by him and permits
issued thereunder if required by him--(1) to regulate the kind, size, branding, marking,
sale, resale, possession, use, and reuse of containers (of a capacity of not more than 5
wine gallons) designed or intended for use for the sale of distilled spirits[.]’ Section
5368 provides:

(a) GAUGING AND MARKING.--All wine or wine spirits shall be locked, sealed, and
gauged, and shall be marked, branded, labeled, or otherwise identified, in such
manner as the Secretary may by regulations prescribe.

(b) MARKING.--Wines shall be removed in such containers (including vessels,
