Section 5412 provides: “Beer may be removed from the brewery for consumption or
sale only in hogsheads, packages, and similar containers, marked, branded, or labeled
in such manner as the Secretary may by regulation require, except that beer may be
removed from the brewery pursuant to section 5414 or by pipeline to contiguous distilled
spirits plants under section 5222.”

The three IRC provisions grant different authorities for distilled spirits, wine, and beer.
Section 5301(a)(1) grants branding and marking authority, but not labeling authority, for
distilled spirits. Section 5368 grants marking, branding, and labeling authority for wine.
Section 5412 grants marking, branding, and labeling authority for beer. From the
comparison of the language in the three provisions, it is clear that labeling is different
from marking and branding. So the first thing to note is that TTB has no authority to
impose the Alcohol Facts label on distilled spirits, especially given the inclusion of
labeling authority for wine and beer, but exclusion of it for distilled spirits.°* Note also
that the wine labeling authority is very limited under section 5368; it extends only to
labeling necessary for identification or to evidence “compliance with’ chapter 51 of the
Internal Revenue Code, neither of which reaches the Biden-proposed Alcohol Facts
Rule’s requirement for a label to show serving size, servings per container, alcohol by
volume, calories, carbohydrate, fat, or protein. With respect to beer, section 5412
grants a labeling authority as long as the beer leaves the brewery in a container.
Accordingly, the Treasury Department has no authority under the Internal Revenue
Code to impose the Biden-proposed Alcohol Facts Rule on distilled spirits, wine, or
beer, except possibly for beer that leaves a brewery in a container.

The Treasury Department claim of labeling authority under section 105(e) of the Federal
Alcohol Administration Act fares no better. The current absence of labeling on serving
size, servings per container, alcohol by volume, calories, carbohydrate, fat, or protein by
the beer, wine, and distilled spirit industry does not involve actual or alleged deception,
misleading of consumers, inaccurate statements, disparaging, false, misleading,
obscene, or indecent statements, or misleading brand or trade names, so the only
provision of section 105 under which the Treasury Department could claim Alcohol
Facts labeling authority is section 105(e)(2).

Section 105(e)(2) authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury to issue labeling regulations
for bottled distilled spirits, wine, or malt beverages “(2) as will provide the consumer with
adequate information as to the identity and quality of the products, the alcoholic content
thereof (except that statements of, or statements likely to be considered as statements

So, at the end of the day, TTB has no statutory authority require the Biden-proposed

Second, the Biden-proposed Alcohol Facts Rule imposes much cost to achieve little
benefit. TTB estimates that the proposed rule, if made applicable in five years, will cost
the industry $201.2 million over five years, or $40.2 million per year to implement
(figures expressed in 2023 dollars).** Also, recurring costs will occur in subsequent
years for as long as the rule remained in force. TTB’s negative statement that “TTB has
no reason to believe that the proposed rule would require industry members to
purchase new labeling equipment”? is a clever way of addressing the subject without
admitting that TTB cannot say affirmatively that the proposed rule will not require them
to purchase such new equipment. And, of course, with more costly regulatory labeling
requirements, new entrants to the industry will face higher entry costs than they
otherwise would have faced.

As for benefits, TTB admits that, even though it has been considering the subject of
alcohol facts labeling at least since December 2003, “TTB does not have data to
quantify the monetary benefits of the proposed rule[.]’“4 Again, TTB cleverly refers in
the absence of data to “the monetary benefits’ as opposed to “any monetary benefits,”
assuming, without having any supporting data, that there are some monetary benefits.
In the end, TTB cites only two purported benefits for the Biden-proposed Alcohol Facts
Rule:

TTB does not have data to quantify the monetary benefits of the proposed rule, but
as stated previously, the overall purpose of the proposed rule is to provide
consumers with more information about the identity, quality, and alcohol content of
alcohol beverages. This information will in turn enable consumers to follow advice

38 Loper Bright Enterprises v. Raimondo, 603 U.S. 369, 412 (2024).
4 24 U.S.C. 343(q).

41 90 Fed. Reg. at 6676, col. 1 and note 34.

42 90 Fed. Reg. at 6677, col. 1.

43 90 Fed. Reg. at 6656, col. 2.

44 90 Fed. Reg. at 6684, col 2.
14

about moderate alcohol consumption and will provide them with additional
information about the calorie and macronutrient content of alcohol beverages.

The first claimed benefit of the Biden-proposed Alcohol Facts labeling, that it will
“enable consumers to follow advice about moderate alcohol consumption,” hangs by a
thread. For the many consumers who do not read package labeling, the Alcohol Facts
labeling will have zero effect. And perhaps alcohol content and calorie counts would
mean something to some consumers who read an Alcohol Facts label, but
carbohydrate, fat, and protein numbers will mean little if anything to most consumers.
Also, only consumers who serve themselves (for example, bought beer at the grocery
store), and not those served in establishments (for example, served a drink at a table in
a bar), will have the chance to see any labeling at all. And, for those who see a label, it
might be useful to consider whether the alleged drinking deterrence of an Aicoho! Facts
label diminishes after one moderate drink (woman) or two moderate drinks (man) with
respect to whether another drink might occur.* And lastly, for some consumers, the
Alcohol Facts labeling may have an anti-moderation effect, as it enables a consumer to
compare alcoholic content of different beer, wines and spirits and select a drink with a
higher alcohol content than the consumer might otherwise have chosen. TTB should
take human behavior into account to a greater degree before it makes and relies on
assumptions about the effects of the Biden-proposed Alcohol Facts Rule.

The second claimed benefit of the Biden-proposed Alcohol Facts labeling, that it will
provide consumers “with additional information about the calorie and macronutrient
content of alcohol beverages,” is not a benefit -- it is merely a statement of what the
proposed rule allegedly does. It says nothing about what the impact will be of providing
the additional information. And, as mentioned above, many consumers will not see the
labeling, will ignore the labeling, will not understand the labeling, or, if they see the
labeling, will make decisions other than the TTB-desired moderation decision.

For the reasons set forth above, the costs of the Biden-proposed Alcohol Facts Rule
greatly outweigh the purported benefits of the proposed rule.

Thirdly, TTB’s failure to provide an initial regulatory flexibility analysis for the Biden-
proposed Alcohol! Facts rule plainly violates section 603 of title 5 of the U.S. Code.4”

4 90 Fed. Reg. at 6684, col. 2. TTB skips over the fact that the proposed rule’s mandated information
requirement goes far beyond “the identity, quality, and alcohol content” to reach serving size, servings per
container, alcohol by volume, calories, carbohydrate, fat, and protein.

48 The Dietary Guidelines for Americans published by the U.S. Department of Agriculture and the U.S.
Department of Health and Human Services, p. 18 (Key recommendation: “Alcoholic beverages—Adults of
legal drinking age can choose not to drink or to drink in moderation by limiting intake to 2 drinks or less in
a day for men and 1 drink or less in a day for women, when alcohol is consumed. Drinking less is better
for health than drinking more. There are some adults who should not drink alcohol, such as women who
are pregnant.”).

47 Section 603(a) of title 5 states in part: “Whenever an agency is required by section 553 of this title, or
any other law, to publish general notice of proposed rulemaking for any proposed rule, or publishes a
notice of proposed rulemaking for an interpretative rule involving the internal revenue laws of the United
15

TTB claims that it has no duty to provide such an analysis because section 605 of title 5
“allows the head of an agency to certify that a rule will not, if promulgated, have a
significant economic impact on a substantial number of small entities." And
immediately thereafter TTB states: “TTB certifies that this proposed rule, if adopted,
would not have a significant economic impact on a substantial number of small entities.
But that certification is plainly incorrect, by TTB’s own admissions in the preambles to
the proposed rules.

n

The data TTB provides in the preambles show more than 80% of the 7,550 enterprises
(a substantial number) in the beer, wine, and spirits industry are small businesses (in
this case, with fewer than 20 employees each) and that the implementation costs of the
proposed rule exceed $40 million per year over five years (without even taking account
of recurring costs).42 The TTB’s implementation cost estimate per enterprise, then, is
$5,298 per year. So, TTB estimates, each of the small businesses would spend $5,298
per year in the first five years, plus recurring costs on into the future, to carry out the
Biden-proposed Alcohol Facts Rule. With the average small business owner making
about $69,000 per year,®° it is plain that a new $5,298 per year government-imposed
charge on small businesses with the proposed rule is significant.

Particularly galling is the statement TTB made in attempting (but failing) to justify its
decision to certify that the proposed rule has no significant economic impact on a
substantial number of small entities:

The production, bottling, importation, and distribution of alcohol beverages is an
industry subject to extensive Federal, State, and local regulation. The labeling and
advertising regulations under the FAA Act have been in place since 1936. Adding
more elements of mandatory information to the label will not have a significant
impact on the regulated industry.°!

The TTB attitude that the industry is already so highly regulated on labeling that adding
more labeling requirements really does not matter is appalling, contrary to presidential
policy, and contrary to law. TTB had a duty to publish an initial regulatory flexibility
analysis under section 603 of title 5 and failed to comply with that law.

kkKEK

States, the agency shall prepare and make available for public comment an initial regulatory flexibility
analysis.”

48 90 Fed. Reg. at 6685, col. 3.

48 90 Fed. Reg. at 5775, col. 1 (percentage of small businesses) and 90 Fed. Reg. at 6676, col. 1 (dollar
costs).

5° “Top Small Business Statistics,” Forbes Advisor (as of January 31, 2024), Item 16, available at
https:/Awww. forbes. com/advisor/business/small-business-
statistics/#small_business_ownership_statistics_section (visited July 25, 2025).

51 90 Fed. Reg. at 6687, col. 1.
16

NFIB recommends and requests that the Department of the Treasury withdraw the rules
on Allergen Labeling and Alcohol Facts proposed by the Biden Administration three
days before he left office. The Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau of the
Department of the Treasury has no legal authority to promulgate the Biden-proposed
rules and failed to provide the regulatory analyses required in proposing the rules. And
the proposed rules run flatly contrary to the deregulatory policies President Trump has
established by executive order. Withdrawal of the Biden-proposed Allergen Labeling
and Alcohol Facts rules will prevent imposition of unwarranted, burdensome, and costly
rules on small businesses in the beer, wine, and spirits industry.

Tell,

David S. Addington
Executive Vice President and General Counsel

comment_text: I am writing in strong support of the proposed rule requiring "Alcohol Facts" labeling on wines, distilled spirits, and malt beverages. This rule represents a long-overdue step toward transparency and consumer protection in the labeling of alcoholic beverages. From a public health standpoint, requiring clear, accessible, and standardized information on alcohol product packaging is essential to empower consumers to make informed choices that support their health and safety. Alcohol is one of the few consumer products ingested orally that is not currently subject to standardized, comprehensive labeling requirements. Unlike packaged foods and non-alcoholic beverages, alcoholic products are not required to list basic information such as calories, ingredients, allergens, or nutrients. This lack of labeling leaves consumers in the dark and undermines their ability to make informed decisions. The public health consequences of excessive alcohol consumption are well documented, ranging from motor vehicle accidents and injuries to chronic conditions such as liver disease, cardiovascular disease, and multiple types of cancer. Additionally, alcohol is calorie-dense and contributes significantly to daily energy intake—on average, 9% of daily calories for people who drink. Many products also contain sugars and carbohydrates that contribute to obesity, diabetes, and other chronic illnesses. Requiring Alcohol Facts labeling is a simple, commonsense measure that promotes consumer awareness and aligns alcoholic beverages with the labeling standards already applied to virtually all other consumable products. Support for the Proposed Rule I support this proposed rule as a crucial step forward in advancing transparency, consumer rights, and public health. The inclusion of Alcohol Facts labeling on the packaging of all wine, spirits, and malt beverages is vital to help consumers better understand what they are drinking. In particular, I urge TTB to require that Alcohol Facts be displayed directly on the container and not solely via electronic means, such as QR codes. Electronic-only access to this information would create an unnecessary barrier, especially for populations who are older, lower income, live in rural or tribal areas, or have limited access to smartphones or internet services. On-package labeling ensures equity and accessibility for all consumers. Recommendations to Strengthen the Rule While this proposal is a major advance, several key improvements would enhance its effectiveness: Include Number of Standard Drinks and Moderate Drinking Advice: Consumers need more than nutrient data—they need context. To help consumers understand how much alcohol they are actually consuming, labels should include the number of standard drinks per container and a statement of the Dietary Guidelines for Americans' advice on moderate drinking. This will help align consumer behavior with public health recommendations and provide essential context for evaluating alcohol content. Make Dual-Column Labeling Mandatory: The current proposal allows for voluntary dual-column labeling. However, mandatory dual-column labels—showing nutrition information per serving and per container—are critical, particularly for multi-serving containers such as bottles of wine or large malt beverages. Consumers often consume the entire container, and per-serving-only labeling may mislead or obscure the true nutritional and alcohol content. Expand the Required Nutrient Information: The proposed rule includes calories, carbohydrates, protein, and fat. While this is a solid foundation, labels should also be required to include added sugars, saturated fat, and sodium, which are nutrients that the Dietary Guidelines for Americans recommend limiting due to their connection with major chronic diseases. Including these elements would bring alcohol labels in line with FDA-regulated nutrition labeling for food and beverages. Shorten the Compliance Timeline: TTB has proposed a five-year compliance period. Given how long this issue has been under consideration, and the urgency of providing this information to consumers, I urge TTB to adopt a shorter compliance period of 3.5 years. Manufacturers have had decades of notice that such labeling may be required, and a prompt timeline reflects the seriousness of the public health need. Consumers have a right to know what is in the products they drink. Alcohol is no exception—especially given its known health risks, high calorie content, and widespread consumption. Transparent, consistent, and accessible labeling is essential to public health efforts to reduce alcohol-related harm and improve population health outcomes. I commend TTB for this important proposal and encourage the agency to further strengthen it by implementing the above recommendations. Sincerely, Maria Kovell
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
I am writing in strong support of the proposed rule requiring “Alcohol Facts” labeling on wines, distilled spirits, and malt beverages. This rule represents a long-overdue step toward transparency and consumer protection in the labeling of alcoholic beverages. From a public health standpoint, requiring clear, accessible, and standardized information on alcohol product packaging is essential to empower consumers to make informed choices that support their health and safety.

Alcohol is one of the few consumer products ingested orally that is not currently subject to standardized, comprehensive labeling requirements. Unlike packaged foods and non-alcoholic beverages, alcoholic products are not required to list basic information such as calories, ingredients, allergens, or nutrients. This lack of labeling leaves consumers in the dark and undermines their ability to make informed decisions.

The public health consequences of excessive alcohol consumption are well documented, ranging from motor vehicle accidents and injuries to chronic conditions such as liver disease, cardiovascular disease, and multiple types of cancer. Additionally, alcohol is calorie-dense and contributes significantly to daily energy intake—on average, 9% of daily calories for people who drink. Many products also contain sugars and carbohydrates that contribute to obesity, diabetes, and other chronic illnesses.

Requiring Alcohol Facts labeling is a simple, commonsense measure that promotes consumer awareness and aligns alcoholic beverages with the labeling standards already applied to virtually all other consumable products.

Support for the Proposed Rule

I support this proposed rule as a crucial step forward in advancing transparency, consumer rights, and public health. The inclusion of Alcohol Facts labeling on the packaging of all wine, spirits, and malt beverages is vital to help consumers better understand what they are drinking.

In particular, I urge TTB to require that Alcohol Facts be displayed directly on the container and not solely via electronic means, such as QR codes. Electronic-only access to this information would create an unnecessary barrier, especially for populations who are older, lower income, live in rural or tribal areas, or have limited access to smartphones or internet services. On-package labeling ensures equity and accessibility for all consumers.

Recommendations to Strengthen the Rule

While this proposal is a major advance, several key improvements would enhance its effectiveness:

Include Number of Standard Drinks and Moderate Drinking Advice:
Consumers need more than nutrient data—they need context. To help consumers understand how much alcohol they are actually consuming, labels should include the number of standard drinks per container and a statement of the Dietary Guidelines for Americans' advice on moderate drinking. This will help align consumer behavior with public health recommendations and provide essential context for evaluating alcohol content.

Make Dual-Column Labeling Mandatory:
The current proposal allows for voluntary dual-column labeling. However, mandatory dual-column labels—showing nutrition information per serving and per container—are critical, particularly for multi-serving containers such as bottles of wine or large malt beverages. Consumers often consume the entire container, and per-serving-only labeling may mislead or obscure the true nutritional and alcohol content.

Expand the Required Nutrient Information:
The proposed rule includes calories, carbohydrates, protein, and fat. While this is a solid foundation, labels should also be required to include added sugars, saturated fat, and sodium, which are nutrients that the Dietary Guidelines for Americans recommend limiting due to their connection with major chronic diseases. Including these elements would bring alcohol labels in line with FDA-regulated nutrition labeling for food and beverages.

Shorten the Compliance Timeline:
TTB has proposed a five-year compliance period. Given how long this issue has been under consideration, and the urgency of providing this information to consumers, I urge TTB to adopt a shorter compliance period of 3.5 years. Manufacturers have had decades of notice that such labeling may be required, and a prompt timeline reflects the seriousness of the public health need.

Consumers have a right to know what is in the products they drink. Alcohol is no exception—especially given its known health risks, high calorie content, and widespread consumption. Transparent, consistent, and accessible labeling is essential to public health efforts to reduce alcohol-related harm and improve population health outcomes.

I commend TTB for this important proposal and encourage the agency to further strengthen it by implementing the above recommendations.

Sincerely,
Maria Kovell

comment_text: My name is Terrence Spain, and I am a public health professional and a parent. Excess alcohol usage among adults and easy access to alcohol by youth is a major issue in my area of the country and contributes to poor school attendance, juvenile crime, domestic violence, and alcohol related car crashes. I agree that alcohol labeling is in important, but I also want to ensure that the labels clearly state how much they are drinking, number of standard drinks and the dietary guidelines for Americans moderate drinking advice. Also, to provide consumers with access to this basic information, TTB should adopt a shorter compliance period of 3.5 years instead of the 5- year period proposed.

comment_text: To Whom It May Concern, Thank you for the opportunity to comment on the proposed rule to require Alcohol Facts labeling on wines, distilled spirits, and malt beverages. Recover Alaska strongly supports this rule as a long-overdue and commonsense step toward transparency that will help protect public health and empower consumers to make more informed choices. Recover Alaska is a statewide multi-sector coalition working to reduce excessive alcohol use and its harms across our state. Alaska experiences some of the highest alcohol-related death rates in the country. In 2021, our alcohol-induced mortality rate was more than twice the national average, and Alaska continues to grapple with the ripple effects of alcohol misuse—including high rates of suicide, domestic violence, and child maltreatment. These consequences are deeply felt in our rural and Tribal communities, which already face major health disparities and limited access to services. As a public health organization, we find it unacceptable that alcohol—the only consumable product in the U.S. directly linked to seven types of cancer—is not required to carry a standard nutrition or content label. Consumers have a right to know what is in the products they consume, just as they do with food, tobacco, and other regulated substances. We urge TTB to finalize and strengthen this proposed rule in the following ways: 1. Require On-Package Alcohol Facts Labels Vital health information should not be relegated to QR codes or websites. Labels must appear directly on alcohol packaging to ensure accessibility—especially for people in rural or remote regions, older adults, and those without reliable internet or smartphones. In Alaska, this is particularly relevant where broadband access is limited and supply chains are complex. 2. Include Number of Standard Drinks and DGA Guidance To support informed drinking decisions, labels should include the number of standard drinks per container and refer to the Dietary Guidelines for Americans' advice on moderate drinking. This helps consumers relate alcohol content to recommended limits and personal health goals. 3. Mandate Dual-Column and Expanded Nutrition Labeling Dual-column labeling (per serving and per container) should be mandatory, not voluntary. Many consumers unknowingly consume an entire container of alcohol in one sitting. Additionally, the Alcohol Facts panel should require disclosure of nutrients the DGA advises limiting: added sugars, saturated fat, and sodium. 4. Shorten the Compliance Period to 3.5 Years Public health and safety cannot wait five more years. A 3.5-year compliance period strikes a more appropriate balance between industry readiness and consumers' right to know what they're drinking. As communities and families in Alaska continue to face the heavy burden of alcohol-related harm, this rule represents a simple yet powerful step toward awareness, prevention, and accountability. We commend the TTB for proposing this rule and urge its swift adoption with the enhancements outlined above. Thank you for your leadership in protecting public health through meaningful, transparent alcohol policy. Sincerely, Tiffany Hall President & CEO Recover Alaska
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
To Whom It May Concern,
Thank you for the opportunity to comment on the proposed rule to require Alcohol Facts labeling on wines, distilled spirits, and malt beverages. Recover Alaska strongly supports this rule as a long-overdue and commonsense step toward transparency that will help protect public health and empower consumers to make more informed choices.
Recover Alaska is a statewide multi-sector coalition working to reduce excessive alcohol use and its harms across our state. Alaska experiences some of the highest alcohol-related death rates in the country. In 2021, our alcohol-induced mortality rate was more than twice the national average, and Alaska continues to grapple with the ripple effects of alcohol misuse—including high rates of suicide, domestic violence, and child maltreatment. These consequences are deeply felt in our rural and Tribal communities, which already face major health disparities and limited access to services.
As a public health organization, we find it unacceptable that alcohol—the only consumable product in the U.S. directly linked to seven types of cancer—is not required to carry a standard nutrition or content label. Consumers have a right to know what is in the products they consume, just as they do with food, tobacco, and other regulated substances.
We urge TTB to finalize and strengthen this proposed rule in the following ways:
1.Require On-Package Alcohol Facts Labels
Vital health information should not be relegated to QR codes or websites. Labels must appear directly on alcohol packaging to ensure accessibility—especially for people in rural or remote regions, older adults, and those without reliable internet or smartphones. In Alaska, this is particularly relevant where broadband access is limited and supply chains are complex.
2.Include Number of Standard Drinks and DGA Guidance
To support informed drinking decisions, labels should include the number of standard drinks per container and refer to the Dietary Guidelines for Americans’ advice on moderate drinking. This helps consumers relate alcohol content to recommended limits and personal health goals.
3.Mandate Dual-Column and Expanded Nutrition Labeling
Dual-column labeling (per serving and per container) should be mandatory, not voluntary. Many consumers unknowingly consume an entire container of alcohol in one sitting. Additionally, the Alcohol Facts panel should require disclosure of nutrients the DGA advises limiting: added sugars, saturated fat, and sodium.
4.Shorten the Compliance Period to 3.5 Years
Public health and safety cannot wait five more years. A 3.5-year compliance period strikes a more appropriate balance between industry readiness and consumers’ right to know what they’re drinking.
As communities and families in Alaska continue to face the heavy burden of alcohol-related harm, this rule represents a simple yet powerful step toward awareness, prevention, and accountability. We commend the TTB for proposing this rule and urge its swift adoption with the enhancements outlined above.
Thank you for your leadership in protecting public health through meaningful, transparent alcohol policy.
Sincerely,

Tiffany Hall
President & CEO
Recover Alaska

document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
Comment on Proposed Rule: Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, 
Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages (Docket No. TTB-2025-0002) 
Submitted by: Recover Alaska 
Date: August 7, 2025 
To Whom It May Concern, 
Thank you for the opportunity to comment on the proposed rule to require Alcohol Facts 
labeling on wines, distilled spirits, and malt beverages. Recover Alaska strongly supports 
this rule as a long-overdue and commonsense step toward transparency that will help 
protect public health and empower consumers to make more informed choices. 
Recover Alaska is a statewide multi-sector coalition working to reduce excessive alcohol 
use and its harms across our state. Alaska experiences some of the highest alcohol-related 
death rates in the country. In 2021, our alcohol-induced mortality rate was more than twice 
the national average, and Alaska continues to grapple with the ripple effects of alcohol 
misuse—including high rates of suicide, domestic violence, and child maltreatment. These 
consequences are deeply felt in our rural and Tribal communities, which already face major 
health disparities and limited access to services. 
As a public health organization, we ﬁnd it unacceptable that alcohol—the only consumable 
product in the U.S. directly linked to seven types of cancer—is not required to carry a 
standard nutrition or content label. Consumers have a right to know what is in the products 
they consume, just as they do with food, tobacco, and other regulated substances. 
We urge TTB to ﬁnalize and strengthen this proposed rule in the following ways: 
1. Require On-Package Alcohol Facts Labels 
Vital health information should not be relegated to QR codes or websites. Labels 
must appear directly on alcohol packaging to ensure accessibility—especially for 
people in rural or remote regions, older adults, and those without reliable internet or 
smartphones. In Alaska, this is particularly relevant where broadband access is 
limited and supply chains are complex. 
2. Include Number of Standard Drinks and DGA Guidance 
To support informed drinking decisions, labels should include the number of 
standard drinks per container and refer to the Dietary Guidelines for Americans’  
advice on moderate drinking. This helps consumers relate alcohol content to 
recommended limits and personal health goals. 
3. Mandate Dual-Column and Expanded Nutrition Labeling 
Dual-column labeling (per serving and per container) should be mandatory, not 
voluntary. Many consumers unknowingly consume an entire container of alcohol in 
one sitting. Additionally, the Alcohol Facts panel should require disclosure of 
nutrients the DGA advises limiting: added sugars, saturated fat, and sodium. 
4. Shorten the Compliance Period to 3.5 Years 
Public health and safety cannot wait ﬁve more years. A 3.5-year compliance period 
strikes a more appropriate balance between industry readiness and consumers’ 
right to know what they’re drinking. 
As communities and families in Alaska continue to face the heavy burden of alcohol-
related harm, this rule represents a simple yet powerful step toward awareness, 
prevention, and accountability. We commend the TTB for proposing this rule and urge its 
swift adoption with the enhancements outlined above. 
Thank you for your leadership in protecting public health through meaningful, transparent 
alcohol policy. 
Sincerely, 
 
Tiffany Hall 
President & CEO 
Recover Alaska

CAMPARI AMERICA LLC 
1114 Avenue of the Americas, 19th Floor – New York, New York 10036 – USA

Washington, D.C.  20005  
 
Re:  Comments to TTB Notice No. 237: Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, 
Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages (Docket No. TTB–2025–0002) 
 
Dear Director Greenberg,  
 
Campari America LLC (“Campari America”), a producer and importer of distilled spirits in the 
United States, submits the following comments in response to the TTB’s Notice No. 237, “Alcohol Facts 
Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages ,” Docket No. TTB –2025–
0002.  Campari America is a subsidiary of Davide Campari -Milano N.V., which began in 1860 with its 
one eponymous brand.  Today, Campari America sells a wide range of beverage alcohol products in 
the United States, but is most well-known for its portfolio of liqueurs, including Campari, Aperol, Averna, 
Frangelico, Cynar, Braulio , and Grand Marnier .  Many of t hese brands, like those of many other 
suppliers, are not accurately represented in the TTB’s currently proposed serving size reference table, 
pasted below for reference, and which is the basis of our comment today.   
Serving size Alcohol percent by volume 
Wine Distilled spirits Malt beverages 
1.5 fl oz (44 mL), or 50 mL for 50 
mL containers of distilled spirits 
n/a > 24% > 24%. 
2.5 fl oz (74 mL) > 16, up to 24% > 16, up to 24% > 16, up to 24% 
5 fl oz (148 mL) 7 to 16% > 7, up to 16% > 7, up to 16% 
12 fl oz (355 mL) n/a ≤ 7% ≤ 7%. 
 
Proposed Serving Sizes Do Not Reflect How Low ABV Liqueurs Are Consumed in Cocktails 
 
The serving sizes recommended above are based in the assumption that the only means of 
drinking a wine, beer, or spirits beverage is straight, unmixed with other beverages.  While this may be 
mostly true for wine and beer, it is most certainly not true for distilled spirits which often serve as 
“ingredients” in a wide range of cocktails.  By way of example, Aperol , which has an ABV of 11%, is 
most commonly consumed in the form of an Aperol Spritz .  When making the brand’s signature 
cocktail, the typical amount of Aperol used is typically 2 ounces, i.e. less than half of what would be 
considered its reference serving size under the TTB’s proposal.  Another Aperol cocktail growing in 
Docusign Envelope ID: 4BF3A609-7A08-4604-B4FD-DE8BB7C974E2 
 
popularity is the Paper Plane (0.75 oz bourbon, 0.75 oz Aperol, 0.75 oz Amaro Nonino, and 0.75 oz 
lemon juice), in which the Aperol consumed is less than 1/5 of the TTB proposed serving size. 
Campari faces a similar issue.  While it can be served in a Campari Spritz (typically 1.5 to 2 
ounces), it is also popularly served in a Boulevardier (1 oz Campari, 1 .5 oz bourbon, and 1 oz sweet 
vermouth) or a Negroni (1 oz Campari, 1 oz gin, and 1 oz sweet vermouth) or a Negroni Sbagliato 
(substitute prosecco for gin ).  There is also the Americano (1oz Campari, 1oz sweet vermouth, and a 
splash of club soda) and the Garibaldi (1.5 oz Campari and the fresh juice of one orange, approximately 
4 oz). 
Examples of similar uses of other low-ABV liqueurs in cocktails abound.  Simply put, these are 
not products that are typically drunk straight.  So while the ABV of a lower proof distilled spirit may be 
similar to wine, it is not consumed in the same manner – thus using the same serving size as wine of 5 
oz., or even 2.5 oz, significantly overstates and distorts the actual serving size of these low ABV liqueurs 
in a way that is misleading and confusing for consumers.  
 
Proposed Serving Sizes Do Not Reflect How Ready-To-Drink Canned Products Are Consumed 
 
Conversely, for many other products, such as  ready-to-drink can s of  “hard” seltzers and 
cocktails, the currently proposed serving sizes greatly understate the actual serving sizes of these 
products.  These products are commonly sold in a 12 -oz can and can vary from 3.5% to 1 4% ABV.  
Spirits-based cocktails are not the only beverage alcohol products facing this issue:  many beers and 
other malt-based beverages now exceed 7% ABV yet are sold in the same 12 oz size cans.  Likewise, 
canned wines, with ABVs ranging from 8 to 15%, are also sold in sizes larger than the proposed serving 
size of 5 oz.  In these instances, having a serving size reference range that is less than the container 
size will certainly mislead consumers into thinking they are drinking less alcohol than they really are. 
 
Recommended Serving Sizes Already Have A Long-Established Framework and Methodology 
 
As a proposed solution, we recommend adopting an approach similar to  the methodology of 
the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for recommended serving sizes for food and non-alcoholic 
beverages.  The FDA creates reference points, known as “Reference Amounts Customarily Consumed” 
or “RACCs,” for different categories of food and beverage, and the FDA then recommends that 
manufacturers use those RACCs as a guideline for determining their advertised serving sizes.   
 
In the food and non -alcoholic beverage realm, FDA-required labelling became required in the 
1990s.  Consumers are long accustomed to this method of calculation of serving facts, with 
recommended or actual consumption amounts being the guiding factor in determining the size.   The 
general understanding of most consumers is that a serving size reflects the size portion of intended or 
typical consumption, or, in the case of single -serve packs, the container size, rather than being based 
on the amount of one of its components .  One analogy would be if the FDA mandated serving sizes 
based on the grams of protein in a product, such as 5g of protein equals one serving size.  This would 
result in a double serving size for a granola bar, and a very small serving size for beef jerky.  Similarly, 
the TTB’s proposed serving sizes are based on the amount of alcohol in a product, resulting in arbitrary 
and sometimes incorrect serving sizes.  The current proposed TTB’s serving sizes would conflict with 
Docusign Envelope ID: 4BF3A609-7A08-4604-B4FD-DE8BB7C974E2 
 
the general understanding of most consumers who have been conditioned for decades to perceive a 
serving size as the recommended amount and/or most customarily consumed amount. 
 
If the TTB were to adopt a serving size reference range that mirrors the FDA ’s process, this 
would allow consumers to buy products and understand serving sizes within a framework that they 
already know and are familiar with from the food and non -alcoholic beverage space.  This w ould also 
accommodate the realities of the types of drinks that consumers are currently havin g or making w ith 
beverage alcohol in the 4% to 30% ABV range and would minimize consumer confusion over  serving 
size, especially with respect to ready-to-drink canned products. 
 
Alternatively, if the TTB wants to maintain the serving size reference ranges proposed in Notice 
No. 237, then another recommendation would be for the TTB to allow an exception for suppliers to 
deviate from the proposed serving size reference range if they  can demonstrate that the proposed 
serving size does not reflect the actual amount of their product that is typically consumed.  This would 
allow the TTB to maintain the current framework but still provide flexibility for those suppliers whose  
products are typically consumed as one part of a cocktails. 
 
We thank you for your consideration of our comments.  If you have any questions or require 
additional information, please do not hesitate to contact me at sarah.bradley@campari.com. 
 
Sincerely, 
 
 
 
Sarah Bradley 
General Counsel, Americas and APAC 
 
Docusign Envelope ID: 4BF3A609-7A08-4604-B4FD-DE8BB7C974E2

comment_text: These comments are submitted on behalf of the European Commission, DG Internal Market, Industry, Entrepreneurship and SMEs (GROW) International Value Chains – A3.
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
COMMENTS FROM THE EUROPEAN UNION REGARDING NOTIFICATION  
G/TBT/N/USA/2183 and G/TBT/N/USA/2182 
Allergen and Nutrition Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt 
Beverages 
 
The European Union (EU) would like to thank the authorities of the United States 
of America for providing the opportunity to comment on the draft “ Major Food 
Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages ”, notified on 22 
January 2025 as G/TBT/N/USA/2183.  
The mandatory labelling of ‘Major Food Allergen’ referred to in the US proposed 
rulemaking includes fish ingredients. The listing of ‘fish’ would also be required 
when the processing aid isinglass or fish gelatine is used as a fining agent to clarify 
wines and beers. 
At a global level, in a report  (1) published last year, the FAO/WHO estimated the 
exposure details including gelatine and isinglass in wine and beer. The Expert 
Committee concluded that for the curren tly accepted exemptions (i.e. in the 
European Union , Australia, New Zealand, Argentina, Paraguay) there is an 
established history of safe consumption and that the exposure estimates at the 
reference dose - RfD/30 - level appears to provide an adequate marg in of 
exposure for derivative safety assessment. 
The EU invites the United States to consider the possible exclusion of isinglass or 
fish gelatine as a processing aid in wine and beer from mandatory allergen 
labelling. 
As regards the “ Alcohol Facts Stateme nts in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled 
Spirits, and Malt Beverages” notified on 22 January 2025 as G/TBT/N/USA/2182, 
the EU invites the United States of America to take into account Codex Guidelines 
on the use of technology to provide food information in food labelling  (CXG 105-
2024) and to consider whether some or all of the mandatory information particulars 
included in the “Alcohol Facts” could be provided to consumers using technology  
such as QR codes instead of on-pack labelling. The EU would furthermore like to 
highlight that none of the Codex standards or guidelines requires the mandatory 
indication of the quantity of pure ethyl alcohol on alcoholic beverages and that, 
contrary to the alcohol content by volume, this information is nearly never indicated 
on traded alcoholic beverages. 
Finally, concerning the proposed transition period, the EU welcomes the proposed 
5-years. In a similar vein, the EU requests that the United States grants the 
operators a possibility to exhaust all their stock which was put on the market before 
the proposed rule comes into effect. 
 
(1) FAO/WHO Report – Risk Assessment of Food Allergens; 
https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789240088924  
2 
 
The EU would be grateful if the above -mentioned comments could be taken into 
account and replied to before adoption of the notified draft. 
*** 
 
 
 
  
Electronically signed on 07/08/2025 11:43 (UTC+02) in accordance with Article 11 of Commission Decision (EU) 2021/2121

document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
T. NEAL MORRIS
nmorris@mcbravelfi rm. com MEElRAYER 20I EAST MAIN STREET, SUITE 9OO
LEXINGTON, KY 40507
859.23 l .8780 EXT. 1259
FAX:859.231.1175
l
August 8,2025
Uploaded to Regulations.sov
Director
Regulations and Rulings Division
Alcohol and Tobacco Trade and Tax Bureau
1310 G Street NW, Box l2
Washington, DC 20005
RE Notice No.os 237 & 238 - Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of
Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages; and Major Food
Allergen Labeling for Wineso Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
Comments of the Kentuckv Distillers' Association
Dear Director,
We are outside counsel for the Kentucky Distillers' Association, located in
Frankfort, Kentucky ("KDA"). The KDA is comprised of seventy-two distilled spirits
producers licensed and permitted in the Commonwealth of Kentucky, and the KDA and
its membership is thankful for the opportunity to provide high-level comments on
potential labelling changes for nutritional and allergen information on spirits packaging.
While the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau ("TTB") has issued two
notices of proposed rulemaking on complex labeling changes, we are choosing to submit
comments to both under a unified response as these issues are directly linked and raise
similar concerns for Kentucky's spirits industry. Please accept the following as the
KDA's comments relative to both Docket TTB-2025-002 (Notice No. 237) and Docket
TTB-2025-003 (Notice No. 238), relating to proposed changes to TTB regulations to
require the inclusion of alcohol fact and major food allergen statements on labels of
distilled spirits.
Since the KDA's founding in 1880, our mission has been to passionately and
responsibly promote, protect and elevate Kentucky's signature Bourbon and Distilled
Spirits Industry. We produce an estimated ninety-five percent (95%) of the world's
supply of Bourbon and our members have operations across the spirits categories. As
such, significant changes to current regulations would have an outsized financial and
administrative impact on our members.
Law Offices: Lexington I Louisville I Frankfort
Govennment Affains: Frankfont
mcbnayenf inm.comMtrBRAYER
Regulations and Rulings Division
Alcohol and Tobacco Trade and Tax Bureau
August 8,2025
Page 2
1. Increased Cost Burden to Producers
The KDA requests that TTB recognize that, first and foremost, the costs
associated with the proposed label changes would be significant for large and craft
producers alike. Nutritional sampling and testing would add substantial expense to
distilling operations and be unduly burdensome for smaller distillers who lack the staff
and capital to add this process. Additionally, reformatting and reprinting labels would be
an expensive undertaking. With our members producing so many different stock keeping
units ("SKUs"), these costs would be astronomical right out of the gate and the continued
testing would be cost prohibitive.
It is also important to note that so much information is already federally mandated
to be on spirits labels. Significant and meaningful data is already provided on spirits
labels, and any additions must balance consumer demand for information with economic
and logistical considerations, such as testing costs, limited labeling space, and expensive
packaging changes. Consumers trust what is labeled now and additional labeling real
estate devoted to unnecessary information might confuse the public, or worse, have them
ignore key labeling information altogether.
2. Alcohol Fact Statement Creating Confusion
The proposed requirements for the Alcohol Facts statement also introduces
redundancy to existing labeling requirements by requiring the percentage of alcohol by
volume ("ABV") be restated on the Alcohol Facts statement, in addition to the
requirement that ABV be presented on the front label. However, the proposal goes further
by requiring that the total quantity of pure ethyl alcohol be stated in fluid ounces as well,
which will result in customer confusion.
Customers are not used to seeing the quantity of alcohol in a beverage being
quantified in fluid ounces of pure ethyl alcohol. By redundantly including the ABV on
the Alcohol Facts statement in combination with a new measurement of quantity of
alcohol in a product, customers will be confused if those measurements are in conflict or
misinterpret the label entirely.
Further, as identified by TTB in Notice No. 238, the distillation process removes
proteins and the resulting spirits are therefore devoid of proteins. Yet, the proposed
Alcohol Facts statement would require distilled spirits to state the amount of protein in
the product, which will be zero. This would create customer confusion as a customer
would reasonably assume that seeing protein on a bottle of distilled spirits means that
there are some distilled spirits that do contain proteins.
tMtrBRAYER
Regulations and Rulings Division
Alcohol and Tobacco Trade and Tax Bureau
August 8,2025
Page 3
The KDA does not support the proposed Alcohol Facts statement as proposed due
to the inclusion of the fluid ounces of pure alcohol and proteins.
3. Digital Labeling Options
Spirits labels currently carry an abundance of consumer information. As
discussed, to keep consumers' attention and give them the ability to learn more about
certain products, a digital label or QR code would be a widely-accepted solution. Such
an approach would boost consumer confidence in the product and give buyers an easy
'click through' for the latest and more in-depth product information.
Moreover, digital labeling supports sustainability by reducing the need for
printing new labels every time regulations change, which can have significant
environmental impacts. The widespread use of smartphones in the U.S. (with almost
ninety-seven percent (97%) ownership) makes digital labeling a practical solution for
helping consumers make informed choices about dietary information while having less
environmental effects.
4. Major Allergens and the Distillation Process
As TTB properly observed, the distillation process removes all proteins -
including gluten - and major allergens from the resulting spirits. The end result of a
proper distillation produces an entirely gluten and allergen free spirit. Because distilled
spirits do not contain allergens or gluten post-distillation, the KDA supports the
exception provided for in proposed 27 CFR $ 5.75(bX2) specifically exempting distilled
spirits from disclosing allergens or proteins, unless allergens or proteins are introduced
post-distillation.
The KDA would suggest that the inclusion of language in the exemption
regarding TTB's testing of distilled spirits clarify that such testing will be on a case-by-
case basis, and not create a regulatory burden for distilled spirit plants and the TTB itself
by requiring lab analysis of every product.
If the proposed exception for distilled spirits is not included in the final
rulemaking, then the KDA opposes the requirement to disclose allergens and proteins due
to the scientific fact that protein and allergens are removed from the final distillation
product. Adding protein, not to mention other ingredients, to spirits labels would cause
tremendous consumer confusion-particularly those consumers who are trying to be
'gluten-free' due to diet or health concems. These consumers might not be aware about
gluten being removed from distillation and may misread bottles containing mash bill
information or just protein on the nutrition label and assume it is not safe to consume.
Including more language on already crowded distilled spirit labels will only amplifu theMEElRAYERI
Regulations and Rulings Division
Alcohol and Tobacco Trade and Tax Bureau
August 8,2025
Page 4
potential to confuse customers while creating misunderstanding among potential
customers.
5. Conclusion
As TTB considers additional labeling and allergen information, it is important to
consider how highly regulated the spirits industry already is. From traditional regulations
that consumers know and trust like the standards of identity that codifu Bourbon and
other spirits, to proof, age-requirements, and government warning labels, consumers are
already well-educated about distilled spirits products. Adding more could create nothing
more than confusion and indifference, all while adding burdensome costs and testing
inefficiencies.
Sincerely,
RRIS
TNM
4904-9883-6316, v. 1

comment_title: Comment 155:  Fédération des Exportateurs de Vins & Spiritueux de France (FEVS)
comment_text: Please, find enclosed comments on behalf of the Fédération des Exportateurs de Vins & Spiritueux de France (FEVS)
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
10, Rue Pergolèse – 75116 PARIS – Tel +33 1 45 22 75 73 – contact@fevs.com  
 
 
 
 
August 11
th, 2025 
 
 
Comments filed on behalf of FEVS (Fédération des Exportateurs de Vins et Spiritueux de France) 
 
Filed via www.regulations.gov 
 
 
Re: TTB‐2025‐0002: Alcohol Facts Statements in the labelling of wines, distilled spirits, and malt beverages 
 
 
The French Federation of Wine and Spirits Exporters (FEVS), appreciates the opportunity to submit comments 
on Notice No. 238 relative to Major Food Allergen Labelling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages. 
 
FEVS is the trade association representing the wine and spirit exporting companies of France. FEVS's 
membership comprises around 600 companies, international corporations as well as small businesses, with 
exports around 15.6 billion Euros in 2024 ($ 16.2 billion). The United States is the largest market in value for 
French wine and spirits exports worldwide (€3.8 billion / $3.9 billion). 
 
FEVS and its members are committed to providing wines and spirits in all price ranges to the American 
consumers, while ensuring that consumers are provided with adequate information as to the identity and 
quality of the wines and spirits they purchase. 
 
Therefore, FEVS is pleased to provide the following comments on TTB’s proposed rulemaking. 
 
 
On the title of the Alcohol Beverage Information Statement 
 
FEVS encourages TTB to adopt the tile “Serving Facts” rather than “Alcohol Facts”, as the proposed content 
of the statement refers to nutrition information in a serving of a specific alcoholic beverage, rather than 
information on alcohol. Therefore, the title “Alcohol Facts” could confuse consumers as it may suggest that 
the statement includes general indication on the consumption of alcoholic beverages. 
 
In addition, consumers are accustomed to the title “ Serving Facts” and to the fact that this is related to 
nutrition information of the beverage they intend to purchase or consume, since most operators who 
currently voluntarily disclose nutrition information use “ Serving Facts ”, as acknowledged by TTB in the 
Notice. As a consequence, choosing the “ Serving Facts” title would also limit costs of re -labelling for these 
operators. 
 
Lastly, FEVS believes that the similarity between “ Serving Facts”, which could apply to alcoholic beverages 
regulated under IRC, and “ Nutrition Facts”, required for alcoholic beverages regulated under FDA rules, is 
more beneficial to consumers as it ensures a kind of coherence on how the nutrition information is provided 
for all products proposed for sale on the market – even if the content of their respective statement may differ 
as proposed by TTB for the former. 
 
2 
On the content of the Alcohol Beverage Information Statement 
 
FEVS thanks TTB to take into account particularities of the wines and spirits production process and sector 
by proposing a content of a nutrition statement which is specific to alcoholic beverages compared to what 
is required for other food products through the FDA Nutrition Facts label. 
 
Nevertheless, FEVS would like to underline that wine or spirits do not contain fat or proteins and is wondering 
whether the compulsory presence of these two elements in a n Alcohol Beverage Information Statement 
would provide useful information to consumers when choosing which alcoholic beverage they want to 
purchase or drink. Whether TTB decides to keep these two elements and considering the limited space of 
wine and spirits labels, FEVS suggests allowing operators to replace these two lines by a unique sentence like 
“Contains negligible amounts of proteins and fat” at the bottom of the Statement. 
 
FEVS takes note of the voluntary sugar content  statement as proposed by TTB. In case operators choose to 
indicate it, FEVS kindly requests TTB to clarify how precisely they will have to label it and how the articulation 
with the carbohydrates content TTB intends to require will have to be made. 
 
More globally, FEVS would like to raise the attention of TTB regarding the difficulty adding other elements 
to the content of the Alcohol Beverage Information Statement, including through a voluntary approach, 
because of: 
• the non-relevance of nutrients like sodium, cholesterol, saturated fat… for alcoholic beverages, 
• the risk introducing nutrients like vitamins or minerals or percentage of the daily value may lead to 
unintended alcohol consumption behaviors, 
• the fact that the more information is added within the Alcohol Beverage Information Statement, the 
more the impact of the most relevant ones for consumers, notably calories, will be diluted, 
• the limited space available on wine and spirits packaging (compared to other food products), 
• the difficulty for operators to put in place the full traceability, risk assessment and analytical procedures 
to guarantee the loyalty and accurate content of such information, 
• the possible impact of such requirement on a trade perspective, for products imported into the US as 
well as for US wine and spirits exported to third countries. 
 
In case TTB is willing to require or to give operators the possibility to include additional elements in the 
Alcohol Beverage Information Statement, FEVS strongly encourages TTB to allow this statement to be 
provided by electronic means like QR-Code (see below). 
 
Finally, FEVS welcomes the tolerance of 20% above or below proposed by TTB as well as the use of “typical 
value” charts in order to ease the ability of wine and spirits operators, especially SMEs, fulfilling the envisaged 
requirements. FEVS strongly encourages TTB to work as far as possible with US trade partners to develop a 
coordinated approach on these “typical values”. 
 
FEVS would like also to stress the importance of including in the TTB regulation the notion of  “average 
values” a s defined by Codex Alimentarius for the nutrition declaration
1. Being complementary to 
tolerances, “average values” would allow operators to provide accurate information to consumers while 
avoiding the re-labelling of their products each year because of crops or evolution of the production method. 
 
 
On the alcohol content statement 
 
FEVS takes note of the TTB proposal requiring an alcohol content statement, expressed as a percentage of 
alcohol by volume, on the labels of all alcohol beverages products, as well as an indication of this statement 
 
1 See Point 3.5 of the Guidelines on Nutrition Labelling: “The values used in nutrient declaration should be weighted average values 
derived from data speciﬁcally obtained from analyses of products which are representative of the product being labelled.” 3 
within the existing  tolerances (in substitution of an indication in terms of ranges). This is aligned with EU 
rules and will ensure consistency in the presentation of products regardless of their alcohol content. 
 
FEVS would also appreciate whether TTB could clarify if this requirement would apply to non-alcoholic wines 
(less than 0.5% alcohol by volume) sold on the US market, too. 
 
On the other hand, FEVS asks TTB not to require the inclusion of the alcohol content in the Alcohol Beverage 
Information Statement. While practical modalities regarding the placement of the alcohol content may differ 
between malt beverages, distilled spirits or wines, c onsumers are used to find this information in the same 
field of vision of other compulsory particulars. In addition, under current TTB regulations, the alcohol content 
has to be labelled in a bigger type size than other compulsory information. Therefore, FEVS does not see why 
including alcohol content in the Alcohol Beverage Information Statement, among several other elements 
related to the product, will guarantee a better visibility or understanding for consumers. 
 
If TTB want s nevertheless going forward on this, FEVS kindly recommends proposing it as an option for 
operators, allowing them the possibility either to indicate the alcohol content as it is today or to include it in 
the Alcohol Beverage Information Statement. 
 
FEVS would also like to share concerns regarding the compulsory indication of the alcohol content in fluid 
ounces of pure alcohol. Firstly, concept of pure alcohol is not always well understood by consumers. Thus, 
providing this information without context would not necessarily empower consumers to make informed 
choices or to understand why and how it differs from the alcohol content expressed in volume by alcohol.  
Second, FEVS notes that TTB is allowing operators, in addition to these two elements, to indicate the alcohol 
content in degrees of proof ; meaning the same information could appear in three different forms in the 
Alcohol Beverage Information Statement. 
 
Beyond issues related to limited available space o n labels and to the complexity for foreign operators who 
do not usually use the fluid ounces of pure alcohol as unit of measurement, FEVS fears the proposed approach 
could lead to an important risk of confusion by consumers. 
 
In addition, FEVS tends to consider that a “per serving size” presentation could increase the difficulties for 
consumers to fully understand the elements provided in the Alcohol Beverage Information Statement. As 
rightly pointed out in the Notice, serving size reference amounts could be considered  by consumers as a 
recommended consumption amount rather than a way to determine the  alcohol, nutrient or calorie intake 
of a specific beverage. Besides, since serving size would have to differ depending on  the alcohol content of 
the product, this will prevent consumers from making comparisons between several alcoholic beverages on 
their respective nutritional impact, due to the lack of an identical basis for comparison. 
 
This approach will also lead to additional complexity for wine and spirits companies, especially exporters who 
are not used to managing serving size and/or will have to manage specific ones for the US market. 
 
FEVS would also like to recall that Codex Alimentarius recommends that the nutrition declaration should be 
expressed per 100 ml and “in addition, this information may be given per serving as quantified on the label“
2. 
 
Whether TTB confirms its intention to request nutrition information to be provided in pure alcohol per 
serving, FEVS strongly suggests TTB to allow the electronic display of these elements. Indeed, the presence 
of a QR -Code on a label could facilitate the provision of substantive information on the concepts of pure 
alcohol and standard drinks, including in relation with the US Dietary Guidelines for Americans  if relevant, 
which would not be practically feasible on a physical label. It  would also reduce the conformity c osts for 
operators, especially those non-US based,  thanks to  automatic calculation of nutrition content of their 
product and conversion of the figures into US unit measures (see below). 
 
 
 
2 See Point 3.4.2 and 3.43 of the Guidelines on Nutrition Labelling 4 
On the Alcohol Beverages Information Statement disclosure 
 
While acknowledging the flexibilities proposed by TTB for the display of the Alcohol Beverages Information 
Statement (ie, linear display option and lesser rules in terms of format and size on the panel), FEVS strongly 
reiterates its call to TTB for allowing these information to be distributed by electronic means. 
 
As previously raised, electronic labelling offers a wide range of advantages to both consumers and operators, 
especially SMEs. Indeed, this digital mean makes it possible: 
• for companies, to have a tool adapted to the variability of wines and spirits, thus limiting the costs of 
modifying packaging, while guaranteeing the loyalty of the information,  
• for the consumer, an easy and permanent access to information (including for people with disabilities), 
updated in real time and in his own language (in or outside the US territory), 
• for public authorities, to avoid the creation of barriers to trade by facilitating convergence of standards 
and administrative cooperation: 
o between the United States and wine and spirits exporting countries, 
o between federal regulations and the increasing number of labelling requirements in force at 
State level (e.g. with regard to beverage packaging deposits schemes). 
 
It also has to be noted that technological challenges (like adequacy of cellular or Wi-Fi coverage) or ability to 
access for particular communities are evolving very quickly, having in mind any final rule on Alcohol Beverage 
Information Statement would only apply in more than five years from now. 
 
In the EU, the labelling of energy and nutrition information and the list of ingredients is compulsory for wine 
products since December 2023 and the spirits sector commit to provide these information on a voluntary 
basis. The EU experience demonstrates the possibility of using the advantages of the QR -Code without 
lowering the ability of consumers to access  key information for their health and for making informed 
choice. Indeed, for companies willing to use digital means, EU regulations oblige them to indicate the calories 
amount as well as the allergens on the physical label, while other information, compulsory or not, are 
displayed online, via a direct and free of marketing information link. 
 
FEVS would like to underline how aligning EU and US requirements on nutrition and energy information 
would be beneficial for economic operators on both sides of the Atlantic, while allowing each party to keep 
its own preference on the content of the information to be provided according to its respective context. This 
would also allow the EU  and US to set a global standard which could support the development of digital 
technologies and avoid trade barriers in third countries market. 
 
In the case of physical labelling, FEVS requests to remove the black box around the Alcohol Beverage 
Information Statement, especially when provided in a linear format . This appear not to be proportionate 
or justified as the title “ Serving Facts” in bold type on a defined space which is a label is sufficient to allow 
consumers to easily locate the information on the packaging. 
 
On the implementation period 
 
FEVS welcomes the proposed 5-year transition period as well as the exemption from requiring new COLA 
when the only change being made to a label is the inclusion or alteration of the statement. 
 
In addition, FEVS kindly requests an unlimited inventory exhaustion clause which would allow operators to 
put on the US market products labelled in accordance with the current rules but before the entry into force 
of any compulsory labelling requirement of major food allergens. 
 
Finally, if TTB adopt s a final rule on Major Food Allergens labelling (as envisaged in Notice  of proposed 
rulemaking No. 238), FEVS asks for an identical date of entry into force for both regulations . This will 
prevent operators changing their label twice, with the disproportionate cost this approach could have for 
them, especially for SMEs.

comment_text: I am a prevention specialist and mother of a daughter in recovery. Her drug of choice was alcohol. Please consider labeling alcoholic beverages in a way that clearly informs consumers about the calories, alcohol and nutrient content and any risks associated with the product. All other products we consume have basic nutrient, calorie, allergen, and ingredient information, but when it comes to alcohol consumers are left in the dark by the lack of labeling. Excess alcohol consumption is associated with various harms including injuries, motor vehicle accidents, liver disease, cardiovascular disease, and certain cancers. Consumers must be better informed. I agree that the "Alcohol Facts" disclosure should be required to appear on-package and never solely via electronic means (a QR code leading to a webpage), as this would place a barrier between consumers and this vital information and specifically disadvantage populations that are less able to utilize smart phones or similar technology (e.g., those who are older, lower income, or living rurally or on tribal land). In order to provide consumers with access to this long-overdue, basic information, TTB should adopt a shorter compliance period of 3.5 years instead of the 5-year period proposed In summary please adopt clear labeling requirements to inform consumers about nutritional content, calories, alcohol content and warnings about cancer and other potential health hazards associated with alcoholic beverages. Thank you for your consideration.

All other products we consume have basic nutrient, calorie, allergen, and ingredient information, but when it comes to alcohol consumers are left in the dark by the lack of labeling.
Excess alcohol consumption is associated with various harms including injuries, motor vehicle accidents, liver disease, cardiovascular disease, and certain cancers.
Consumers must be better informed.
I agree that the “Alcohol Facts” disclosure should be required to appear on-package and never solely via electronic means (a QR code leading to a webpage), as this would place a barrier between consumers and this vital information and specifically disadvantage populations that are less able to utilize smart phones or similar technology (e.g., those who are older, lower income, or living rurally or on tribal land).

comment_text: See attached file(s)
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
**Comments from Argentina – Notice No. 237: Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages**

Title of the Alcohol Beverage Information Statement

*We consider that the title “Alcohol Facts” better describe the information provided inthe proposed statement.*

Mandatory Calorie and Nutrient Information

*Following the same rationale applied to nutritional information, sugar content should remain voluntary. If most alcohol beverages contain only minimal or negligible amounts of sugar, requiring its inclusion would provide little added value to consumers. Similarly, we agree with TTB’s assessment that sodium and other micronutrients should not be included, and we believe they should not be referenced in the proposal at all.*

*We believe that including daily value percentages for nutrients on alcohol beverage labels would be confusing for consumers. Such information could misleadingly suggest that alcohol contributes meaningfully to meeting daily nutritional requirements, which is not the case. Given the fundamental differences between alcoholic beverages and foods, adopting the Nutrition Facts format used by the FDA would not be appropriate in this context.*

*Given that many alcoholic beverages contain negligible amounts of nutrients beyond calories, requiring full nutrition facts similar to FDA food labels could be unnecessarily burdensome and confusing, potentially disadvantaging certain products in both domestic and international markets.*

Calculating Panel Elements and Tolerance Levels

*We support the proposed tolerances of ±20% and the use of "typical values" as a valid alternative to mandatory testing. Allowing broad tolerances and the use of tables or calculation methods to estimate nutrient levels is important to keep costs down and maintain competitiveness. Requiring precise in-house testing or sending products to third-party labs would create significant financial challenges, especially for small producers who make small batches and cannot spread testing costs over many units.*

Mandatory Listing of Alcohol by Volume on All Alcohol Beverage Products

*We have no objections to the proposal requiring an alcohol content statement expressed as a percentage of alcohol by volume on all alcohol beverage labels. This requirement does not pose any issues, as it is already mandatory in Argentina to indicate the alcohol content on all wines. Such labeling ensures transparency for consumers and aligns with existing international practices.*

Placement of Alcohol Content Statements as Part of the Alcohol Facts Statement

*While it is likely that including alcohol content information within the Alcohol Facts statement could make it easier for consumers to locate this information, this advantage may not be particularly significant. Consumers are generally accustomed to looking for alcohol content in various parts of the label, and the overall impact on their ability to find this information is expected to be minimal.*

*The implications of including the alcohol content within the Alcohol Facts statement should be carefully analyzed to avoid the requirement of declaring the alcohol content in two separate locations on the label. According to the World Wine Trade Group (WWTG) Agreement on Requirements for Wine Labeling, wines may display common mandatory information (CMI), including alcohol content, anywhere on the container’s surface visible within a single field of vision. This approach helps ensure clarity and prevents redundant labeling. Therefore, it is necessary to ensure compliance with the agreements established within the WWTG. If the information must appear in multiple locations on the label, this could increase label redesign and printing costs. Additionally, unclear placement requirements might lead to confusion among producers, complicating compliance efforts and potentially increasing administrative burdens. Moreover, having the alcohol content displayed in two different places with differing values could lead to labeling errors and mislead consumers.*

Mandatory Statement of Alcohol in Fluid Ounces of Pure Alcohol per Serving

*If it is mandatory to indicate the alcohol content as a percentage by volume, requiring additional information about the alcohol content per serving size or standard drink would be redundant and could potentially confuse or mislead consumers. Providing multiple measures of alcohol content on the label may create inconsistency and make it harder for consumers to clearly understand the actual alcohol strength of the product.*

Linear Display, Type Size, and Electronic Display of Alcohol Facts Information

a. Linear Display

*We believe it would be appropriate to provide the option for Alcohol Facts information to be presented either in a panel or linear format, as proposed.*

b. Type Size

*We agree with the proposal that the minimum type size requirements for Alcohol Facts statements should mirror the existing type size requirements for mandatory information*

c. Electronic Display of Alcohol Facts Information

*We suggest allowing the possibility of using electronic means, such as QR codes, to present this information, especially for small containers or labels with limited space, while ensuring that mandatory physical labeling remains the minimum requirement.*

Serving Size Reference Amounts

*Proposed serving size amounts should be reference values only. Each consumer, if interested, can evaluate their total intake of alcohol, nutrients, and calories when consuming amounts greater than the reference serving size. The reference amounts serve their purpose by providing a consistent basis for labeling and informing consumer choices without implying a recommended level of consumption.*

*According to Wine in Moderation, the reference consumption guidelines are: up to 2 units of alcohol per day for women (equivalent to approximately 200 ml of wine at 12.5% ABV), and up to 3 units per day for men (approximately 300 ml of wine at 12.5% ABV). Additionally, no more than 4 units of alcohol should be consumed on a single drinking occasion.*

Dual-Column Alcohol Facts Panel Display

*We agree with allowing the option to present Alcohol Facts in a dual-column format.*

*We also support the proposal requiring containers with a net content of more than 100 percent but less than 200 percent of a single serving size reference amount to be labeled as containing a single serving.*

Implementation Period

*The proposed 5-year compliance period for the new labeling regulations is both adequate and reasonable, as it allows the industry ample time to adapt gradually without imposing excessive economic or operational pressures. This timeframe helps minimize costs and facilitates a smooth transition toward more comprehensive and transparent labeling for consumers.*

*However, a shorter period (e.g., 3 years) could be considered only if the labeling is limited to basic elements (alcohol content and calories) and does not include a broader set of nutrients or ingredient declarations.*

*It is likely that some industry members will choose to begin implementing the labeling changes before the official compliance date. Many producers may prefer to adapt to the new requirements earlier to stay ahead of regulations and manage inventory efficiently.*

*Furthermore, it is essential that new label approval applications (COLA) are not required when changes are limited to the inclusion or modification of nutritional information, such as the Alcohol Facts panel or data on calories and alcohol content.*

However, a shorter period (e.g., 3 years) could be considered only if the labeling is limited to basic

on calories and alcohol content.
