understand and properly comply with. Providing industry members with several avenues to 
comply with the regulations would be useful, given the various label designs, container sizes, 
international markets, and existing commitments that would be impacted by these regulations 
throughout the industry.  
 
3. Standard Drink Metrics Should Be the Preferred Method of Providing Alcohol Information 
 
DISCUS urges the Bureau to maintain its existing position related to the disclosure of ﬂuid 
ounces of alcohol in Serving Facts statements. Listing the ﬂuid ounces of alcohol per serving is 
an optional declaration under Ruling 2013-2 and should remain optional under this new 
scheme. Mandating the inclusion of the number of ﬂuid ounces of pure ethyl alcohol per 
serving by itself on every beverage alcohol product could be confusing for consumers and not 
useful in helping them follow beverage alcohol moderation guidance.  
 
Consumers will be confused how the ﬂuid ounces of alcohol relate to a particular serving of 
alcohol, so a consumer education campaign would be necessary if it were required to appear on 
every label. And, unfortunately, standard labels do not have enough space to clearly articulate 
the signiﬁcance of ﬂuid ounces of alcohol. If producers wish to include it voluntarily as part of a 
broader statement, however, along with standard drink information, the option should be 
available to further educate consumers about the particulars of a standard drink.  
 
In lieu of mandatory information related to the ﬂuid ounces of alcohol per serving, DISCUS 
supports the inclusion of standard drink information, either through text or the use of an icon, 
as part of any Alcohol or Serving Facts statement. Consumers have far more familiarity with 
standard drink terminology than with the calculation of ﬂuid ounces of alcohol. And the  
  Ms. Amy Greenberg 
August 15, 2025 
Page 13 
 
   
 
inclusion of standard drinks along with a recommended serving size will communicate 
information that facilitates responsibility, in a manner that is consistent with general consumer 
understanding. 
 
Since 1985, information about standard drinks has been a key part of the Dietary Guidelines for 
American’s guidance on moderate consumption. Government experts and public health 
organizations – in the U.S. and worldwide – have long recognized the importance of providing 
standard drink information. The Departments of Health and Human Services and Agriculture, in 
consultation with health experts around the nation, consistently have deﬁned a standard drink 
in the various editions of the Dietary Guidelines for Americans as containing 0.6 ﬂ. oz. (14 
grams) of alcohol. Also provided in the Dietary Guidelines are examples of standard drink 
equivalents, such as 12 ﬂ. oz. of 5% ABV regular beer, 5 ﬂ. oz. of 12% ABV wine or 1.5 ﬂ. oz. of 
40% ABV (80 proof) distilled spirits. 
 
Consumers have become accustomed to framing their responsible consumption practices 
around these drink measurements. DISCUS believes inclusion of standard drink information in 
relation to serving size nutrient content information will be a beneﬁcial tool for consumers and 
suggests that an icon might be the most eﬀective way to communicate this, whether it is 
through a QR code scan or on label. An example of icons that TTB could look to emulate are 
those currently in use in the Australian market:  
 
 
These icons clearly communicate to the consumer the approximate number of standard drinks 
present in each package. We believe this might be the most eﬃcient and consumer friendly 
method to display alcohol per serving information, and TTB should explore mandating a 
standard drink icon if they seek to ﬁnalize this proposal.  
 
In the NPRM, TTB also queries whether labels should include a summary of the Dietary 
Guidelines’ advice on moderate drinking that would be updated based on any changes in the 
guidelines over time. Although we support consumer education when it comes to moderate 
alcohol consumption, DISCUS does not support including moderate drinking guidance from the 
Dietary Guidelines on spirits labels, given that this information would take up additional label 
space and can change with the issuance of each new edition. The standard drink information or 
icon suﬃciently provides responsible consumption information. And, if information can be 
provided via a QR code, the landing page would have space to provide information on the 
Dietary Guidelines and can include a link to the Guidelines, themselves.

4. TTB’s Proposed Serving Size Reference Amounts in the Nutrient Content Statements Will 
Create Consumer Confusion, Damage Brand Equity, and Impede Innovation 
 
We respectfully submit that TTB's proposed approach to "serving sizes" as a basis for the 
Nutrient Content Statement is ﬂawed: mandating proposed serving sizes (based on Ruling 
2013-2) for many current and future products would be confusing to the consumer and 
damaging to brands, as it is contrary to how it is intended to be enjoyed. It will also impede 
innovation based on consumer trends, such as the current trend to provide lower ABV options. 
TTB’s proposed serving sizes seem to be centered around the assumption that the only means 
of drinking a wine, beer, or spirits product is straight, unmixed with other beverages. While this 
may be mostly true for wine and beer products, it most certainly is not the case for distilled 
spirits products, which often serve as “ingredients” in a wide-range of cocktails. Accordingly, it is 
imperative that producers have more ﬂexibility in deﬁning the serving size for each product.  
 
The terminology “serving size” communicates to the consumer that this is the recommended 
serving that they should be consuming. TTB states that these serving size reference amounts are 
intended “only as a basis for the consumer to determine alcohol, calorie, and nutrient intake 
and not as a recommended consumption amount.”
17  Most consumers will not understand this 
distinction and will rightly assume that the serving size listed on the bottle refers to the 
recommended amount that the consumer should pour into a serving. If the stated serving size is 
5 oz., the consumer will believe that a normal serving for that product is 5 oz. This could be 
misleading and damaging to the brand equity for these brands and inadvertently lead to the 
consumption of more alcohol. A few examples of this confusion and damage to brand equity are 
outlined below.  
 
First, there are many liqueurs, cordials, and specialty products currently on the market that 
producers recommend be enjoyed in a 2oz pour (sometimes as part of a cocktail), but would fall 
into a 5 oz. required serving size in the current proposal. Recommending a 5 oz. pour would 
make the experience less enjoyable and may turn a consumer oﬀ from the product altogether. It 
would also increase the recommended amount of alcohol and calories, which is not the desire 
of producers or consumers, and we do not believe is the goal of the present rulemaking. The 
stated ABV cutoﬀs simply do not align with traditional serving sizes or how the manufacturer 
would recommend that many products are consumed.

Instead of mandating the 2013-2 serving sizes, we urge the Bureau to oﬀer producers the option

Speciﬁc Comments on Other Aspects of the Proposal 
 
Questions/Issues: 
 
I. Title of the Alcohol Beverage Information Statement  
 
With regards to the proposal to amend the title of the beverage alcohol information statement, 
we do not see a reason to alter the existing “Serving Facts” terminology and merge these 
statements under the “Alcohol Facts” moniker.  
 
Consumers readily understand the terminology of “Serving Facts” and have been encountering 
these statements on beverage alcohol products for over a decade now. Altering the title of 
these statements now could lead to consumer confusion, especially considering that the title of 
“Serving Facts” better describes the nature of the information being presented to the consumer 
and that most producers, if looking to include additional consumer information on label, have 
opted to utilize the Serving Facts statement over the existing Alcohol Facts statement.   
 
As such, our members have indicated that a mandated change in the terminology to “Alcohol 
Facts” would increase compliance costs for products already containing a “Serving Facts” panel, 
as every label with a voluntarily "Serving Facts" statement would need to be revised. They 
would incur ﬁnancial impacts for creating new print plates, printing new labels, and writing oﬀ 
costs for "Serving Facts" labels that could no longer be used. One member indicated that this 
change would aﬀect over 1,000 labels in their portfolio that would need to be revised from 
"Serving Facts" to "Alcohol Facts." 
 
Switching the terminology to “Alcohol Facts” would obscure the main purpose of providing this 
information to the consumer, which is to share the nutrient content information related to a 
serving of the product. We urge TTB to maintain the longstanding “Serving Facts” terminology. 
 
II. Mandatory Calorie and Nutrient Information 
 
A. A Host of Nutrient Content Information is Currently Available to Consumers  
 
As we detail in our submission last year, many spirits producers currently voluntarily provide 
nutrient information to consumers. In 2022, DISCUS Members committed to provide consumers Ms. Amy Greenberg 
August 15, 2025 
Page 17 
 
   
 
with nutrient content information, such as serving size, number of calories and grams of carbs, 
protein, and fat per serving size, through either of the currently TTB-approved formats (Serving 
Facts panel or statement of average analysis) on new labels by June 2024.18 This information is 
now available for all spirits products distributed in the United States by DISCUS Director 
Members, either displayed directly on the label or via a URL or scannable QR code on the label.  
 
The majority of multi-national producers also provide nutrient content information on their 
brand and corporate websites to satisfy voluntary commitments made in other markets, such as 
in Europe, as well as on some e-commerce platforms at the point of purchase.  
 
Beyond what distillers provide directly, many governmental and private websites also provide 
serving fact information for categories of standards of identity, which generally do not vary 
dramatically across brand given the strict requirements on production, ingredients, and alcohol 
content. For example, the USDA FoodData Central database includes information for general 
categories of beverage alcohol. The page for “Alcoholic beverage, distilled, vodka, 80 proof” 
provides that 1 ﬂ. oz. contains 64.2 kcals.
19 As with most spirits products, the value for most of 
the other nutrients for that product, including protein, fat, and carbs, is zero.   
 
B. Harmonizing Nutrient Labeling Requirements with FDA Would Be Inappropriate and 
Overly Burdensome 
 
In the NPRM, TTB asks for the industry’s views on whether they should seek greater 
harmonization with the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) on nutrient content statements 
and if TTB should adopt FDA’s Nutrition Facts panel. DISCUS strongly supports TTB’s 
longstanding jurisdiction over beverage alcohol labeling and the Bureau’s approach to nutrient 
content labeling and opposes adoption of the FDA’s nutrition labeling scheme.  
 
We believe that the many diﬀerences between distilled spirits and other non-alcohol beverages 
make it unnecessary and even misleading to adopt the type of nutrient labeling required on 
food labels that are under FDA’s labeling jurisdiction. One major concern is that listing the 
percentage of the daily value of the listed nutrients on an alcoholic beverage label could 
mislead consumers by implying that they may rely on beverage alcohol consumption to satisfy 
part of their daily nutrient requirements. There is no daily recommendation/Dietary Reference  
  
 
18 DISCUS Director Members announced this voluntary commitment to provide “Serving Facts” information for spirits products 
as part of the 2022 White House Conference on Hunger, Nutrition and Health. The commitment by DISCUS Director Members to 
provide “Serving Facts” information for spirits products empowers consumers to make healthy choices and foster environments 
that enable people to make informed decisions. This commitment did not extend to DISCUS Craft Members, who may not have 
as many resources to dedicate to calculate and conform this information to TTB required speciﬁcations. It also does not extend 
to limited-run test products available on-site at production facilities and tasting rooms. 
19 US Department of Agriculture, Food Central Database, Vodka Page (August 13, 2025), available at 
https://fdc.nal.usda.gov/fdc-app.html#/food-details/174818/nutrients.  Ms. Amy Greenberg 
August 15, 2025 
Page 18 
 
   
 
Intake for alcohol. Distilled spirits producers would not in any way want to make that implication 
on our brand labels and strongly oppose the inclusion of daily values on TTB-regulated 
products.  
 
On this point, it’s important to note that no other country requires daily value information for 
listed nutrients on distilled spirits labels, so this would be a departure from common global 
practices. Over the past ﬁve years, our members indicated they have not received any consumer 
inquires for many of these nutrients, such as fat (including saturated fat and trans-fat), sodium, 
protein, and cholesterol. This experience demonstrates that this information is not relevant to 
beverage alcohol products or consumers and should not be required to be listed on labels. 
 
DISCUS also opposes mandated inclusion of any additional components that the FDA may 
require, like sodium, as they would not provide any value to the consumer given their typically 
low or non-existent levels in beverage alcohol products.  
 
The adoption of FDA nutrition facts labels on TTB-regulated products would also impose 
signiﬁcant costs and burdens on industry members as it would require extensive testing and a 
complete overhaul of existing labels, whereas the proposed statements could be implemented 
with less disruption to label portfolios. Requiring a full FDA nutrition facts table would take up 
even more space on already limited labels and hamper competition throughout the industry. 
 
Additionally, unlike most food and beverage products, spirits undergo a rigorous pre-approval 
process at TTB for their labels and formulas to ensure compliance with the Bureau’s rules and 
regulations. This pre-approval process is unique in relation to products by the FDA, where there 
is no pre-approval process before products can enter the marketplace. Beverage alcohol 
products under the FDA’s purview contain the full FDA nutrition and ingredients label, but they 
are not required to go through the same pre-approval process as those regulated by TTB and 
are only subject to post-market sampling enforcement eﬀorts to ensure product compliance and 
safety.  
 
As part of its pre-approval process, TTB reviews every proposed label submission for all distilled 
spirits products, with a particular focus on whether the product meets its identiﬁed class/type 
and does not mislead consumers about the nature of the product. Through this review, TTB also 
essentially signals that spirits labels in the marketplace contain accurate and understandable 
information that consumers can rely on to make their purchasing decisions.  
 
The mandate of any additional information—either through TTB’s proposed statement or an 
FDA nutrition facts label—will inevitably be complicated by the pre-approval process and should 
be carefully evaluated through that lens. In particular, there will be acute complications if 
information is required to be presented on the label (rather than via scannable QR code or URL)  
  Ms. Amy Greenberg 
August 15, 2025 
Page 19 
 
   
 
and if the longstanding acceptable practice of providing ingredient ranges for formulas is 
disallowed or compromised through the adoption of an FDA-like system of labeling ingredients 
in order of predominance.  
 
Reasonable timelines for formula and label approvals are key to manage industry member 
production, marketing, and state registration requirements. Additional delays or complications 
in this process could cause undue ﬁnancial hardships for industry members—hardships that 
other food and beverage products do not face in the FDA process with no prior approval. Testing 
for nutrients, particularly if an FDA nutrition facts label was required, would be cost prohibitive 
for the majority of industry members and would create signiﬁcant burdens on their operations. 
This is particularly true for innovators that release several new brands or limited releases each 
year. Formula ranges have been allowed for decades and shifting this policy now would create 
havoc for every industry member who has a formula currently approved with the TTB, as these 
would need to be revisited and altered.  
 
C. Sugar Content Statements Should Remain Optional 
 
In its NPRM, TTB proposed to allow optional sugar content statements as part of the Alcohol or 
Serving Facts statement. DISCUS supports the optional inclusion of sugar content statements, 
consistent with the current approach, and agree with its inclusion in the Alcohol or Serving Facts 
statement if provided.  
 
D. Inclusion of Micronutrients Should Remain Optional 
 
DISCUS strongly suggests that micronutrients should remain an optional inclusion. In most 
instances, micronutrient values would be zero and would not provide consumer beneﬁt to being 
included in the Alcohol Facts statement but might cause consumer confusion.  
 
E. Spirits Products Should Have the Ability to List Only Nutrients Present in the Product 
 
We can appreciate the Bureau’s response to our previous comment on this topic in the NPRM 
that “[w]hile certain alcohol beverages are unlikely to contain certain nutrients, such as fat or 
protein, even the absence of these components provides information and may be of interest to 
consumers.”
20 While some consumers certainly may be interested in seeing the absence of 
those components on the label, we believe the vast majority of consumers are well aware that 
whiskey or vodka products, for example, do not contain any fat or protein. These nutrients are 
not commonly associated with distilled spirits products, unless they contain cream or other 
such ingredients. Allowing the listing of calories alone on label for products without any other 
nutrients would also align the U.S. with the EU marketplace, creating additional eﬃciencies for 
exporters.  
 
 
20 90 Fed. Reg. at 6665. Ms. Amy Greenberg 
August 15, 2025 
Page 20 
 
   
 
At a minimum, TTB should consider allowing producers to employ a short-hand version of the 
statement for products containing only calories that identiﬁes the absence of other nutrients, 
without having to print the entire statement with only zeros. Carbohydrates, fat, and protein 
should only be required to be included on label to the extent they are actually present in the 
product at certain levels. 
 
F. Vitamin or Mineral Statements Should Be Prohibited 
 
The distilled spirits industry strongly opposes the inclusion of vitamin or mineral statements on 
labels. We believe that including numerical statements of the vitamin and mineral content of 
alcohol beverages could create an erroneous impression to consumers that the consumption of 
beverage alcohol has nutritional value or other health-related beneﬁts, or is part of their daily 
dietary needs. We know TTB strictly enforces potential health claims under the current 
regulations and allowing vitamin or mineral statements will only lead to increased confusion 
around health claims for both consumers and the Bureau. As such, we strongly recommend 
against including such a numerical statement.  
 
III. Calculating Panel Elements and Tolerance Levels 
 
In this NPRM, TTB proposes modifying the tolerance levels outlined in TTB Procedure 2020-1 by 
eliminating references to "reasonable ranges" based on "good manufacturing practice 
limitations" and shifting to an objective standard, which allows a tolerance of 20% either above 
or below the labeled amount for calories, carbohydrates, protein, and fat. DISCUS supports this 
proposal.  
 
The proposed 20% above or below the labeled amount is reasonable and broad enough to 
facilitate reliance on databases for standard products, among other methods for calculating 
calorie and nutrient content, but still speciﬁc enough to provide accurate information to 
consumers. Further clariﬁcation would be welcomed, however, on how the tolerance might 
apply for products making speciﬁc calorie claims (e.g. "only 100 calories.”) 
 
The ability to continue to rely on databases and this updated tolerance will be critical for 
industry compliance with this proposal. Relying on databases and calculators allows industry 
members to provide nutrient content information without conducting costly and burdensome 
laboratory testing on each of their products, particularly for brand extensions that might have 
variation in ABV from bottle to bottle, such as bottled-in-bond or barrel strength whiskies. TTB’s 
continued recognition that databases and calculation methods can accurately determine 
nutrient content information is appreciated and will help lessen burdens associated with this 
proposal and increase eﬃciencies with international markets.  
  Ms. Amy Greenberg 
August 15, 2025 
Page 21 
 
   
 
IV. Mandatory Listing of Alcohol by Volume on all Alcohol Beverage Products  
 
While we do not support mandating the inclusion of the number of ﬂuid ounces of pure ethyl 
alcohol per serving by itself on every beverage alcohol product, we fully support and applaud 
the Bureau's proposal to require the disclosure of the alcohol content, expressed as a 
percentage of alcohol by volume (ABV), for all beverage alcohol products both under its 
jurisdiction and FDA’s. By this action, TTB will ﬁnally require all regulated alcohol products to 
bear an alcohol content statement, which has long been required for all distilled spirits 
products. There’s no rationale to exempt certain beverage alcohol products from declaring their 
alcohol content on label while others are required to do so and the Bureau’s action will ensure 
consumers can be increasingly aware of the alcohol content of their alcohol beverage of choice.  
 
Importantly, TTB also proposed to mandate alcohol content labeling on non-alcohol beverage 
products, which DISCUS greatly supports. As the non-alcohol beverage space continues to 
become more popular, industry would welcome guidance on labeling requirements since many 
of these products may straddle TTB and FDA labeling requirements. Ambiguity in this category 
and proper regulatory authority has resulted in inconsistent labeling practices across the 
marketplace. 
 
V. Placement of Alcohol Content Statements as Part of the Alcohol Facts Statement 
 
As raised by the Bureau in the NPRM, we respectfully request that the alcohol content 
statement not be mandated as part of an Alcohol or Serving Facts statement and that the 
alcohol by volume statement on the brand label remain the primary alcohol content statement 
required. Distilled spirits consumers are accustomed to interacting with ABV information in the 
same ﬁeld of vision as other mandatory information on the front of most distilled spirits bottles, 
so moving the required statement onto an Alcohol or Serving Facts statement could lead to 
consumer confusion or inconvenience. If this change was adopted, consumers will not, in most 
cases, readily be able to see the ABV statement while perusing product at a retail location as 
they will need to turn container to look for the ABV disclosure in the Alcohol or Serving Facts 
statement.  
 
Given that this would be an enormous departure from how distilled spirits labels have 
historically been organized, TTB does not provide suﬃcient rationale in the NPRM for why the 
Alcohol or Serving Facts statement is the appropriate mandatory location for this information or 
why a currently optional declaration under the voluntary scheme outlined by TTB Ruling 2013-2 
is now becoming required. Current Serving Facts panels under the voluntary scheme are only 
required to list serving size, servings per container, calories, carbohydrates, fat, and protein.  
 
If information related to serving size and the number of standard drinks per serving are included 
in the Alcohol or Serving Facts panel, this information is adequate, in terms of what a consumer 
needs to help inform their responsible consumption. If the ABV is already stated in another Ms. Amy Greenberg 
August 15, 2025 
Page 22 
 
   
 
location on the product, the producer should have the option and ﬂexibility to include it in an 
Alcohol or Serving Facts statement if they choose to do so. Producers wanting to maintain their 
current label design and placement of the ABV on the front of the label should not be burdened 
with displaying the same information twice on their label in order for it to be compliant with 
this new scheme.  
 
VI. Linear Display and Type Size of Alcohol Facts Information  
 
A. Proposed Linear Display Increases Flexibility and Should Not Require a Box 
 
DISCUS appreciates the inclusion of a linear display option for the Alcohol or Serving Facts 
statement, as this will increase the ﬂexibility for industry members in how they choose to 
display the mandated information based upon their speciﬁc label characteristics and available 
space. There is no reason to believe that the linear display option would be diﬃcult for 
consumers to understand or locate on label, as TTB has essentially permitted a similar 
statement for over 20 years. Consumers have become accustomed to engaging with statements 
of average analysis since the Bureau approved them in 2004 and, while they do not include all 
of the information outlined in this proposal, they do provide all of the nutrient content 
information included in the Serving Facts format, without a box surrounding the statement. 
Given the similarities between this linear display and statements of average analysis, consumers 
should be able to easily locate and understand this information.  
 
DISCUS urges the Bureau to revise the proposal to make the box around both the linear and 
panel display Alcohol Facts statements optional. Given the amount of information being 
provided in the statement, consumers will have no trouble locating these statements on the 
label. The box is another element that adds complexity to designing labeling that meets all 
mandatory requirements with limited space availability. The Bureau allows this ﬂexibility now, 
as many Serving Facts statements are provided on label without a box around them, and they 
are just as recognizable for consumers. TTB also pre-approves every label and will retain the 
option to send a COLA back for correction if a specialist felt a producer was trying to obscure or 
hide an Alcohol Facts statement. Industry members should be given maximum ﬂexibility to 
decide how to best implement this proposal for their products - whether with a linear or panel 
display, as well as where it is located on label.  
 
B. Formatting and Type Size Requirements 
 
DISCUS agrees with TTB’s proposal that, if required on label, the type size for an Alcohol or 
Serving Facts statement should be consistent with the existing mandatory disclosures. While 
pertaining to beer and wine products only, DISCUS also supports the elimination of the 
maximum type size limitation. 
  Ms. Amy Greenberg 
August 15, 2025 
Page 23 
 
   
 
C. Cost Estimates for Linear Display  
 
While we discuss the anticipated cost of this proposal in depth above, we would like to stress 
that, even with a linear display allowance, each label will need to be reviewed and readjusted to 
ﬁt this additional information. For those labels that are space constrained, dielines would have 
to increase for the inclusion of the Alcohol Facts statement, which could have a detrimental 
environmental and sustainability impact. Every statement option aside from a QR code would 
pose a signiﬁcant ﬁnancial burden to update all product labels to include Alcohol Facts 
statements. Among the on-pack options, the linear display format will impose the least burdens 
for industry members because it takes up much less space, in what is already a limited area for 
many of our products. This ﬁnancial impact would also decrease if the box around the linear 
and panel displays was made optional, as producers could then ﬁt the required information into 
even more space on the label.  
 
VII. Dual-Column Alcohol Facts Panel Display 
 
DISCUS agrees that the dual-column alcohol facts panels should remain optional. We also agree 
with TTB’s proposal to allow the dual-column format on alcohol beverages sold in containers 
holding at least 200 percent and less than 500 percent of the serving size reference amount, as 
this would more accurately reﬂect the way in which alcohol beverages are bottled and labeled 
and how producers might want to utilize these panels. 
 
Education may be needed, however, around the meaning of dual-column labels for the 
consumer to correctly read and understand dual-column labels and to understand how the 
manufacturer is intending the consumer to approach the servings shown. It’s possible that dual-
column displays could create the impression that consumption of multiple servings of an alcohol 
beverage at once or in one sitting is expected or recommended. In other regions, such as the 
EU, most companies only provide nutrient content facts per 100mL measurements. With so 
many diﬀerent serving sizes and container sizes in the US, it would be practically very diﬃcult 
for companies to implement a dual-column display for every bottle size and SKU.  
 
In addition, if TTB does not allow Alcohol or Serving Facts statements to be provided by QR 
codes, the amount of space required to print dual-column panels information can impact 
already limited label space availability, so allowing producers the option of including a dual-
column display at their discretion rather than requiring it provides essential ﬂexibility.  
 
VIII. Implementation Period 
 
Thousands of brands will be aﬀected by this initiative, both domestically and internationally. 
Given the global commerce in beverage alcohol products and the multitude of products that 
are imported into the United States, DISCUS appreciates the ﬁve-year phase-in period included Ms. Amy Greenberg 
August 15, 2025 
Page 24 
 
   
 
in the proposal and believes that this implementation timeframe should be suﬃcient to 
eﬀectuate the necessary labeling and branding changes. 
 
This length of time will be essential to address label development and redesign, along with the 
associated resources and outside expertise required in a label initiative aﬀecting the industry. 
DISCUS appreciates the Bureau not requiring resubmission of COLAs to include Alcohol or 
Serving Facts statements, as this would greatly increase burdens throughout the industry and 
for the Bureau’s ALFD staﬀ by creating a tidal wave of applications. A ﬁve-year phase-in 
timetable for compliance provides a more orderly transition period across a company's brand 
portfolio - be it a large, medium or small portfolio and/or with "fast moving" or "slow moving" 
brands. This timeframe would allow companies to transition to new labeling requirements in a 
structured manner, which would beneﬁt all stakeholders. 
 
Even with this ﬁve-year implementation period, exceptions would need to be considered for 
legacy products or products that have aged in bottle (e.g., ice wine, etc.). A waiver or other 
mechanic should be in place to help protect investments that may not comply. Further 
clariﬁcation is also needed regarding the exact mechanics of the ultimate compliance date and 
which products it could impact that are already in the marketplace. Would it only be applicable 
to new products produced after the ﬁnal rule goes into eﬀect? What about inventory sitting 
either in a warehouse or on a store shelf? Would existing inventory need to be reworked to 
comply with the ﬁnal rule? These important questions demonstrate the realities producers will 
need to contend with if this proposal is ﬁnalized, as well as the type of questions the Bureau 
should be prepared to respond to either in the rule language itself or an accompanying FAQ 
guidance document.  
 
In the NPRM, the Bureau asked how frequently labels are changed on beverage alcohol 
products, and the answer truly diﬀers based on producer and brand. Each brand is unique in 
the frequency that labels are changed. While not always the case, generally speaking, straight 
spirits brands change product labels less frequently than formulated products or certain 
categories like ready-to-drink (RTDs). A shorter amount of time to comply than the proposed 
ﬁve years isn't realistic given the uniqueness of each label. Each label size will need to be 
analyzed and possibly reworked to provide enough space for the inclusion of an Alcohol Facts 
statement. Labels may have to increase their dieline to meet the requirements, which from an 
environmental and sustainability practice introduces additional burden to the industry.  
 
Companies that choose to comply earlier obviously would be free to do so and, if QR code 
transmission was permitted, we believe you would see a host of companies able to comply in 
very quick order given the ease of updating or changing information hosted on those webpages. 
If required on label, however, some of our members indicated that they would opt to begin to 
include the required information as a brand goes through a redesign or is being updated. This 
would reduce the amount of times a label has to be touched, thus helping to reduce the cost 
associated with updating a label, but would result in a slower roll-out than if there was more Ms. Amy Greenberg 
August 15, 2025 
Page 25 
 
   
 
ﬂexibility. Our members relayed that they would need to begin taking steps towards the 
implementation of the labeling changes right away in order to become compliant before the 
compliance period begins in ﬁve years. 
  
We also urge the Bureau to synchronize the implementation of any mandatory labeling changes 
so that industry members are able to comply with these new requirements in the most eﬃcient 
manner. This would include not only the mandatory allergen labeling requirements, but also 
any ingredient labeling proposal the Bureau might be considering.  
 
While we understand that the advance notice of proposed rulemaking related to ingredient 
labeling was withdrawn earlier this year prior to its release, if the Bureau intends to revive it in 
another form, it’s critical to note that any eventual ingredient labeling requirements being on a 
diﬀerent implementation track would be ﬁnancially and logistically devasting for industry 
members large and small. It would be unreasonable to ask industry members to undergo costly 
label redesign to include nutrient content and allergen information and begin production on 
those new labels across all their product lines, only to be notiﬁed they will need to restart label 
redesign to incorporate ingredient information in a couple years. We respectfully request that 
TTB consider this important point as they seek to ﬁnalize these pending rulemakings and 
prepare their future regulatory agenda.  
 
Conclusion and Summary 
 
DISCUS supports TTB’s objective to provide consumers with clear, consistent information about 
alcohol. It is critical that the ﬁnal rule serves the public's interests, without placing undue 
burden on distillers, overwhelming agency staﬀ, or inadvertently confusing consumers. We 
believe this proposal, if adopted as-is, would not meet these objectives, and we urge TTB to 
reconsider certain aspects.  
 
We request greater ﬂexibility in terms of how and where the Alcohol Facts information is 
provided. Most critically, we propose the option to include it via QR codes or links. This 
approach: 
• Ensures broad consumer access (e.g., QR codes/links in advertising) and readability (e.g., 
multiple languages for non-English speakers);  
• Oﬀers the ability to provide consumers with up-to-date, detailed information, while 
accounts for small product/label space limitations;  
• Reduces burden on producers, especially craft distillers, who are already facing 
economic headwinds; 
• Allows producers to be nimble in responding to labeling changes and/or geographical 
diﬀerences (e.g., bottle return) and, thus, minimizes waste; and 
• Aligns with labeling in other regions of the world, including the EU, which results in 
greater consistency and can reduce potential trade barriers. 
 Ms. Amy Greenberg 
August 15, 2025 
Page 26 
 
   
 
DISCUS recommends that Alcohol Facts information specify the number of standard drinks 
per container – potentially via a graphic alongside text that states the number of servings. The 
inclusion of standard drink information better aligns with consumer understanding than the 
proposed requirement to list the amount of pure alcohol in grams, which could result in 
consumer confusion. 
 
DISCUS has concerns regarding the signiﬁcant anticipated costs associated with this proposal, 
which are not commensurate with the stated beneﬁts. TTB’s own cost estimates anticipate 
implementing this Alcohol Facts proposal will cost producers millions of dollars in label redesign, 
marketing, logistics, and printing expenditures, at a time when the industry is constricting and 
unable to absorb these unbudgeted costs. Allowing for ﬂexibility in transmission of this 
information will enable broad industry compliance.   
 
DISCUS believes TTB’s proposed serving size reference amounts for the nutrient content 
statements will create consumer confusion, damage brand equity, and impede innovation. 
The Ruling 2013-2 serving sizes do not appropriately ﬁt with consumer understanding around 
traditional pours for many products and misrepresent serving sizes for many liqueurs and lower 
ABV products. Allowing ﬂexibility for producers to provide their recommended serving size 
when a prescribed one does not neatly ﬁt is required if this proposal were to be adopted.   
 
* * * * * 
 
America’s distillers and marketers of spirits want to ensure that consumers have access to the 
information they need, but this proposal leaves several important issues unaddressed and 
opens distillers up to potential costs that might be insurmountable in the current market. We 
implore TTB to carefully evaluate all potential implications of this proposal to avoid undue 
burden on distillers and TTB staﬀ, as well as any inadvertent consumer confusion. We believe 
ﬂexibility and clarity will be the key to ﬁnding a balanced approach.   
 
Thank you again for providing an opportunity to discuss this important topic and we look 
forward to liaising with the Bureau on these matters going forward. If you have any questions 
regarding our submission, please do not hesitate to reach out.  
 
Best regards,  
 
 
 
 
Courtney Armour 
Chief Legal Oﬃcer 
Distilled Spirits Council of the United States

displayed
 
serving
 
size,
 
that
 
would
 
be
 
very
 
reasonable.
 
 
10.  Dual-Column  Alcohol  Facts  Panel  Display  
10.1.  Does  dual-column  labeling  create  the  impression  that  consumption  of  
multiple
 
servings
 
of
 
an
 
alcohol
 
beverage
 
at
 
one
 
time
 
is
 
expected
 
or
 
recommended?
 
 
 
No
 
more
 
so
 
than
 
it
 
does
 
for
 
food
 
products.
 
10.2.  Should  dual-column  displays  be  limited  to  containers  with  three  or  fewer  
servings,
 
consistent
 
with
 
the
 
FDA
 
regulations?
 
Or
 
is
 
a
 
limit
 
of
 
less
 
than
 
five
 
servings
 
better
 
suited
 
to
 
the
 
way
 
in
 
which
 
alcohol
 
beverages
 
may
 
be
 
bottled
 
and
 
labeled?
 
 
 
See
 
our
 
answer
 
to
 
the
 
next
 
question.
 
10.3.  Should  dual-column  displays  be  allowed  on  any  container,  regardless  of  
the
 
number
 
of
 
servings
 
in
 
that
 
container,
 
consistent
 
with
 
TTB
 
Ruling
 
2013–2?
 
The
 
proposed
 
rule
 
would
 
require
 
containers
 
with
 
a
 
net
 
content
 
of
 
more
 
than
 
100
 
percent
 
but
 
less
 
than
 
200
 
percent
 
of
 
a
 
single
 
serving
 
size
 
reference
 
amount
 
to
 
be
 
labeled
 
as
 
containing
 
a
 
single
 
serving.
 
TTB
 
solicits
 
comments
 
on
 
whether
 
this
 
is
 
the
 
best
 
way
 
to
 
convey
 
the
 
alcohol
 
and
 
nutrient
 
content
 
of
 
these
 
products
 
to
 
consumers.
 
 
We
 
see
 
no
 
reason
 
to
 
forbid
 
dual-column
 
displays
 
on
 
any
 
container.
 
If
 
Alcohol
 
Facts
 
panels
 
are
 
intended
 
to
 
give
 
consumers
 
easier
 
access
 
to
 
information,
 
then
 
28   
permit  those  producers  who  wish  to  provide  an  easier  way  to  understand  that  
information
 
the
 
right
 
to
 
do
 
so.
 
11.  Implementation  Period   
11.1.  How  frequently  do  bottlers  and  importers  of  alcohol  beverages  typically  
change
 
labels?
 
 
The
 
only
 
accurate
 
answer
 
to
 
this
 
is
 
“it
 
depends.”
 
Printing
 
labels
 
is
 
one
 
of
 
the
 
areas
 
of
 
our
 
industry
 
that
 
is
 
most
 
affected
 
by
 
economies
 
of
 
scale.
 
The
 
unit
 
cost
 
of
 
printing
 
the
 
same
 
exact
 
label
 
might
 
go
 
from
 
ten
 
cents
 
apiece
 
for
 
an
 
order
 
of
 
tens
 
of
 
thousands
 
to
 
several
 
dollars
 
apiece
 
for
 
an
 
order
 
of
 
a
 
couple
 
hundred.
 
As
 
such,
 
some
 
of
 
our
 
members
 
order
 
large
 
quantities
 
of
 
labels
 
they
 
intend
 
to
 
use
 
for
 
years
 
to
 
decrease
 
unit
 
costs.
 
But
 
some
 
of
 
our
 
members
 
might
 
print
 
smaller
 
runs
 
more
 
frequently.
 
Some
 
members
 
only
 
make
 
one
 
or
 
two
 
products
 
that
 
stay
 
the
 
same
 
for
 
years.
 
Some
 
members
 
only
 
make
 
limited
 
release
 
products
 
and
 
require
 
new
 
labels
 
many
 
times
 
a
 
year
 
for
 
each
 
new
 
product.
 
Many
 
members
 
pursue
 
a
 
mix
 
of
 
the
 
above
 
strategies.
 
11.2.  How  long  do  industry  members  need  to  comply  with  the  requirements  of  
the
 
proposed
 
rule?
 
 
If
 
the
 
proposed
 
rule
 
goes
 
through
 
and
 
does
 
not
 
exempt
 
small
 
businesses,
 
5
 
years
 
is
 
an
 
appropriate
 
implementation
 
timeline.
 
11.3.  Will  5  years  provide  enough  time  for  small  businesses  to  coordinate  
labeling
 
changes
 
required
 
by
 
regulatory
 
changes
 
with
 
labeling
 
changes
 
that
 
are
 
planned
 
in
 
the
 
ordinary
 
course
 
of
 
business?
 
 
 
We
 
urge
 
that
 
TTB
 
exempt
 
small
 
businesses
 
from
 
the
 
proposed
 
rule.
 
Small
 
businesses
 
are
 
less
 
likely
 
to
 
implement
 
changes
 
to
 
their
 
labels
 
significant
 
enough
 
to
 
require
 
new
 
graphic
 
design
 
or
 
even
 
new
 
tooling
 
every
 
5
 
years
 
since
 
the
 
expense
 
is
 
significant.
 
Usually
 
a
 
small
 
business
 
will
 
spend
 
a
 
significant
 
amount
 
of
 
money
 
in
 
branding
 
and
 
design
 
once
 
every
 
10
 
years
 
for
 
its
 
most
 
popular
 
products.
 
11.4.  Is  5  years  too  long  a  compliance  period?  Should  the  compliance  period  
instead
 
be
 
2
 
years,
 
3
 
years,
 
or
 
another
 
length
 
of
 
time?
 
 
 
For
 
large
 
companies,
 
every
 
5
 
years
 
should
 
be
 
fine.
 
For
 
small
 
companies,
 
there
 
should
 
be
 
an
 
exemption
 
process
 
available
 
as
 
there
 
is
 
with
 
food
 
products.
 
11.5.  If  a  final  rule  is  issued,  will  industry  members  begin  implementation  of  the  
labeling
 
changes
 
in
 
advance
 
of
 
the
 
compliance
 
date?
 
 
Some
 
may
 
choose
 
to
 
do
 
so
 
if
 
it
 
aligns
 
with
 
their
 
priorities
 
and
 
needs.
 
29   
Thank  you  for  consideration  of  ACSA’s  comments.   We  appreciate  the  ability  to  respond  and  are  
happy
 
to
 
answer
 
any
 
questions
 
you
 
may
 
have
 
upon
 
review.
 
Respectfully  submitted,  
Margie  A.S.  Lehrman,  CEO  
American  Craft  Spirits  Association  
     
30

comment_title: Comment 188:  Alliance for Sustainability in Mezcal (Alianza por la Sustentabilidad en el Mezcal).
comment_text: The attached comments are submitted on behalf of the Alliance for Sustainability in Mezcal (Alianza por la Sustentabilidad en el Mezcal).
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
August, 14, 2025.  
 
 
Agency responsible: 
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB), Department of the Treasury 
USA WTO TBT Inquiry Point, Email: usatbtep@nist.gov 
 
Subject: Comments on: Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and 
Malt Beverages  
 
To whom it may concern, 
 
I write to you today on behalf of the Mezcal Sustainability Alliance , a strategic collaboration  among 
companies and with institutions in the sector, committed to the sustainable development of Mezcal. Its 
purpose is to  strengthen the identity of the spirit by disseminating good practices, promoting joint 
projects and generating a positive impact on producing communities. With a focus on innovative  
solutions, the Alliance seeks to accelerate change and preserve the artisanal tradition that  defines 
Mezcal.  
 
The Mezcal Sustainability Alliance thanks the TTB  for notifying its proposed regulation to the TBT 
Committee, in compliance with its commitments as a member of the World Trade Organization, in 
accordance with article 2.9.2 of the Agreement, which establishes that notifications of technical 
regulations should occur at a stage where comments can be considered and modifications to the initial 
proposal can be made. 
 
Background 
 
On January 17, 2025, the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) of the U.S. published a 
proposal (Notice No. 237 ) to amend the labeling of wines, distilled spirits, and malt beverages. The 
main objective is to provide consumers with more comprehensive and clear information about the 
alcoholic beverages they consume, similar to the nutrition information found on foods 
 
Key points of the proposal: 
• "Alcohol Facts" Panel:  The creation of a mandatory panel on alcoholic beverage labels is 
proposed, similar to the "Nutrition Facts" panel on foods. This panel would include  alcohol 
content per serving; calories per serving; basic nutrients; standard serving size and number 
of servings per container .  The proposal establishes specific serving sizes for each type of 
alcoholic beverage, which vary depending on their alcohol content.   
• Flexible presentation formats:  The "Alcohol Facts" panel would be presented in different 
formats, adapting to the container size and beverage content. 
 
 
 
 
 
• Compliance Period : A period of 5 years from the publication of the final rule in the Federal 
Register is proposed for producers and distributors to comply with the new requirements. 
 
General comments on the proposal:  
 
Alcohol content 
It is acknowledged that declaring the alcohol content on alcoholic beverage labels is important to 
inform consumers and help prevent harmful consumption. However, expressing this content in fluid 
ounces of pure ethanol per serving is considered unnecessari ly complex and not easily understood by 
the average consumer. Therefore, it is recommended that only alcohol by volume (% ABV) be declared, 
and that this information be allowed anywhere on the label as long as it is clearly visible, without 
requiring placement in a specific panel or format. 
 
Serving and servings per container: 
The proposal aims to standardize the declaration of serving size and number of servings per container 
across all regulated alcoholic beverages, placing this information within the “Alcohol Facts” panel. 
While it is considered essential for consumers to understand how much alcohol is in a container and in 
a standard drink to promote moderation, it is suggested that this information be provided voluntarily. If 
mandated, it should be included through electronic labeling (e.g., QR code, digital platform, or website), 
which would ensure access to relevant information without imposing unnecessary regulatory or 
commercial burdens. 
 
Nutritional information 
 
The proposal seeks to include nutritional information —such as calories, carbohydrates, fats, and 
proteins—within the “Alcohol Facts” panel on alcoholic beverage labels. However, this approach may 
confuse consumers by implying that alcoholic beverages offer  nutritional benefits, which contradicts 
Codex Alimentarius guidelines that prohibit the addition or promotion of nutrients in alcohol. Alcohol 
 
should not be considered a food or nutrient and presenting it as such could mislead consumers into 
viewing it as comparable to non -alcoholic beverages, potentially influencing purchasing decisions 
based on inappropriate criteria. This could divert attention from the health risks associated with alcohol 
consumption and negatively impact public health perceptions. 
 
 
Key Questions from the TTB: 
1. Should TTB’s proposed nutrient content labeling statement be more consistent with the 
Nutrition Facts Label found on foods that are under FDA’s labeling jurisdiction? 
Alternatively, do the differences between alcohol beverages and other foods make it 
unnecessary, or even misleading, to adopt the type of nutrient labeling required on food 
labels that are under FDA’s labeling jurisdiction? For example, would information on the 
percentage of the daily value of the listed nutrients provided by alcohol beverages be useful 
information for consumers? Alternatively, could such statements mislead consumers by 
implying that they may rely on alcohol beverage consumption to satisfy part of their daily 
nutrient requirements? 
 
We believe that requiring the inclusion of the "Alcohol Facts" panel on labels would not provide any 
benefit to consumers, since the objective of alcoholic beverages labeling, from a health perspective, is 
to prevent harmful alcohol use. Therefore, including nutritional information on such beverages could 
create the perception that they have a "nutritional benefit," which could cause confusion among 
consumers. 
 
We consider that this measure, which implies including information on caloric content, sodium content, 
sugar or fat content, among others, can influence the consumer’s perception of alcohol as healthier 
than other products or foods. Therefore, it is extremely risky to combine two health objectives that could 
confuse non -alcoholic beverages with alcoholic beverages, given that the calorie content, sodium 
content, sugar or fat content, among others, and the amount of alcohol, are diff erent elements in the 
consumer's diet and are not comparable. 
 
By its nature, alcohol should not be considered a food or a nutrient, so including the nutrimental 
information on the label of alcoholic beverages can lead to consumer confusion, understanding that 
alcoholic beverages provide nutrients similar to food, and this may influence their purchasing decision 
and favor the consumption of one beverage over another without taki ng into account the amount of 
alcohol that each product contains. 
 
Making this labeling mandatory would also add costs for producers, importers, and distributors, which 
goes against trade agreements such as the Agreement on Technical Barriers to Trade (TBT Agreement) 
of the World Trade Organization (WTO), which prohibits creating unnecessary barriers to international  
trade. However, if the "Alcohol Facts" panel becomes mandatory, we strongly recommend allowing this 
information to be presented digitally (QR codes, websites, etc.). This makes the information accessible 
to consumers without creating unnecessary regulatory and commercial burdens. 
Digital labeling offers many advantages: 
• Unlimited space to inform consumers. 
• Consumer-friendly and easy-to-understand format. 
• Easy updating as regulations change. 
• Effective communication with vulnerable groups (such as young people) about the risks of 
harmful alcohol consumption. 
• Opportunity to create engaging and educational content. 
 
This approach is in line with the "Guidance for providing food information to consumers by using 
technology", which is being developed by the CODEX Alimentarius Committee on Food Labeling. 
Finally, we believe that a gradual implementation period of 5 years would be the best way to implement 
these changes, particularly to give small producers time to adapt their supply chains for distribution in 
the U.S. 
 
2. For greater consistency with the FDA Nutrition Facts Label, should Alcohol Facts statements be 
allowed or required to include other elements (such as sodium and cholesterol) or a further 
breakdown of fat (to include saturated fat and trans-fat)? 
 
As previously noted, the inclusion of expanded nutritional information on alcoholic beverage labels 
could lead consumers to mistakenly believe these products offer nutritional benefits, causing serious 
confusion. Evidence from the Organization for Economic Co -operation and Development (OECD) 
shows that labeling can be an effective tool for informing consumers, but only when the information is 
clear, concise, and relevant. Overloading labels with excessive or complex data may result in confusion 
or misinformation, undermining the goal of providing accessible and useful consumer information. 
 
 
3. Would the inclusion of elements not ordinarily expected to be found in alcohol beverages (such 
as trans-fat and dietary fiber) be useful or potentially misleading? 
 
As previously mentioned, including nutritional information on alcoholic beverages may lead consumers 
to believe these products offer nutritional benefits, causing significant confusion. Specifically, elements 
like dietary fiber could reinforce this misconception, suggesting added health value. Therefore, it is not 
recommended to include any of the nutritional components proposed. Rather than being helpful, such 
declarations could directly mislead consumers and result in misinterpretation. 
 
4. Should TTB allow numerical statements of the vitamin and mineral content of alcohol 
beverages, assuming the product contains vitamins or minerals, or could such a statement create  
an erroneous impression that consumption of the alcohol beverage has nutritional value or other 
health-related benefits? 
 
Including nutritional information on alcoholic beverage labels may lead consumers to mistakenly 
believe these products offer nutritional benefits, causing serious confusion. Specifically, elements like 
dietary fiber could reinforce this misconception by su ggesting added health value. Therefore, such 
information should not be required in any form.  
 
In Mexico, legislation explicitly prohibits alcoholic beverages from referencing any nutritional benefits 
or therapeutic properties. According to Article 308 of the General Health Law, advertising must focus 
solely on product characteristics, quality, and production methods, without implying health or wellness 
benefits. Additionally, Article 307 prohibits associating non -alcoholic food and beverage advertising 
with alcohol consumption or promoting harmful dietary habits, while Article 6 of the Advertising 
Regulation reinforces the ban on attributing preventive, therapeutic, or nutritional qualities to products. 
These declarations, rather than being helpful, could mislead consumers and distort public health 
messaging. 
 
In summary, Mexican legislation is clear in prohibiting the attribution of nutritional properties or health 
benefits that they do not possess to alcoholic beverages. This is because including such declarations 
on labeling could confuse consumers instead of providing useful information. 
 
 
5. How many industry members already provide nutrient content information on labels, in 
advertisements (such as websites), or upon request (for example, to consumers or restaurants)? 
No comments on this topic. 
 
 
6. Do consumers want to see Alcohol Facts labeling on alcohol beverage products? How might 
consumers benefit from such a label? Do consumers have adequate information about the identity 
and quality of alcohol beverages if alcohol beverage containers do not  include Alcohol Facts 
labeling? How do those benefits compare to the costs and regulatory burdens associated with 
such revisions? 
 
The current information on alcoholic beverage labeling is sufficient. The inclusion of the "Alcohol Facts" 
panel would not provide any benefits to consumer s and would generate unnecessary costs and 
regulatory burdens. 
 
 
7. How, if at all, would the new mandatory labeling requirements affect competition in the alcohol 
beverage market? 
  
Making a change in the labels of these products would generate an extra cost for manufacturers, 
importers, and distributors, particularly harming small and emerging businesses. Therefore, if adopted, 
this proposal would create unnecessary barriers to trade in violation of Article 2.2 of the WTO 
Agreement on Technical Barriers to Trade, that establishes that “… technical regulations shall not be 
more trade-restrictive than necessary to fulfil a legitimate objective, taking account of the risks non -
fulfilment would create”. 
 
8. How would the new mandatory labeling requirements affect small businesses and,  in 
particular, new businesses entering into the alcohol beverage marketplace? 
 
The proposed regulation would have a disproportionate impact on international suppliers, especially 
small and new producers. This is due to increased costs associated with additional analyses, packaging 
and labeling modifications, new shipments, and the re structuring of supply chains for the U.S. market. 
This burden could even force some small producers to leave the market. 
 
9. How, if at all, would the new mandatory labeling requirements affect international trade of 
alcohol beverages? Is there any information that should, or should not, be included to align the 
proposed labeling requirements with those of other countries? 
 
To reduce operational costs and improve access to detailed information, electronic labeling is 
recommended. This approach would help avoid trade barriers and harmonize requirements 
internationally, minimizing the impact of new labeling rules on producers and supply chains. 
 
 
Conclusion: 
 
Detailed nutritional labeling on alcoholic beverages may confuse consumers by implying health 
benefits. If required, such information should be provided voluntarily or via electronic labeling to avoid 
regulatory burdens and disproportionate costs, especially for international and small producers. 
 
 
Best regards, 
 
 
 
Rocio Melendrez Ramirez 
Representative 
 
Members of the “Alianza para la Sustentabilidad”: Casa Xipe; Del Maguey Single Village Mezcal; Mezcal Los Danzantes; Mezcal Amarás; Mezcal El Tinieblo; 
Mezcal Júrame; Marqués del Jaral de Berrio; Casa Mezcal Huitzila; Mezcal Amaxak; Promotora y Comercializadora de Destilados SA de CV; Casa Parada 
Mezcal; Santa Fátima; WYN Spirits S. de R.L de C.V./Dos Hombres.

comment_title: Comment 197:  West Indies Rum & Spirits Producers' Association (WIRSPA)
comment_text: System not allowing file to upload.
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
Mars House, #13 Pine Road, Belleville, St. Michael BB11113, Barbados, W.I. 
T +1 246 228 8033     E wirspa@wirspa.com     www.wirspa.com     www.acr-rum.com 
 
Chairman: Mr. Clement Lawrence   E c.lawrence@spiritspool.com 
 
 
 
 
WIRSPA Submission to the 
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) 
 
Regarding: TTB Notice No. 237 – Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, 
Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages  and TTB Notice No. 238 – Major Food Allergen 
Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages 
1. Introduction 
The West Indies Rum & Spirits Producers’ Association (WIRSPA) represents producers 
and brand owners of Authentic Caribbean Rum and other spirits across 15 countries. Our 
members are long -established exporters to the United States, with many products 
benefiting from recognition under the U.S. Caribbean Basin Initiative. The rum industry is 
a major economic driver and an important part of the cultural heritage of the Caribbean, 
supporting thousands of jobs in both production and tourism.   We welcome the 
opportunity to comment on TTB’s proposed rulemaking under Notice No. 237 and Notice 
No. 238. WIRSPA supports the goal of providing consumers with accurate, clear, and 
accessible information. However, we believe that the proposed approach requires 
adjustments to ensure that it is: 
→ Meaningful for consumers  — avoiding duplication, overly technical terms, or 
misleading nutritional framing. 
→ Flexible for producers  — recognising varied product types, serving traditions, and 
container sizes. 
→ Aligned internationally — to minimise trade barriers and regulatory divergence with 
other major markets. 
→ Practical and proportionate  — limiting compliance burdens, especially for small 
producers, and avoiding unnecessary label changes. 
Key Requests at a Glance: 
1. Change the panel title from “Alcohol Facts” to “Serving Facts”. 
2. Permit digital labeling (QR codes) to provide full information, with minimal mandatory 
on-pack content. 
3. Remove “pure alcohol in fluid ounces” and keep ABV optional in the panel. 
4. Omit irrelevant nutrients. 
5. Adapt serving sizes to reflect real-world consumption; allow justified deviations. 
6. Allow flexible formatting, including linear formats without boxed borders. 
7. Maintain ±20% tolerance and avoid unnecessary COLA resubmissions. 2 
 
8. Support 5-year transition with stock sell -through and alignment with allergen labeling 
timelines. 
9. Confirm no allergen labeling for pre -distillation ingredients, with case -by-case post-
distillation checks. 
2. Title of the Statement 
The proposed title “Alcohol Facts” risks misleading consumers into thinking that the 
panel offers a safety or health advisory, rather than factual serving information. It also 
differs from established voluntary practice and international norms. 
Argument: 
 “Serving Facts” is a more neutral, accurate descriptor. 
 The EU and many global producers already use “Serving Facts” or similar. 
 A consistent title fosters consumer understanding across markets. 
Conclusion / Ask: Replace “Alcohol Facts” with “Serving Facts” in all references and 
label examples. 
3. Digital Labeling (QR Codes and Online Access) 
The proposed rule requires all information to appear physically on the label, which can 
be restrictive for small containers, multilingual products, and brands selling in multiple 
markets. 
Argument: 
 Codex Guidelines (CXG 105 -2024) support the use of technology to deliver food and 
beverage information. 
 The EU already allows energy content on-pack with full nutrition information online . 
The Spirits Europe and DISCUS submission s both provide extensive background to 
justify this position. 
 Digital labeling reduces costs, supports sustainability, and avoids frequent reprints. 
 QR codes can provide richer, multilingual, and updated content. 
Conclusion / Ask: Allow mandatory particulars to be provided digitally via QR codes, with 
only essential on-label data required in physical print. 
4. Content of the Statement 
Several proposed elements are either duplicative or not relevant to distilled spirits. 
Argument: 
 ABV — already required elsewhere on the label; repeating it is redundant. 
 Fluid ounces of pure alcohol — unfamiliar to U.S. consumers and rarely used 
internationally. 
 Protein and fat — always negligible in distilled spirits; inclusion implies nutritional 
benefit. 3 
 
 Avoid adopting FDA -style nutrient label format –adopting FDA’s “Nutrition Facts” 
style could mislead consumers into thinking alcohol has health or nutritional benefits. 
Conclusion / Ask: Keep ABV optional in the panel; remove pure alcohol in fluid ounces; 
omit protein and fat unless above de minimis levels. 
5. Serving Sizes and Real-World Consumption 
The fixed ABV -based serving size table does not reflect actual consumption for many 
spirits categories. 
Argument: 
 Low-ABV liqueurs are often used in cocktails in portions smaller than proposed 
reference sizes. 
 High ABV spirits may be dispensed in smaller measures either on their own or as 
cocktail components, which is increasingly popular. 
 RTDs and high-ABV beers/ciders are often sold and consumed in containers larger 
than the proposed serving size. 
 FDA’s RACC methodology better matches consumer expectations. 
Conclusion / Ask: Greater flexibility on serving sizes – Allow sizes to reflect actual 
consumption patterns, product type, ABV, and category norms, rather than fixed ABV -
based thresholds. 
6. Format and Presentation 
The proposed boxed, prescriptive panel format is not always feasible, especially for small 
bottles or multi-market labels. Most spirits have applied label s which constrain the use 
of additional printed information. 
Argument: 
 Linear formats without a box can be clearer and more space efficient. 
 Excess formatting rules can create conflicts with other jurisdictions. 
Conclusion / Ask: Allow linear formats without boxed borders; permit integration with 
existing branding. 
7. Tolerances and Compliance 
Nutrient and alcohol content can vary slightly between production runs. 
Argument: 
 ±20% tolerance is reasonable and aligns with other jurisdictions. 
 Exempting minor 'Serving Facts' updates from COLA resubmission reduces burdens. 
Conclusion / Ask: Retain ±20% tolerance; avoid mandatory COLA resubmission for minor 
factual updates. 4 
 
8. Implementation Timeline and Stock Sell-Through 
Label changes are costly and time -consuming, especially for small -volume, long-shelf-
life products. 
Argument: 
 A 5-year transition is proportionate. 
 Stock sell-through avoids waste. 
 Coordinating allergen and nutrition changes reduces costs. 
Conclusion / Ask: Retain 5 -year transition; allow sell -through; align implementation 
dates for Notices 237 and 238. 
9. Allergen Labeling 
The proposed allergen labeling could unintentionally apply to ingredients used before 
distillation. 
Argument: 
 Scientific consensus supports exemption for allergens removed by distillation. 
 Many jurisdictions already exempt such cases. 
Conclusion / Ask: Confirm no allergen labeling for pre-distillation ingredients; apply case-
by-case checks for post-distillation additions. 
 
Thank you for the opportunity to make a comment on these two important issues. 
 
Contact: 
Vaughn Renwick, CEO WIRSPA 
vaughn.renwick@wirspa.com

comment_text: See Attached
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages 
Docket No. TTB-2025-0002  
Notice No. 237: Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and 
Malt Beverages 
 
Comments submitted from  Jamaica Manufacturers and Exporters Association (JMEA) Member, 
Red Stripe, pertaining to the US TTB Alcohol Facts Statements Proposed Rule: 
 
1. Support for Consumer Transparency and Public Health 
  
We support the intent of the proposed rule to provide consumers with clear, consistent, and 
accessible information regarding alcohol content, calories, and macronutrients. This aligns 
with public health goals and empowers consumers to make informed decisions. 
However, we urge TTB to ensure that the implementation of these requirements does not 
disproportionately burden small producers or create unintended barriers to market entry. 
  
2. Concerns Regarding Cost and Burden on Small Businesses 
While the proposed five-year compliance period is appreciated, we remain concerned about 
the cumulative costs of: 
• Label redesign and printing 
• Laboratory testing for nutrient content 
• Regulatory compliance and recordkeeping 
  
We recommend that TTB consider the following mitigations: 
• Providing a simplified compliance pathway for small producers, such as a tiered 
implementation schedule or reduced testing requirements. 
  
3. Flexibility in Label Format and Placement 
We support the proposed flexibility in allowing either panel or linear formats for the Alcohol 
Facts statement. This is particularly important for smaller containers and products with limited 
label space. 
We also support the removal of maximum type size restrictions and the allowance of dual-
column formats for multi-serving containers. 
  
4. Electronic Disclosure Options 
While we understand TTB’s concern about accessibility, we encourage the Bureau to 
reconsider allowing QR codes or web links as a supplemental—not exclusive—means of 
disclosure. This could reduce label clutter and allow for multilingual or dynamic content, 
especially for export markets. This is even more relevant in 2025 where in the USA nearly 90 % 
of the population owns a smartphone. 
  
5. Harmonization with FDA and International Standards 
We encourage TTB to continue aligning its labeling requirements with those of the FDA and 
international standards where feasible. This will reduce compliance complexity for producers 
operating across regulatory jurisdictions. 
  
6. Clarification on Alcohol Content Tolerances 
We support the proposed tolerances for alcohol content and nutrient declarations. However, 
we request clarification on how TTB will enforce these tolerances and whether periodic testing 
will be required post-implementation. 
  7. Implementation Timeline and COLA Flexibility 
  
We support the proposed five-year implementation period and the provision that new COLA 
applications will not be required solely for the addition of Alcohol Facts statements. This will 
significantly reduce administrative burden. 
  
8. Contrasting Label Background 
  
Additionally, please note that Red Stripe already discloses alcohol, calorie, and nutrient 
content on our labels in a clear and legible format, the introduction of a mandated contrasting 
background, without specific visual guidelines, poses practical concerns: 
• It could necessitate a complete redesign of label layouts across multiple SKUs, 
potentially impacting brand equity and incurring significant reprinting and compliance 
costs. 
• Without a clear and standardized definition of what qualifies as “contrasting,” there is a 
risk of inconsistent enforcement or rejection at port, which could disrupt exports. 
 
We would therefore recommend that TTB: 
• Provide clear design guidance or acceptable examples of compliant contrasting label 
background formats; 
• Allow some discretion in label design to preserve brand identity while meeting 
transparency objectives. 
  
Conclusion 
We appreciate the opportunity to comment on this important rulemaking. We believe that with 
thoughtful adjustments, the proposed Alcohol Facts labeling requirements can achieve their 
intended public health goals while minimizing undue burden on industry stakeholders.

comment_text: As a primary care doctor, I have a front row seat to the harm caused by alcohol. I've seen plenty of patients who had no idea that alcohol played a role in their disease, whether it was cancer or liver disease. I strongly support the proposed Alcohol Facts labeling rule and urge you to take it one step further: require standard drink information and explicit cancer warnings on every alcohol label. Alcohol is not an ordinary consumer product. Even moderate use increases the risk of several cancers. Without clear, accessible information, consumers cannot make fully informed choices. We already do this for other products with health risks. Alcohol should be no exception to the rule. The TTB should require the following on alcoholic beverage containers: (1) Standard drink labeling Listing the number of standard drinks per container would make it far easier for consumers to track their intake, as opposed to ABV and product volume that requires a complex calculation. Studies from Canada's Yukon territory show that when standard drink information is displayed on alcoholic beverage containers, it is highly effective. (2) A clear cancer warning. U.S. labels currently warn about drinking during pregnancy and impaired driving, but they do not explicitly mention cancer. Yet the evidence is clear: alcohol, even in small amounts, can increase the risk of breast, colon, and other cancers. The World Health Organization, the U.S. Surgeon General, and countries like Ireland have already called for these warnings. The study from Yukon, Canada also found that a simple label "Alcohol can cause cancer" boosted public awareness of the relationship between alcohol and cancer. By adding these two elements, the TTB could create a labeling standard that is not only informative, but life-saving. Alcohol use is common; its risks should therefore be common knowledge. Giving people the tools to understand what they're drinking and the health risks involved is a basic public health responsibility. I strongly support the current proposal and encourage the TTB to strengthen it with standard drink labeling and cancer warnings. These are small changes with the potential for a large impact by protecting health, saving lives, and ensuring consumers have the facts they need. Please prioritize the health and lives of Americans over alcohol industry profits.
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
As a primary care doctor, I have a front row seat to the harm caused by alcohol. I've seen plenty of patients who had no idea that alcohol played a role in their disease, whether it was cancer or liver disease.

I strongly support the proposed Alcohol Facts labeling rule and urge you to take it one step further: require standard drink information and explicit cancer warnings on every alcohol label.

Alcohol is not an ordinary consumer product. Even moderate use increases the risk of several cancers. Without clear, accessible information, consumers cannot make fully informed choices. We already do this for other products with health risks. Alcohol should be no exception to the rule.

The TTB should require the following on alcoholic beverage containers:
(1) Standard drink labeling
Listing the number of standard drinks per container would make it far easier for consumers to track their intake, as opposed to ABV and product volume that requires a complex calculation. Studies from Canada’s Yukon territory show that when standard drink information is displayed on alcoholic beverage containers, it is highly effective.

(2) A clear cancer warning. 
U.S. labels currently warn about drinking during pregnancy and impaired driving, but they do not explicitly mention cancer. Yet the evidence is clear: alcohol, even in small amounts, can increase the risk of breast, colon, and other cancers. The World Health Organization, the U.S. Surgeon General, and countries like Ireland have already called for these warnings. The study from Yukon, Canada also found that a simple label “Alcohol can cause cancer” boosted public awareness of the relationship between alcohol and cancer.

By adding these two elements, the TTB could create a labeling standard that is not only informative, but life-saving. Alcohol use is common; its risks should therefore be common knowledge. Giving people the tools to understand what they’re drinking and the health risks involved is a basic public health responsibility.

I strongly support the current proposal and encourage the TTB to strengthen it with standard drink labeling and cancer warnings. These are small changes with the potential for a large impact by protecting health, saving lives, and ensuring consumers have the facts they need.

Please prioritize the health and lives of Americans over alcohol industry profits.

comment_text: The Scotch Whisky Association (SWA) is grateful for the opportunity to provide comments regarding Docket No. TTB-2025-0002; Notice No. 237 on Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages. The SWA is the Scotch Whisky industry's trade association. We have over 90 member companies, from multinational spirits producers through to small family-run distillers, bottlers, blenders, and brand owners. Membership accounts for around 97% of the Scotch Whisky industry by production. Any rulemaking in this area is important for the SWA as the United States has long been the Scotch Whisky's biggest market by value, with exports worth £971 million in 2024. In addition, many of our larger members are also investors in the United States. You will find our detailed comments in the attached file.
