document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
SWA RESPONSE - Docket No. TTB–2025–0003; Notice No. 237  
 
1 
 
 
15 August 2025 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Director 
Regulations and Ruling Division , 
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade 
Bureau 
1310 G Street NW, Box 12 
 Washington, DC 20005 
 
Re: Docket No. TTB -2025-0002; Notices No. 237 and 238 – Alcohol 
Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and 
Malt Beverages; and Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, 
Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages 
 
Dear Director, 
 
The Scotch Whisky Association (SWA) is grateful for the opportunity to provide comments to The 
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) regarding  Docket No. TTB -2025-0002; Notice 
No. 237 on Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits. 
 
The SWA is the Scotch Whisky industry ’s trade association . We have over 90 member 
companies, from multinational spirits producers through to small family -run distillers, bottlers, 
blenders, and brand owners. Membership accounts for around 97% of the Scotch Whisky 
industry by production.  
 
Any rulemaking in this area is important for the SWA as the United States has long been the 
Scotch Whisky’s biggest market by value, with exports worth £971 million in 2024. In addition, 
many of our larger members are also investors in the United States. 
 
We fully support TTB's efforts to ensure that consumers have the relevant product information to 
make informed decisions. Our members have been doing this domestically and in their export 
markets, and consumers are already familiar with this practice. We w ould therefore like to 
submit specific comments below for your consideration on behalf of the Scotch Whisky industry. 
 
I. Notice No. 237 on Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled 
Spirits, and Malt Beverages 
 
Additional on -product labelling requirements present numerous disadvantages both to 
consumers and businesses, particularly SMEs. Distilled spirits are one of the most highly 
regulated products in the United States, subject to rigorous pre -approval processes for labels 
and formulas. Despite this, the industry has proactively developed and implemented various 
self-regulatory initiatives to provide consumers with additional non -mandatory product 
information, exceeding TTB guidelines. For example, many distille rs already disclose allergen 
details and “Serving Facts” statements either on labels, websites, or via QR codes, 
SWA RESPONSE - Docket No. TTB–2025–0003; Notice No. 237  
 
2 
 
demonstrating the industry’s leadership in enhancing product transparency. Companies using 
digital labelling in international markets have reported clear benefits.  
 
Voluntary information currently provided by our industry is displayed through a host of different 
means and formats . Specifying mandatory labelling requirements will  therefore inevitably cost 
every spirit producer, as they will be required to incur some form of label redesign and printing 
costs, no matter their current level of voluntary disclosure of product information.  The SWA 
therefore recommends retaining the voluntary approach to additional product information. 
However, should the TTB pursue a mandato ry regime, we recommend the following 
considerations be taken into account. A key concern for us is to ensure that new rules are as 
flexible as possible, and do not result in unnecessary cost or burden for companies, while 
improving information to consumers. 
 
Product Information Statement: Serving Facts v. Alcohol Facts 
 
We recommend that the title of the alcohol beverages information statement be “Serving Facts” 
instead of “Alcohol Facts” as the content of the statement refers to the serving size and the 
nutritional information in a serving of a specific alcoholic beverag e. “Alcohol Facts” could 
confuse consumers as it may suggest that the statement includes general indications on the 
consumption of alcoholic beverages. In addition, consumers are accustomed to finding 
nutritional information in a “Serving Facts” statement because most operators who currently 
voluntarily disclose the information use “Serving Facts” as the title. Changing the labels of 
alcoholic beverages would generate additional costs for manufacturers, importers, and 
distributors, negatively affecting an industry that already works well in disclosing information 
effectively. 
 
Display of the Product Information Statement: Digital labelling benefits  
 
We continue to recommend that “Serving Facts” information be allowed to be provided through 
digital labelling, particularly via digital QR codes. Spirits labels are already required to include a 
great deal of information in the same field of vision. Numero us studies have concluded that the 
more health information a physical label has, the less attention the consumer pays to that 
information. To avoid over-crowding labels, and consequently confusing consumers, any newly 
required information should be allowed to be provided through a website or QR code.  
 
While some consumer organisations oppose digital labelling on the grounds that it places the 
burden on consumers and puts them at a disadvantage , there are no significant studies that 
support this argument.  Digital labelling is not prohibitive for consumers considering that over 
90% of adult Americans own a smartphone device and 95% of adults use the internet.1 Notably, 
mobile phone ownership amongst senior citizens has been found to be as high as 94%, with 76% 
owning smartphones.2 The three largest phone carriers in the US currently each claim that their 
4G LTE network covers more than 99% of the US population, so consumers in both urban and 
rural areas should have access to the necessary coverage to access online information  in retail 
settings. Furthermore, digital labels can assist with accessibility requirements, facilitating 
product information in multiple languages and allowing auditory text -to-speech access on 
devices.  
 
1 Pew Research – Mobile Fact Sheet. January 31, 2024, https://www.pewresearch.org/internet/fact-sheet/mobile/#who-
owns-cellphones-and-smartphone; Pew Research – Internet, Broadband Fact Sheet. January 31, 2024, 
https://www.pewresearch.org/internet/fact-sheet/internet-broadband/. 
2 Consumer Affairs – Cell phone statistics 2025. https://www.consumeraffairs.com/cell_phones/cell-phone-statistics.html SWA RESPONSE - Docket No. TTB–2025–0003; Notice No. 237  
 
3 
 
 
Some research suggests that gender, age, education and socioeconomic status might not have 
significant influence on intention to purchase product with a QR code applied to it.  Additionally, 
the presence of QR codes on products correlates to increased consumer comprehension and 
confidence about the product they are buying. It was likened to being in a traditional market, 
where one can speak to a vendor; a QR code allows the consu mer to find out much more than 
they would normally be able to do in a supermarket. QR codes also reduce the chances of there 
being multiple labels in market for the same brand as it goes through reformulation. This assists 
with avoiding consumer confusion when they encounter brand labels with different values side 
by side. Consumers are more trusting of digital label claims, in particular about the traceability 
of ingredients and components, manufacturing processes and environmental claims.3 
 
Today, digital labelling has become a universally accessible, convenient, and user -friendly 
feature, with consumers being able to access information easily through means of a smart phone 
or other electronic device. Digital labelling comes with several additional benefits: 
• Reduction of Costs for SMEs:  Digital labelling allows for quick adaptation to new legal 
requirements without having to design and print new labels. All companies, but 
especially SMEs, will reduce labelling costs and will have the opportunity to explore new 
export markets around the w orld, including the US. This will benefit foreign companies, 
but also US distillers, who will be able to use labels that are commonly used 
internationally with only additional information to be modified online. 
• Sustainability: digital labelling is beneficial for environmental protection, as  it reduces 
waste and costs associated with changes to traditional physical labels.  Many sectors 
(including the Scotch Whisky industry) are committed to sustainable packaging 
practices, of which labels are an essential part. The destruction of labels that are 
commonly used in the US market and the process of printing new la bels, with the 
significant amount of energy involved, will have a major environmental impact. This could 
be a recurring issue every time labelling regulations are updated. However, by using 
digital labelling businesses can reduce waste, conserve resources, and positively impact 
the environment. 
• Geo-specific information:  Recycling information and other sustainability -related 
information which are location -specific can easily be integrated into digital labels. One 
such example in Europe is in Italy, where mandatory recycling information for glass 
bottles can be provided in a geo-localised manner via QR-code-accessible digital labels 
since last year.  
 
Digital labels have been broadly implemented as a solution to provide access to product 
information for consumers across Europe, and we believe this could be replicated for US 
consumers. The future of food and beverage labelling is digital. The use of this innovative 
measure is transformative and beneficial for the US market, where almost 97% of the population 
owns a mobile phone. Future trends predict that the number of American smartphone users 
will increase to more than 364 million people by 2040 4. Digital labelling would be more 
effective in enabling consumers to make informed choices about their health, dietary 
restrictions, and the environmental impact of their consumption. 
 
 
3 Digital Labelling in the EU State -of-play Report. EDELMAN for Food FoodDrinkEurope. See: 
https://www.fooddrinkeurope.eu/wp-content/uploads/2024/01/FoodDrinkEurope_State-of-play-research-report-on-
digital-labelling_May-2023.pdf 
4 Consumer Affairs – Cell phone statistics 2025. See: https://www.consumeraffairs.com/cell_phones/cell-phone-
statistics.html SWA RESPONSE - Docket No. TTB–2025–0003; Notice No. 237  
 
4 
 
In the undesirable situation where nutritional information could only be provided on a physical 
label, we kindly request to be given the option of using a linear display that is not surrounded by 
a box. The space available for labelling distilled spirits is limited and a box around the claim would 
unnecessarily take up space on the label. In addition, we believe that the title “Serving Facts” in 
bold type is sufficient to allow consumers to easily locate the information on the label.  
Furthermore, we request that TTB, at minimum, consider allowing producers to list only nutrients 
present in the product instead of having to print the entire statement with multiple zeros.  
We would like to stress that, pursuant to Articles 2.2 and 2.3 of the WTO TBT Agreement, technical 
regulations shall not be prepared, adopted, or applied with the purpose or effect of creating 
unnecessary obstacles to international trade to fulfill the legitimate objectives of member states. 
Content of Product Information Statement 
 
Distilled spirits are not significant sources of nutritional value for consumers. Scotch Whisky, 
under UK regulation, can only be produced in Scotland from cereals, water and yeast, with no 
flavourings or sweeteners. Because of the stringently regulated di stillation process, Scotch 
Whisky spirits do not contain carbohydrates, fat, or protein. Requiring extensive nutritional 
information on labels, especially when most of the nutritional facts are not applicable to distilled 
spirits, risks confusing consumers into the belief that they have a "nutritional benefit” and that 
some alcoholic beverages are more nutritious than others. This is especially so if the statement 
contains additional information such as protein, vitamins and minerals, sodium, and further 
breakdown of fats, as considered in Notice No. 237.  
TTB asked for views on greater harmonization with the Food and Drug Administration’s  (FDA) 
nutrient content statements. We believe this would be unnecessary and misleading for the same 
reasons outlined above. No other country requires daily value information for listed nutrients on 
distilled spirits labels, as it would deviate from common global practices . It is well -understood 
that the consumption of spirits  provide no significant nutritional value and is not part of a 
consumer’s daily dietary needs. Furthermore, the adoption of FDA nutrition facts levels on spirits 
would also impose significant costs and burdens to our industry. 
The SWA therefore recommends that any nutritional information required to be provided under 
the “Serving Facts” be limited in scope and accessible via QR code. If the TTB adopts the 
requirement for a “Serving Facts” statement, the SWA would also recommend the following: 
• We welcome the proposed 20% tolerance for energy and nutritional calculations.  It 
would be beneficial for TTB to explicitly recognise that producers can continue to rely on 
databases and calculators to provide nutrient content information without having to 
undertake costly and burdensome laboratory testing on each of their products, 
particularly for brand extensions that might have variation in ABV from bottle to bottle, 
such as cask-strength whiskies. 
• The “Serving Facts” statement should not be required to include the alcohol content 
statement. For distilled spirits, the ABV is already required to appear in the same field of 
vision as the brand name and the class designation. Consumers are accustomed to  
finding this information on the main/front label. Particularly in the case of physical labels, 
space is limited and including it to the “Serving Facts” would not add any value.  
• We kindly request to keep the provision of the quantity of pure alcohol per serving in the 
“Serving Facts” statement optional. Providing this information without context would not 
necessarily empower consumers to make informed choices if the concept of pur e 
alcohol is not well understood. The presence of a QR code on a label could facilitate the 
provision of substantive information on the concepts of pure alcohol and standard SWA RESPONSE - Docket No. TTB–2025–0003; Notice No. 237  
 
5 
 
drinks, as well as TTB’s Dietary Guidelines, which would not be practically feasible on a 
physical label. 
• We would welcome more flexibility from TTB on the proposed serving sizes , which can 
vary from country to country depending on the ABV of the product. For instance, Scotch 
Whisky has a wide variety of products, some of which go beyond 40% ABV and for which 
the serving size would differ. Furthermore, r igid one-size-fits-all serving size 
requirements based on ABV could lead to several unintended consequences.  This 
includes consumers incorrectly conflat ing “serving size” with recommended 
consumption amount, the latter of which may drastically differ depending on the brand 
and ABV. This is especially so when the spirit is consumed as part of a mixed drink. Rigid 
serving sizes may undermine brand integrity and inadvertently encourage higher alcohol 
and calorie consumption. For these reasons, we recommend TTB’s proposed serving size 
guidelines remain optional, while permitting customized serving sizes where justified by 
product type and consumption patterns. 
• We welcome the fact that TTB will not require operators to submit new COLA applications 
when the only change being made to a label is the inclusion or alteration of the “Serving 
Facts” statement. This should also be extended to the case where the only change is the 
inclusion or al teration of the QR code, if it is permitted to provide the “Serving Facts” 
statement in this manner. 
 
Compliance Period, Stock Exhaustion, Alignment with TTB Notice No. 238  
 
In the event the proposed rulemaking contained in Notice No. 237 is adopted, the SWA endorses 
the proposed transition period of 5 years. Any shorter period for compliance would present 
difficulties for our members given our sector’s current economic climate. 
Furthermore, we would like to request the possibility for our operators to exhaust all their stock 
which was put on the market before the proposed rule comes into effect. The stock turnover of 
our products can often be slower than for other categories of distilled spirits. 
Finally, we further recommend that its implementation is aligned with that of Notice No. 238 on 
Major Food Allergen Labeling for Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages, along with any other 
ingredient labeling proposal TTB might be considering . This would allow businesses to comply 
with all labelling requirements within similar implementation periods.  
In conclusion, the Scotch Whisky industry remains firmly committed to ensuring consumers 
have access to clear and relevant product information. However, we respectfully urge the TTB to 
carefully assess the potential impact of any new requirements —both to a void placing undue 
burdens on businesses, particularly SMEs, and to prevent consumer confusion regarding the 
nature of our products. 
 
Yours sincerely, 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
María José Kong  
Head of Trade Americas  
Scotch Whisky Association

comment_title: Comment 175:  Alcohol Justice, American Society for Nutrition, and 15 Other Organizations and 5 Individuals
comment_text: See attached file(s)
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
August 15, 2025 
Regulations and Ruling Division  
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau  
1310 G Street NW, Box 12  
Washington, DC 20005 
Comment on Proposed Rule: Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, 
and Malt Beverages (Docket No. TTB-2025-0002) 
 
The undersigned organizations call on the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) to finalize 
the proposed rule mandating on-package labeling of alcohol content and nutritional information. These 
rules will be a step forward, as current alcohol labels do not provide the information that consumers need 
to make informed purchasing and consumption decisions. 
 
The “Alcohol Facts” panel set forth by the proposed rule includes “alcohol content expressed both as a 
percentage of alcohol by volume and in fluid ounces of pure ethyl alcohol per serving, the number of 
calories, and the number, in grams, of carbohydrates, fat, and protein, per serving.”
1  
While this information represents a major step forward, the rule could be strengthened by additionally 
requiring sugars in grams, added sugars in grams, saturated fat in grams, sodium in milligrams, percent 
Daily Value for each nutrient based on a 2,000-calorie diet, number of standard drinks per container, the 
conversion between standard drinks and fluid ounces of pure ethyl alcohol, and the 2020-2025 Dietary 
Guidelines for Americans moderate drinking advice. The final rule should also make dual-column 
labeling mandatory. 
This additional information is important as part of a commonsense approach to promoting transparency, 
health, and safety for those who consume alcohol. Excess alcohol consumption is associated with various 
harms including motor vehicle accidents, liver disease, cardiovascular disease, and certain cancers.2 
Alcoholic beverages may also contribute to other forms of diet-related chronic disease as alcohol is 
calorie-dense and on average accounts for 9% of daily calories for those who drink.3 Many alcoholic 
beverages also contain carbohydrates, added sugars, and other nutrients to limit. Alcohol content labeling 
is a straightforward approach that increases consumer awareness of the contents of alcoholic beverages 
through greater transparency.4 
 
Consumers desire this information and would use it to make decisions about alcohol consumption and 
purchasing. In a March 2024 poll of 1,509 adults who drink alcohol (commissioned by CSPI and 
conducted by Big Village), strong majorities (78-90%) said alcohol content, calorie content, and 
nutritional content, would be at least somewhat important for their alcohol purchasing decisions.
5 
 
We agree with the requirement in the proposed rule that the “Alcohol Facts” disclosure appear on-
package and never solely via electronic means (e.g., a QR code leading to a webpage), as this would 
specifically disadvantage populations that are less able to utilize smart phones or similar technology 
(including those who are older or living rurally). 
 
We urge TTB to prioritize transparency and health and finalize the proposed Alcohol Facts rule to ensure 
that Americans can make more informed decisions about what and how much to drink. To ensure timely 
consumer access to this important information, the final rule should adopt a shorter compliance period of 
3.5 years instead of the 5-year period proposed. 
 
  Sincerely, 
 
Alcohol Justice 
American Society for Nutrition 
Association of State Public Health Nutritionists 
Celiac Disease Foundation 
Center for Science in the Public Interest 
Consumer Federation of America 
Consumer Reports 
CURED 
FARE (Food Allergy Research & Education) 
Food Equality Initiative 
Interfaith Public Health Network 
National Consumers League 
Project Extra Mile 
Recover Alaska 
The FPIES Foundation 
U.S. Alcohol Policy Alliance 
Winooski Partnership for Prevention 
 
Individuals: 
 
Sarah Ermer, MPH, CHES 
Prevention Specialist 
Tillamook Family Counsel 
 
Thomas K. Greenfield 
Senior Scientist 
Alcohol Research Group 
 
Marissa Hall 
Assistant Professor 
University of North Carolina 
 
Kaela Plank 
Health Program Planner 
San Francisco Department of Public Health 
 
Lisa R. Young, PhD, RDN 
Adjunct Professor of Nutrition 
New York University 
 
  References 
 
1 90 Fed. Reg. 6654. Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt 
Beverages. 
2 World Health Organization. Global Status Report on Alcohol and Health.; 2018. Accessed March 22, 
2024. https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/274603/9789241565639-eng.pdf?sequence=1  
3 Dietary Guidelines Advisory Committee. Scientific Report of the 2020 Dietary Guidelines Advisory 
Committee: Advisory Report to the Secretary of Agriculture and the Secretary of Health and Human 
Services. Part D. Chapter 11: Alcoholic Beverages. U.S. Department of Agriculture, Agricultural 
Research Service; 2020. Accessed March 6, 2024. 
https://www.dietaryguidelines.gov/sites/default/files/2020-07/PartD_Ch11_AlcoholicBev_first-print.pdf  
4 Wettlaufer A. Can a Label Help me Drink in Moderation? A Review of the Evidence on Standard Drink 
Labelling. Subst Use Misuse. 2018;53(4):585-595. doi:10.1080/10826084.2017.1349798 
5 Big Village’s CARAVAN U.S. Online Omnibus Survey, administered March 15-20, 2024.

Nutrient

and

of

Distilled
 
Spirits,
 
and

Beverages.
 
The

alcohol
 
beverage
 
labels

include
 
Serving
 
Facts
 
statements
 
on

basis
 
while

Bureau

to

the

withdrew

Serving
 
Facts
 
rulemaking
 
from

Agenda
 
of

and
 
Deregulatory

in
 
the

of

In  the  intervening  years,  the  TTB  has  received  letters  from  various  groups  to  revisit  the  potential  
for
 
changes
 
to
 
beverage
 
alcohol
 
labels.
 
Additionally,
 
in

issued

report,
 
“Competition
 
in
 
the
 
Markets
 
for

Wine,
 
and
 
Spirits.”
 
The
 
competition
 
report
 
recommended

TTB
 
should
 
revive
 
or
 
initiate
 
rulemaking
 
proposing
 
ingredient
 
labeling
 
and
 
mandatory  information  on  alcohol  content,  nutritional  content,  and  appropriate  serving  sizes.  
Consistent
 
with

TTB
 
published
 
Notice
 
No.
 
232,

two

listening

on

28
 
and
 
29,
 
2024,
 
and
 
the

of

docket
 
to
 
receive
 
public
 
input

labeling
 
of
 
wine,
 
distilled
 
spirits,
 
and
 
malt
 
beverages
 
with
 
per-serving
 
alcohol
 
and
 
nutritional
 
information,
 
major
 
food
 
allergens,
 
and/or
 
ingredients.

received
 
over

in

to
 
Notice
 
No.
 
232
 
and
 
heard
 
from
 
47
 
speakers
 
during
 
the
 
listening
 
sessions.
 
TTB  is  now  publishing  for  public  comment  a  new  proposal  that  would  require  “Alcohol  Facts”  
labeling
 
for
 
wines,

spirits,
 
and
 
malt
 
beverages
 
that
 
provides
 
alcohol
 
and
 
nutritional
 
information,
 
per
 
serving,
 
for
 
these
 
products
 
on
 
labels.

is
 
addressing
 
the
 
Competition
 
Report's

and
 
Notice
 
No.
 
232
 
comments
 
from

sessions
 
on
 
mandatory
 
allergen
 
and

Title  of  the  Alcohol  Beverage  Statement  
TTB  is  proposing  “Alcohol  Facts”  as  the  title  of  the  informational  statement,  instead  of  “Serving  
Facts,”
 
which
 
was
 
proposed
 
in
 
2007.
 
WineAmerica
 
does
 
not
 
support
 
this
 
change
 
as
 
it
 
would
 
create
 
confusion
 
for
 
consumers
 
who
 
have
 
grown
 
accustomed
 
to
 
the
 
existing
 
alcohol
 
content
 
statement
 
on
 
beverage
 
alcohol
 
labels.
  
We
 
will
 
now
 
address
 
TTB’s
 
specific
 
questions:
 
1.  Which  title,  “Serving  Facts”  or  “Alcohol  Facts,”  would  be  more  informative  to  consumers?  
Does
 
the
 
title
 
“Alcohol
 
Facts”
 
better
 
describe
 
the
 
information
 
provided
 
in
 
the
 
proposed
 
statement,
 
which
 
includes
 
per-serving
 
alcohol
 
content
 
information?
 
The  title  of  “Serving  Facts”  will  be  more  informative  to  consumers.  The  consumer  is  already  
accustomed
 
to
 
the
 
alcohol
 
content
 
disclosure
 
to
 
inform
 
how
 
much
 
alcohol
 
is
 
in
 
the
 
labeled
 
product.
 
Creating
 
an
 
“Alcohol
 
Facts”
 
disclosure
 
will
 
only
 
confuse
 
the
 
consumer.
 
2.  Would  the  use  of  the  title  “Alcohol  Facts”  affect  compliance  costs  or  regulatory  burdens  by  
requiring
 
a
 
title
 
change
 
for
 
products
 
already
 
voluntarily
 
labeled
 
with
 
a
 
“Serving
 
Facts”
 
statement?
 
Yes,  the  producers  who  are  already  voluntarily  disclosing  serving  facts  and  nutrition  information  
will
 
need
 
to
 
redo
 
all
 
of
 
their
 
existing
 
labels
 
at
 
significant
 
cost.
 
 
3.  Are  consumers  accustomed  to  finding  nutrient  content  information  in  a  Serving  Facts  
statement?
 
Would
 
changing
 
the
 
title
 
to
 
“Alcohol
 
Facts”
 
cause
 
confusion?
 
Yes,  as  described  above,  the  consumer  already  knows  to  look  for  the  alcohol  content  statement,  
and
 
the
 
serving
 
facts
 
should
 
remain
 
separate
 
from
 
that.
 
4.  Alternatively,  does  the  title  “Alcohol  Facts”  make  it  easier  for  consumers  to  readily  
distinguish
 
alcohol
 
beverages
 
from
 
other
 
food
 
items?
 
That  is  unknown,  as  it  does  not  currently  exist  in  any  form.  Alcohol  consumers  already  are  able  
to
 
distinguish
 
alcohol
 
beverages
 
from
 
other
 
food
 
items
 
through
 
the
 
Government
 
Warning
 
statement
 
and
 
alcohol
 
disclosure,
 
which
 
is
 
not
 
on
 
other
 
food
 
items.

below
 
the
 
labeled
 
amount.
 
TTB
 
believes
 
that
 
these
 
proposed
 
changes
 
will
 
facilitate
 
the
 
use
 
of
 
“typical
 
values”
 
charts
 
and
 
other
 
methodologies
 
to
 
calculate
 
the
 
calories,
 
carbohydrates,
 
fat,
 
and
 
protein
 
content
 
of
 
an
 
alcohol
 
beverage
 
product.
 
TTB
 
is
 
also
 
proposing
 
to
 
expand
 
the
 
alcohol
 
content
 
tolerance
 
for
 
malt
 
beverage
 
labeling
 
statements.
 
This
 
means
 
bottlers
 
would
 
be
 
less
 
likely
 
to
 
have
 
to
 
change
 
labels
 
due
 
to
 
minor
 
variations
 
in
 
alcohol
 
content
 
among
 
different
 
batches.
 
Wine
 
America
 
supports
 
this
 
as
 
well.
 
 
Conclusion  
WineAmerica  would  like  to  thank  TTB  for  the  opportunity  to  comment  on  the  proposed  
rulemaking:
 
Notice
 
237:
 
Alcohol
 
Facts
 
Statements
 
in
 
the
 
Labeling
 
of
 
Wines,
 
Distilled
 
Spirits,
 
and
 
Malt
 
Beverages.
 
To
 
sum
 
up
 
our
 
main
 
points:
  ●  An  off-label/web  based  solution  should  be  allowed  for  disclosure  of  serving  facts.  ●  On-label  disclosure  should  be  in  a  linear  format.  ●  In  order  to  avoid  confusion,  the  disclosure  should  be  referred  to  as  SERVING  FACTS,  
not
 
ALCOHOL
 
FACTS.
 ●  Testing  of  each  product  should  not  be  required.  ●  We  hope  that  TTB  will  bear  in  mind  that  the  10,000+  American  wineries  are  
predominantly
 
small
 
family
 
farms
 
with
 
very
 
limited
 
resources,
 
and
 
that
 
$1600
 
per
 
label
 
and
 
$500
 
per
 
product
 
test
 
would
 
be
 
a
 
major
 
financial
 
burden.
  Respectfully  submitted.    Michael  Kaiser  Executive  Vice  President  and  Director  of  Government  Affairs
