comment_text: Please see attached comment from Wine Institute.
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
Page 1 of 10  
 
 
August 15, 2025 
 
Ms. Amy Greenberg 
Director, Regulations and Rulings Division 
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau  
1310 G Street NW, Box 12 
Washington, DC 20005 
 
RE: Docket No. TTB-2025-0002, Notice No. 237: Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of 
Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages  
 
Dear Ms. Greenberg, 
 
Wine Institute is the public policy advocacy association representing over 1,000 California 
wineries and affiliated businesses.  Our membership consists of wineries of all sizes including 
many small, family-owned wineries.  California is responsible for more than 81 percent of the 
nation’s wine production and more than 95 percent of US wine exports.   W e provide the 
following comments in response to Notice of Proposed Rulemaking No. 237: Alcohol Facts 
Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages (NPRM 237). 
 
In general, Wine Institute supports the current “Serving Facts” framework as voluntary.  If TTB 
imposes mandatory Serving Facts labeling, we respectfully request a similar framework but 
with several important recommendations and considerations that we outline below.   
 
1. Wine is Unique—it is not a Recipe Product—and Wineries Vary Greatly in Size 
 
It is important to note at the outset that wine is u nique.  Wine is not a recipe product.  Unlike 
other beverages, wine is inherently tied to its place of origin.  Every vintage is different, and 
each wine varies by year, winegrape varietal, location, climate and growing conditions.   
Because the winemaking process is dynamic and highly variable, decisions impacting 
nutritional content can be made right up to the time of blending and bottling.  This is significant 
because wine labels are most often printed many months in advance of bottling and changes 
to those labels can take up to two years to implement. 
Beyond the vineyard and winery, the wine marketplace is also distinct in terms of both the 
number of producers and unique wines available.   According to TTB, there are currently more 
than 17,500 bonded wine producers across the US  and approximately 6,300 of them are in 
California.  Like our membership, the overwhelming majority of these are small, family-owned 
Page 2 of 10  
wineries that operate in a heavily regulated industry with correspondingly high cost s in 
establishing and maintaining their businesses.  Therefore, it is critical that any new regulations 
be fiscally responsible, reasonable, minimally intrusive to winery operations, and adopted only 
if legitimate public goals and established benefits to consumers justify them.  In furtherance 
of those good rulemaking principles, TTB should consider whether it has sufficient information 
and stakeholder input to design and implement new labeling rules  at this time.  We note that 
NPRM 237 poses more than  80 questions and expressly solicits comments on over 45 topics 
that range from general to specific.   That leaves many  of the issues subject to change  and 
creates a challenge for stakeholders to provide sufficient information and data in the time 
provided.  G iven that NPRM 237 constitute s a “significant regulatory action”  if adopted, it is 
important that the issues are fully vetted and TTB  is fully informed before deciding whether or 
how to proceed. 
 
Cost Burden Falls Unevenly on Wine 
It is appropriate that TTB is required to design regulations, including this proposed regulation, 
in the most cost-effective , least burdensome  manner while still achieving the intended 
regulatory objective.  We applaud TTB for seeking industry input in attempting to accurately 
estimate the costs, however, we are concerned that TTB ’s cost analysis does not fully reflect 
the likely fiscal impact on the nation’s 17,000+ wineries.  
 
TTB’s analysis of the cost impact on wineries is based in large part on NielsenIQ data including 
an estimate of the number of universal product codes (UPCs) associated with wines in the US 
marketplace.  We are very concerned that focusing on UPCs  may vastly undercount the 
number of wine labels that this proposal would require to be changed.  Many wine labels do 
not include a UPC  because thousands of wineries rely on non-traditional sales channels 
including direct-to-consumer (DTC) sales and winery tasting room sales  where a UPC is not 
needed.  DTC wine sales are a unique and important feature of the wine marketplace now that 
48 states and the District of Columbia allow some form of DTC wine sales.  Wine analytics firm, 
bw166, has done research showing that Nielsen/NIQ data represents only 54 percent of all tax 
paid volume entering the US wine market in 2024.
1  
 
If TTB’s analysis does  not appropriately account for the gaps in the data it is using , then it is 
likely that its analysis grossly underestimates the potential costs for wineries.   We are 
concerned this analysis undercount s the thousands of wines that do not reach consumers 
through traditional distribution and retail channels  and thus are not accounted for in the 
Nielsen data.  Between 2018 and 2024, TTB approved an average of 113,536 COLAs for wine 
per year.  In recent years, TTB has also expanded the list of items that may be revised on wine 
labels without the need to resubmit a new COLA application.  This list now includes forty 
different pieces of information that can be changed without the need for a new COLA which 
suggests that many COLAs may be active in the marketplace for multiple years  (if not many 
years).  As a result, bw166 estimates that there are between 300,000 and 400,000 distinct wine 
products for sale in the US at any given time  and which would require a newly designed label  
 
1 https://www.bw166.com/data-science-services/  Page 3 of 10  
as a result of this proposed regulation. 2  The sheer size and diversity of the wine marketplace 
means the cost of this proposal would be significant for wineries of all sizes. 
 
We also note that as presented in NPRM 237, TTB’s cost analysis demonstrates that the cost 
burden of the proposal will fall disproportionately on wine producers.  Table 4 shows that with 
a five-year compliance period, fully 49 percent  of the total cost of the proposal would fall to 
wineries, while spirits and beer producers would face half the cost  of wineries.  Yet when TTB 
estimates the number of Total Units in the marketplace in Table 1, wine constitutes only 18  
percent of the Total Units. Wine Institute is very concerned about the impact this uneven cost 
burden will have on the t housands of small and medium sized wineries in the US.  We are 
continuing to review TTB’s cost analysis and seek input from our winery members on the 
anticipated costs of this proposal and will be sharing that information with TTB when available. 
 
2. Wineries Should be Allowed to Provide Serving Facts Information by Electronic 
Means (e.g., QR Codes) 
 
In NPRM 237, TTB explains  that it considered but is not proposing to allow the Serving Facts 
panel to be distributed by electronic means via a link, code, or other marking on the physical 
label.  Instead, TTB proposes requiring the full panel to appear on the physical label, but it also 
sought comments about its assumptions on this topic. 
 
Established Benefits of Permitting QR Codes 
Permitting the use of electronic means —such as a Quick Response ( QR) code—to present 
Serving Facts would provide many be nefits to many  stakeholders including consumers, 
producers, retailers, and regulators.  In NPRM 237, TTB recognized some of the benefits.  They 
included cost -efficiency, flexibility, reduction in time -to-market, and the ability to present 
relevant information in a more consumer -friendly format that is away from overcrowded 
physical labels.  There are other benefits, however, including: 
 
• Translation of e-label content into the language of the consumer  in real time, which is 
not possible using physical labels.   This is already used to comply with the E uropean 
Union’s (EU) labeling requirements for wine—which permits mandatory nutrition and 
ingredient information via QR code—given the EU’s 24 official languages. 
• Enhanced accessibility via new audio technologies for the visually impaired.
3 
• Reduced waste, consistent with industry sustainability goals, since the use of e-labels 
reduces label re-prints. 
 
 
 
2 https://www.bw166.com/2025/07/28/tariffs-pricing-and-volume/  
3 See, e.g., Blind Welfare Society, available at  https://blindwelfaresociety.in/blogs/innovative-food-packaging-solutions-
making-food-more-accessible-for-the-visually-impaired (“QR codes can link to audio descriptions when scanned with 
a smartphone.  This feature can provide detailed information about the product, including ingredients, cooking 
instructions, and dietary information.”) ; see also, BBC News, The codes helping visually -impaired people shop, 
available at https://www.bbc.com/news/business-57679943. Page 4 of 10  
QR Codes in the Marketplace 
Electronic means such as QR codes are already common in the marketplace.   For instance , 
in NPRM 237, TTB cited broad implementation of digital labels  for wine  in the EU and the 
benefits electronic information disclosure could have for international trade.   We agree that 
permitting Serving Facts information by electronic means in the US will help harmonize 
approaches, minimize negative trade impacts, and facilitate US wine exports.  
 
The EU is not the only place where mandatory disclosures are permitted exclusively via 
electronic means.   For example, the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) permits products 
that are subject to the National Bioengineered Food Disclosure Standard to provide the 
mandatory bioengineered symbol via QR code rather than on the physical label.
4  Likewise, in 
2023 amendments to the California Beverage Container Recycling and Litter Reduction Act , 
the Legislature made clear that the Department of Resources Recycling and Recover y “may 
require that a beverage container intended for sale in the state be … marked with a scan code, 
a quick response (QR) code, or a universal product code or similar machine-readable indicia” 
when providing the mandatory California Redemption Value or “CRV” mark rather than 
printing or embossing it on the container.5 
  
Notably, GS1—the international global standards organization for developing and maintaining 
barcodes—is working toward what it calls Sunrise 2027.  That is the year by which the global 
supply chain (manufacturers and retailers ) will move toward “two-dimensional barcodes ” 
(e.g., QR codes) .  According to GS1, b y the end of 2027, retailers w ill need to ensure their 
point-of-sale systems are equipped with scanners capable of reading both traditional 
barcodes and 2D barcodes.  The shift has already begun with the new technology being tested 
in 48 countries across the world.  In short, QR codes will become more ubiquitous, common 
and familiar to consumers, and accessible as manufacturers and retailers make this shift in 
the coming years. 
 
QR Code Accessibility 
As a related point, it is critical for TTB to consider the direction and pace at which technologies 
are trending along with consumer access, familiarity, and preferences.  For example, in NPRM 
237, TTB references a 2023 survey that the Pew Research Center conducted .  TTB notes the 
survey found that “79 percent of adults with annual incomes less than $30,000 owned 
smartphones compared to 90-98 percent of higher income groups.”  The same survey data for 
2024, however,  shows that 84 percent of adults with annual incomes less than $30,000 
reported owning smartphones.
6  That is a five percent increase over just one year.  Pew’s 2024 
survey data also shows that nine out of ten (91 percent) Americans now own a smartphone. 
 
Other information at the inter section of technology, consumer products, and public policy  
demonstrates that  QR codes and other electronic means  of conveying information are 
 
4 See 7 CFR 66.100(b)(3). 
5 See California Public Resources Code section 14561(d). 
6 See Pew Research Center, Mobile Fact Sheet, available at https://www.pewresearch.org/ internet/fact-sheet/
mobile. Page 5 of 10  
increasingly feasible, accept ed, and effective .  The Information Technology and Innovation 
Foundation issued a report in 2022 in which it found that (1) US mobile coverage is 
“ubiquitous,” (2) 4G covers “almost 100 percent of the population,” and (3) “improved fixed 
wireless and low-earth orbit satellites are emerging to fill the remaining gaps” over the coming 
years.7  According to GS1, recent survey data showed that 79 percent of consumers are more 
likely to purchase products with a scannable barcode/QR code (via smartphone) that provides 
the additional product information that they would want to see.8  That number will likely grow 
as QR codes become more common. 
 
Wine Labels Already Contain Other Mandatory Information on Limited Space 
Due to bottle sizes , wine labels are often mere inches  tall and wide .  Some label suppliers 
identify 3.5 x 4 inches as  the “common” or “traditional” size for the front label on a standard 
750 milliliter wine bottle.  Back labels are often  smaller.  In sum, there is limited space  to 
provide information.  That is important to note because physical labels are already subject to 
various federal and state laws that strictly prescribe what wine label s must include, may 
include, and may not include.  Below are non-exhaustive lists with some examples: 
 
• Wine label s must include: a government health warning; brand name; producer, 
bottler, or (if applicable) importer name and address; class or type designation; 
alcohol content statement; sulfite declaration (if present at 10 or more parts per 
million); net contents; color ingredient disclosures (if applicable);  an appellation of 
origin in certain circumstances; and, as a practical reality, a barcode.
9   
• Wine labels may include: a vintage date, winegrape variety, the term “estate bottled,” 
appellation of origin or approved American Viticultural Area, certification claims (if 
applicable), and other descriptive information that consumers desire including tasting 
and sensory notes, food pairing suggestions, recognizable trademarks, or information 
about the winery, winemaker, and winemaking process.
10 
• Wine labels may not include:  any statement that is false or untrue in any particular, or 
that, irrespective of falsity, directly, or by ambiguity, omission, or inference, or by the 
addition of irrelevant, scientific or technical matter, tends to create a misleading 
impression; that is  disparaging of a competitor's products; or any statement, design, 
device, or representation which is obscene or indecent; and more.
11 
 
In addition, labeling laws often dictate not only the  substance of what must or may be 
included on a label, but other details like the specific placement, font type, and font size used 
on labels.  Finally, wines set for export must comply with labeling regimes in the destination 
market.  As noted, this means US wines exported to the EU may use a QR code on the physical 
label to provide mandatory nutrition and ingredient information,  and—given there are 24 
 
7 See Information Technology and Innovation Foundation, The State of US Broadband in 2022: Reassessing the 
Whole Picture, https://itif.org/publications/2022/12/05/state-of-us-broadband-in-2022-reassessing-the-whole picture/. 
8 See id.; see also https://www.gs1us.org/content/dam/gs1us/documents/who-we-are/about-us/How-Product-
Data-Influences-Shoppers.pdf.  
9 See, generally, Wine Labeling: Checklist of Mandatory Labeling Information.  
10 See, generally, Optional Wine Label Information. 
11 See, generally, 27 CFR 4.39. Page 6 of 10  
official languages across the EU—many US wineries use this solution that EU lawmakers 
provided. 
 
In sum, if TTB imposes mandatory provision of Serving Facts, it should permit the use of QR 
codes or other electronic means to disclose that information as an alternative to printing it on 
labels. 
 
3. The Title of the Proposed Panel Should Remain as “Serving Facts” 
 
The current voluntary rules for disclosing nutritional information use the title “Serving Facts”  
and have since those rules initially issued in 2013.  In NPRM 237, TTB proposes now using the 
title “Alcohol Facts” but also seeks input on whether it should continue using “Serving Facts” 
instead. 
 
If TTB imposes mandatory provision of Serving Facts, it should continue using the title “Serving 
Facts” for several reasons.  The most obvious reason is consistency.   Again, since 2013, TTB 
has permitted the optional disclosure of the same nutritional information proposed in NPRM 
237 but under title “Serving Facts.”  That title is what consumers, producers, and retailers 
have come to know not only on labels but also websites and product fact sheets.  Changing 
that title after years of continued use will lik ely cause confusion.  Moreo ver, it is misleading 
and confusing to use the title “Alcohol Facts” when most of the information in the proposed 
panel has nothing to do with alcohol.  Instead, it presents information about serving size, 
servings per container, and respective amounts of calories, carbohydrates, fat, and protein 
per serving.  Finally, “Serving Facts” is sufficiently distinct from FDA’s “Nutrition Facts” title 
and thus avoids any confusion with beverages that do not contain alcohol.  The title sho uld 
remain as “Serving Facts.” 
 
4.  An Implementation Period of Five Years is Reasonable and Necessary 
 
TTB proposes a compliance date of five years from when a final rule is published in the Federal 
Register.  If TTB  imposes mandatory Serving Facts labeling , we strongly agree with the  
proposed five-year compliance period and with TTB’s sound reasons for proposing  it.  Five 
years would allow businesses to exhaust existing label stocks and prepare for new labeling 
processes which will help minimize —but not eliminate—financial and operation burdens.  It 
would allow ample time for public and stakeholder education  and regulatory guidance .  It 
would also allow time to align other resources like product fact sheets, websites, and 
advertising materials and ensure compliance.  Finally, as TTB noted in NPRM 237, five years is 
within the t ypical cycle for food and beverage products to relabel according t o an  FDA 
regulatory impact analysis for a food labeling rule.
12 
 
12 U.S. Food and Drug Administration, Regulatory Impact Analysis for Final Rules On: “Food Labeling: Revision of 
the Nutrition and Supplement Facts Labels” and “Food Labeling: Serving Sizes of Foods That Can Reasonably Be 
Consumed at One Eating Occasion; Dual -Column Labeling; Updating, Modifying, and Establishing Certain 
Reference Amounts Customarily Consumed; Serving Size for Breath Mints; and Technical Amendments,” 2016, 
available at https://www.fda.gov/media/98712/download. Page 7 of 10  
 
5. Proposed Serving Size and Servings Per Container Should be Maintained 
 
TTB proposes including a serving size of 2.5 fluid ounces for wines with above 16 to 24 percent 
Alcohol by Volume (ABV) and 5 fluid ounces for wines with 7 to 16 percent ABV.   TTB also 
proposes including the number of servings per container.  We consider the proposed serving 
sizes and a servings per container disclosure to be reasonable,  familiar to consumers , and 
consistent with what is used under the current voluntary rules and therefore appropriate to 
use if TTB imposes mandatory provision of Serving Facts. 
 
6.  A Single Alcohol Content Statement Expressed as ABV is Appropriate 
 
TTB proposes including an alcohol content statement—expressed as ABV per serving—for all 
wines including for those with 7 to 16 percent ABV and, underneath, a statement of alcohol 
content in fluid ounces of pure alcohol per serving.   
 
If TTB imposes mandatory provision of Serving Facts , it should require only one alcohol 
content statement expressed as ABV and not  require a statement in fluid ounces of pure 
alcohol per serving.  For many decades, ABV has been the near universal means for disclosing 
alcohol content for wines.  This is true in  the US and many parts of the world.  As a result, 
consumers are already familiar with and understand how to interpret ABV levels in wines.   
 
This consumer acceptance of ABV labeling is reflected not only in the US’s current labeling 
regulations but also in multiple trade agreements to which the US is a party.   The World Wine 
Trade Group Agreement on Requirements for Wine Labeling specifies that all parties must 
accept alcohol content labeling by volume (ABV).
13  Additionally, the US -Mexico-Canada 
Agreement (USMCA) includes a similar provision in Annex 3-C which also requires the parties 
to permit alcohol content labeling by volume. 14  In neither case do these agreements require 
or permit alcohol content labeling by other measures such as fluid ounces.  Likewise, the 
International Organization of Vine and Wine (OIV), in its International Standard for the Labeling 
of Wines, also includes alcohol strength expressed as a percentage of volume (ABV) as an 
item of compulsory information.
15 
 
ABV is what consumers know and understand.  A lcohol content expressed as ABV has long 
since been required for wines above 16 percent ABV and voluntarily used for most wines that 
are 7 to 16 percent ABV.  It is also used on spirits and malt beverages.   Thus, if  TTB adopts 
mandatory provision of ABV within the Serving Facts panel , that single disclosure should 
suffice and it should not also be required elsewhere on the label.   Wine Institute urges that  
TTB not require a statement in fluid ounces of pure alcohol per serving.   Unlike ABV, 
consumers are  unfamiliar with alcohol statements  in the form of fluid ounces and thus it  
 
13 https://www.wwtg.gov/assets/uploads/labelling-agreement.pdf. 
14 https://ustr.gov/sites/default/files/files/agreements/FTA/USMCA/Text/03_Agriculture.pdf . 
15https://www.oiv.int/sites/default/files/publication/202503/OIV%20Wine%20Labelling%20Standard%20EN_20
25%20complet.pdf. Page 8 of 10  
would cause confusion.  The fact that it would be presented in addition to ABV, would only 
compound the likelihood for confusion.  The ABV statement provides all that an interested 
consumer needs to determine how much alcohol they are consuming and in a familiar and 
common form.  
  
Likewise, ABV information will provide uniform labeling of alcohol content that will assist 
taxpayers in complying with their obligations under the Internal Revenue Code and will assist 
TTB in identifying alcohol beverage products that pose compliance risks .  Those are reasons 
TTB cites for proposing alcohol content labeling.  Also requiring a statement in fluid ounces of 
pure alcohol per serving  will have no added benefit .  Instead, it will potentially cause 
confusion and burden businesses. 
As a final point, requiring a statement in fluid ounces of pure alcohol per serving  could invite 
misleading and deceptive claims since it presents a number that appears lower than ABV and 
in a form that is unfamiliar to consumers (e.g., “Just 0.7 fluid ounces of alcohol!”).  TTB should 
avoid that problem by requiring only one alcohol content statement expressed as ABV .  It 
should not require a statement in fluid ounces of pure alcohol per serving. 
 
7.  TTB Should Consider Several Points Regarding Calories, Carbohydrate, Fat, 
Protein, and Sugar 
 
TTB proposes mandatory disclosure of calories  per serving, and carbohydrates, fat, and 
protein in grams per serving.  For sugar, the Serving Facts panel may express the number of 
total sugars in grams per serving.   
 
If TTB imposes mandatory provision of Serving Facts, requiring the amounts of calories, 
carbohydrates, fat, and protein in the Serving Facts panel does not present serious concerns 
for our members aside from those raised elsewhere in our comments (e.g., permitting 
provision via electronic means  like a QR code ).  That said, there are at least three important 
points that TTB should consider: 
• For carbohydrates, Wine Institute has  repeatedly expressed concern s about 
inaccuracies of the “by difference” method that TTB and FDA use for calculating 
carbohydrates in wine.  The “by difference” method as described by Merrill and Watt in 
the USDA publication, Energy Value of Foods: Basis and Derivation. Agriculture 
Handbook No. 74 (Merrill & Watt, 1973) is not accurate for wine.  TTB should work with 
FDA to permit the use of the more  accurate “quantitation and summation of sugars” 
approach as an approved method for calculating total carbohydrate content in wine 
and wine-based beverages. 
• In general, fat and protein amounts in wine will almost always be zero. 
• In general, California law prohibits the addition of sugar to wine.
16 
TTB should consider those points and perhaps seek further stakeholder input before imposing 
mandatory provision of Serving Facts. 
 
16 See Cal. Code Regs. tit. 17, § 17010. Page 9 of 10  
 
8. The Proposed Rules for Tolerances, Typical Values, and Format and Placements 
Options Should be Maintained 
TTB proposes an objective standard,  which allows a tolerance of 20 percent either above or 
below the labeled amount for calories, carbohydrates, protein, and fat.  TTB believes these 
proposed tolerances would facilitate the use of “typical values” charts and other 
methodologies to calculate the level of calories, carbohydrates, fat, and protein in alcohol 
beverage products.   
If TTB imposes mandatory provision of Serving Facts, we agree with the proposed “objective 
standard” tolerance of 20 percent and the continued ability to use “typical values” to calculate 
calories, carbohydrates, fat, and protein.  Doing so will help allev iate some of the cost, 
operational, and other burdens—including the need for repeated and expensive testing—while 
still providing adequate information.  We note, however, that most wines have very little or no 
fat or protein.  Consequently, if a winery nee ds to declare a non-zero level (e.g. less than 0.5 
grams per serving for fat and/or protein), a 20 percent tolerance level may be insufficient and 
indeed may be below the level of measurement uncertainty associated with the analytical 
method used.  We recommend that for low levels (e.g. less than one gram per serving) that an 
absolute level be used as the specified tolerance rather than a percent  of the declared value.  
This concept is already used in other markets.  As an example, in the EU for declared le vels of 
carbohydrates, protein, and fat in food that are under 10  grams/100 grams in concentration, 
the allowed tolerances are expressed in absolute terms (i.e., +/- 2 grams for carbohydrates and 
protein, and +/- 1.5 grams for fat).
17 
If TTB imposes mandatory provision of Serving Facts, we agree with its proposal to permit much 
needed flexibility in terms of format (e.g., panel or linear) and placement  (e.g., horizontal or 
vertical).  Likewise, we agree with TTB’s  proposal that if Serving Facts becomes  mandatory, it 
will not require industry members to submit new C ertificate of Label Approval applications 
when the only change being made to a label is the inclusion, or alteration, of a required Serving 
Facts panel or statement containing alcohol content information.  These important and flexible 
elements will help alleviate some of the cost and operational burdens on wineries and provide 
flexibility to decide what works best for their products.   We reiterate, however, that the best 
solution is to permit the provision of mandatory information via electronic means (QR codes) 
for the many reasons stated above. 
*** 
 
 
 
17 See Table 1, Guidance Document for Competent Authorities for the Control of Compliance with EU Legislation on 
Regulation EU 1169/2011, December 2012, available at https://food.ec.europa.eu/system/files/2016-10/labelling_ 
nutrition -vitamins_minerals-guidance_tolerances_1212_en.pdf.  Page 10 of 10  
In closing, Wine Institute thanks TTB for the opportunity to comment on the issues raised in 
NPRM 237.  We would be pleased to respond to any  follow-up questions that TTB might have 
concerning our comments. 
 
Thank you for your consideration. 
 
Robert P. Koch  
 
 
 
 
President & CEO 
Wine Institute

comment_text: Please see our comment letter attached.
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text: Please see our comment letter attached.

comment_text: Please see our comment letter attached.
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
August 15, 2025 
 
Director, Regulations and Ruling Division 
Alcohol, and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau 
1310 G Street NW, 
Washington, DC 20005 
 
Submitted electronically via Regulations.gov  
RE: Docket No. TTB-2025-0002; Notice No. 237; Alcohol Facts Statement in the Labeling of 
Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages 
 
To whom it may concern: 
 
As the association for the consumer-packaged goods (CPG) industry, including makers of food, 
beverage, personal care, and household products, the Consumer Brands Association champions 
the industry that makes the products you choose and the brands you trust. From household and 
personal care to food and beverage products, the consumer  packaged goods (CPG) industry 
plays a vital role in powering the U.S. economy, contributing $2.5 trillion to U.S. GDP and 
supporting 22.3 million American jobs. Consumer Brands advocates for uniform, workable, and 
durable regulatory frameworks that are informed by risk -based science, promote consumer 
choice, and build consumer trust across the sectors we represent. As such, we appreciate the 
opportunity to provide comments on the Alcohol, and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB or the 
Agency) proposed rule titled, “Alcohol Facts Statement in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, 
and Malt Beverages.” (Proposed Rule).  
 
As TTB develops labelling standards for most wine, spirits and malt beverages, we encourage it 
to allow  for the use of digital technologies to share labelling information with consumers. 
Succinctly, we urge the agency to be flexible in how labeling information is provided, 
including recognizing the valuable role that digital disclosure tools like SmartLabel can 
provide in facilitating accurate and up -to-date information ultimately leading to greater 
transparency for consumers.   
 
Introduction 
 
SmartLabel® by Consumer Brands Association is a nimble, adaptable digital platform launched 
in 2015 by brand owners and grocery retailers to give consumers access to more detailed product 
information than could ever fit on a package. SmartLabel serves as the defacto standard for  
consumer transparency and allows brands to display state and federally mandated and voluntary 
label information . Currently 80 parent companies participate in the SmartLabel program, 
representing more than 1,000 brands and over 100,000 products across all CPG categories, the 
largest being food and beverage. SmartLabel data is maintained by the participating brands who 
can provide  up-to-date product information with the click of a button. SmartLabel can easily 
accommodate the addition of data for wine, spirits and malt beverages.  
 
Further, SmartLabel can augment  federally required nutritional, ingredient , and allergen 
information with voluntary details that go beyond the package label such as ingredient definitions 
and sourcing  information, links to allergy prevention and management resources , as well as  SmartLabel® Comments to Docket No. TTB-2025-0002; Notice No. 237 
July 9, 2025 
Page 2 of 10 
 
sustainability attributes and practices.  Much of the voluntary information in SmartLabel spans 
nutrition, product claims,  certifications, and disclosures that consumers really care about.  
Consumers interacted with the SmartLabel platform over 22 million times in calendar year 2024. 
A national consumer survey with 1,000 respondents conducted in 2023 by the Consumer Brands 
Association found that consumers most often view the nutrition, ingredient , and allergen 
information on the SmartLabel pages. The survey also found that one-third of consumers have 
used SmartLabel and/or scanned a QR code to access product information  and 97% of those  
have used SmartLabel more than once. Almost six in ten (59%) American adults are likely to trust 
brands that feature SmartLabel, and more than half (55%) of consumers believe that integrating 
product information with SmartLabel will improve their impression of the brand. Consequently, 
SmartLabel food labeling provides the product information consumers seek to make informed 
decisions about the CPG products they purchase. 
 
SmartLabel Standardizes the Product Data Display 
 
SmartLabel complies with GS1 data standards (sourced via the Global Data Synchronisation 
Network or GDSN) for all attributes displayed on the platform and is a single source of up-to-date 
and accurate CPG product details because the data is directly owned, managed, updated, and 
hosted by the brand owner or the brand owner’s solution provider. Further, SmartLabel utilizes a 
uniform display and structure, which facilitates the ability of consumers to quickly and easily find 
the information they are seeking.  
 
SmartLabel can play an important role in providing accurate and up-to-date product information 
about alcoholic beverages to consumers.  SmartLabel data is displayed in a consistent 5 -tab 
template for all product categories  (Food and Beverage, Household Cleaning, Personal Care, 
Over-the-Counter Medications, Dietary Supplements and Pet Food)  and includes 
all federally mandated information that would be required to appear on the label  
(except for date code labeling for infant formula, which must be provided for the 
specific packaged product). For food and beverage products, the tabs are Nutrition, 
Ingredients, Allergens, About this Product (most of the voluntary information, 
including claims, resides on this tab) and Company, Brand & Sustainability.  
SmartLabel® Comments to Docket No. TTB-2025-0002; Notice No. 237 
July 9, 2025 
Page 3 of 10 
 
The product image in the header of all SmartLabel pages can be clicked to display an enlarged 
image to aid consumers in determining if the product they have in hand matches the SmartLabel 
information. 
 
SmartLabel nutrition, ingredient, and allergen details are displayed in a consistent, readable 
template that mirrors the information on the packaging  and allows for variations in product 
formulations. The product image in the SmartLabel template header can be clicked to display an 
enlarged image of the package, which can be helpful for people with vision impairment. 
 
SmartLabel presents FDA mandatory information (nutrition information, ingredients, allergens, 
statement of identity, net quantity of contents, name and place of business, percent juice 
declaration and flavor labeling where applicable) in a consistent, easy to access and easy to read 
format. The SmartLabel program uses implementation manuals working with brands to provide 
information in accordance with applicable regulations for a consistent, reliable experience for 
consumers. For instances, the implementation manual for food and beverage prescribes that “the 
Nutrition Panel must exactly mirror what appears on the physical package for single column 
displays. ‘Exactly’ refers to all elements of the FDA’s Nutrition Facts label design including relative 
font sizes, indentations, alignment, and separation bar width. The Nutrition tab is not constrained 
by package size so the Nutrition Facts Panel should follow the FDA guidelines without truncation.” 
SmartLabel could implement a template that meets Alcohol/Serving Facts labelling requirements 
if any.  
 
The SmartLabel Trademark Licensing Agreement signed by all SmartLabel participants requires 
them to adhere to the specifications in the SmartLabel Food and Beverage Implementation 
Manual for the design and content in their SmartLabel pages. The program con ducts annual 
reviews of SmartLabel pages to make certain the data is consistent between the product 
packaging and the corresponding SmartLabel page. Elements that do not comply with 
programmatic and / or regulatory requirements are identified, and brands are given a reasonable 
time frame to bring their pages into compliance.   
 
SmartLabel is Accessible 
 
SmartLabel product pages can be accessed easily in several different ways including 
smartphones, tablets, and computers – and allow users to view the information in an easily legible 
format regardless of device . SmartLabel pages appear in the browser and do not require any 
software to download or install to view SmartLabel.   
 
Consumers commonly use the native camera app on a smartphone or tablet to scan the 
SmartLabel branded QR code to reach the digital product information.  SmartLabel also offers a 
free application that can be downloaded for both iPhone and android smartphones. The app 
allows users to scan UPC barcodes for products that participate in SmartLabel. SmartLabel pages 
can also be searched and accessed using the Sm artLabel product database 
(https://SmartLabel.org/product-search) without access to the actual package. 
 
Given the ubiquity of smartphones and wide availability of broadband, consumers can readily 
access SmartLabel information by scanning the SmartLabel branded QR code. USDA’s 
Agricultural Marketing Service ( AMS) has found that as of 2021, most Americans (97 percent) SmartLabel® Comments to Docket No. TTB-2025-0002; Notice No. 237 
July 9, 2025 
Page 4 of 10 
 
owned a smartphone of some kind.1 In particular, the Pew Research Center found that 89 percent 
of urban adults, 84 percent of suburban adults, and 80 percent of rural adults in America own a 
smartphone2. The Pew Research Center also found that 61 percent of individuals 65 and older  
own a smartphone.  
 
Similarly, QR code interactions increased by an estimated 6,200% between 2017 and 2021, with 
91% of consumers now having used a QR code at least once, and 87.1% of survey participants 
stating that QR codes are easy to use. 3 Moreover, internet access today is not the issue it once 
was. Today, 95% of American adults have reported that they use the internet.4  
 
Further, SmartLabel pages comply with the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines developed by 
the World Wide Web Consortium’s (W3C’s) Web Accessibility Initiative, which partners with 
organizations around the world to provide a high degree of internet usability for people with 
disabilities by: 
• ensuring that W3C standards support accessibility 
• developing accessibility guidelines for web content and applications, browsers, and 
authoring tools 
• developing resources to improve web accessibility evaluation processes and tools 
• supporting education and outreach on web accessibility 
• coordinating with research and development that may impact future accessibility of the 
web 
• promoting harmonized international uptake of web accessibility standards 
 
The SmartLabel Template 
 
The SmartLabel landing page for food and beverage products is the Nutrition Tab, which 
replicates the Nutrition Facts Panel (NFP) on pack, including the FDA required formatting. In-
depth interviews from the 2021 national survey conducted by the Consumer Brands Association 
and FMI, revealed consumers found the product information in SmartLabel to be very clear, easy 
to navigate and easy to read. Consumers explained the digital rendering of the NFP in SmartLabel 
is easier to read than the NFP on-pack. 
 
 
1 DELOITTE, Study of Electronic or Digital Link Disclosure: A Third-Party Evaluation of Challenges Impacting Access 
to Bioengineered Food Disclosure, U.S. DEP’T OF AG. (July 2017), https://www.ams.usda.gov/sites/default/files  
/media/USDADeloitteStudyofElectronicorDigitalDisclosure20170801.pdf  (hereinafter, “Deloitte Study”). 
 
2 See PEW RESEARCH CENTER, Mobile Fact Sheet (Jan. 31, 2024), https://www.pewresearch.org/internet/fact-
sheet/mobile/. 
3 See Alexander Eser, Essential QR Code Statistics in 2024, ZIPDO (July 4, 2023), https://zipdo.co/statistics/qr-
code/; see also Laura Ceci, U.S. smartphone users scanning QR codes 2020-2025, STATISTICS (Feb, 28, 2023), 
https://www.statista.com/statistics/1297768/us-smartphone-users-qr-scanner/(noting that in 2022, 
approximately 89 million smartphone users in the United States scanned a QR code on their mobile devices, up by 
26% compared to 2020. Usage of mobile QR code scanners is projected to experience constant growth, reaching 
over 100 million users in the U.S. by 2025). 
4 See PEW RESEARCH CENTER, Internet/Broadband Fact Sheet (Jan. 31, 2024), 
https://www.pewresearch.org/internet/fact-sheet/internet-broadband/. SmartLabel® Comments to Docket No. TTB-2025-0002; Notice No. 237 
July 9, 2025 
Page 5 of 10 
 
 
 
Ingredients are displayed on the second tab in descending order of predominance in a stacked, 
legible format. Many of the food and beverage implementors in SmartLabel also include voluntary 
information on ingredient definitions and functions , which can be accessed by clicking on the 
arrow next to the listed ingredient . The ingredients tab also supports information on ingredient 
sourcing and growing methods, providing consumers with valuable information about the products 
they consume. 
 
SmartLabel® Comments to Docket No. TTB-2025-0002; Notice No. 237 
July 9, 2025 
Page 6 of 10 
 
 
The third tab, Allergens, displays a statement identifying the nine major food allergens under the 
Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act. Allergens contained in the product are listed in a stacked 
format, with the option for brands to also provide additional information on the composition of the 
allergen – for example, the allergen “milk” in a product might be composed of pasteurized milk 
and cream, dried milk , and cream cheese  – and links to allergy prevention and management 
resources. 
The fourth tab – About this Product  – displays voluntary information like claims, certifications, 
health and safety  warnings and product instructions. The fifth tab – Company, Brand & 
Sustainability – displays hyperlinks to the brand’s customer suppor t and website, company 
SmartLabel® Comments to Docket No. TTB-2025-0002; Notice No. 237 
July 9, 2025 
Page 7 of 10 
 
website, Dietary Guidelines for Americans and USDA My Plate. The fifth tab is also used to display 
product sustainability attributes like How2Recycle , Recycle Check, CIRT  and hyperlinks to 
corporate sustainability practices. 
SmartLabel is a viable option for manufacturers to provide product information, both mandatory 
and voluntary, that may not be as readily available or in -depth on the product packaging. Other 
types of detailed product information that are available to consumers through SmartLabel that go 
beyond what is commonly available on the product packaging  include information about, 
bioengineered food declarations, product certifications, sustainability attributes, and company or 
brand information.  
 
Additionally, SmartLabel informs consumers that a product contains a known allergen and, if 
provided by the manufacturer, can go further and advise if the product was made in a shared 
facility or even on shared equipment for hyper-sensitive consumers. 
 
SmartLabel Facilitates Data Management  
 
For CPG manufacturers, the processes for managing digital product content generally run in 
parallel with the changes made to the physical label. Manufacturers need to determine when the 
updated product and its label will be in market to identify when it would be appropriate to circulate 
the updated online retail information. This determination does not follow a specific timeline  
because it is based on the estimated turnover rate of the product that is in commerce.  
 
Manufacturers can update SmartLabel to accommodate reformulations in near real time . 
Furthermore, SmartLabel displays the  date of the  information up date in the footer of each 
SmartLabel page: 
 
 
 
 
Consumer Research Validates SmartLabel as a Digital Transparency Tool 
 
Through consumer research , SmartLabel has confirmed that consumers expect the labeling 
information in SmartLabel to be consistent with the information on the label. As noted, the program 
SmartLabel® Comments to Docket No. TTB-2025-0002; Notice No. 237 
July 9, 2025 
Page 8 of 10 
 
conducts annual reviews of SmartLabel pages to ensure the data is consistent between the 
product packaging and the corresponding SmartLabel page.  
 
Consumer research conducted in 2023 by SmartLabel nationally with 1,000 respondents across 
all demographic groups found that 43% of consumers are very likely to access more product 
information online (compared to what is provided on the label).  
 
For reasons related to their family’s well-being, 80% of respondents said they would like to know 
more about products than what is usually  on the package label . When asked about shopping 
online, 80% of survey respondents said they seek more information about a product when 
shopping online than when shopping in-store. 
 
The same survey found that 84% of consumers said they believe product information directly from 
the manufacturer is most accurate. SmartLabel pages are populated directly by the brand owners. 
 
Consumers also sa id access to product information in SmartLabel is faster and easier  to read 
than the same information on the package label . The 5 -tab SmartLabel template serves as a 
standard and ensures consistency in the way product information is displayed  
 
Digital Disclosure Provides Benefits to Manufacturers and Consumers 
 
The benefits of digital labeling accrue to both consumers and manufacturers. Consumers demand 
transparency and value the detailed ingredient, nutrition and health information  in SmartLabel. 
They appreciate the consistency of the SmartLabel design, its organized layout and the ease of 
access. Moreover, providing information via off -label, electronic means benefit s consumers by 
ensuring they receive the most up -to-date, accurate, and more comprehensive information  
directly from the product manufacturers.  A national consumer survey with 1,000 respondents 
conducted in 2023 by the Consumer Brands Association and FMI found that: 
• 58% of consumers look for SmartLabel on products  and 51% are likely to buy products 
featuring SmartLabel. 
• 60% of consumers are likely to trust brands that feature SmartLabel. 
• Accurate and up -to-date product information and detailed product information a re key 
purchase drivers. 26% of consumers are willing to pay more for products that offer 
additional information through SmartLabel.  
 
For brand owners, the primary benefit of using the electronic or digital link disclosure option is the 
ability for the industry to rapidly and efficiently update product information, therefore minimizing 
packaging costs and packaging obsolescence. Updates are influenced by numerous factors 
including reformulations, supplier driven changes, supply chain pressures, packaging inventory 
turnover as well as limited vendor resources. Electronic or digital disclosure provides flexibility for 
manufacturers to quickly address product changes as ingredient supplies are updated and 
modified. A nimble and adaptable tool allows for efficient communication and transparency, 
ultimately benefiting consumers. with minimal disruptions to both the manufacturer and 
consumers.  
With SmartLabel, brands don’t need to touch their packaging as often, since changes can be 
made to the SmartLabel page on the fly. When a change is made on the SmartLabel page, it will SmartLabel® Comments to Docket No. TTB-2025-0002; Notice No. 237 
July 9, 2025 
Page 9 of 10 
 
appear everywhere the page is hosted in real time – on the brand ecommerce pages and retail 
ecommerce sites. In other words, with SmartLabel, manufacturers only have to make a change 
once, instead of on multiple platforms. As important, the ability to make real-time corrections and 
provide real-time information can streamline and aid regulatory enforcement efforts associated 
with any new and mandatory labeling rules. 
 
GS1 Sunrise 2027 is Just Around the Corner 
 
SmartLabel is collaborating with GS1 US in prepara tion for Sunrise 2027 – the transition from 
UPC barcodes to 2D barcodes (Digital Links). With a single scan on a smartphone, a GS1 digital 
link-enabled SmartLabel QR code will allow consumers to access nutritional information, 
allergens, sustainability and sourcing data on the SmartLabel product page. That same QR code 
can be scanned at the point-of-sale (POS) checkout counter for price lookup and a variety of other 
supply chain processes related to inventory management and recall readiness. More information 
on GS1 Sunrise 2027 and 2D barcodes can be found here. A June 13, 2025 article in Packaging 
World described how brands are piloting 2D barcodes today in anticipation of Sunrise 2027. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
******************************************************************** 
 
 
Thank you again for the opportunity to provide comment on the TTB’s proposal for mandatory 
labeling for wine, distilled spirits and malt beverages . SmartLabel and its  implementers are 
committed to consumer transparency, enhancing trust in the CPG industry, and ensuring that 
consumers can make informed product purchasing decisions. The TTB has an important role to 
play in supporting the standardization of labeling information and supporting innovation  and 
flexibility by permitting the use of digital technology to provide  core regulatory information to 
consumers. Further, SmartLabel is a solution to the transition to 2D barcodes.  
SmartLabel® Comments to Docket No. TTB-2025-0002; Notice No. 237 
July 9, 2025 
Page 10 of 10 
 
We urge the agency to be flexible  in how labeling information is provided, including 
recognizing the valuable role that digital disclosure tools like  SmartLabel can provide in 
facilitating accurate and up-to-date information ultimately leading to greater transparency 
for consumers.   
 
 
Respectfully submitted, 
 
 
 
Rishi Banerjee 
Senior Director, SmartLabel 
Consumer Brands Association

comment_text: We have enough regulations on the industry as it is. We do not need caloric or serving size or nutritional information on the labels. There is no benefit to adding this information to the labels, only to force producers to have their products tested by "certified" labs which will severely hamper the small producer with multiple products. This is a ridiculous proposal and government overreach at its best. Looking at many other comments, i see the premise is that this will be enacted and QR codes should be implemented. We don't need QR codes either. This regulation should be put back in the trash heap.

document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
August 15, 2025  Ms. Amy Greenberg  Director, Regulations and Rulings Division Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau 1310 G Street NW, Box 12  Washington, DC 20005   RE: Document Number: TTB-2025-0002; 90 FR 6654 Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages (RIN 1513-AC93) Dear Ms. Greenberg: Thank you for the opportunity to comment on the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) notice of proposed rulemaking: Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages, dated January 17, 2025.  Wine & Spirits Wholesalers of America (WSWA) is the national trade association representing the wholesale tier of the wine and spirits industry. Founded in 1943, WSWA represents companies in all 50 States and the District of Columbia that hold federal permits and state licenses to act as wine and/or spirits distributors and/or brokers.   As an initial matter, WSWA strongly supports TTB’s work to implement the Federal Alcohol Administration Act (FAA Act) labeling requirements and views them as a critical tool to inform consumers while allowing for flexibility and innovation within the industry. We applaud efforts to modernize this system to meet evolving needs and advances in technology.  Our comment is limited to two elements of the proposal. First, we comment on Section VII.B.8.C regarding the electronic display of alcohol facts information. Secondly, we comment on Section VII.B.9 regarding serving size reference amounts.  I. Electronic Display of Alcohol Facts Information    The proposal seeks comment on whether a final rule should allow the proposed Alcohol Facts information to be disclosed via electronic means. We appreciate the perspectives TTB has received in previous comments both in support and opposition to electronic disclosure and agree with those commenters who have suggested Quick Response (QR) codes provide flexibility for industry members while empowering consumers with detailed, easy to ready information on an electronic device. As the proposal notes, rapid advancements are underway in technology and consumer expectations around how information is accessed, and we believe these factors will only increase in coming years making such technologies even more mainstream.  Further, QR-based information is already in use in many global alcohol markets where it is currently demonstrating its utility. With a simple capture of the code on the phone, all relevant information can be displayed in a clear, easy to decipher format in seconds.   Specific to readability, we note that QR codes can provide consumers with larger font sizes than the 1 millimeter minimum for wine and spirits and may provide a useful mechanism for viewing alcohol facts   
     
information in an easier to read format than some labels may provide. Often the QR view fills a smartphone screen and provides significantly more text size than would be found on a physical label, especially those for 50ml and other smaller standards of fill. Such flexibility addresses the very issues raised with linear display and type size for smaller containers.   We encourage TTB to allow electronic means as a mode of compliance for any new label requirements that may be promulgated.   II. Alcohol Expressed in Fluid Ounces may Lead to Consumer Confusion  Secondly, regarding serving size reference amounts, we comment on the questions posed in section VII.B.9 of the proposal. Specifically, we respectfully suggest that the proposed reference amounts will create unnecessary consumer confusion around what constitutes a “serving”. We recognize the proposal does not intend for the reference amounts to be “recommended consumption amounts”, but we believe they could easily be interpreted as such by consumers.   Under the proposal, consumers could be led to believe that, for instance, a distilled spirits product of 16% ABV or below is intended to be consumed in a 5-ounce serving. This is not universally true as many spirit products under this threshold are intended for use in smaller servings. In this case, having the 5-ounce serving could promote confusion around “real-world” calorie and alcohol content amounts. Similarly, in the expanding world of ready-to-drink cocktails, many similar products exist on both sides of the proposed 7% ABV delineation between 12- and 5-ounce serving references. This too could lead to significant consumer confusion around what a “serving” is intended to be for two very similar products. We encourage TTB to consider alternatives to this approach.   WSWA applauds TTB for this important work around how consumers access information and urges TTB to ensure that any changes required by a final rule avoid creating unnecessary consumer confusion and allow for industry members to utilize prevalent technology to satisfy new regulatory requirements.  Thank you for your consideration of our perspective on these important matters.  Respectfully Submitted,  
  Jacob Hegeman General Counsel and Senior Vice President, Legal and Regulatory Wine & Spirits Wholesalers of America

comment_text: I write as President and CEO of the American Distilled Spirits Alliance ("ADSA") to provide the collective comments of ADSA members on TTB's Notice No. 237, Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages. ADSA is a trade association of twenty member companies that collectively produce over sixty percent of all distilled spirits sold in the United States, with a history of more than forty years under its former name, the Presidents' Forum of the Distilled Spirits Industry. Our members share TTB's commitment to providing consumers with accurate, meaningful information, particularly regarding alcohol content and allergens, while ensuring that any regulatory changes are designed to avoid consumer confusion, unnecessary costs, or disruptions to trade. Drawing on decades of industry experience, consumer research, and lessons from both U.S. and foreign regulatory frameworks, ADSA emphasizes three principles in these comments: the need for flexibility in disclosure methods, including QR codes and digital tools; the importance of avoiding ingredient disclosures that do not accurately reflect the composition of distilled spirits; and the value of collaborative, phased rulemaking with adequate implementation timelines tailored to U.S. market conditions rather than wholesale adoption of foreign models. Please see the attached comment for additional details.
