document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
August 15, 2025 
 
Amy Greenberg 
Director, Regulations and Ruling Division 
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau 
1310 G Street NW, Box 12 
Washington, DC 20005 
 
Re: Comments on TTB Notice No. 237, Docket No. TTB-2025-0002: Alcohol 
Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt 
Beverages 
 
Dear Director Greenberg: 
 
I write as President and CEO of the American Distilled Spirts Alliance (“ADSA”) to provide 
the collective comments of ADSA members to TTB’s Notice No. 23 7, entitled Alcohol 
Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages (the 
“Notice”).1  ADSA is a trade association of twenty member companies with common 
interests in the manufacturing, importation, and marketing of distilled spirits products in 
the United States.  ADSA members produce over sixty percent of all the distilled spirits 
sold i n the U.S.  Previously known as the Presidents’ Forum of the Distilled Spirits 
Industry, ADSA traces its history back over 40 years.   
ADSA and its members share TTB’s commitment to ensuring that consumers have 
access to accurate and meaningful information about the products they purchase and 
consume. We recognize the importance of transparency, particularly with respect to 
alcohol conten t and allergens that may affect consumer safety. At the same time, we 
believe that any regulatory changes must be carefully calibrated to avoid confusing 
consumers, imposing unnecessary costs on producers, or disrupting established trade 
practices in the United States and abroad. 
In these comments, ADSA responds to questions posed by TTB, offering 
recommendations based on decades of industry experience, consumer research, and 
lessons learned from both domestic and foreign regulatory approaches. We emphasize 
three overarching principles: 
1. The need for flexibility in how information is disclosed, particularly through the 
use of QR codes and digital tools; 
2. The importance of avoiding unnecessary or misleading ingredient 
disclosures that do not reflect the actual composition of distilled spirits; and 
 
1 90 FR 6654 (Jan. 17, 2025).   
 
TTB-2025-0002 
Page 2 of 6 
 
3. The critical role of collaborative, phased rulemaking  with adequate time for 
implementation, tailored to U.S. market conditions rather than imported wholesale 
from jurisdictions like the European Union. 
Current Labeling Rules and Consumer Understanding 
We believe that current labeling rules already provide consumers with the essential 
information they need to make informed decisions, including alcohol content by volume, 
class or type of spirit, and required health warnings. These disclosures, together wi th 
long-standing standards of identity for distilled spirits, ensure that consumers understand 
the basic characteristics of the products they are purchasing. 
That said, ADSA acknowledges that consumer groups and other stakeholders have 
expressed a desire for more information, particularly regarding serving size and potential 
allergens. We support TTB’s consideration of these issues but caution against expanding 
labeling requirements in ways that would overload labels with text, lead to consumer 
confusion, or introduce inconsistencies across product categories. A one -size-fits-all 
mandate will not achieve the goal of clarity for consumers and may instead obscure key 
information. 
Modern technology provides tools that were not available when current labeling rules 
were first established. QR codes, in particular, can bridge the gap between static on-pack 
information and consumers’ growing appetite for detailed data. By allowing produ cers to 
provide additional information digitally, QR codes prevent label clutter, enable regular 
updates without costly reprinting, and give consumers access to more robust product data 
than could reasonably fit on a label. We strongly encourage TTB to recognize QR codes 
as a central solution for future disclosures. 
A proven precedent exists in SmartLabel, a digital disclosure tool that has transformed 
how brands communicate product information. SmartLabel allows participating brands to 
display both state and federally mandated as well as voluntary label information in a clear, 
consistent, and consumer-friendly format. Currently, 80 parent companies—representing 
more than 1,000 brands and 100,000 products across all consumer -packaged goods 
categories, most prominently food and beverage—use the program. 
The data is maintained by participating brands, who can update product information 
instantly, ensuring accuracy and timeliness without costly physical label changes. This 
model enables manufacturers to present mandatory and voluntary information that may 
be too detailed to fit on traditional packaging, while still ensuring consumer access. In the 
FDA context, SmartLabel presents required disclosures —such as nutrition facts, 
ingredients, allergens, statement of identity, net quantity, name and place of busin ess, 
percent juice declarations, and flavor labeling —using a consistent and easy -to-read 
interface. 
In-depth interviews from a 2021 national survey conducted by the Consumer Brands 
Association and the Food Marketing Institute revealed that consumers found  
 
TTB-2025-0002 
Page 3 of 6 
 
SmartLabel’s product information very clear, easy to navigate, and easy to read. The 
strong adoption by brands and positive reception by consumers show that a well -
structured digital disclosure tool enhances transparency and consumer confidence. 
By embracing QR codes and similar digital platforms for alcohol beverage labeling, the 
agency can facilitate timely, accurate, and complete disclosures without overburdening 
packaging, producers, or consumers. The SmartLabel model proves that this approach  
can work across a highly diverse marketplace, balancing regulatory needs with industry 
innovation and consumer expectations. 
Alcohol Content, Nutritional Information, and Serving Facts 
Alcohol content per serving is one of the most important pieces of information consumers 
can have. Current rules require ABV disclosures for spirits, but similar requirements do 
not apply consistently across all beverage types. As a result, consumers are left to guess 
how a serving of beer, wine, or spirits relates to U.S. Dietary Guidelines defining a 
“standard drink” as 0.6 fluid ounces (14 grams) of pure alcohol. We recommend that TTB 
standardize alcohol content disclosures across categories, requiring b oth ABV and 
alcohol content per serving to give consumers clear, comparable information. To promote 
responsible consumption, all serving sizes should be set equal to a standard drink. 
Providing for a “single serving” that differs from a standard drink woul d confuse 
consumers; if there is more than one standard drink in a container, the label should state 
the number of standard drinks. 
We encourage TTB to use “Serving Facts” rather than “Alcohol Facts” as the title for the 
informational statement. Because the required disclosures will include both nutrient and 
alcohol content information, “Serving Facts” is a broader and more accurate de scriptor. 
This approach also avoids costly label updates for producers who already voluntarily use 
“Serving Facts” under current policy. 
We support allowing flexibility in format, including the linear display option, which is 
already in widespread voluntary use and easily located by consumers. For certain small 
formats—such as 50ml containers —we recommend an exemption from alcohol facts 
labeling, as space constraints make meaningful on -pack disclosure impractical. We 
further reiterate our request to permit off-pack disclosure through a website or QR code, 
ensuring consumers have access to complete and current information without 
overburdening packaging. 
Nutritional information such as calories, carbohydrates, protein, fat, and alcohol content 
can be useful to consumers, but TTB should not require other nutrients or elements (such 
as sodium, caffeine, sugar, cholesterol, fiber, vitamins, minerals, or fat breakdown) to be 
listed, as this may convey unintended nutritional or health value. Nor should TTB require 
inclusion of a summary of the Dietary Guidelines’ advice on moderate drinking. 
We also recommend that TTB allow compliance via a Statement of Average Analysis for 
products where exact alcohol content is not known at the time of label creation, such as  
 
TTB-2025-0002 
Page 4 of 6 
 
“cask strength” whiskeys. This flexibility would preserve accuracy while recognizing 
production realities. 
In response to TTB’s question regarding the extent of current voluntary nutrition labeling, 
we note that many ADSA members already provide nutrition content information, with 
some doing so across their entire portfolios. This demonstrates that industry members 
are already responsive to consumer interest in this information without a rigid, one -size-
fits-all mandate. 
Ingredient Lists and Why They May Mislead Consumers 
We continue to believe that requiring full ingredient lists for distilled spirits would not help 
consumers make informed choices and may, in fact, mislead them. Distillation is a 
transformative process that removes nearly all traces of the raw materials us ed in 
production. For example, while wheat may be the starting material for vodka, the final 
distilled product contains no gluten proteins or other remnants of the grain. Listing “wheat” 
as an ingredient on such a product could lead consumers with celiac d isease to avoid it 
unnecessarily, or others to assume that vodka contains nutritional qualities associated 
with wheat, neither of which is true. 
TTB has previously recognized this problem, and its long-standing position—affirmed by 
the courts—is that ingredient lists for distilled spirits provide little value and may even 
misinform consumers. Standards of identity and statements of composition alre ady tell 
consumers what type of spirit they are purchasing (e.g., gin, Scotch whisky, rum), and 
these designations are widely understood. There is no evidence that ingredient lists would 
enhance consumer understanding beyond what is already provided. 
In contrast, the European Union has taken a different approach, requiring ingredient lists 
and certain nutritional information on alcoholic beverages. However, EU regulatory 
systems are harmonized across food and beverage categories and operate under 
different legal frameworks. Importing EU-style requirements into the U.S. would not align 
with our domestic labeling standards, would create significant costs for U.S. producers 
exporting overseas, and could disrupt international trade. U.S. policy should be guided by 
U.S. consumer needs and our established regulatory approach, not by wholesale 
adoption of foreign rules. 
Allergen Disclosure and Consumer Safety 
ADSA supports mandatory disclosure of allergens where science shows that allergens 
remain present in the final product and may pose a risk to consumers. We recommend 
that TTB align definitions of “major allergens” with the Food Allergen Labeling and 
Consumer Protection Act while acknowledging that distilled spirits frequently contain no 
allergenic proteins from their raw materials. Where allergens are fully removed during 
production, no disclosure should be required.  
 
TTB-2025-0002 
Page 5 of 6 
 
As is already the case in some jurisdictions, allergens that are clearly indicated in the 
product name—such as “hazelnut liqueur”—should not require duplicative labeling. Over-
disclosure could create confusion or cause unnecessary concern for consumers. 
Cost Implications and Small Business Impacts 
The costs of implementing new labeling mandates would be substantial. Producers would 
face expenses related to product testing, formula verification, label redesign, and legal 
compliance reviews. These costs would be particularly burdensome for small or ne w 
businesses, many of which lack the resources to conduct laboratory analysis or manage 
multiple label redesigns. 
To mitigate these burdens, ADSA strongly urges TTB to adopt a phased implementation 
period of at least five years and to avoid piecemeal rulemaking that would require multiple 
rounds of expensive changes. A single effective date for all labeling changes would help 
businesses plan and budget appropriately. We also applaud TTB for withdrawing the 
ingredient labeling rulemaking and for proposing a 5 -year implementation period in both 
the alcohol facts and major food allergens rulemakings. 
QR codes and web -based disclosures can further reduce costs by eliminating the need 
for frequent physical label changes while still providing consumers with the detailed 
information they may seek. 
The Need for Collaborative Rulemaking 
Labeling regulations are fundamental to consumer understanding, market integrity, and 
international trade. Any changes to these rules must be science -based, practical, and 
tailored to U.S. market conditions. ADSA urges TTB to continue engaging with 
stakeholders before drafting final rules, conducting thorough cost -benefit analyses, and 
considering real-world production practices. Rules that are too rigid, overly burdensome, 
or modeled on foreign systems will not serve U.S. consumers or producers effectively. 
We welcome the opportunity to participate in future dialogue, workshops, or advisory 
groups to help develop labeling rules that provide genuine value to consumers while 
preserving the competitiveness of the U.S. distilled spirits industry. 
* * * 
ADSA appreciates TTB’s leadership in evaluating these important issues and its 
willingness to engage industry stakeholders in the process. We support mandatory 
disclosure of alcohol content per serving and science -based allergen disclosures, 
provided they accurately reflect the final product. We oppose ingred ient lists for distilled 
spirits because they are scientifically inaccurate and potentially misleading. We strongly 
encourage TTB to adopt flexible, modern disclosure methods, particularly QR codes, 
which meet consumer needs without imposing undue burdens on producers or creating 
cluttered, confusing labels.  
 
TTB-2025-0002 
Page 6 of 6 
 
Most importantly, we urge TTB to proceed collaboratively, engaging in an open and 
iterative rulemaking process that reflects U.S. realities rather than importing foreign 
approaches ill-suited to our market. ADSA and its members stand ready to work with TTB 
to ensure that future labeling rules are clear, effective, and practical for both consumers 
and producers. 
Respectfully submitted, 
 
Amanda Nguyen 
President & CEO 
American Distilled Spirits Alliance

comment_title: Comment 191:  New Belgium Brewing Company, Inc.
comment_text: New Belgium Brewing Company, Inc. respectfully submits this comment in response to TTB proposed rule published as Notice No. 237 (Docket No. TTB-2025-0002). New Belgium Brewing is a leading US premium adult beverage company, known for its iconic portfolio and unique approach to business. Founded in a Fort Collins, Colorado basement in 1991, New Belgium has grown into one of the most successful breweries in the country, expanding into Asheville, North Carolina in 2016, Daleville, Virginia in 2023, and acquired Bell's Brewery in Kalamazoo, Michigan in 2021. New Belgium is known for producing fan-favorite brands including Voodoo Ranger IPA, Fat Tire Ale, Bell's Two Hearted IPA, Oberon Ale, an award-winning wood cellar program, and more. Over the past three decades, New Belgium's Human Powered Business model of caring for people, protecting the environment, and owning our impact has remained consistent, guiding our business practices in all that we do. This ethos continues on today and has enabled us to reach many significant milestones over the past three decades including becoming the first craft brewery to become a certified B Corp still in operation, developing the first carbon-neutral beer in Fat Tire, and much more. I. Support for the TTB Proposal to Exclude a Small Business Exception New Belgium agrees with the TTB that there should not be a permanent exemption for small businesses to comply with any new mandatory labeling requirements. In addition to the reasoning the TTB presents, New Belgium believes that the practical effects of having a small business exemption would lead to unnecessarily inequitable and anti-competitive results and potentially stifle growth and hiring. New Belgium and Bell's combined is currently the largest craft beer producer in the US by volume, yet the company only narrowly exceeds the 1,250 employee threshold to be defined as a small brewery under the SUSB definition. Based on this, New Belgium is concerned that any small business exemption would result in a majority of craft beer on store shelves excluding any new mandatory label information. It is likely that only New Belgium, and potentially a few other craft brewers, would not be required to provide this information, along with the large brewers who operate mainly outside the craft set. The anti-competitive effects of an exemption would outweigh any additional costs for small businesses to comply. Not only would exempt competitors not be required to include nutrition information such as calories per serving, but exempt competitors would be easily identifiable on the shelf as small businesses, when in fact their businesses may be only slightly smaller than those who do not meet the exemption. Such potential marketing advantages should not be dictated by regulation, particularly when costs to comply with new regulations are minimal. New Belgium was once a small business, so it understands the challenges faced by small brewers, but equity must also be considered in any mandatory labeling. There are alternatives to small business exemptions, such as alternative nutrition information calculation processes, that would be less anti-competitive. Therefore, New Belgium agrees with the TTB to not include a small business exemption to any new mandatory labeling requirements. II. The Proposed "Single Serving Size" Definition Is Likely to Cause Confusion The proposed serving size with a threshold at 7% alc/vol is likely to cause confusion to craft beer consumers and brewers. Craft beer spans a wide range of alcohol content, typically from 4% alc/vol up to 10% alc/vol, with the higher end of the range often being the distinguishing factor of craft beer from non-craft beer. Using New Belgium's brands as an example, 7% alc/vol. would split certain products of our brand families with multiple flavors on either side of the proposed 7% dividing line, causing different serving sizes within the family with only minimal shifts in alcohol content. With brand families generally positioned together on retail shelves, consumers would see mismatched information, creating confusion as to alcohol content and any nutrition information, and making it difficult for consumers to compare similar products. Craft beer consumers are familiar with the current disclosures of percentage of alcohol per volume, and New Belgium encourages the TTB to not introduce complicated alcohol content or serving size disclosures that would result in labels that are more confusing to craft beer consumers and brewers. III. Conclusion New Belgium agrees with TTB that the goals of the proposal would not be served by treating certain brewers as exempt from mandatory label disclosures. For the above reasons, New Belgium encourages TTB to reconsider the proposed rule on serving size thresholds to limit confusion to craft beer consumers and brewers.
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
New Belgium Brewing Company, Inc. respectfully submits this comment in response to TTB proposed rule published as Notice No. 237 (Docket No. TTB-2025-0002).

New Belgium Brewing is a leading US premium adult beverage company, known for its iconic portfolio and unique approach to business. Founded in a Fort Collins, Colorado basement in 1991, New Belgium has grown into one of the most successful breweries in the country, expanding into Asheville, North Carolina in 2016, Daleville, Virginia in 2023, and acquired Bell’s Brewery in Kalamazoo, Michigan in 2021. New Belgium is known for producing fan-favorite brands including Voodoo Ranger IPA, Fat Tire Ale, Bell’s Two Hearted IPA, Oberon Ale, an award-winning wood cellar program, and more. Over the past three decades, New Belgium’s Human Powered Business model of caring for people, protecting the environment, and owning our impact has remained consistent, guiding our business practices in all that we do. This ethos continues on today and has enabled us to reach many significant milestones over the past three decades including becoming the first craft brewery to become a certified B Corp still in operation, developing the first carbon-neutral beer in Fat Tire, and much more.   

I. Support for the TTB Proposal to Exclude a Small Business Exception

New Belgium agrees with the TTB that there should not be a permanent exemption for small businesses to comply with any new mandatory labeling requirements. 

In addition to the reasoning the TTB presents, New Belgium believes that the practical effects of having a small business exemption would lead to unnecessarily inequitable and anti-competitive results and potentially stifle growth and hiring.   

New Belgium and Bell’s combined is currently the largest craft beer producer in the US by volume, yet the company only narrowly exceeds the 1,250 employee threshold to be defined as a small brewery under the SUSB definition. Based on this, New Belgium is concerned that any small business exemption would result in a majority of craft beer on store shelves excluding any new mandatory label information. It is likely that only New Belgium, and potentially a few other craft brewers, would not be required to provide this information, along with the large brewers who operate mainly outside the craft set.

The anti-competitive effects of an exemption would outweigh any additional costs for small businesses to comply.  Not only would exempt competitors not be required to include nutrition information such as calories per serving, but exempt competitors would be easily identifiable on the shelf as small businesses, when in fact their businesses may be only slightly smaller than those who do not meet the exemption.  Such potential marketing advantages should not be dictated by regulation, particularly when costs to comply with new regulations are minimal.

New Belgium was once a small business, so it understands the challenges faced by small brewers, but equity must also be considered in any mandatory labeling.  There are alternatives to small business exemptions, such as alternative nutrition information calculation processes, that would be less anti-competitive. Therefore, New Belgium agrees with the TTB to not include a small business exemption to any new mandatory labeling requirements.

II. The Proposed “Single Serving Size” Definition Is Likely to Cause Confusion

The proposed serving size with a threshold at 7% alc/vol is likely to cause confusion to craft beer consumers and brewers. Craft beer spans a wide range of alcohol content, typically from 4% alc/vol up to 10% alc/vol, with the higher end of the range often being the distinguishing factor of craft beer from non-craft beer. Using New Belgium’s brands as an example, 7% alc/vol. would split certain products of our brand families with multiple flavors on either side of the proposed 7% dividing line, causing different serving sizes within the family with only minimal shifts in alcohol content. With brand families generally positioned together on retail shelves, consumers would see mismatched information, creating confusion as to alcohol content and any nutrition information, and making it difficult for consumers to compare similar products. Craft beer consumers are familiar with the current disclosures of percentage of alcohol per volume, and New Belgium encourages the TTB to not introduce complicated alcohol content or serving size disclosures that would result in labels that are more confusing to craft beer consumers and brewers.

III. Conclusion

New Belgium agrees with TTB that the goals of the proposal would not be served by treating certain brewers as exempt from mandatory label disclosures. For the above reasons, New Belgium encourages TTB to reconsider the proposed rule on serving size thresholds to limit confusion to craft beer consumers and brewers.

document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
AIM Global | 100 Allegheny Drive, Suite 105C| Warrendale, Pennsylvania 15086 USA 
www.aimglobal.org | +1.724.742.4470 | @AIM_Inc_ 
 
August 15, 2025 
 
 
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau 
Regulations and Rulings Division 
1310 G Street NW, Box 12 
Washington, DC 20005 
 
Re: Docket No. TTB–2025–0002; Notice No. 237 – Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling 
of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages 
 
To Whom It May Concern: 
 
On behalf of AIM we appreciate the opportunity to provide comments on the Alcohol and Tobacco 
Tax and Trade Bureau’s (TTB) proposed rule to require “Alcohol Facts” statements on alcohol 
beverage labels. 
 
About AIM 
AIM is the global industry alliance for stakeholders in Automatic Identification and Data Capture 
(AIDC) technologies, including barcoding, RFID, smart packaging, and connected solutions that 
enable accurate, accessible, and interoperable data. Our members represent all industries and 
applications that depend on trusted product information from manufacturing and supply chain to 
healthcare, retail, and consumer goods. For over 50 years, AIM has advanced the adoption of open, 
international standards to improve data quality, enhance transparency, and empower informed 
decision-making. 
 
Our Position 
AIM strongly supports TTB’s goal of improving consumer access to accurate, standardized 
information on alcohol beverage labels. Transparency is central to consumer trust, and 
standardized labeling built on internationally recognized data formats and identification systems 
ensures that the information provided is not only accurate and readable but also interoperable 
across platforms, supply chains, and digital environments. 
 
We believe that: 
 
• Standardization is essential – Mandatory “Alcohol Facts” labeling should use consistent 
data structures and presentation formats so that the information can be reliably 
understood by consumers, regulators, and digital systems alike. Utilizing recognized 
standards such as ISO/IEC 15459-1:2014 (Information technology — Automatic 
identification and data capture techniques — Unique identification Unique Identifiers) 
ISO/IEC 18004:2024 (Information technology — Automatic identification and data capture 
techniques — QR Code bar code symbology specification) and ISO/IEC 30161-1:2020 (Internet of Things (IoT) — Data exchange platform for IoT services Part 1: General 
requirements and architecture) will help ensure consistency and interoperability. 
• Digital access complements physical labels – Alongside printed information, machine-
readable data carriers (such as standardized barcodes or QR Codes linked to authoritative 
product data) can provide extended content, including multilingual details, allergen alerts, 
and sustainability information. The use of GS1 General Specifications, including GS1 
DataMatrix and GS1 Digital Link standards, will ensure that the “Alcohol Facts” label can 
integrate seamlessly into domestic and international distribution, retail, and e-commerce 
systems. 
• Interoperability enables efficiency – Leveraging established AIDC standards and best 
practices can help industry meet compliance requirements while reducing costs and errors, 
particularly for companies operating across multiple jurisdictions. 
 
AIM’s Offer of Support 
As the recognized authority for AIDC standards and best practices, AIM is willing to assist TTB and 
the industry in developing the technical guidance and frameworks necessary to implement these 
requirements effectively. We can provide expertise on: 
• Selection and application of appropriate data carriers 
• Data encoding standards to ensure interoperability 
• Integration guidance of physical and digital labeling for consumer engagement and 
regulatory compliance 
 
We commend TTB for advancing this initiative and share its commitment to protecting 
consumers, fostering transparency, and supporting fair competition. We welcome the opportunity 
to participate in future discussions or technical working groups that will help ensure the 
successful rollout of standardized alcohol labeling. 
 
 
Sincerely yours, 
 
 
Chuck Evanhoe     Mary Lou Bosco 
Chair, AIM Board     CEO, AIM Global 
President, Aware Innovations   marylou@aimglobal.org 
       724-742-4473

comment_text: RE: Docket No. TTB 2025-0002; Notice 237: Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages The American Cider Association (ACA) appreciates the opportunity to submit comments on the proposed rulemaking regarding mandatory nutritional, allergen, and ingredient labeling for alcohol beverages. Our association represents more than 1,200 cider and perry producers across the United States—from orchard-based family operations to regional brands selling across multiple states. While our members vary in size and structure, they are unified by their commitment to transparency, craftsmanship, and agricultural tradition. We support the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau's (TTB) goal of modernizing beverage alcohol labeling to ensure consumers have clear, consistent access to information about what they're drinking. However, we respectfully urge the TTB to consider the operational impact of these changes on small and agricultural-based producers—particularly those in the cider sector. Nutritional Labeling Requirements The proposed nutritional labeling requirement presents one of the most significant challenges for small cideries—many of which are closely tied to local agriculture and farm-based production. Cider makers often rely on fruit grown on their own farms or purchased from nearby orchards, supporting agricultural diversity and rural economies. Many producers do not have access to in-house laboratories and would be required to send each product—or in many cases, each vintage or seasonal batch—out for expensive third-party testing. This would be cost prohibitive for many and could discourage the use of varied, seasonal fruit that reflects annual harvest conditions. We strongly encourage the TTB to adopt a tiered approach to nutritional labeling, including: - Exemptions or simplified compliance pathways for producers under a defined annual production threshold, similar to the FDA's model for small food manufacturers. - The option to provide average or representative nutritional values rather than batch-specific data. - Permission to disclose nutritional information digitally via QR code — a system that is already accepted under the European Union's labeling requirements. This approach would promote international regulatory alignment, minimize packaging changes, and allow consumers ready access to accurate product information without imposing undue cost or operational burdens on producers. For limited-release, non-packaged, or taproom-only products, QR codes would allow minimal testing requirements while still meeting transparency goals. Without such accommodations, the cost and logistical burden of compliance could significantly affect the smallest and most innovative segments of the cider industry—many of which are rooted in agriculture and depend on flexibility to highlight the diversity of fruit from year to year. Label Flexibility for Small-Batch and Direct-to-Consumer Products Innovation is a hallmark of the craft cider movement. Many of our members release limited-edition blends, experimental fermentations, or single-varietal ciders in small volumes—sometimes only a few kegs or cases. These products are often sold directly to consumers and are not distributed through traditional retail channels. For these types of products, we ask the TTB to allow more flexible labeling options, including: - Universal batch-level nutritional and allergen disclosures available on-premise or online. - Expanded use of QR codes to communicate required information without relabeling every SKU. Implementation Timeline and Industry Support Should these proposed labeling changes be adopted, it is critical that cideries—especially those with limited staffing and infrastructure—are given sufficient time and support to comply. We support the phased rollout of the final rule, with five years of lead time for producers to comply. In addition, we recommend the development of technical guidance materials, including sample label formats and FAQs. These resources would help ensure that the final rule is not only effective, but also achievable. Conclusion We support the TTB's goal of creating a more transparent and consumer-friendly labeling system across all alcohol categories. At the same time, we believe it is essential to preserve the diversity and accessibility of our industry, which includes many small, regional, and agricultural producers who will be disproportionately affected by these changes. With thoughtful modifications, this rule can accomplish both goals—empowering consumers and supporting the sustainability of small producers. We appreciate the opportunity to share our perspective and look forward to working with the TTB as this rulemaking process continues. Sincerely, Monica Cohen, CEO American Cider Association
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
RE: Docket No. TTB 2025-0002; Notice 237: Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages

The American Cider Association (ACA) appreciates the opportunity to submit comments on the proposed rulemaking regarding mandatory nutritional, allergen, and ingredient labeling for alcohol beverages. Our association represents more than 1,200 cider and perry producers across the United States—from orchard-based family operations to regional brands selling across multiple states. While our members vary in size and structure, they are unified by their commitment to transparency, craftsmanship, and agricultural tradition.

We support the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau’s (TTB) goal of modernizing beverage alcohol labeling to ensure consumers have clear, consistent access to information about what they’re drinking. However, we respectfully urge the TTB to consider the operational impact of these changes on small and agricultural-based producers—particularly those in the cider sector.

Nutritional Labeling Requirements
The proposed nutritional labeling requirement presents one of the most significant challenges for small cideries—many of which are closely tied to local agriculture and farm-based production. Cider makers often rely on fruit grown on their own farms or purchased from nearby orchards, supporting agricultural diversity and rural economies. Many producers do not have access to in-house laboratories and would be required to send each product—or in many cases, each vintage or seasonal batch—out for expensive third-party testing. This would be cost prohibitive for many and could discourage the use of varied, seasonal fruit that reflects annual harvest conditions.

We strongly encourage the TTB to adopt a tiered approach to nutritional labeling, including:
- Exemptions or simplified compliance pathways for producers under a defined annual production threshold, similar to the FDA’s model for small food manufacturers.
- The option to provide average or representative nutritional values rather than batch-specific data.
- Permission to disclose nutritional information digitally via QR code — a system that is already accepted under the European Union’s labeling requirements. This approach would promote international regulatory alignment, minimize packaging changes, and allow consumers ready access to accurate product information without imposing undue cost or operational burdens on producers. For limited-release, non-packaged, or taproom-only products, QR codes would allow minimal testing requirements while still meeting transparency goals.

Without such accommodations, the cost and logistical burden of compliance could significantly affect the smallest and most innovative segments of the cider industry—many of which are rooted in agriculture and depend on flexibility to highlight the diversity of fruit from year to year.

Label Flexibility for Small-Batch and Direct-to-Consumer Products
Innovation is a hallmark of the craft cider movement. Many of our members release limited-edition blends, experimental fermentations, or single-varietal ciders in small volumes—sometimes only a few kegs or cases. These products are often sold directly to consumers and are not distributed through traditional retail channels.

For these types of products, we ask the TTB to allow more flexible labeling options, including:
- Universal batch-level nutritional and allergen disclosures available on-premise or online.
- Expanded use of QR codes to communicate required information without relabeling every SKU.

Implementation Timeline and Industry Support
Should these proposed labeling changes be adopted, it is critical that cideries—especially those with limited staffing and infrastructure—are given sufficient time and support to comply. We support the phased rollout of the final rule, with five years of lead time for producers to comply.

In addition, we recommend the development of technical guidance materials, including sample label formats and FAQs. These resources would help ensure that the final rule is not only effective, but also achievable.

Conclusion
We support the TTB’s goal of creating a more transparent and consumer-friendly labeling system across all alcohol categories. At the same time, we believe it is essential to preserve the diversity and accessibility of our industry, which includes many small, regional, and agricultural producers who will be disproportionately affected by these changes.

With thoughtful modifications, this rule can accomplish both goals—empowering consumers and supporting the sustainability of small producers. We appreciate the opportunity to share our perspective and look forward to working with the TTB as this rulemaking process continues.

Sincerely,
Monica Cohen, CEO
American Cider Association

comment_text: I support the proposal to require an "Alcohol Facts" label showing alcohol content, calories, and nutrients because it helps consumers make informed choices and promotes transparency. Requiring alcohol content on all malt beverages, beer, and wine will reduce confusion and make labeling more consistent and consumer friendly. The 5-year guideline gives all the producers enough time to adjust and I also agree that clear guidance on serving sizes, nutrient testing, and label formatting will ensure the rule is easy to follow. Overall, this rule is a positive step for consumer information and public health.
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
I support the proposal to require an “Alcohol Facts” label showing alcohol content, calories, and nutrients because it helps consumers make informed choices and promotes transparency.
Requiring alcohol content on all malt beverages, beer, and wine will reduce confusion and make labeling more consistent and consumer friendly.
The 5-year guideline gives all the producers enough time to adjust and I also agree that clear guidance on serving sizes, nutrient testing, and label formatting will ensure the rule is easy to follow. Overall, this rule is a positive step for consumer information and public health.

comment_text: Speaking as a consumer and adult beverage producer, requiring yet another government mandated info panel that goes mostly unread is onerous on the producer (lab analysis is very costly) and a time waster for the consumer. The alcohol level is already required on spirits and other adult beverages and requiring a nutrient contents would also be useless for the consumer as the nutritional content is really besides the point. What would be more useful are policies requiring more transparency by producers: for example, requiring the alcohol content for ALL adult beverages, requiring disclosure of any post-processing additives such as common allergens, colorants, sweeteners, glycerin, etc.
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
Speaking as a consumer and adult beverage producer, requiring yet another government mandated info panel that goes mostly unread is onerous on the producer (lab analysis is very costly) and a time waster for the consumer. The alcohol level is already required on spirits and other adult beverages and requiring a nutrient contents would also be useless for the consumer as the nutritional content is really besides the point.

What would be more useful are policies requiring more transparency by producers: for example, requiring the alcohol content for ALL adult beverages, requiring disclosure of any post-processing additives such as common allergens, colorants, sweeteners, glycerin, etc.

comment_title: Comment 195:  National Association of Beverage Importers (NABI)
comment_text: NOTE: Regulations.gov would not let me upload this comment letter. Because it exceeds the 5000-character limit, I am pasting part of it here and I have emailed Mr. Eilers and Ms. Greenberg the full letters. Hopefully, Mr. Eilter will be able to put them in the Public Comment folder. Thank you. National Press Building Suite 1300-NPC Washington, DC 20045 August 15, 2025 Submitted by regulations.gov Director, Regulations and Ruling Division Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau 1310 G Street NW, Box 12 Washington, DC 20005 ATTN: Curt Eilers, Regulations and Rulings Division Re: Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages, Notice No. 237, Docket No. TTB-2025-0003, 90 Fed. Reg. 6654 (January 17, 2025) Dear Ms. Greenberg and Mr. Eilers: The National Association of Beverage Importers (NABI) greatly appreciates the opportunity to provide comments on the notice of proposed rulemaking (NPRM) on Alcohol Facts Labeling. In the past, the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) has referred to this information as "Serving Facts." The topic here is more longstanding than simply the Treasury Report on Competition cited by TTB. For the past 20 years, TTB has considered the Serving Facts rulemaking and issued an administrative ruling on this topic, along with proposed rulemaking, and nutritional labeling guidance. TTB has a continuing experience with this labeling topic. And as noted during the listening sessions, several public advocacy groups have filed Federal litigation to seek action here and that litigation is stayed (and not dismissed) during the pendency of this current rulemaking. TTB has dealt with rulemaking and administrative rulings on these issues during the George W. Bush, Barack Obama, Donald Trump, and Joseph Biden Administrations. Typically, the regulatory climate of Washington, DC changes with each new Administration. The current Administration has issued several executive orders on the promulgation of new regulations and review of existing regulations to ensure "regulations [are] squarely authorized by constitutional Federal statutes, and to commence the deconstruction of the overbearing and burdensome administrative state." Additionally, the trend of recent United States Supreme Court judicial decisions on review of regulations has changed where agencies now face a higher burden to show that the regulation is authorized by the underlying statute. The proposed regulations were published for public comment before the current Administration took office. NABI believes they will face a higher bar of review and clearance by Administration officials and by the Office of Management and Budget (OMB), in particular. Accordingly, NABI's comments recognize the regulatory climate of the current Administration and the higher bar facing TTB in a judicial review of its regulations. NABI respectfully recommends that the alcohol facts statements regulation remain as a voluntary statement that may appear on a label or is accessible to consumers by a Quick Response (QR) code. Sufficiency of Voluntary Alcohol Facts Statement TTB has dealt with the "Servings Fact"-type label disclosure regulatory considerations through proposed regulations and a TTB Ruling. The proposed Alcohol Facts Statement labeling regulations require the same elements of information as the voluntary Serving Facts label: • Serving Size • Servings per Container • Alcohol by volume
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
NOTE: Regulations.gov would not let me upload this comment letter. Because it exceeds the 5000-character limit, I am pasting part of it here and I have emailed Mr. Eilers and Ms. Greenberg the full letters. Hopefully, Mr. Eilter will be able to put them in the Public Comment folder. Thank you.
National Press Building
Suite 1300-NPC
Washington, DC 20045
August 15, 2025

Submitted by regulations.gov

Director, Regulations and Ruling Division
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau
1310 G Street NW, Box 12
Washington, DC 20005
ATTN: Curt Eilers, Regulations and Rulings Division

Re: Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages, Notice No. 237, Docket No. TTB-2025-0003, 90 Fed. Reg. 6654 (January 17, 2025)

Dear Ms. Greenberg and Mr. Eilers:

The National Association of Beverage Importers (NABI) greatly appreciates the opportunity to provide comments on the notice of proposed rulemaking (NPRM) on Alcohol Facts Labeling. In the past, the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) has referred to this information as “Serving Facts.”

The topic here is more longstanding than simply the Treasury Report on Competition cited by TTB. For the past 20 years, TTB has considered the Serving Facts rulemaking and issued an administrative ruling on this topic, along with proposed rulemaking, and nutritional labeling guidance. TTB has a continuing experience with this labeling topic. And as noted during the listening sessions, several public advocacy groups have filed Federal litigation to seek action here and that litigation is stayed (and not dismissed) during the pendency of this current rulemaking.

TTB has dealt with rulemaking and administrative rulings on these issues during the George W. Bush, Barack Obama, Donald Trump, and Joseph Biden Administrations. Typically, the regulatory climate of Washington, DC changes with each new Administration. The current Administration has issued several executive orders on the promulgation of new regulations and review of existing regulations to ensure “regulations [are] squarely authorized by constitutional Federal statutes, and to commence the deconstruction of the overbearing and burdensome administrative state.” Additionally, the trend of recent United States Supreme Court judicial decisions on review of regulations has changed where agencies now face a higher burden to show that the regulation is authorized by the underlying statute.

The proposed regulations were published for public comment before the current Administration took office. NABI believes they will face a higher bar of review and clearance by Administration officials and by the Office of Management and Budget (OMB), in particular. Accordingly, NABI’s comments recognize the regulatory climate of the current Administration and the higher bar facing TTB in a judicial review of its regulations.

NABI respectfully recommends that the alcohol facts statements regulation remain as a voluntary statement that may appear on a label or is accessible to consumers by a Quick Response (QR) code.


Sufficiency of Voluntary Alcohol Facts Statement

TTB has dealt with the “Servings Fact”-type label disclosure regulatory considerations through proposed regulations and a TTB Ruling. The proposed Alcohol Facts Statement labeling regulations require the same elements of information as the voluntary Serving Facts label:

•Serving Size
•Servings per Container
•Alcohol by volume
