document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
1 
 
 
 
National Press Building  
Suite 1300-NPC  
Washington, DC  20045   
August 15, 2025  
  
Submitted by regulations.gov    
  
Director, Regulations and Ruling Division  
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau  
 1310 G Street NW, Box 12   
Washington, DC 20005    
ATTN: Curt Eilers, Regulations and Rulings Division  
  
Re: Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt 
Beverages, Notice No. 237, Docket No. TTB-2025-0003, 90 Fed. Reg. 6654 (January 17, 
2025)    
 
Dear Ms. Greenberg and Mr. Eilers:   
  
The National Association of Beverage Importers (NABI) greatly appreciates the opportunity to 
provide comments on the notice of proposed rulemaking (NPRM) on Alcohol Facts Labeling.1  
In the past, the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) has referred to this 
information as “Serving Facts.”   
  
The topic here is more longstanding than simply the Treasury Report on Competition2 cited by 
TTB.  For the past 20 years, TTB has considered the Serving Facts rulemaking and issued an 
administrative ruling on this topic, along with proposed rulemaking, and nutritional labeling 
guidance.  TTB has a continuing experience with this labeling topic.  And as noted during the 
listening sessions, several public advocacy groups have filed Federal litigation to seek action 
 
1 Prior to the publication of this notice, the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) held two virtual 
“Listening1 Sessions” on these topics in February 2024, and NABI presented a statement and submitted a written 
comment at https://www.regulations.gov/comment/TTB-2024-0002-0416   
2 This report resulted from President Biden’s Executive Order 14036, Promoting Competition in the American 
Economy, dated July 9, 2021 at https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2021/07/14/2021-15069/promoting-
competition-in-the-american-economy  On August 13, 2025, the President issued an Executive Order that revoked 
Executive Order 14036 at https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/08/revocation-of-executive-order-
on-competition/    The Chairman of the Federal Trade Commission applauded this action as “protecting everyday 
Americans from anticompetitive practices through tailored action, promoting economic growth, and ensuring that 
American workers benefit from competition for their labor.” at https://www.ftc.gov/news-events/news/press-
releases/2025/08/ftc-chairman-applauds-revocation-biden-harris-executive-order-
competition?utm_source=govdelivery   
  
   
  
   
  2 
 
here and that litigation is stayed (and not dismissed) during the pendency of this current 
rulemaking.    
 
TTB has dealt with rulemaking and administrative rulings on these issues during the George W. 
Bush, Barack Obama, Donald Trump, and Joseph Biden Administrations.  Typically, the 
regulatory climate of Washington, DC changes with each new Administration. The current 
Administration has issued several executive orders on the promulgation of new regulations and 
review of existing regulations to ensure “regulations [are] squarely authorized by constitutional 
Federal statutes, and to commence the deconstruction of the overbearing and burdensome 
administrative state.”3  Additionally, the trend of recent United States Supreme Court judicial 
decisions on review of regulations has changed where agencies now face a higher burden to 
show that the regulation is authorized by the underlying statute.4   
 
The proposed regulations were published for public comment before the current Administration 
took office.  NABI believes they will face a higher bar of review and clearance by 
Administration officials and by the Office of Management and Budget (OMB), in particular. 
Accordingly, NABI’s comments recognize the regulatory climate of the current Administration 
and the higher bar facing TTB in a judicial review of its regulations.       
 
NABI respectfully recommends that the alcohol facts statements regulation remain as a voluntary 
statement that may appear on a label or is accessible to consumers by a Quick Response (QR) 
code.   
 
       
Sufficiency of Voluntary Alcohol Facts Statement 
 
TTB has dealt with the “Servings Fact”-type label disclosure regulatory considerations through 
proposed regulations and a TTB Ruling.  The proposed Alcohol Facts Statement labeling 
regulations require the same elements of information as the voluntary Serving Facts label: 
 
• Serving Size 
• Servings per Container 
• Alcohol by volume 
 
3 Executive Order, dated February 19, 2025, titled “Ensuring Lawful Governance and Implementing the 
President’s ‘Department of Government Efficiency’ Deregulatory” Initiative.”  
https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/02/ensuring-lawful-governance-and-implementing-the-
presidents-department-of-government-efficiency-regulatory-initiative/  
Executive Order, dated January 31, 2025, titled “Unleashing Prosperity through Deregulation.”     
https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/01/unleashing-prosperity-through-deregulation/  
Presidential Memorandum, dated April 9, 2025,“Memorandum for the Head of Departments and Agencies, 
Directing the Repeal of Unlawful Regulations”    https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-
actions/2025/04/directing-the-repeal-of-unlawful-regulations/   
Executive Order, dated May 9, 2025, titled “Fighting Over Criminalization in Federal Regulations” at 
https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/05/fighting-overcriminalization-in-federal-regulations/  and 
White House Fact Sheet at https://www.whitehouse.gov/fact-sheets/2025/05/fact-sheet-president-donald-j-trump-
fights-overcriminalization-in-federal-regulations/    
4 Loper Bright Enterprises v. Raimondo, 603 U.S.369 (2024) overruling Chevron U. S. A. Inc. v. Natural Resources 
Defense Council, Inc., 467 U. S. 837 (1984).  3 
 
• Fluid ounces of Alcohol per Serving   
• Calories 
• Carbohydrate by grams 
• Fat by grams 
• Protein by grams  
 
The information may appear in a panel or in a linear display.   
 
The current requirements for the voluntary use of the Serving Facts label were issued in TTB 
Ruling 2013-2, May 28, 2013, V oluntary Nutrient Content Statements in the Labeling and 
Advertising of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages.5   
 
The current proposed rulemaking seeks comments on whether the Alcohol Facts Statement label 
should be mandatory information on a label affixed to the container or continue to be voluntary.  
The proposal also seeks comments on multiple options about the presentation of the label. In this 
regard, NABI is only commenting on the use of the electronic alternative to communicate the 
voluntary information to consumers.   
 
Mandatory or Voluntary 
 
Under the Federal Alcohol Administration Act,6 TTB is authorized to issue labeling regulations 
that, among other things, will provide “adequate information as to the identify and quality of the 
products.”  TTB has broad discretion in issuing regulations under this standard.7  While the Food 
and Drug Administration (FDA) is required to issue such food labeling requirements on the 
nutrient statement under the Nutrition Labeling and Education Act of 1990, TTB is not covered 
by that law.  Accordingly, TTB’s decision to issue the Alcohol Facts/Serving Fact requirement is 
discretionary.   
 
A review of the Supplementary Information on comments submitted previously to TTB opposing 
the Serving Facts label requirement shows that the singular opposition raised is the potential 
costs associated with a mandatory requirement.  In particular, the burden of these product testing 
costs on small and medium size importers and producers was noted.8  
 
NABI agrees that this information may be valuable to many consumers and believes that many 
industry members will include it voluntarily on a label or in a QR code reference.  TTB lists a 
number of steps it has taken to mitigate these costs, such as increased tolerance ranges, use of 
typicity charts, and the five-year transition period.   A pivotal concern is whether making this 
requirement mandatory will attract or raise concerns in the regulatory approval process which 
would not arise were the requirement remains voluntary.  
 
 
5  https://www.ttb.gov/media/72036/download?inline   
6  27 USC 205(e)(2).   
7 Center for Science in the Public Interest v. Department of Treasury, 797 F. 2d 995 (D.C. Cir. 1986) at 
https://law.justia.com/cases/federal/appellate-courts/F2/797/995/104822/  
8 See, 90 Federal Register at 6664 (January 17, 2025) 4 
 
In a survey of NABI members, many of the following reasons were cited for keeping the Alcohol 
Fact Statement voluntary.  
 
• The voluntary option has worked.  Industry members can present this information if they 
believe that their consumers want it. 
• Congress did not enact a specific legal requirement for the Alcohol Facts/Serving Facts label 
for beverage alcohol unlike other beverages.   
• The information must be understandable to the consumer.  For example, does the average 
consumer know what a serving size is?  It is not explained on the label and the consumer 
would have to look at a chart in the regulations in order to determine it.  Similarly, do 
consumers understand that the disclosures of quantities are subject to a tolerance of plus or 
minus 20 percent? 
• Have the petitioners established and do the past comments show that consumers want all of 
this information?   
• Compliance costs are passed along to consumers in higher prices.  
• The necessary testing is expensive and is recurring.  While TTB cites ways to mitigate the 
costs, do those undercut the value of the information for the consumer?  Broader tolerances 
and typicity charts provide less accurate and more general information to consumers.  
• Logistical challenges of the global market in these products arise where labeled product 
enter U.S. to be shipped to another country’s market where that country does not allow the 
information presented in the same manner as does the U.S.    
• From a cost perspective, a five-year implementation date still poses economic challenges to 
new entrants near the effective date or those who enter the business after the effective date.   
• Quick Response (QR) codes are a good option but still have costs to update and maintain.   
• V oluntary option is consistent with the Administration’s executive directives that regulations 
must not be burdensome and must be based on clear statutory authorization.   
• Importers are currently under economic stress due to the tariffs and this labeling requirement 
is an additional expense to mandate now.   
 
These reasons support maintaining the Alcohol Fact/Serving Facts.as voluntary information.   
 
 
Quick Response (QR) Codes for Voluntary Alcohol Facts Statements are Valuable if 
Properly Regulated 
  
Quick Response (QR) codes are valuable for conveying large amounts of information about a 
product without cluttering a front, neck, and back label given the limited physical “real estate” 
on a bottle or other consumer container.    
  
NABI supports the use of a QR code.  The quality and quantity of additional information that 
may be given to a consumer via the QR code is enormous and, moreover, the QR code allows 
this additional information to be updated constantly at a cost to the industry that is far less than a 
paper label.  The QR code gives the industry member the opportunity to include some 
explanation about the element of information that would not otherwise be available on the 
limited "real estate" of labels on the bottle or container.  Moreover, broad generational 5 
 
acceptance of e-devices and I-phones necessitate their use today. Consumers today look for the 
QR code on a label as an information resource.     
  
There is certain information about the wine, distilled spirits, and beer/malt beverages that must 
be available to all consumers and appear on a label on the bottle or consumer container.  The 
brand name, class and type of wine or distilled spirit or category of beer, name of the producer 
and/or bottler, and alcohol content are the elements of information that fall within this category.  
The alcohol by volume (ABV) content should appear on the label while the additional details 
provided in the alcohol facts statement could be accessed through the QR code.     
  
Finally, as a practical matter, for a country like the United States that has a pre-approval review 
of labels, how does TTB envision the label specialist reviewing the QR code information?  The 
information on the QR code site would need to comply with the TTB advertising regulations.9  
Would the importer have to submit a transcript or copy of all of the information behind the QR 
code?  Given the importer must obtain the certificate of label approval (COLA) and it is possible 
that the foreign producer will operate the QR code site, the importer will need to monitor the QR 
code sites that appear on the label.  Whatever approach is adopted by TTB, it must be reasonably 
administrable in order to protect the consumer.     
  
Please do not hesitate to reach out with any questions or requests for clarification.  NABI greatly 
appreciates your time on this important public policy decision.  
  
Sincerely,   
  
 Robert M. Tobiassen   
Robert M. Tobiassen, 
NABI President  
 
 
9  TTB Industry Circular 2024-1, Use of Social Media in the Advertising Alcohol Beverages at 
https://www.ttb.gov/public-information/industry-circulars/ttb-industry-circular-2024-1

comment_text: See Attached
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text: See Attached

comment_text: See Attached
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
August, 14, 2025.  
 
 
Agency responsible: 
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB), Department of the Treasury 
USA WTO TBT Inquiry Point, Email: usatbtep@nist.gov 
 
Subject: Comments on: Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and 
Malt Beverages  
 
To whom it may concern, 
 
I write to you today on behalf of the Mezcal Sustainability Alliance , a strategic collaboration  among 
companies and with institutions in the sector, committed to the sustainable development of Mezcal. Its 
purpose is to  strengthen the identity of the spirit by disseminating good practices, promoting joint 
projects and generating a positive impact on producing communities. With a focus on innovative  
solutions, the Alliance seeks to accelerate change and preserve the artisanal tradition that  defines 
Mezcal.  
 
The Mezcal Sustainability Alliance thanks the TTB  for notifying its proposed regulation to the TBT 
Committee, in compliance with its commitments as a member of the World Trade Organization, in 
accordance with article 2.9.2 of the Agreement, which establishes that notifications of technical 
regulations should occur at a stage where comments can be considered and modifications to the initial 
proposal can be made. 
 
Background 
 
On January 17, 2025, the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) of the U.S. published a 
proposal (Notice No. 237 ) to amend the labeling of wines, distilled spirits, and malt beverages. The 
main objective is to provide consumers with more comprehensive and clear information about the 
alcoholic beverages they consume, similar to the nutrition information found on foods 
 
Key points of the proposal: 
• "Alcohol Facts" Panel:  The creation of a mandatory panel on alcoholic beverage labels is 
proposed, similar to the "Nutrition Facts" panel on foods. This panel would include  alcohol 
content per serving; calories per serving; basic nutrients; standard serving size and number 
of servings per container .  The proposal establishes specific serving sizes for each type of 
alcoholic beverage, which vary depending on their alcohol content.   
• Flexible presentation formats:  The "Alcohol Facts" panel would be presented in different 
formats, adapting to the container size and beverage content. 
 
 
 
 
 
• Compliance Period : A period of 5 years from the publication of the final rule in the Federal 
Register is proposed for producers and distributors to comply with the new requirements. 
 
General comments on the proposal:  
 
Alcohol content 
It is acknowledged that declaring the alcohol content on alcoholic beverage labels is important to 
inform consumers and help prevent harmful consumption. However, expressing this content in fluid 
ounces of pure ethanol per serving is considered unnecessari ly complex and not easily understood by 
the average consumer. Therefore, it is recommended that only alcohol by volume (% ABV) be declared, 
and that this information be allowed anywhere on the label as long as it is clearly visible, without 
requiring placement in a specific panel or format. 
 
Serving and servings per container: 
The proposal aims to standardize the declaration of serving size and number of servings per container 
across all regulated alcoholic beverages, placing this information within the “Alcohol Facts” panel. 
While it is considered essential for consumers to understand how much alcohol is in a container and in 
a standard drink to promote moderation, it is suggested that this information be provided voluntarily. If 
mandated, it should be included through electronic labeling (e.g., QR code, digital platform, or website), 
which would ensure access to relevant information without imposing unnecessary regulatory or 
commercial burdens. 
 
Nutritional information 
 
The proposal seeks to include nutritional information —such as calories, carbohydrates, fats, and 
proteins—within the “Alcohol Facts” panel on alcoholic beverage labels. However, this approach may 
confuse consumers by implying that alcoholic beverages offer  nutritional benefits, which contradicts 
Codex Alimentarius guidelines that prohibit the addition or promotion of nutrients in alcohol. Alcohol 
 
should not be considered a food or nutrient and presenting it as such could mislead consumers into 
viewing it as comparable to non -alcoholic beverages, potentially influencing purchasing decisions 
based on inappropriate criteria. This could divert attention from the health risks associated with alcohol 
consumption and negatively impact public health perceptions. 
 
 
Key Questions from the TTB: 
1. Should TTB’s proposed nutrient content labeling statement be more consistent with the 
Nutrition Facts Label found on foods that are under FDA’s labeling jurisdiction? 
Alternatively, do the differences between alcohol beverages and other foods make it 
unnecessary, or even misleading, to adopt the type of nutrient labeling required on food 
labels that are under FDA’s labeling jurisdiction? For example, would information on the 
percentage of the daily value of the listed nutrients provided by alcohol beverages be useful 
information for consumers? Alternatively, could such statements mislead consumers by 
implying that they may rely on alcohol beverage consumption to satisfy part of their daily 
nutrient requirements? 
 
We believe that requiring the inclusion of the "Alcohol Facts" panel on labels would not provide any 
benefit to consumers, since the objective of alcoholic beverages labeling, from a health perspective, is 
to prevent harmful alcohol use. Therefore, including nutritional information on such beverages could 
create the perception that they have a "nutritional benefit," which could cause confusion among 
consumers. 
 
We consider that this measure, which implies including information on caloric content, sodium content, 
sugar or fat content, among others, can influence the consumer’s perception of alcohol as healthier 
than other products or foods. Therefore, it is extremely risky to combine two health objectives that could 
confuse non -alcoholic beverages with alcoholic beverages, given that the calorie content, sodium 
content, sugar or fat content, among others, and the amount of alcohol, are diff erent elements in the 
consumer's diet and are not comparable. 
 
By its nature, alcohol should not be considered a food or a nutrient, so including the nutrimental 
information on the label of alcoholic beverages can lead to consumer confusion, understanding that 
alcoholic beverages provide nutrients similar to food, and this may influence their purchasing decision 
and favor the consumption of one beverage over another without taki ng into account the amount of 
alcohol that each product contains. 
 
Making this labeling mandatory would also add costs for producers, importers, and distributors, which 
goes against trade agreements such as the Agreement on Technical Barriers to Trade (TBT Agreement) 
of the World Trade Organization (WTO), which prohibits creating unnecessary barriers to international  
trade. However, if the "Alcohol Facts" panel becomes mandatory, we strongly recommend allowing this 
information to be presented digitally (QR codes, websites, etc.). This makes the information accessible 
to consumers without creating unnecessary regulatory and commercial burdens. 
Digital labeling offers many advantages: 
• Unlimited space to inform consumers. 
• Consumer-friendly and easy-to-understand format. 
• Easy updating as regulations change. 
• Effective communication with vulnerable groups (such as young people) about the risks of 
harmful alcohol consumption. 
• Opportunity to create engaging and educational content. 
 
This approach is in line with the "Guidance for providing food information to consumers by using 
technology", which is being developed by the CODEX Alimentarius Committee on Food Labeling. 
Finally, we believe that a gradual implementation period of 5 years would be the best way to implement 
these changes, particularly to give small producers time to adapt their supply chains for distribution in 
the U.S. 
 
2. For greater consistency with the FDA Nutrition Facts Label, should Alcohol Facts statements be 
allowed or required to include other elements (such as sodium and cholesterol) or a further 
breakdown of fat (to include saturated fat and trans-fat)? 
 
As previously noted, the inclusion of expanded nutritional information on alcoholic beverage labels 
could lead consumers to mistakenly believe these products offer nutritional benefits, causing serious 
confusion. Evidence from the Organization for Economic Co -operation and Development (OECD) 
shows that labeling can be an effective tool for informing consumers, but only when the information is 
clear, concise, and relevant. Overloading labels with excessive or complex data may result in confusion 
or misinformation, undermining the goal of providing accessible and useful consumer information. 
 
 
3. Would the inclusion of elements not ordinarily expected to be found in alcohol beverages (such 
as trans-fat and dietary fiber) be useful or potentially misleading? 
 
As previously mentioned, including nutritional information on alcoholic beverages may lead consumers 
to believe these products offer nutritional benefits, causing significant confusion. Specifically, elements 
like dietary fiber could reinforce this misconception, suggesting added health value. Therefore, it is not 
recommended to include any of the nutritional components proposed. Rather than being helpful, such 
declarations could directly mislead consumers and result in misinterpretation. 
 
4. Should TTB allow numerical statements of the vitamin and mineral content of alcohol 
beverages, assuming the product contains vitamins or minerals, or could such a statement create  
an erroneous impression that consumption of the alcohol beverage has nutritional value or other 
health-related benefits? 
 
Including nutritional information on alcoholic beverage labels may lead consumers to mistakenly 
believe these products offer nutritional benefits, causing serious confusion. Specifically, elements like 
dietary fiber could reinforce this misconception by su ggesting added health value. Therefore, such 
information should not be required in any form.  
 
In Mexico, legislation explicitly prohibits alcoholic beverages from referencing any nutritional benefits 
or therapeutic properties. According to Article 308 of the General Health Law, advertising must focus 
solely on product characteristics, quality, and production methods, without implying health or wellness 
benefits. Additionally, Article 307 prohibits associating non -alcoholic food and beverage advertising 
with alcohol consumption or promoting harmful dietary habits, while Article 6 of the Advertising 
Regulation reinforces the ban on attributing preventive, therapeutic, or nutritional qualities to products. 
These declarations, rather than being helpful, could mislead consumers and distort public health 
messaging. 
 
In summary, Mexican legislation is clear in prohibiting the attribution of nutritional properties or health 
benefits that they do not possess to alcoholic beverages. This is because including such declarations 
on labeling could confuse consumers instead of providing useful information. 
 
 
5. How many industry members already provide nutrient content information on labels, in 
advertisements (such as websites), or upon request (for example, to consumers or restaurants)? 
No comments on this topic. 
 
 
6. Do consumers want to see Alcohol Facts labeling on alcohol beverage products? How might 
consumers benefit from such a label? Do consumers have adequate information about the identity 
and quality of alcohol beverages if alcohol beverage containers do not  include Alcohol Facts 
labeling? How do those benefits compare to the costs and regulatory burdens associated with 
such revisions? 
 
The current information on alcoholic beverage labeling is sufficient. The inclusion of the "Alcohol Facts" 
panel would not provide any benefits to consumer s and would generate unnecessary costs and 
regulatory burdens. 
 
 
7. How, if at all, would the new mandatory labeling requirements affect competition in the alcohol 
beverage market? 
  
Making a change in the labels of these products would generate an extra cost for manufacturers, 
importers, and distributors, particularly harming small and emerging businesses. Therefore, if adopted, 
this proposal would create unnecessary barriers to trade in violation of Article 2.2 of the WTO 
Agreement on Technical Barriers to Trade, that establishes that “… technical regulations shall not be 
more trade-restrictive than necessary to fulfil a legitimate objective, taking account of the risks non -
fulfilment would create”. 
 
8. How would the new mandatory labeling requirements affect small businesses and,  in 
particular, new businesses entering into the alcohol beverage marketplace? 
 
The proposed regulation would have a disproportionate impact on international suppliers, especially 
small and new producers. This is due to increased costs associated with additional analyses, packaging 
and labeling modifications, new shipments, and the re structuring of supply chains for the U.S. market. 
This burden could even force some small producers to leave the market. 
 
9. How, if at all, would the new mandatory labeling requirements affect international trade of 
alcohol beverages? Is there any information that should, or should not, be included to align the 
proposed labeling requirements with those of other countries? 
 
To reduce operational costs and improve access to detailed information, electronic labeling is 
recommended. This approach would help avoid trade barriers and harmonize requirements 
internationally, minimizing the impact of new labeling rules on producers and supply chains. 
 
 
Conclusion: 
 
Detailed nutritional labeling on alcoholic beverages may confuse consumers by implying health 
benefits. If required, such information should be provided voluntarily or via electronic labeling to avoid 
regulatory burdens and disproportionate costs, especially for international and small producers. 
 
 
Best regards, 
 
 
 
Rocio Melendrez Ramirez 
Representative 
 
Members of the “Alianza para la Sustentabilidad”: Casa Xipe; Del Maguey Single Village Mezcal; Mezcal Los Danzantes; Mezcal Amarás; Mezcal El Tinieblo; 
Mezcal Júrame; Marqués del Jaral de Berrio; Casa Mezcal Huitzila; Mezcal Amaxak; Promotora y Comercializadora de Destilados SA de CV; Casa Parada 
Mezcal; Santa Fátima; WYN Spirits S. de R.L de C.V./Dos Hombres.

comment_text: See Attached
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
From: 
Cámara Nacional 
de la Industria 
Tequilera  
To: Alcohol and Tobacco Tax 
and Trade Bureau (TTB) Subject: 
Comments on: Alcohol Facts Statements in 
the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and 
Malt Beverages 
Docket No. TTB-2025-0002; Notice No. 237 
Notification : G/TBT/N/USA/2182 
 
Agency responsible: 
 
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB), Department of the Treasury 
USA WTO TBT Inquiry Point, Email: usatbtep@nist.gov 
 
About the Cámara Nacional de la Industria Tequilera: The Chamber of the Tequila Industry (CNIT – 
for its acronym in Spanish) is the leading voice of the Tequila industry worldwide, championing the 
interests of its members and promoting the responsible production and consumption of Tequila. As 
a globally recognized symbol of Mexico, Tequila has a rich history dating back to the 16th century 
and boasts a Designation of Origin Tequila (DOT) acknowledged by 57 countries. The Tequila 
industry plays a vital role in Mexico's economy, supporting approximately 41,840 agave farmers, 
100,000 distillery employees, and 209 authorized distilleries. 
 
Appreciation Statement: The Chamber of the Tequila Industry extends its sincere gratitude to the 
TTB for the opportunity to submit our comments on this significant matter. We trust that the TTB 
will give due consideration to our perspective and to the potential impact of t his proposed 
rulemaking on the Tequila industry and its supply chain within the United States market. 
 
TTB Proposal on Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, 
Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages 
 
On January 17, 2025, the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) of the U.S. published a 
proposal (Notice No. 237) to amend the labeling of wines, distilled spirits, and malt beverages. The 
main objective is to provide consumers with more comprehensive and clear information about the 
alcoholic beverages they consume, similar to the nutrition information found on foods. 
Key points of the proposal: 
 "Alcohol Facts" Panel: The creation of a mandatory panel  on alcoholic beverage labels is 
proposed, similar to the "Nutrition Facts" panel on foods. This panel would include: 
1. Alcohol content per serving:  Expressed as alcohol by volume (ABV) and as fluid 
ounces of pure alcohol per serving (rounded to the nearest tenth). 
2. Calories per serving: The amount of calories in each standard serving. 
3. Basic nutrients: Includes the declaration of carbohydrates, fats, and proteins. 
4. Standard serving size and number of servings per container:  The proposal 
establishes specific ser ving sizes for each type of alcoholic beverage, which vary 
depending on their alcohol content. For example: 
i. Malt beverages with no more than 7% alcohol: 12 fl oz (355 ml) 
ii. Wines: 
1. 5 fl oz (148 ml) for wines with 7-16% alcohol. 
2. 2.5 fl oz (74 ml) for products with 16% to 24% alc./vol. 
iii. Distilled spirits: 
1. 12 fl oz (355 ml) if they contain up to 7% alc./vol.; 
2. 5 fl oz (148 ml) between 7% and 16% alc./vol.; 
3. 2.5 fl oz (74 ml) between 16% and 24% alc./vol.; and 1.5 fluid 
ounces (44 ml) 
4. 50 ml for 50 ml containers if they exceed 24% alc./vol. 
 
 Flexible presentation formats: The "Alcohol Facts" panel would be presented in different 
formats, adapting to the container size and beverage content. 
 
 
 
 
 
Compliance Period: A period of 5 years from the publication of the final rule in the Federal Register 
is proposed for producers and distributors to comply with the new requirements. 
 
Comments on the proposal: 
 Alcohol content: We view the inclusion of the alcohol content declaration positively, but 
question the necessity of including fluid ounces of ethanol, as this information is not 
considered relevant to the average consumer. In fact, the Official Mexican Standard NOM-
006-SCFI-2012, Alcoholic Beverages -Tequila-Specifications already provides for the 
declaration of the product's alcohol content. 
 Serving and servings per container: The importance of consumers knowing the amount of 
alcohol in each container and each standard serving is recognized. However, it is suggested 
that this information be provided voluntarily or through elect ronic labeling (QR codes, 
digital platforms, websites) to avoid additional costs and unnecessary regulatory burdens. 
 Nutritional information: Including nutritional information (calories, carbohydrates, fats, 
proteins) on alcoholic beverage labels could confuse consumers. It could be interpreted as 
if these beverages have nutritional benefits, which is contrary to CODEX Alimentarius 
guidelines. It is emphasized that alcohol should not be considered a food or nutrient and 
that nutritional information could di stract from the risks associated with alcohol 
consumption. 
Key Questions from the TTB: 
1. Should TTB’s proposed nutrient  content labeling statement be more  consistent with the 
Nutrition Facts Label found on foods that are under FDA’s labeling jurisdiction? Alternatively, do 
the differences  between alcohol beverages and other  foods make it unnecessary, or even  
misleading, to adopt the type of nutrient  labeling required on food labels that are under FDA’s 
labeling jurisdiction? For example, would information on the percentage of the daily value of the 
listed nutrients provided by alcohol  beverages be useful information for  consumers? 
Alternatively, could such statements mislead consumers by implying that they may rely on alcohol 
beverage consumption to satisfy part of their daily nutrient requirements? 
Our position highli ghts that requiring the "Alcohol Facts" panel on labels would not genuinely 
benefit consumers. From a public health perspective, the true objective of alcoholic beverage 
labeling is to discourage harmful alcohol consumption. Including nutritional information on labels 
could easily lead people to believe that these beverages have some sort of health benefit, which 
would only create confusion. Alcoholic beverages simply do not provide nutrients. Putting 
nutritional information on labels could give consumers t he wrong idea, making them think that 
alcohol fits into a balanced diet or offers essential nutrients. This could skew their purchasing 
decisions, distracting them from the most important information: alcohol content. 
Furthermore, it is misleading to compa re alcoholic and non-alcoholic beverages because they are 
fundamentally different. Elements like calories, carbohydrates, sugars, and fats in alcoholic 
beverages simply cannot be compared to normal food, because the key difference is the alcohol 
itself. At tempting to use nutritional labeling (including calories) to prevent harmful alcohol 
consumption could even be counterproductive. It could make consumers perceive alcohol as 
somehow healthy or harmless, potentially leading to worse health consequences than  current 
labeling was trying to prevent. It is risky to confuse non-alcoholic and alcoholic beverages. They are 
distinct products, with distinct target consumers, and should not be presented as comparable. Making this labeling mandatory would also add cost s for producers, importers, and distributors, 
which goes against trade agreements such as the Agreement on Technical Barriers to Trade (TBT 
Agreement) of the World Trade Organization (WTO), which prohibits creating unnecessary barriers 
to international tra de. However, if the "Alcohol Facts" panel becomes mandatory, we strongly 
recommend allowing this information to be presented digitally (QR codes, websites, etc.). This 
makes the information accessible without creating unnecessary regulatory and commercial 
burdens. 
Digital labeling offers many advantages: 
 Unlimited space to inform consumers. 
 Consumer-friendly and easy-to-understand format. 
 Easy updating as regulations change. 
 Effective communication with vulnerable groups (such as young people) about the risks 
of harmful alcohol consumption. 
 Opportunity to create engaging and educational content. 
 
This approach is in line with the "Guidance for providing food information to consumers by using 
technology", which is being developed by the CODEX Alimentarius Committee on Food Labeling. 
Finally, we believe that a gradual implementation period of 5 years would be the best way to 
implement these changes, particularly to give small producers time to adapt their supply chains for 
distribution in the U.S. 
2. For greater consistency with the FDA Nutrition Facts Label, should Alcohol Facts statements be 
allowed or required to include other elements (such as sodium and cholesterol) or a further 
breakdown of fat (to include saturated fat and trans-fat)? 
It is not recommended to include additional information on sodium, cholesterol, or saturated and 
trans fats. The inclusion of more nutritional information could increase confusion and reinforce the 
misconception that alcoholic beverages have nutritional benefits. 
3. Would the inclusion of elements not ordinarily expected to be found in alcohol beverages (such 
as trans-fat and dietary fiber) be useful or potentially misleading? 
The inclusion of items such as trans fats and dietary fiber would not be useful and could be 
misle ading. These elements are not relevant to alcoholic beverages and their inclusion could 
confuse consumers. 
4. Should TTB allow numerical statements of the vitamin and mineral content of alcohol 
beverages, assuming the product contains vitamins or minerals, or could such a statement create 
an erroneous impression that consumption of the alcohol beverage has nutritional value or other 
health-related benefits? 
It is not recommended to include numerical declarations of vitamin and mineral content. This could 
create a misleading  impression that alcoholic beverages have nutritional value, which is not true 
and could be harmful to public health. In Mexico, laws prohibit alcoholic beverages from being promoted with nutritional, therapeutic, or 
rehabilitation benefits. 
The General Health Law, in its article 308, establishes that advertising for these beverages must be 
limited to describing their characteristics, quality, and how they are made, without presenting them 
as something that improves health or well-being. 
Furthermore, article 307 of the same law prohibits advertising for food and non-alcoholic beverages 
from being directly or indirectly related to the consumption of alcoholic beverages, or from 
promoting harmful eating habits. 
The Regulations of the General Health Law on Advertising, in its article 6, reinforces this prohibition 
by establishing that advertising for no product may attribute preventative, therapeutic, 
rehabilitative, nutritional, stimulating, or any other type of quality. 
In summary, Mexican legislation is clear  in prohibiting the attribution of nutritional properties or 
health benefits that they do not possess to alcoholic beverages. This is because including such 
declarations on labeling could confuse consumers instead of providing useful information. 
5. How many industry members already provide nutrient content information on labels, in 
advertisements (such as websites), or upon request (for example, to consumers or restaurants)? 
No comments on this topic. 
6. Do consumers want to see Alcohol Facts labeling on alcohol beverage pro ducts? How might 
consumers benefit from such a label? Do consumers have adequate information about the 
identity and quality of alcohol beverages if alcohol beverage containers do not include Alcohol 
Facts labeling? How do those benefits compare to the cost s and regulatory burdens associated 
with such revisions? 
The current information on alcoholic beverage labeling is sufficient. The inclusion of the "Alcohol 
Facts" panel would not provide significant ben efits to the consumer and would generate 
unnecessary costs and regulatory burdens. 
7. How, if at all, would the new mandatory labeling requirements affect competition in the alcohol 
beverage market? 
This measure would impose excessive costs and regulatory burdens on producers, importers, and 
distributors of alcoholic beverages, particularly harming small and emerging businesses. This would 
go against the spirit of Article 2.2 of the Agreement on Technical Barriers to Trade (TBT Agreement) 
of the World Trade Organization (WTO), which seeks to prevent the imposition of technical 
regulations that unnecessarily restrict international trade, unless there are legitimate objectives 
justified by member states. 
According to the TBT Agreement, technical regulations sho uld not limit trade more than strictly 
necessary to achieve a legitimate objective. Therefore, it is considered that the proposed measures 
would have a disproportionate impact on international suppliers. This is mainly due to the increased 
costs associated  with additional product analyses, modifications to packaging and labeling, new 
shipments, and especially the restructuring of supply chains for the U.S. alcoholic beverage market. 8. How would the new mandatory labeling requirements affect small businesses and, in particular, 
new businesses entering into the alcohol beverage marketplace? 
The proposed regulation would have a disproportionate impact on international suppliers, 
especially small and new producers. This is due to increased costs associated with additional  
analyses, packaging and labeling modifications, new shipments, and the restructuring of supply 
chains for the U.S. market. This burden could even force some small producers to leave the market. 
9. How, if at all, would the new mandatory lab eling requirements affect international trade of 
alcohol beverages? Is there any information that should, or should not, be included to align the 
proposed labeling requirements with those of other countries? 
It is certain that the new labeling requirements would have a negative impact on international trade 
in alcoholic beverages, as they would increase costs and complexity. To avoid this, it is suggested to 
consider harmonizing such requirements with those of other countries, as well as implementing the 
use of tools such as elec tronic labeling, which allows for much more information than physical 
labels, while reducing operational costs. 
Conclusion: Detailed nutritional labeling could confuse consumers, and information about alcohol 
is sufficient. It is proposed that, in any case , nutritional information be voluntary or provided 
electronically. It is reiterated that the implementation of the proposal would generate significant 
costs, especially affecting small and new businesses, as well as international trade in alcoholic 
beverages in general. 
End of the document

comment_text: See Attached
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
On behalf of the Government of Mexico, please find attached the consolidated 
comments of the Mexican alcoholic beverages industry regarding the Alcohol 
and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau’s (TTB) proposal (Notice No. 237) to amend 
the labeling of wines, distilled spirits, and malt beverages, notified
(G/TBT/N/USA/2182) to the WTO TBT Committee in accordance with Article 2.9.2 
of the WTO Agreement on Technical Barriers to Trade (TBT Agreement).
While Mexico recognizes the objective of providing consumers with clear and 
comprehensive information, our industry expresses serious concerns that the 
proposed mandatory “Alcohol Facts” panel—particularly the inclusion of detailed 
nutritional information—could mislead consumers by suggesting that alcoholic 
beverages provide nutritional or health benefits. This approach contradicts 
Codex Alimentarius guidelines, Mexican legislation (General Health Law, Articles 
307 and 308, and its Advertising Regulation), and may distract from the core 
health objective of preventing harmful alcohol consumption.
Furthermore, the requirement to declare alcohol content in both % ABV and fluid 
ounces of pure ethanol per serving is unnecessarily complex and not easily 
understood by the average consumer. Similarly, the proposed mandatory 
declaration of serving size and servings per container would impose 
disproportionate regulatory and commercial burdens, particularly on small 
producers and exporters.
The Government of Mexico therefore strongly recommends that:
1. Nutritional information be provided on a voluntary basis or through
electronic labeling (QR codes, websites, or digital platforms), ensuring
access to relevant information without creating unnecessary barriers to
trade, in line with Article 2.2 of the TBT Agreement.2. Alcohol content be declared exclusively in % ABV, allowing its placement
anywhere on the label as long as it is clearly visible.
3. Implementation be gradual, with a minimum transition period of five (5)
years, to allow producers—particularly SMEs—to adapt their supply chains.
Mexico reiterates that the creation of labeling requirements that may mislead
consumers or impose excessive costs on producers could constitute an
unnecessary obstacle to international trade and have a disproportionate impact
on small and emerging businesses in the alcoholic beverages sector.
We thank you in advance for your kind attention to these comments and
respectfully request that they be duly considered in the elaboration of the final
rule.
Kind regards,

comment_text: Wine is so unique and needs a story to be set apart from others. Having to add a nutritional panel takes precious real estate from the winery's opportunity to tell the consumer about the wine
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text: Wine is so unique and needs a story to be set apart from others. Having to add a nutritional panel takes precious real estate from the winery’s opportunity to tell the consumer about the wine

comment_text: Alcohol content I agree with listing pursuant to current requirements. That makes sense to me as alcohol content can vary drastically and as a psychoactive drug/depressant would have a direct impact on a safe consumption rate. However, alcohol is a 'non-essential' beverage when considering 'health benefits'. If a producer chooses to list the caloric and nutritional info to appeal to the health conscious consumer, that is their prerogative. It may even give them an advantage. However, I don't believe producers should be REQUIRED to list the info. The consumer is already assuming a certain amount of risk by choosing to imbibe. There is an age minimum law for a reason. If adults need to be helicoptered on their consumption habits to an even greater degree.. God help us. Not to mention, how would this info be monitored and checked? A logistical nightmare. I like the idea of having a website or QR code linked to more info about the product as that would allow more flexibility between batches/vintages/etc. (live updates) without the expense of having to constantly update a printed label. But again, I don't believe it should be required per reasoning above and it continues to raise the concern of how the info will be fact checked/monitored.

comment_text: Regarding uniform labeling requirements: should be uniform across beer, wine, and spirit labels. The following should be required on all labels: Alcohol content, common allergens, artificial or natural colorants (should state what was used), added sweetener (natural or artificial). The following should NOT be required on labels overseen by the TTB: Calorie and Nutrients Regarding requiring additional panels: Requiring yet another largely ignored information panel (Surgeon General statement) by requiring Calorie and Nutrient, Serving Facts, and/or Alcohol Facts panels is onerous for the small producer and importer. Also, does anyone read the Surgeon General's statement? Not really. Do consumers pay attention to serving size on boxes of cereal, pasta, or potato chips? Not so much. However, I do believe it is in consumers AND the industry's best interest to be more transparent and that disclosing allergens and additives (ie coloring and/or sugar dosing as is done with spirits) should be required in a legible font and type size.
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
Regarding uniform labeling requirements: should be uniform across beer, wine, and spirit labels.

The following should be required on all labels: Alcohol content, common allergens, artificial or natural colorants (should state what was used), added sweetener (natural or artificial).

The following should NOT be required on labels overseen by the TTB: Calorie and Nutrients

Regarding requiring additional panels:
Requiring yet another largely ignored information panel (Surgeon General statement) by requiring Calorie and Nutrient, Serving Facts, and/or Alcohol Facts panels is onerous for the small producer and importer. Also, does anyone read the Surgeon General’s statement? Not really. Do consumers pay attention to serving size on boxes of cereal, pasta, or potato chips? Not so much.

However, I do believe it is in consumers AND the industry’s best interest to be more transparent and that disclosing allergens and additives (ie coloring and/or sugar dosing as is done with spirits) should be required in a legible font and type size.

comment_text: These requirements would be a tremendous burden to my small winery. We make honey wine in tiny batches that sometimes are only made once. Sometimes up to 24 different flavors in a single year. Needing to go through the testing and label requirements for every one of these that may only be a handful of cases would be very detrimental to my business.

comment_text: The beer, wine, and distilled spirits industry should not need to be so heavily regulated by the government with regards to serving size, calories, allergens, etc. The wine industry especially has been around for thousands of years and we need to not be "helicopter parents" consumers know how many calories are in a glass of wine, in a can of beer, and in a shot glass of spirits Doing this will not make people healthier, or more aware of their calorie intake. Consumers will have what they will have and this is an added burden that needs to not be sought after. Consumers are very proactive in looking on websites for information especially if there is a QR code that is available for scanning on the bottles thereby giving all the information needed at their fingertips. In fact I just came across a TTB Beer Resources guide that has QR codes for formula, formula guidance, beer labeling guidance. The alcohol industry would be able to do the same if it is so necessary to list ingredients, calories, serving size, alc. content etc. Changing the labels is an unnecessary expense and a regulation that is not needed for this industry.

Consumers will have what they will have and this is an added burden that needs to not be sought after. Consumers are very proactive in looking on websites for information especially if there is a QR code that is available for scanning on the bottles thereby giving all the information needed at their fingertips.

In fact I just came across a TTB Beer Resources guide that has QR codes for formula, formula guidance, beer labeling guidance. The alcohol industry would be able to do the same if it is so necessary to list ingredients, calories, serving size, alc. content etc.

Changing the labels is an unnecessary expense and a regulation that is not needed for this industry.

comment_text: I am in complete agreement with this proposed rule. It is only fair that alcoholic beverages like every other beverage and food item on the market contain per-serving information about calories, nutrients, and, when necessary, alcohol content. The reasons why I believe this proposed rule should go into effect are the number of calories consumed from alcoholic beverages, the amount of obesity tied to alcoholic consumption, and the benefit of knowing what is in the product you are drinking. Firstly, this proposed rule is beneficial because of the number of calories consumed from alcoholic beverages. Alcoholic beverages like everything else we consume contain calories and if too many calories are consumed every day it can lead to weight gain, which we already have too much of in this country as a whole. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention "on a given day, consumers of alcoholic beverages obtain approximately 16% of their total caloric intake from alcoholic beverages" (Nielsen et al, 2012). Assuming the consumers follow the recommendation of 2,000 calories a day that would equal 320 calories from alcoholic beverages every day. Without the proper labeling, consumers cannot know exactly how many calories they are consuming, making it extremely difficult to follow the recommended daily caloric intake if they are trying to follow it. Secondly, this proposed rule should go into effect because the United States is known to be an obese country with around 40% of adults being obese (Emmerich et al, 2024), as well as some research showing increases in obesity and heavy alcohol consumption in adults in the United States. Between 2017-2020 the combination of heavy alcohol consumption and obesity was 3.1% of adults in the United States which is up from 1.8% in 1999-2000, and it has increased 72% over time (Raza et al, 2023). That shows that not only is obesity and heavy alcohol consumption linked, but it is also on the rise. It very well could be on the rise because of the lack of consistent labeling on alcoholic beverages that do not always include the caloric value which can lead to an overconsumption of calories which in turn can cause obesity. Finally, this proposed rule should go into effect because of the benefit of knowing what is in the product you are consuming. When there is no consistent labeling among alcoholic beverages it can lead to confusion or if there is a lack of any labeling it can lead consumers to be uninformed about what they are consuming. A study of college students showed that 65% were unaware of the caloric content of the alcoholic beverages they consumed (Lloyd-Richardson et al, 2008). 65% of college students not knowing the caloric content of their alcoholic beverages is astronomically too high and this proposed rule could help lower that number by a large margin. Also, another study suggests that alcohol labeling can be effective in increasing consumers' knowledge and understanding of the health risks involved in drinking alcoholic beverages (Edmunds et al, 2023). Just knowing the risks will not stop people from consuming alcoholic beverages, but it will allow them to make informed decisions moving forward, which could allow consumers to live healthier lives. Being informed about what is consumed is extremely important and is already in place for every other consumable good so it only makes sense to hold alcoholic beverages to the same standards. In conclusion, the caloric content of alcoholic beverages, the amount of obesity tied to alcohol consumption, and the benefit of increased information on alcoholic beverages are all reasons why I believe this proposed rule should become regulation under the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau. References: Edmunds, C. E. R., Gold, N., Burton, R., Smolar, M., Walmsley, M., Henn, C., Egan, M., Tran, A., Harper, H., Dale, M. K., Brown, H., Londakova, K., Sheron, N., & Greaves, F. (2023). The effectiveness of alcohol label information for increasing knowledge and awareness: a rapid evidence review. BMC public health.2023 Emmerich SD, Fryar CD, Stierman B, Ogden CL. Obesity and severe obesity prevalence in adults: United States, August 2021–August 2023. NCHS Data Brief, no 508. Hyattsville, MD: National Center for Health Statistics. 2024. Lloyd-Richardson, E. E., Lucero, M. L., Dibello, J. R., Jacobson, A. E., & Wing, R. R. (2008). The relationship between alcohol use, eating habits and weight change in college freshmen. Eating behaviors. 2008 Nielsen SJ, Kit BK, Fakhouri T, Ogden CL. Calories consumed from alcoholic beverages by U.S. adults, 2007–2010. NCHS data brief, no 110. Hyattsville, MD: National Center for Health Statistics. 2012 Raza, S. A., Sokale, I. O., & Thrift, A. P. Burden of high-risk phenotype of heavy alcohol consumption among obese U.S. population: Results from National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey, 1999–2020. The Lancet Regional Health - Americas, 23. 2023

document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
SUNY Delhi's American Government Class (10AM) supports adding this label to alcoholic beverages for many reasons:

1. This gives the consumer more information on the amount of calories and to allow them to make better health decisions.
2. This encourages businesses to spotlight healthier beverages.
3. We currently do this for food, soft drinks and other beverages.
4. A list of ingredients including total number of sugar and other aspects we currently see on a nutritional label.
5. We want to have clear understanding of the nutrition issues.
6. A guide on weight to intoxication.
We feel that this would be benefical to the American people.

comment_text: TTB's proposal for the panel to include calorie, carbohydrate, protein and fat content will be helpful to consumers when making choices at the point of purchase. Due to the current lack of labeling, many consumers are not aware of how many calories alcohol alone contributes to the diet, let alone finished alcohol beverages that may contain lots of added sugars, or ones that are cream based and also contribute some fat and protein. That said, having "Serving Facts" as the title of the panel would be more encompassing than the proposed "Alcohol Facts", since it will display information other than just the alcohol content. and it will display information based on the finished beverage, not just the alcohol component of the beverage. I do not believe the title "Alcohol Facts" would make it easier for consumers to distinguish alcohol beverages from other food items, nor should it be relied upon to do so. The principal display panel of the package should make it clear that the product is an alcohol containing product, as some consumers may not even view the nutrient content panel at the point of purchase. Regarding similarity to the FDA Nutrition Facts Label, the proposed nutrient content labeling should mimic two key elements: 1) highlighting of the calorie value and 2) display of percent daily values. On the 2016 FDA Nutrition Facts Label, calorie content is the largest and most prominent piece of information. When purchasing an alcohol beverage, this is the key piece of information a consumer needs when it comes to making a conscious dietary decision. Percent daily values are also very important to help consumers make conscious dietary decisions, as many do not have the background knowledge to how many grams of carbohydrates, for example, from a beverage would be considered high or low without having a percent daily value to provide a frame of reference. Without that, consumers will not know what to do with the information presented in the panel and will eventually ignore it. Unlike the FDA Nutrition Facts Label, alcohol beverages should not include micronutrient data. Inclusion of this information could lead consumers to believe that the alcohol beverage is a positive contribution to their diet and/or assume it imparts health-related benefits. This could lead to an increase in alcohol consumption.

I do not believe the title “Alcohol Facts” would make it easier for consumers to distinguish alcohol beverages from other food items, nor should it be relied upon to do so. Regarding similarity to the FDA Nutrition Facts Label, the proposed nutrient content labeling should mimic two key elements: 1) highlighting of the calorie value and 2) display of percent daily values. On the 2016 FDA Nutrition Facts Label, calorie content is the largest and most prominent piece of information. When purchasing an alcohol beverage, this is the key piece of information a consumer needs when it comes to making a conscious dietary decision. Inclusion of this information could lead consumers to believe that the alcohol beverage is a positive contribution to their diet and/or assume it imparts health-related benefits. comment_text: As a small business just starting out in the grape and wine industry, this requirement puts yet another legal requirement on an already burdensome industry. Such a legal requirement would impose new costs (e.g., cost of laboratory assays to determine caloric content) and increase exposure to liability (e.g., fines or frivolous lawsuits related to the content of the labeling). The legal industry looks for opportunities to make millions by creating action lawsuits bringing incredible revenues into their business without regard to the impact on small and struggling businesses; just one lawsuit alleging that a wine label declared that there is 0.11 mL of ethanol per serving when outside testing measured 0.10 mL of ethanol per serving, which caused millions of dollars of theoretical damage to the purchasers of that wine, would put a business like mine into bankruptcy. What exactly is this proposed regulation seeking to solve? This is a 'solution in search of a problem', and is a threat to business, jobs, and tax revenue. If this administration is indeed concerned with "common sense" and the reduction of silly regulatory burdens, then this is exactly the type of silliness that should be eliminated. By the way, if the proponents/supporters of this regulation are convinced that this regulation is essential for consumer health, then logic dictates that cigarette containers will need to publish the exact amount of nicotine per cigarette.

comment_text: Alcohol being labeled adequately with nutritional facts is deeply important to the consumer's rights. People deserve to know what they are putting in their bodies. Information such as calories, Carbohydrates, and fats should be on any beverage label. Alcohol is a substance that is psychoactive and can impact health if used incorrectly; therefore, labeling alcoholic beverages is the ethical thing to do. Having a standardized labeling requirement would be helpful for the average consumer. Doing so also helps promote informed choices and places an emphasis on better public health standards.
