comment_text: Alcohol content has always been a requirement for wine labels, but adding nutrition facts to an age old beverage is out right ridiculous. No one who drinks wine, or wine adjacent products, cares about the facts except for how strong the beverage is (ABV), and how good or bad the flavor is. The labeling would be a nightmare, and needing to submit a new label with any changes or updates to the "facts" would be extremely cost prohibitive. No batch is ever identical even if the beverage in question is made the same way, with the same fruits or grains, with the same yeasts, year in and year out. They're all different. They're always different. Not to mention with the smaller businesses, having to get these tests are not in their budget, even if its expected in the range of 200-500 per sample, but if they have multiple flavors, or blends, or even lines of products, it's going to add up. There's no way to enforce it, either. Like most table wine labels, or wines that are made the same way, or blended the same every year, the fluctuation in product never has the same nutritional profile. And if there's a deviation in the product verses what is listed on the label, becomes a logistical nightmare. The sugars might change, even if its by grams. Or the ABV might be a percent higher or lower than what's listed. Which then makes the labeling false, and opens up an entire can of worms that could lead to false advertising or misleading labeling claims, which in turn would spell the end of some of the smaller or starting up businesses.

No one who drinks wine, or wine adjacent products, cares about the facts except for how strong the beverage is (ABV), and how good or bad the flavor is. The labeling would be a nightmare, and needing to submit a new label with any changes or updates to the "facts" would be extremely cost prohibitive. No batch is ever identical even if the beverage in question is made the same way, with the same fruits or grains, with the same yeasts, year in and year out. They're all different. They're always different. Not to mention with the smaller businesses, having to get these tests are not in their budget, even if its expected in the range of 200-500 per sample, but if they have multiple flavors, or blends, or even lines of products, it's going to add up. There's no way to enforce it, either. Like most table wine labels, or wines that are made the same way, or blended the same every year, the fluctuation in product never has the same nutritional profile. And if there's a deviation in the product verses what is listed on the label, becomes a logistical nightmare. The sugars might change, even if its by grams. Or the ABV might be a percent higher or lower than what's listed. Which then makes the labeling false, and opens up an entire can of worms that could lead to false advertising or misleading labeling claims, which in turn would spell the end of some of the smaller or starting up businesses.

comment_text: De Maison Selections Inc. is a small business with 20 employees that imports fine wine, cider, and spirits from small, family-run wineries in France and Spain. We are commenting on the questions the TTB posed in the proposed rulemaking notice. Although there has been little to no demand for nutritional information from our distributors and consumers, we understand the motivations behind the Alcohol Facts statement outlined in the proposed rulemaking. Complying with the proposed regulation would require us to incur upfront costs in terms of time and money; however, we appreciate the TTB's flexibility regarding nutrition labeling, COLA approval, thresholds, and nutrition testing. While we value the TTB's allowance for the alcohol facts label to be displayed linearly, utilizing a QR code would enable us to update information and align with EU labeling protocols. We are thankful for the TTB's implementation of a five-year period, which will save time and money in the long run. Despite the potential cost savings, the new labeling requirement would impose a minimum expense of $818,260 on our company. Thus, this proposed regulation would still present challenges for small importers and producers. Many small foreign producers struggle to comprehend US regulations and requirements, making it difficult to communicate them accurately and precisely to their production partners. This could lead to numerous errors in attempts at compliance, resulting in lost time and resources. We estimate that fulfilling the proposed regulations will increase production and transit times, as producers must invest time and resources to meet these new requirements. We have attached a more detailed comment document.

De Maison Selections Inc. is a small business with 20 employees that imports fine wine, cider, and spirits from small, family-run wineries in France and Spain. We are commenting on the questions the TTB posed in the proposed rulemaking notice.

Although there has been little to no demand for nutritional information from our distributors and consumers, we understand the motivations behind the Alcohol Facts statement outlined in the proposed rulemaking. Complying with the proposed regulation would require us to incur upfront costs in terms of time and money; however, we appreciate the TTB’s flexibility regarding nutrition labeling, COLA approval, thresholds, and nutrition testing. While we value the TTB's allowance for the alcohol facts label to be displayed linearly, utilizing a QR code would enable us to update information and align with EU labeling protocols. We are thankful for the TTB’s implementation of a five-year period, which will save time and money in the long run. Despite the potential cost savings, the new labeling requirement would impose a minimum expense of $818,260 on our company. Thus, this proposed regulation would still present challenges for small importers and producers. Many small foreign producers struggle to comprehend US regulations and requirements, making it difficult to communicate them accurately and precisely to their production partners. This could lead to numerous errors in attempts at compliance, resulting in lost time and resources. We estimate that fulfilling the proposed regulations will increase production and transit times, as producers must invest time and resources to meet these new requirements.

We have attached a more detailed comment document.

in
 
attempts
 
at
 
compliance,
 
resulting
 
in
 
lost
 
time
 
and
 
resources.
 
We
 
estimate
 
that
 
fulfilling
 
the
 
proposed
 
regulations
 
will
 
increase
 
production
 
and
 
transit
 
times,
 
as
 
producers
 
must
 
invest
 
time
 
and
 
resources
 
to
 
meet
 
these
 
new
 
requirements.
  Serving  Facts  vs  Alcohol  Facts   Labeling  alcoholic  products  with  “Alcohol  Facts”  will  help  consumers  differentiate  between  
alcoholic
 
items
 
and
 
other
 
food
 
products.
 
"Alcohol
 
Facts"
 
is
 
also
 
a
 
more
 
accurate
 
descriptor
 
of
 
the
 
information
 
included
 
in
 
the
 
proposed
 
statement.
 
However,
 
voluntarily
 
labeled
 
products
 
will
 
incur
 
costs
 
to
 
transition
 
from
 
"Serving
 
Facts"
 
to
 
"Alcohol
 
Facts."
  Alcohol  Facts  Labeling   The  back  label  of  a  wine  or  spirit  is  valuable  real  estate  that  includes  what  consumers  desire,  such  as  the  terroir,  grape  varieties,  and  the  technical  skills  of  the  winemaker  (Bettaglene,  2014).  Including  alcohol  facts  on  the  back  label  reduces  space  for  these  attributes  and  may  hinder  
small
 
wine
 
producers'
 
ability
 
to
 
connect
 
with
 
consumers.
 
We
 
recognize
 
that
 
not
 
all
 
consumers
 
are
 
wine
 
connoisseurs;
 
however,
 
consumers
 
may
 
be
 
inclined
 
to
 
purchase
 
a
 
product
 
if
 
the
 producer  shares  an  authentic  story,  fostering  trust  with  specific  regions  and  producers  (Tortolero  Cervantes,  2023).  With  the  increasing  requirement  for  warning  statements  and  sulfite  content,  a  QR  code  or  linear  Alcohol  Facts  label  would  allow  producers  to  showcase  important  attributes  
consumers
 
want
 
while
 
providing
 
alcohol
 
facts
 
and
 
allergens.
 
  Linear  Alcohol  Facts  Statement:    We  oppose  the  back  label’s  nutrient  statement  aligning  with  the  nutrition  facts  label  found  on  
foods
 
under
 
the
 
FDA’s
 
labeling
 
jurisdiction.
 
Eighteen
 
percent
 
of
 
individuals
 
in
 
the
 
US
 
read
 
wine
 
labels;
 
among
 
those
 
who
 
do,
 
shorter
 
ingredient
 
lists
 
or
 
clean-labeled
 
wines
 
without
 
listed
 ingredients  are  preferred  (Pabst  et  al.,  2021).  Therefore,  we  endorse  the  linear  label,  which  contains  all  the  information  required  by  the  TTB  while  also  allowing  for  listing  wine  attributes.   QR  Codes:    We  advocate  using  QR  codes  on  labels,  enabling  consumers  to  access  mandatory  Alcohol  
Facts
 
statements
 
and
 
allergen
 
information
 
on
 
their
 
mobile
 
devices.
 
QR
 
codes
 
are
 
also
 
required
 
in
 
the
 
EU,
 
and
 
producers
 
can
 
include
 
the
 
US
 
alcohol
 
facts
 
regulations
 
on
 
the
 
same
 
webpage,
 
thereby
 
reducing
 
the
 
regulatory
 
burden
 
on
 
these
 
small
 
businesses.
 
  Commenters  noted  that  not  everyone  has  a  cell  phone,  particularly  those  over  65,  and  that  tribal  
lands
 
and
 
rural
 
areas
 
often
 
lack
 
sufficient
 
4G
 
LTE
 
coverage.
 
According
 
to

The  STARLINK  availability  map  reveals  that  most  of  the  US  (>=99%),  even  in  rural  areas,  has  access  to  high-speed  internet  ( Starlink ,  2025).  Therefore,  consumers  will  likely  access  QR  codes  on  their  mobile  devices  within  five  years.  In  
2023,

Although

this
 
trend
 
has

Across  all  age  groups,  smartphone  ownership  is  on  the  rise,  and  this  is  expected  to  continue  in  the  coming  years.  Thus,  the  commenters'  concerns  about  the  lack  of  smartphone

comment_text: opposes the proposed Alcohol Facts labelling rule because it is misaligned with historical labelling and consumer trends, imposes substantial economic burdens on producers, and is an impractical use of limited label space. RATIONALE IN SUPPORT OF REJECTING THE RULE: 1. Consumer confusion has been identified in prior rulemaking and, notably, in this scenario, dietary disclosure lacks demonstrable necessity. People do not consume alcohol for nutritional content, and to suggest otherwise may be at cross purposes to regulations that support responsible alcohol consumption. Proscriptions can avoid market deceptions. Absent a documented market failure, dietary labeling mandates violate rules of necessity (APA §706(2)(A). 2. The economic burden of dietary testing and compliance, particularly considering limited editions, seasonal variations, and batch variations, would be disproportionately borne by small businesses in an industry of aggressive consolidative pressures and marketing obstacles. Small businesses cannot offset recurrent costs through economies of scale. Further, this cost overrun undermines the public benefit, such as through less consumer choice and signal noise. The proposal has not considered less burdensome alternatives such as voluntary and QR disclosures. 3. The proposed rule disrupts established conventions to use limited label space, responsible free speech, and aesthetics. Signals must relate to qualifiers that aid consumers in making informed choices about product differentiation. Consumers may not object to the abstract idea of dietary information on a label; however, they look to qualifiers such as region, source ingredients, production methods, and sustainability. The proposed rule would, therefore, conflict with the comprehensive labeling framework (27 CFR 4.32—4.'). Additional label information would unintentionally increase container sizes. 4. Alcohol consumption is declining significantly among Gen Z. Regulatory cues that accentuate limited dietary benefits would reinforce avoidance behaviors, shift comparison to dietary content of non-alcoholic alternatives, diminish the stated benefits of the regulation, and may represent regulatory overreach. Further, the NIH knows that similar regulations have disparate impacts on socioeconomic groups, including gender, race, and ethnicity. Babor, T. et al. (2010). SBA Office of Advocacy Report. https://www.govinfo.gov/content/pkg/GOVPUB-SBA-PURL-LPS95767/pdf/GOVPUB-SBA-PURL-LPS95767.pdf Motor Vehicle Mfrs. Ass'n v. State Farm, 463 U.S. 29 (1983); Michigan v. EPA, 576 U.S. 743, 752–53 (2015) https://www.researchgate.net/publication/225709127_What_you_see_may_not_be_what_you_get_Asking_consumers_what_matters_may_not_reflect_what_they_choose Sunstein, Cass R. "The limits of quantification." Calif. L. Rev. 102 (2014): 1369.(The marginal utility of disclosure declines when consumer trends are toward cautious, risk-averse behavior) Kilian, Carolin et al. document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
opposes the proposed Alcohol Facts labelling rule because it is misaligned with historical labelling and consumer trends, imposes substantial economic burdens on producers, and is an impractical use of limited label space.

RATIONALE IN SUPPORT OF REJECTING THE RULE:

1. Consumer confusion has been identified in prior rulemaking and, notably, in this scenario, dietary disclosure lacks demonstrable necessity. People do not consume alcohol for nutritional content, and to suggest otherwise may be at cross purposes to regulations that support responsible alcohol consumption. Proscriptions can avoid market deceptions. Absent a documented market failure, dietary labeling mandates violate rules of necessity (APA §706(2)(A).

2. The economic burden of dietary testing and compliance, particularly considering limited editions, seasonal variations, and batch variations, would be disproportionately borne by small businesses in an industry of aggressive consolidative pressures and marketing obstacles. Small businesses cannot offset recurrent costs through economies of scale. Further, this cost overrun undermines the public benefit, such as through less consumer choice and signal noise. The proposal has not considered less burdensome alternatives such as voluntary and QR disclosures.

3. The proposed rule disrupts established conventions to use limited label space, responsible free speech, and aesthetics. Signals must relate to qualifiers that aid consumers in making informed choices about product differentiation. Consumers may not object to the abstract idea of dietary information on a label; however, they look to qualifiers such as region, source ingredients, production methods, and sustainability. The proposed rule would, therefore, conflict with the comprehensive labeling framework (27 CFR 4.32—4.39). Additional label information would unintentionally increase container sizes.

4. Alcohol consumption is declining significantly among Gen Z. Regulatory cues that accentuate limited dietary benefits would reinforce avoidance behaviors, shift comparison to dietary content of non-alcoholic alternatives, diminish the stated benefits of the regulation, and may represent regulatory overreach. Further, the NIH knows that similar regulations have disparate impacts on socioeconomic groups, including gender, race, and ethnicity.

Babor, T. et al. (2010). Alcohol: No Ordinary Commodity (2nd ed.), Oxford University Press, Ch. 11 [equating alcohol to food may send conflicting messages about healthful diet]
American Radio Relay League, Inc. v. FCC, 524 F.3d 227, 247 (D.C. Cir. 2008)
State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Co. v. DOT, 463 U.S. 29, 43 (1983)

M., & Crain, N. V. (2010). The Impact of Regulatory Costs on Small Firms. SBA Office of Advocacy Report.
https://www.govinfo.gov/content/pkg/GOVPUB-SBA-PURL-LPS95767/pdf/GOVPUB-SBA-PURL-LPS95767.pdf
Motor Vehicle Mfrs. Ass’n v. State Farm, 463 U.S. 29 (1983); Michigan v. EPA, 576 U.S. 743, 752–53 (2015)
https://www.researchgate.net/publication/225709127_What_you_see_may_not_be_what_you_get_Asking_consumers_what_matters_may_not_reflect_what_they_choose

Subject:
Comments from P. R. China on United States Notification G/TBT/N/USA/2182
Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
1 of 4Comments from P. R. China on United States Notification
G/TBT/N/USA/2182
Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
Dear Sir or Madam,
We appreciate the opportunity to submit comments on the notified draft proposed by
United States of America.
Enclosed please find comments in English and Chinese.
Please acknowledge receipt of the comments by e-mail to tbt@customs.gov.cn and
pengdy_tbt@163.com.
Thank you very much in advance for United States of America taking into account
comments from P.R. China. Your formal reply will be appreciated.
Best regards,
Jiao Yang
Deputy Director General
China WTO/TBT National Notification & Enquiry Center
No.20，Hepingli East Street, Dongcheng District, Beijing
Post Code: 100013
Tel: 86-10-57954638
Fax: 86-10-57954689
E-mail: tbt@customs.gov.cn pengdy_tbt@163.com
2 of 4Comments from P. R. China on United States Notification
G/TBT/N/USA/2182
1. The draft regulation required all alcohol beverage labels regulated by TTB to
disclose the alcohol content, calories, and nutritional information of each beverage in
the "alcohol content" statement. Due to the fact that alcoholic beverages are mainly
composed of ethanol and water, and do not contain conventional nutrients such as
protein, fat, carbohydrates, etc., for example, distilled spirits almost do not contain
these components. If the product does not add nutritional fortifiers or make nutritional
claims, labeling the nutritional content table is meaningless; Fermented alcoholic
beverages (such as beer and fruit wine) may contain small amounts of carbohydrates,
and it may consider adding only labeled carbohydrates as appropriate. However, beer
labels also require labeling malt content, therefore, labeling carbohydrates is not very
meaningful for consumers. For ordinary consumers, the nutritional value of alcoholic
beverages is limited, and labeling indicators such as carbohydrates may be misleading
(such as implying that they have nutritional supplementation functions). The
additional and unnecessary laboratory analysis costs incurred are also a heavy burden
for producers or traders.
According to the relevant standards of the CAC (Codex Alimentarius Commission),
most countries do not require the labeling of conventional nutrients such as protein,
fat, carbohydrates, etc. for alcoholic beverages. The provision of Regulation (EU) No
1169/2011 of the European Parliament and of the Council on the Provision of Food
Information to Consumers concerning the ingredient list and nutrition declaration for
alcoholic beverages with an alcohol content exceeding 1.2% is non-mandatory. When
the nutrition statement for alcoholic beverages is voluntarily provided, it is limited to
energy values only.
Based on the principle of scientific evidence and necessity, it is recommended that the
United States should coordinate its requirements for alcoholic beverage labeling with
international standards, or differentiated the requirements according to the different
product forms of alcoholic beverages: consider not mandating the labeling of
conventional nutrients such as protein, fat, carbohydrates, etc. on ordinary alcoholic
beverage labels as appropriate; If additional ingredients such as sugar, juice, or other
nutritional enhancers are added to alcoholic beverages, the carbohydrate content or
other nutrient content may be indicated according to the actual situation. To avoid
excessive regulation, reduce compliance costs for businesses, and alleviate the burden
on small and medium-sized enterprises.
2. The draft regulation required the addition of new subpart L - alcohol factual
statements in Parts 4, 5, and 7 of Title 27 of the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR).
The current regulations require the display of information such as alcohol content,
carmine, sulfite, etc. The proposed rule required an addition of alcohol factual
statements such as single portion size, number of portions per container, and liquid
ounces per unit of pure ethanol, and the liquid ounce information per unit of pure
ethanol should be accurate to one tenth of the liquid ounce. The provision differs from
international standards and may impose additional costs and burdens on alcoholic
beverage manufacturers and importers, especially small businesses. It is
recommended that the United States should maintain the current regulations without
3 of 4adding the provision and not mandating the labeling of information such as "single
portion size, number of portions per container, and number of ounces of pure ethanol
per serving" to avoid unnecessary barriers to trade.
Comments in Chinese are as below:
1、 规章修订提案中要求所有受TTB 监管的酒精饮料标签“酒精含量”声明
中必须披露每份饮料的酒精含量、 卡路里及营养成分信息。 由于酒精饮料的主要
成分为乙醇和水， 基本不含蛋白质、 脂肪、 碳水化合物等常规营养素，比如蒸馏
酒几乎不含这些成分， 若产品未添加营养强化剂或未进行营养声称， 则标示营养
成分表毫无意义；发酵酒（如啤酒、果酒）可能含有少量碳水化合物，可以酌情
考虑仅添加标示碳水化合物， 但啤酒标签也已要求标注麦芽度， 因此标示碳水化
合物对于消费者也无太大意义。对普通消费者而言，酒精饮料的营养价值有限，
标注碳水化合物等指标可能产生误导（如暗示其具有营养补充功能） 。其产生额
外的、不必要的实验室分析费用对生产商或贸易商来说也是繁重的负担。
根据食品法典委员会的相关标准， 国际上绝大多数国家对酒精饮料不强制要
求标注蛋白质、脂肪、碳水化合物等常规营养素。欧盟（EU）第 1169/2011 号条
例《关于向消费者提供食品信息》涉及酒精含量超过 1.2%的酒精饮料提供成分
清单、营养声明的规定属于非强制性条款，当酒精饮料营养声明是自愿提供时，
营养声明仅限于能量值。
本着科学性与必要性， 建议美方对酒精饮料标签的要求与国际标准协调一致，
也可根据酒精饮料的不同产品形式区分要求： 酌情考虑不强制普通酒精饮料标签
标注蛋白质、 脂肪、 碳水化合物等常规营养素； 若酒精饮料中额外添加了糖、果
汁等配料， 或使用其他营养强化剂的， 可根据实际情况要求标示碳水化合物含量
或其他营养素含量。以避免过度监管，降低企业合规成本与中小企业的负担。
2、规章修订提案中要求在《美国联邦法规》第27 篇第 4、5、7 部分中分别
增加新的子部分 L——酒精事实陈述条款。 现行法规已要求显示酒精含量、 胭脂
红、 亚硫酸盐等信息， 该拟议规则要求增加单份份量、 每个容器的份数和每份纯
乙醇的液体盎司数等酒精事实声明， 且每份纯乙醇的液体盎司信息需精确到液体
盎司的十分之一。 该条款与国际通行标准存在差异， 会给酒精饮料制造商和进口
商， 特别是小企业带来额外的成本和负担。 建议美方维持现行法规， 不增加该条
款， 不强制要求标示 “单份份量、 每个容器的份数和每份纯乙醇的液盎司数”等
信息，以避免对贸易造成不必要的障碍。
4 of 4

comment_text: Dear Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau, As a U.S. consumer, I do not believe current alcohol labels provide adequate information on alcohol content and nutrition. Summary of the Regulation This proposed TTB rule revises labeling, registration, and enforcement criteria for alcohol products to promote transparency on ingredients, health warnings, and environmental impact. By focusing on clear disclosures, it aims to advance consumer protection, facilitate equitable market access for small producers, and encourage more sustainable production practices. 2. Related Case Studies and Examples Scottish Alcohol Labeling Initiative (Scotland) - Scenario: Public Health Scotland found that clearer alcohol labeling helped reduce alcohol-related hospital admissions by 4% (source: Public Health Scotland, 2022, https://publichealthscotland.scot). - Proposal: Adopt similarly prominent health disclaimers in the U.S. context, aligning with TTB's efforts to include expanded warning text in labeling requirements. California Sustainable Winegrowing Program (California) - Scenario: This program's rigorous environmental standards lowered water usage by 15% in participating vineyards (source: California Sustainable Winegrowing Alliance, 2021, https://www.sustainablewinegrowing.org). - Proposal: Incorporate verifiable sustainability metrics in TTB labeling rules, giving producers the option to display recognized eco-certifications. Alcohol Tax Reform (Iceland) - Scenario: Iceland's progressive tax structure, which adjusts levies based on alcohol content, helped reduce overall consumption (source: European Journal of Public Health, 2020, DOI:10.1093/eurpub/ckz185). - Proposal: Explore targeted taxation strategies under TTB oversight that incentivize lower-alcohol or responsibly produced beverages. Cooperative Brewing Ventures (Various U.S. States) - Scenario: Worker-owned breweries in Oregon and Colorado reported increased employee retention and community engagement (source: Democracy at Work Institute, 2020, https://institute.coop). - Proposal: Facilitate accessible TTB licensing pathways for cooperative models to expand equitable ownership in alcohol production. 3. Comments and Questions On Proposed Section 4.2: - Comment: "Requiring allergen disclosures is critical for public health. The rule should include clear thresholds for potential cross-contamination." - Supporting Evidence: CDC, 2022, allergic reaction data, https://www.cdc.gov On Proposed Section 5.1: - Comment: "Consider integrating standardized carbon footprint labeling to encourage sustainable practices, especially among craft producers." - Supporting Evidence: EPA, 2021, emissions reduction guidance, https://www.epa.gov On Proposed Section 7.3: - Question: "Does TTB plan to offer fee waivers or tiered fee structures to smaller, minority-owned distilleries that adopt these new labeling requirements?" - Supporting Evidence: Small Business Administration, 2022, minority business development report, https://www.sba.gov On Proposed Section 8.5: - Comment: "Public health data indicate that stronger health warnings reduce alcohol misuse. Including new language reflecting current CDC findings could improve consumer awareness." - Supporting Evidence: CDC, 2023, alcohol-related harm statistics, https://www.cdc.gov On Data Collection and Oversight: - Question: "How will TTB verify labeling accuracy and ensure compliance without overburdening small producers?" - Supporting Evidence: GAO, 2021, regulatory compliance best practices, https://www.gao.gov 4. References and Citations - Public Health Scotland, 2022, "Alcohol Statistics and Trends," https://publichealthscotland.scot - California Sustainable Winegrowing Alliance, 2021, "Annual Sustainability Report," https://www.sustainablewinegrowing.org - European Journal of Public Health, 2020, "Alcohol Tax Policy in Iceland," DOI:10.1093/eurpub/ckz185 - Democracy at Work Institute, 2020, "Worker-Owned Business Data," https://institute.coop - CDC, 2022, "Food Allergies and Reactions," https://www.cdc.gov - EPA, 2021, "Greenhouse Gas Reduction Guidelines," https://www.epa.gov - Small Business Administration, 2022, "Minority Business Ownership," https://www.sba.gov - CDC, 2023, "Alcohol and Public Health," https://www.cdc.gov - GAO, 2021, "Federal Regulatory Compliance," https://www.gao.gov
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
1. Summary of the Regulation
This proposed TTB rule revises labeling, registration, and enforcement criteria for alcohol products to promote transparency on ingredients, health warnings, and environmental impact. By focusing on clear disclosures, it aims to advance consumer protection, facilitate equitable market access for small producers, and encourage more sustainable production practices.

2. Related Case Studies and Examples

Scottish Alcohol Labeling Initiative (Scotland)
- Scenario: Public Health Scotland found that clearer alcohol labeling helped reduce alcohol-related hospital admissions by 4% (source: Public Health Scotland, 2022, https://publichealthscotland.scot).
- Proposal: Adopt similarly prominent health disclaimers in the U.S. context, aligning with TTB’s efforts to include expanded warning text in labeling requirements.

California Sustainable Winegrowing Program (California)
- Scenario: This program’s rigorous environmental standards lowered water usage by 15% in participating vineyards (source: California Sustainable Winegrowing Alliance, 2021, https://www.sustainablewinegrowing.org).
- Proposal: Incorporate verifiable sustainability metrics in TTB labeling rules, giving producers the option to display recognized eco-certifications.

Alcohol Tax Reform (Iceland)
- Scenario: Iceland’s progressive tax structure, which adjusts levies based on alcohol content, helped reduce overall consumption (source: European Journal of Public Health, 2020, DOI:10.1093/eurpub/ckz185).
- Proposal: Explore targeted taxation strategies under TTB oversight that incentivize lower-alcohol or responsibly produced beverages.

Cooperative Brewing Ventures (Various U.S. States)
- Scenario: Worker-owned breweries in Oregon and Colorado reported increased employee retention and community engagement (source: Democracy at Work Institute, 2020, https://institute.coop).
- Proposal: Facilitate accessible TTB licensing pathways for cooperative models to expand equitable ownership in alcohol production.

3. Comments and Questions

On Proposed Section 4.2:
- Comment: “Requiring allergen disclosures is critical for public health. The rule should include clear thresholds for potential cross-contamination.”
- Supporting Evidence: CDC, 2022, allergic reaction data, https://www.cdc.gov

On Proposed Section 5.1:
- Comment: “Consider integrating standardized carbon footprint labeling to encourage sustainable practices, especially among craft producers.”
- Supporting Evidence: EPA, 2021, emissions reduction guidance, https://www.epa.gov

On Proposed Section 7.3:
- Question: “Does TTB plan to offer fee waivers or tiered fee structures to smaller, minority-owned distilleries that adopt these new labeling requirements?”
- Supporting Evidence: Small Business Administration, 2022, minority business development report, https://www.sba.gov

On Proposed Section 8.5:
- Comment: “Public health data indicate that stronger health warnings reduce alcohol misuse. Including new language reflecting current CDC findings could improve consumer awareness.”
- Supporting Evidence: CDC, 2023, alcohol-related harm statistics, https://www.cdc.gov

On Data Collection and Oversight:
- Question: “How will TTB verify labeling accuracy and ensure compliance without overburdening small producers?”
- Supporting Evidence: GAO, 2021, regulatory compliance best practices, https://www.gao.gov

4. References and Citations
- Public Health Scotland, 2022, “Alcohol Statistics and Trends,” https://publichealthscotland.scot
- California Sustainable Winegrowing Alliance, 2021, “Annual Sustainability Report,” https://www.sustainablewinegrowing.org
- European Journal of Public Health, 2020, “Alcohol Tax Policy in Iceland,” DOI:10.1093/eurpub/ckz185
- Democracy at Work Institute, 2020, “Worker-Owned Business Data,” https://institute.coop
- CDC, 2022, “Food Allergies and Reactions,” https://www.cdc.gov
- EPA, 2021, “Greenhouse Gas Reduction Guidelines,” https://www.epa.gov
- Small Business Administration, 2022, “Minority Business Ownership,” https://www.sba.gov
- CDC, 2023, “Alcohol and Public Health,” https://www.cdc.gov
- GAO, 2021, “Federal Regulatory Compliance,” https://www.gao.gov

comment_text: Dear TTB Administrator, I am writing to express my strong support for the proposed rules requiring standardized nutrition and ingredient labeling on alcoholic beverages (Docket Nos. TTB–2025–0002 and TTB–2025–0003). This issue is especially meaningful to me on a personal level. Over the past three years, I have undergone a major transformation in my health and lifestyle, losing over 100 pounds through deliberate choices and a commitment to understanding the nutritional content of what I consume. After years of struggling with my weight and related health issues, I've learned firsthand how crucial transparent labeling is in making informed, health-conscious decisions. Alcohol is often part of our culture, tied to celebrations and social occasions. I do not want to avoid these moments; I simply want to be able to make informed decisions when I participate in them. Unfortunately, unlike nearly every other consumable product, alcohol is not required to disclose basic information such as calories, ingredients, or allergens. This lack of transparency is unfair, outdated, and out of step with consumer expectations and health needs. I strongly urge the TTB to move forward with finalizing these proposals and to require full ingredient, nutrition, and allergen labeling on all alcoholic beverages for several key reasons: 1. Empowering Health-Conscious Consumers – People like me who are managing their health need accurate nutritional information to make intentional choices. This information is essential—not optional—for supporting long-term health. 2. Consumer Right to Know – It is only reasonable that consumers be given the same level of transparency for alcohol as is provided for food, soda, or even bottled water. We deserve to know what's in the products we consume. 3. Safety and Allergen Disclosure – Hidden ingredients and allergens can pose real dangers. Requiring full disclosure helps protect individuals with dietary restrictions, allergies, or intolerances. 4. Public Demand – The majority of Americans support this change. Transparency builds trust, supports public health, and aligns with the growing demand for cleaner, more informed choices. Consumers deserve clarity, safety, and the ability to make deliberate decisions about their health - especially in a product category as widely consumed as alcohol. Thank you for the opportunity to comment and for your work on this important initiative. Sincerely, Jessica Block Rosemount, MN jessicablock@comcast.net P.S. Please see attached for a copy of this comment in PDF form.
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
Dear TTB Administrator,

I am writing to express my strong support for the proposed rules requiring standardized nutrition and ingredient labeling on alcoholic beverages (Docket Nos. TTB–2025–0002 and TTB–2025–0003).

This issue is especially meaningful to me on a personal level. Over the past three years, I have undergone a major transformation in my health and lifestyle, losing over 100 pounds through deliberate choices and a commitment to understanding the nutritional content of what I consume. After years of struggling with my weight and related health issues, I’ve learned firsthand how crucial transparent labeling is in making informed, health-conscious decisions.

Alcohol is often part of our culture, tied to celebrations and social occasions. I do not want to avoid these moments; I simply want to be able to make informed decisions when I participate in them. Unfortunately, unlike nearly every other consumable product, alcohol is not required to disclose basic information such as calories, ingredients, or allergens. This lack of transparency is unfair, outdated, and out of step with consumer expectations and health needs.

I strongly urge the TTB to move forward with finalizing these proposals and to require full ingredient, nutrition, and allergen labeling on all alcoholic beverages for several key reasons:
1.Empowering Health-Conscious Consumers – People like me who are managing their health need accurate nutritional information to make intentional choices. This information is essential—not optional—for supporting long-term health.

2.Consumer Right to Know – It is only reasonable that consumers be given the same level of transparency for alcohol as is provided for food, soda, or even bottled water. We deserve to know what’s in the products we consume.

3.Safety and Allergen Disclosure – Hidden ingredients and allergens can pose real dangers. Requiring full disclosure helps protect individuals with dietary restrictions, allergies, or intolerances.

4.Public Demand – The majority of Americans support this change. Transparency builds trust, supports public health, and aligns with the growing demand for cleaner, more informed choices.

Consumers deserve clarity, safety, and the ability to make deliberate decisions about their health - especially in a product category as widely consumed as alcohol.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment and for your work on this important initiative.

Sincerely,
Jessica Block
Rosemount, MN
jessicablock@comcast.net

P.S. Please see attached for a copy of this comment in PDF form.

SUBJECT: Support for Mandatory Nutrition and Ingredient Labeling on Alcoholic Beverages  
Dear TTB Administrator, 
I am writing to express my strong support for the proposed rules requiring standardized nutrition 
and ingredient labeling on alcoholic beverages (Docket Nos. TTB–2025–0002 and TTB–2025–0003). 
This issue is especially meaningful to me on a personal level. Over the past three years, I have

transparent labeling is in making informed, health-conscious decisions.

these moments; I simply want to be able to make informed decisions when I participate in them. 
Unfortunately, unlike nearly every other consumable product, alcohol is not required to disclose 
basic information such as calories, ingredients, or allergens. This lack of transparency is unfair, 
outdated, and out of step with consumer expectations and health needs. 
I strongly urge the TTB to move forward with ﬁnalizing these proposals and to require full ingredient, 
nutrition, and allergen labeling on all alcoholic beverages for several key reasons: 
1. Empowering Health-Conscious Consumers – People like me who are managing their 
health need accurate nutritional information to make intentional choices. This information 
is essential—not optional—for supporting long-term health. 
2. Consumer Right to Know – It is only reasonable that consumers be given the same level of 
transparency for alcohol as is provided for food, soda, or even bottled water. We deserve to 
know what’s in the products we consume. 
3. Safety and Allergen Disclosure – Hidden ingredients and allergens can pose real dangers.

4. Public Demand – The majority of Americans support this change. Transparency builds

Consumers deserve clarity, safety, and the ability to make deliberate decisions about their health -

Jessica Block 
Rosemount, MN 
jessicablock@comcast.net

comment_text: In theory, the thought of regulating alcohol facts on Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt beverages seems like a good idea, but it comes with much more cost to the consumer than health benefits. Studies have shown that "big business" is the only beneficial party in this regulation because they can not only withstand the compliance cost, flexibility, staff/expertise, and turn the labeling into a marketing ploy. Regulations shouldn't be a strategic profitability strategy for big businesses but a form of accountability for their delivery of goods and services that is attainable for all without jeopardizing a favorable market. We as a country need to make sure that political and capitalistic motivations are not being pushed in the name of democracy, and broad laws giving agencies too much power.

comment_text: This is a non-issue pushed by nefarious actors who are actively pushing against the alcohol industry. This proposed rule would add increased cost to our labels, require the incurred cost of additional time to comply, and require us to change our labels at great cost to provide this information that NO consumers are asking for. People that consume alcohol are aware of the risks thanks to the existing government warning that is already mandatory. These are responsible adults who are consciously choosing to imbibe with all the existing information. Furthermore, these allergens do not survive the distillation process, and are therefore redundant and unnecessary. This is government overreach due to misplaced good intentions. This should not be instituted.

comment_text: There are several problems with this rule; 1. This rule targets wineries. Tea and coffee are similarly chemically complex to wine, yet have no such requirements. 2. So many factors affect affect the composition of a wine including timing of harvest, yeast selection, nutrient content of juice, fermentation temperature, just to name a few. Has a study even been conducted to see if there is a high degree of nutritional variability? 3. This would put a significant cost burden on small wineries who already operate on very small margins. It is infinitely more sensible to publish a reasonable range of nutritional info for red, white and desert wines and post the info at wine retailers and online market places.
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
There are several problems with this rule;
1. This rule targets wineries. Tea and coffee are similarly chemically complex to wine, yet have no such requirements.
2. So many factors affect affect the composition of a wine including timing of harvest, yeast selection, nutrient content of juice, fermentation temperature, just to name a few. Has a study even been conducted to see if there is a high degree of nutritional variability?
3. This would put a significant cost burden on small wineries who already operate on very small margins.
It is infinitely more sensible to publish a reasonable range of nutritional info for red, white and desert wines and post the info at wine retailers and online market places.

document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
April 17, 2025
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) 
TTB Regulations and Rulings Division 
1310 G Street NW, Box 12 
Washington, DC 20005 
From: Namita Kulkarni, Master of Public Health Candidate, Cornell University 
Re: Docket ID No. TTB-2025-0002, Proposed Rule – Alcohol Beverage Labeling Requirements 
(Alcohol Facts Statement)
Position and Background of the Regulation:
I am writing in strong support of the proposed regulation TTB-20205-0002 issued by the Alcohol 
and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau which mandated the inclusion of “Alcohol Facts” panel on 
labels of distilled spirits, wines and malt beverages across the United States.1 As a Master of 
Public Health student, I believe this regulation is a crucial step towards improving consumer’s 
health literacy about risks of excessive alcohol consumption, enables them to make informed 
health decisions, and reduce alcohol-related harm to health.1 This proposed regulation requires 
labels to include per-serving information such as alcohol content, calorie count, serving size and 
basic nutritional information.1 These changes are long overdue and reflect public health best 
practices. Importantly, this regulation is at the Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM) stage 
which invites public comments prior to finalization.1 As a student studying public health policy, I 
realize that this phase is a vital opportunity for stakeholders, public, researchers and 
professionals to shape regulations that directly impact the health and lives of people.1 Public 
commenting is not just a democratic mechanism but it is a critical tool that aligns regulatory 
actions with evidence and equity.
Health Risks of Alcohol Consumption:
Road traffic accidents are a pressing public health issue in the US with 32 people dying of 
automobile crashes each year involving alcohol impaired driving accounting for 1 death in every 
45 minutes.2 According to National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA), driving 
under influence deaths were highest among young individuals aged 21 to 24 yrs (29%) and 25-34 
yrs (28%).3 Excessive consumption of alcohol causes 178,000 deaths each year in the US, and 
leads to chronic heart and liver diseases, stroke, digestive issues, cancer and weakened immune 
system.4,5 It also has caused shorter life span leading individuals to die by an average of 24 
years.4 Effective regulations like TTB-2025-0002 can help reduce deaths by making people 
choose to limit their alcohol consumption.4 
Evidence-Based Impact of Labelling Alcoholic Beverages:
According to Vasiljevic, M. et al. (2018), a randomized controlled trial found that when 
alcoholic beverages are labeled with clear information about Alcohol by Volume (ABV), and 
amount of pure alcohol content per serving, individuals aged 18-40 years, social and non-
dependent drinkers are significantly less likely to select high strength drinks.6 These finds show 
that quantitative labels of alcoholic drinks reduces the appeal to strong alcoholic beverages 
especially among individuals with low literacy levels about the risks of alcohol consumption, and 
groups that are at an elevated risk of binge drinking and impaired driving.6 Another study done by Center of Science in the Public Interest (CSPI), conducted a national survey with an aim to 
receive consumer’s opinion about transparency in labeling alcoholic beverages with information 
such as calories, serving size, nutritional content, and alcohol content, that are a part of the 
regulation, TTB-2025-0002, along with other alcohol facts.7 The sample for the survey was 
nationally representative with US adults from all demographics.7 This study found that 63% to 
77% respondents supported policies that required the inclusion of nutrition and alcohol content 
information on the labels of alcoholic beverages, either somewhat or strongly.7 Whereas, 72% to 
90% respondents supported having more information on the labels as it would impact their 
choice to purchase alcohol.7 A systematic review done in the UK also shows moderate evidence 
of labeling calories and ABV on purchasing choices of consumers showing increased preference 
for alcoholic beverages with calorie count labels, and reduction in purchase of high calorie 
alcohol.8 While there is not much research done on evaluating the direct impact of labeling on 
“Driving While Intoxicated” (DWI) and alcohol related health issues among people in the US, 
the above evidence-based research shows the psychological impact of labelling on consumers 
purchasing and alcoholic beverage choices based on content, that in turn suggests an increase in 
consumer awareness about alcohol risks and a reduction in driving under influence and health 
issue prevalence due to alcohol consumption.6,7,8 While labeling alcoholic beverages alone 
cannot eliminate the issue of impaired driving, it can be a valuable evidence-informed strategy to 
complement other policy tools such as age limits, taxes and enforcement to help people make 
informed health choices.9
Addressing Health Equity:
Standardized “Alcohol Facts” panel on labels of alcoholic beverages would be an equitable and 
low cost strategy in bridging information gap.10 Rural and low-income communities often lack 
access to resources and education.11 Labeling helps people from all socioeconomic and 
educational backgrounds stay informed about alcohol risks through clear information on labels of 
alcoholic beverages.12 If standardized labels are not clearly presented, it would perpetuate lack of 
access to resources and education about alcohol risks among communities causing them to face 
alcohol-related health issues.
Recommendations:
Integrating linguistic competency in the labels would help communities who don’t have literacy 
in English understand the information on the labels. Having alcohol facts panels on labels in 
different commonly spoken languages in the US would help people understand it and make 
informed health choices.
Conclusion:
I commend the proposed regulation, TTB-2025-0002, as it supports evidence based strategies. 
The nation has witnessed horrifying incidences such as the case of Jacqueline Saburido, who had 
to suffer from third degree burns due to her car being hit by a heavily intoxicated.13 The people 
of our country must never have to go through such experiences. TTB-2025-0002 can make this 
happen. Therefore, I request the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau to immediately 
finalize and implement the regulation to protect the lives and health of all communities in the 
United States.1 TTB-2025-0002 ensures equity, helps alcohol risk communication and reduces 
alcohol-related harm.1References
1. Regulations.gov. Alcohol Beverage Labeling Requirements (Alcohol Facts 
Statement).https://www.regulations.gov/docket/TTB-2025- 
0002?utm_campaign=&utm_id=&utm_medium=&utm_source=.   
2. Impaired Driving Facts. Impaired Driving. 
https://www.cdc.gov/impaireddriving/facts/index.html. Published May 16, 2024. 
3. Brooks A. 2025 Drunk driving statistics. Bankrate. 
https://www.bankrate.com/insurance/car/drunk-driving/#drunk-driving-statistics2025.  
Published January 8, 2025. 
4. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Facts about alcohol use in the United States. 
CDC. https://www.cdc.gov/alcohol/facts-stats/index.html. Updated November 17, 2022. 
Accessed April 16, 2025.
5. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. About alcohol use. CDC. 
https://www.cdc.gov/alcohol/about-alcohol-use/index.html. Updated January 19, 2024. 
Accessed April 16, 2025. 
6. Vasiljevic, M., Couturier, D. L., & Marteau, T. M. (2018). Impact of low and high 
alcohol verbal descriptors on perceived strength: A randomized experiment. Psychology 
of Addictive Behaviors, 32(7), 784–793. 
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6241458/
7. U.S. consumers support improved alcohol labeling. Center for Science in the Public 
Interest. https://www.cspinet.org/resource/us-consumers-support-improved-
alcohollabeling 
8. Packer J, Stansfield C, Sifaki M, Michalopoulou S, Viner R, Russell S. Assessing the 
Impact of Alcohol Calorie and Unit Labelling on Consumer Behaviours: Findings from a 
Systematic Review. University College London; 2022. Accessed April 17, 2025. 
https://www.ucl.ac.uk/health/sites/health/files/sept22_assessing_impact_of_alcohol_c 
alorie_and_unit_labelling.pdf 
9. Wagenaar, A. C., Tobler, A. L., & Komro, K. A. (2010). Effects of alcohol tax and price 
policies on morbidity and mortality: A systematic review. American Journal of Public 
Health, 100(11), 2270–2278. https://doi.org/10.2105/AJPH.2009.186007 
10. Giesbrecht N, Reisdorfer E, Rios I. Alcohol Health Warning Labels: A Rapid Review 
with Action Recommendations. International Journal of Environmental Research and 
Public Health. 2022;19(18):11676. https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/36141951/ 
11. Davis CN, O’Neill SE. Treatment of Alcohol Use Problems Among Rural Populations: a 
Review of Barriers and Considerations for Increasing Access to Quality Care. Current 
Addiction Reports. 2022;9(4):432-444. 
https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9702879/ 
12. Nelson M. Alcohol labeling and the importance of transparency. Spirited Brands. 
https://sipspiritedbrands.com/blogs/news/the-evolution-of-alcohol-labeling-and-
theimportance-of-transparency. Published September 16, 2024. 
13. Karimi F. Jacqui Saburido, face of anti-drunk driving campaign, dies at 40. CNN.

document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
Dear TTB,
I’m writing as the owner of Three Sisters Winery, aka, Chestatee Valley Vintners to
share my concerns about TTB’s proposed rule, Notice No. 237 and No. 238, which
would require new “Alcohol Facts” labels on wine bottles.
While I support educating consumers, this rule would create serious financial challenges
for small wineries in Georgia. Redesigning labels and testing for nutritional content is
costly and time-consuming—especially for small producers like us.
There are better ways to promote health awareness without hurting local businesses.
Public campaigns or online education tools could inform consumers without forcing
costly label changes.
Please consider the impact of this rule on Georgia’s wine industry and the small
businesses that support our state’s economy and agriculture.
Thank you for your time and attention.
Sincerely,
Sharon V. Paul
Chestatee Valley Vintners- BWGA43
PO Box 3
Dahlonega, GA  30533

text:
Dear TTB,



I’m writing as the owner of Three Sisters Winery, aka, Chestatee Valley Vintners to share my concerns about TTB’s proposed rule, Notice No. 237 and No. 238, which would require new “Alcohol Facts” labels on wine bottles.



While I support educating consumers, this rule would create serious financial challenges for small wineries in Georgia. Redesigning labels and testing for nutritional content is costly and time-consuming—especially for small producers like us.



There are better ways to promote health awareness without hurting local businesses. Public campaigns or online education tools could inform consumers without forcing costly label changes.



Please consider the impact of this rule on Georgia’s wine industry and the small businesses that support our state’s economy and agriculture.



Thank you for your time and attention.



Sincerely,





Sharon V. Paul

Chestatee Valley Vintners- BWGA43

PO Box 3

Dahlonega, GA  30533

comment_text: Knowing how many grams of sugar (separate from carbohydrates) are in wines would actually be a huge help for consumers. There are wines that are marketed as "dry" or "off-dry" that have sugar levels on par with fruit juices, which the consumers currently have no way of knowing. I would also fully support an exception to nutritional labeling requirements for small producers, as the testing requirements would be a significant burden for them.

text:
Knowing how many grams of sugar (separate from carbohydrates) are in wines would actually be a huge help for consumers. There are wines that are marketed as "dry" or "off-dry" that have sugar levels on par with fruit juices, which the consumers currently have no way of knowing.

comment_text: The most important aspect to this is having producers list ALL ingredients within the containers, including any ingredients used to correct the look, smell, or taste of the product. American consumers deserve to know ALL ingredients used in their spirits so they know exactly what they are consuming, especially when today's industrial-grade ingredients are highly concentrated. A perfect example: in the Tequila industry, producers can use additives before bottling of sweetening agents, glycerin, oak extract, and colorings, of up to 1% of the volume, while still using a label like "100% Agave" and are not required to disclose those ingredients on the bottle. That doesn't sound like much, but remember, today's artificial ingredients are extremely concentrated, with some sweeteners being hundreds of times sweeter than table sugar. And again, because this is all legal by the CRT, the consumer doesn't know what's in their tequila, so they may think they are drinking a cleanly made spirit when in fact there are artificial ingredients in it. That's why it's important to have nutritional labels that list ALL ingredients in a spirit. That way American consumer have a source of truth.

American consumers deserve to know ALL ingredients used in their spirits so they know exactly what they are consuming, especially when today’s industrial-grade ingredients are highly concentrated.

That doesn’t sound like much, but remember, today’s artificial ingredients are extremely concentrated, with some sweeteners being hundreds of times sweeter than table sugar. And again, because this is all legal by the CRT, the consumer doesn’t know what’s in their tequila, so they may think they are drinking a cleanly made spirit when in fact there are artificial ingredients in it.

That’s why it’s important to have nutritional labels that list ALL ingredients in a spirit. That way American consumer have a source of truth.

comment_text: I do not believe TTB's proposed nutrient content labeling statement should be more consistent with the Nutrition Facts Label found on foods under the FDA's labeling jurisdiction; although the consumer could glean useful information from it, the wording of "Nutrition Facts" could lead them to believe that alcohol has a substantial amount of nutrients they could benefit from. This could mistakenly lead them to consuming more alcohol than they normally would out of a perceived health benefit.

comment_text: See attached file(s)
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
April 23, 2025 
 
Director 
Regulations and Ruling Division 
Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau 
1310 G Street NW. Box 12 
Washington, DC 20005 
 
Re: Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages 
(Docket No. TTB-2025-0002) 
 
To Whom it May Concern, 
 
The American Society for Nutrition (ASN) appreciates the opportunity to comment on Alcohol 
Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages. Founded in 
1928, ASN is the nation’s leading society for nutrition research and practice, representing more 
than 8,000 professional members across 100 countries. Our members – including nutrition 
scientists, physicians, dietitians, and other stakeholders – are dedicated to advancing our mission 
of “A Healthier World Through Evidence-Based Nutrition.” ASN supports the Alcohol and 
Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau’s (TTB) efforts to implement labeling of alcohol content and 
nutritional information on alcoholic beverages, as this will impart important information to 
consumers that they need to make informed health and nutrition-related purchases and decisions. 
 
The “Alcohol Facts” panel in the proposed rule includes “alcohol content expressed both as a 
percentage of alcohol by volume and in fluid ounces of pure ethyl alcohol per serving, the 
number of calories, and the number, in grams, of carbohydrates, fat, and protein, per serving.” 
This information is important to promote transparency regarding the contents of alcoholic 
beverages, and to highlight health and safety information for those who consume alcohol. 
Alcohol consumption is the third leading preventable cause of cancer in the United States, after 
tobacco and obesity, increasing risk for at least seven types of cancer
1. Alcoholic beverages can 
be calorie-dense and therefore contribute to diet-related chronic diseases. On average, alcohol 
accounts for 9% of daily calories for those who drink.2 Many alcoholic beverages also contain 
added sugars and other nutrients to limit. 
 
As such, the proposed rule could be strengthened by also requiring additional nutritional content, 
including total sugars in grams, added sugars in grams, saturated fat in grams, sodium in 
milligrams, and a percent Daily Value for each of these nutrients based on a 2,000-calorie diet. 
 
 
1 Alcohol and Cancer Risk 2025: The U.S. Surgeon General’s Advisory. US Department of Health and Human 
Services, Office of the Surgeon General. January 3, 2025. 
2 Dietary Guidelines Advisory Committee. 2020. Scientific Report of the 2020 Dietary Guidelines Advisory 
Committee: Advisory Report to the Secretary of Agriculture and the Secretary of Health and Human Services . U.S. 
Department of Agriculture, Agricultural Research Service, Washington, DC.   
 
The final rule should also require the number of standard drinks per container (instead of the 
proposed number of fluid ounces of pure ethyl alcohol per serving), and the conversion between 
standard drinks and fluid ounces of pure ethyl alcohol. TTB may also consider dual-column 
labeling for certain alcoholic beverages for those that are customarily consumed in one sitting. 
This label has two columns, one for listing the nutritional facts related to a single serving and one 
listing the nutritional facts for the contents of the entire package. 
 
ASN supports the requirement in the proposed rule that the “Alcohol Facts” disclosure appear on 
alcoholic beverage packages and never solely via electronic means (e.g., a QR code leading to a 
webpage), as this would specifically disadvantage populations that may be less likely to utilize 
technology to gain this important health and safety information.  
 
ASN urges TTB to prioritize transparency and health and finalize the proposed Alcohol Facts 
rule to ensure that Americans can make more informed decisions about what and how much to 
drink. To ensure timely consumer access to this important information, the final rule should 
adopt a shorter compliance period of 3.5 years instead of the 5-year period proposed. 
 
Thank you in advance for your consideration of the American Society for Nutrition’s comments 
on Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages. 
Please contact Sarah Ohlhorst, MS, RD, ASN’s Chief Science Policy Officer 
(sohlhorst@nutrition.org; 240-428-3647) for more information. 
 
Sincerely, 
 
John E. Courtney, PhD 
Chief Executive Officer

comment_text: As the owner of a small winery, I am writing to express concern about the proposed changes related to mandatory Alcohol Facts labeling. While I understand and support transparency for consumers, I urge the TTB to consider the unique challenges these changes would pose for small producers like us. Many small wineries, including mine, purchase labels in bulk to manage costs. The current option to use the generic term "table wine" with a standard alcohol range allows us to print labels in larger quantities, which significantly reduces our per-label cost. If we are required to print specific alcohol content on each label, this would necessitate annual or even batch-specific printing in smaller runs. The financial burden of this—both in cost per label and in managing multiple inventories—could be significant for operations producing under 2,000 cases per year. I respectfully propose the TTB consider an exemption or alternate compliance option for small wineries selling fewer than 2,000 cases annually. A carveout like this would help preserve the viability of small producers while still allowing flexibility for consumer transparency. Thank you for the opportunity to provide input. I appreciate the TTB's commitment to a fair and inclusive rulemaking process. Sincerely, Judy Lubben Lubben Vineyards & Wines Anamosa, Iowa
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
As the owner of a small winery, I am writing to express concern about the proposed changes related to mandatory Alcohol Facts labeling. While I understand and support transparency for consumers, I urge the TTB to consider the unique challenges these changes would pose for small producers like us.

Many small wineries, including mine, purchase labels in bulk to manage costs. The current option to use the generic term “table wine” with a standard alcohol range allows us to print labels in larger quantities, which significantly reduces our per-label cost. If we are required to print specific alcohol content on each label, this would necessitate annual or even batch-specific printing in smaller runs. The financial burden of this—both in cost per label and in managing multiple inventories—could be significant for operations producing under 2,000 cases per year.

I respectfully propose the TTB consider an exemption or alternate compliance option for small wineries selling fewer than 2,000 cases annually. A carveout like this would help preserve the viability of small producers while still allowing flexibility for consumer transparency.

Thank you for the opportunity to provide input. I appreciate the TTB’s commitment to a fair and inclusive rulemaking process.

Sincerely,
Judy Lubben
Lubben Vineyards & Wines
Anamosa, Iowa

comment_text: Alcohol product labeling is evolving. Non-alcoholic beers are a growing product category(1) and market research suggests that consumers find the definition of these products confusing.(2) In 2023, the World Health Organization called for updated labeling mandates to ensure potential consumers are not misled by product descriptors and to protect groups seeking to abstain from alcohol.(3) If the TTB proposal is approved, non-alcoholic beers would be required to report alcohol content either in terms of percentage or through terminology: using the term non-alcoholic (for those with <0.5% alcohol by volume) or the term, alcohol-free (for those with 0.0% alcohol by volume). If the term non-alcoholic is used, then alcohol percentage would also be required, but this is not the case for the term alcohol-free. To ensure consumers receive consistent, clear information that facilitates understanding of different terms, both alcohol by volume percentage and concordant terminology should be required. In fact, as a non-alcoholic beverage researcher, I recently evaluated non-alcoholic beer labels and found that all of the sample evaluated included both alcohol by volume percentage and relevant terminology on their labels, suggesting that a new requirement to include both would not involve an overhaul of current labeling practices. With regard to nutritional content, the Food and Drug Administration requires that soft drinks (e.g., sodas, juices) include nutritional content on their labels and, if the TTB proposal is approved, full-strength alcohol would follow suit. A question from the TTB is whether non-alcoholic beers should be exempt from the nutritional content requirement. There is no reason for non-alcoholic beers to be exempt from this – caloric content influences beverage purchasing decisions(4) and consumers have a right to nutritional information to make informed decisions. To offer a clinical perspective, as a clinical psychologist, I have provided therapy for a client who had alcohol use disorder and who found value in using non-alcoholic beers to support abstinence from alcohol use, yet the client also had concern about carbohydrate intake due to co-occurring diabetes. Nutritional content on non-alcoholic beers would support awareness of carbohydrate content, with potential to shape health behavior. Further, in my assessment of non-alcoholic beers, the majority assessed included calorie, carbohydrate, protein, and fat content on their labels, indicating that most producers would be amenable to a new nutritional content requirement. Also worth comment and absent from the TTB proposal is consumer communication about who should avoid non-alcoholic beers (and other non-alcoholic beverages that mirror alcohol). Certain kombucha companies voluntarily include on their label a warning against consumption for people avoiding alcohol (e.g., due to pregnancy, sensitivities), as the fermentation process can yield up to 0.5% alcohol by volume. A similar warning on non-alcoholic beers may be worthwhile. While non-alcoholic beers can be a helpful substitute for some,(5) their alcohol cues may activate craving for full-strength alcohol.(6) A minority of non-alcoholic beer labels I evaluated included the mandated government health warning for alcohol. Arguably, a consumer communication that is tailored to the specific (non-alcoholic) product would be more relevant and informative than simply using the warning required for full-strength alcohol. Another consideration is whether minors should be permitted to consume non-alcoholic beers(7,8) – labels that clearly note to avoid consumption if avoiding alcohol may guide parent considerations about providing non-alcoholic beers to their children.(9) A minority of non-alcoholic beer labels I evaluated included an age-restriction. As federal and state regulations evolve regarding at what age non-alcoholic beers can be purchased, relevant labeling will need to track. At present non-alcoholic beer labeling is largely self-regulated. I appreciate the opportunity to offer comment, informed by both my research and clinical experiences, to support effective labeling strategies of non-alcoholic beers. References 1. NielsenIQ. Non-alcoholic beverage trends in the US. 2022. 2. Corfe S, Hyde R, Shepherd J. Soc Mark Found. 2020. 3. World Health Organization. 2023. 4. Clarke N, Ferrar J, Pechey E, et al. Addiction. 2023. 5. Yoshimoto H, Kawaida K, Dobashi S, Saito G, Owaki Y. BMC Med. 2023. 6. Bowdring MA, McCarthy DM, Fairbairn CE, Prochaska JJ. Addiction. 2024. 7. Miller M, Pettigrew S, Wright CJC. Drug Alcohol Rev. 2022. 8. Bowdring MA, Prochaska JJ. JAMA Pediatr. 2024. 9. Bartram A, Harrison NJ, Norris CA, et al. Prev Med. 2023.
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
Alcohol product labeling is evolving. Non-alcoholic beers are a growing product category(1) and market research suggests that consumers find the definition of these products confusing.(2) In 2023, the World Health Organization called for updated labeling mandates to ensure potential consumers are not misled by product descriptors and to protect groups seeking to abstain from alcohol.(3) If the TTB proposal is approved, non-alcoholic beers would be required to report alcohol content either in terms of percentage or through terminology: using the term non-alcoholic (for those with <0.5% alcohol by volume) or the term, alcohol-free (for those with 0.0% alcohol by volume). If the term non-alcoholic is used, then alcohol percentage would also be required, but this is not the case for the term alcohol-free. To ensure consumers receive consistent, clear information that facilitates understanding of different terms, both alcohol by volume percentage and concordant terminology should be required. In fact, as a non-alcoholic beverage researcher, I recently evaluated non-alcoholic beer labels and found that all of the sample evaluated included both alcohol by volume percentage and relevant terminology on their labels, suggesting that a new requirement to include both would not involve an overhaul of current labeling practices.

With regard to nutritional content, the Food and Drug Administration requires that soft drinks (e.g., sodas, juices) include nutritional content on their labels and, if the TTB proposal is approved, full-strength alcohol would follow suit. A question from the TTB is whether non-alcoholic beers should be exempt from the nutritional content requirement. There is no reason for non-alcoholic beers to be exempt from this – caloric content influences beverage purchasing decisions(4) and consumers have a right to nutritional information to make informed decisions. To offer a clinical perspective, as a clinical psychologist, I have provided therapy for a client who had alcohol use disorder and who found value in using non-alcoholic beers to support abstinence from alcohol use, yet the client also had concern about carbohydrate intake due to co-occurring diabetes. Nutritional content on non-alcoholic beers would support awareness of carbohydrate content, with potential to shape health behavior. Further, in my assessment of non-alcoholic beers, the majority assessed included calorie, carbohydrate, protein, and fat content on their labels, indicating that most producers would be amenable to a new nutritional content requirement.

Also worth comment and absent from the TTB proposal is consumer communication about who should avoid non-alcoholic beers (and other non-alcoholic beverages that mirror alcohol). Certain kombucha companies voluntarily include on their label a warning against consumption for people avoiding alcohol (e.g., due to pregnancy, sensitivities), as the fermentation process can yield up to 0.5% alcohol by volume. A similar warning on non-alcoholic beers may be worthwhile. While non-alcoholic beers can be a helpful substitute for some,(5) their alcohol cues may activate craving for full-strength alcohol.(6) A minority of non-alcoholic beer labels I evaluated included the mandated government health warning for alcohol. Arguably, a consumer communication that is tailored to the specific (non-alcoholic) product would be more relevant and informative than simply using the warning required for full-strength alcohol. Another consideration is whether minors should be permitted to consume non-alcoholic beers(7,8) – labels that clearly note to avoid consumption if avoiding alcohol may guide parent considerations about providing non-alcoholic beers to their children.(9) A minority of non-alcoholic beer labels I evaluated included an age-restriction. As federal and state regulations evolve regarding at what age non-alcoholic beers can be purchased, relevant labeling will need to track.

At present non-alcoholic beer labeling is largely self-regulated. I appreciate the opportunity to offer comment, informed by both my research and clinical experiences, to support effective labeling strategies of non-alcoholic beers.

References
1.NielsenIQ. Non-alcoholic beverage trends in the US. 2022.
2.Corfe S, Hyde R, Shepherd J. Soc Mark Found. 2020.
3.World Health Organization. 2023.
4.Clarke N, Ferrar J, Pechey E, et al. Addiction. 2023.
5.Yoshimoto H, Kawaida K, Dobashi S, Saito G, Owaki Y. BMC Med. 2023.
6.Bowdring MA, McCarthy DM, Fairbairn CE, Prochaska JJ. Addiction. 2024.
7.Miller M, Pettigrew S, Wright CJC. Drug Alcohol Rev. 2022.
8.Bowdring MA, Prochaska JJ. JAMA Pediatr. 2024.
9.Bartram A, Harrison NJ, Norris CA, et al. Prev Med. 2023.

comment_text: I work in the beer industry. I welcome this discussion. However, I don't think the change in label requirements will have the desired effects proponents want. I think there will be significant unintended consequences that do not benefit the consumer and burden the manufacturer. 1. Most products could go into containers (boxes, wraps, etc…) that the TTB is unauthorized to regulate. Access to label information will only be available after purchase 2. Increase cost to the consumer 3. Less variety on store shelves 4. Less craft manufacturers, more corporate manufacturers 5. Average consumer may not know how to accurately read and interpet the label's nutrional information 6. Using a QR code will result in additional personal data collection 7. Wasted time: Scan QR code in grocery store, wait minutes for manufacturer website to load, confirm age, wait minutes for nutritional information page to load, read and interpret information. Repeat X amount times when comparing brands. Proponents of this rule change are projecting their loftiest ideals on how they think the average consumer will behave. The average consumer spends single digit seconds selecting products in the grocery or convenience store. With regards to beer, the primary factors of a purchase are branding, price, and ABV. The status quo works. In my personal experience, the proponents are unabashed about contacting the manufacturer and asking their nutritional questions. Requiring the information to be accessible via a QR code does not save them time, does not effect the average consumer and creates an expensive strain on the small manufacturer.
document_title: Notice No. 237:  Alcohol Facts Statements in the Labeling of Wines, Distilled Spirits, and Malt Beverages
text:
I work in the beer industry. I welcome this discussion. However, I don’t think the change in label requirements will have the desired effects proponents want. I think there will be significant unintended consequences that do not benefit the consumer and burden the manufacturer.

1. Most products could go into containers (boxes, wraps, etc…) that the TTB is unauthorized to regulate. Access to label information will only be available after purchase
2. Increase cost to the consumer
3. Less variety on store shelves
4. Less craft manufacturers, more corporate manufacturers
5. Average consumer may not know how to accurately read and interpet the label's nutrional information
6. Using a QR code will result in additional personal data collection
7. Wasted time: Scan QR code in grocery store, wait minutes for manufacturer website to load, confirm age, wait minutes for nutritional information page to load, read and interpret information. Repeat X amount times when comparing brands.

Proponents of this rule change are projecting their loftiest ideals on how they think the average consumer will behave. The average consumer spends single digit seconds selecting products in the grocery or convenience store. With regards to beer, the primary factors of a purchase are branding, price, and ABV.

The status quo works. In my personal experience, the proponents are unabashed about contacting the manufacturer and asking their nutritional questions. Requiring the information to be accessible via a QR code does not save them time, does not effect the average consumer and creates an expensive strain on the small manufacturer.
